File photo of Gaya airport

GAYA: Probably for the first time in Gaya airport ’s history, Air India’s international weekly flight from Yangon landed empty at the airport. The AI flight operates on Yangon-Gaya-Delhi route .

The 13-member crew flew the empty aircraft from the Myanmar capital on Wednesday afternoon.

Confirming the zero passenger flight from Yangon, Gaya airport director Dilip Kumar said, “Another international flight, a chartered flight also from Yangon, landed and took off with no passengers. The chartered flight was booked to fly 107 tourists from Gaya to Yangon. However, no passenger reported for the flight and the aircraft returned empty. Though the Yangon flight landed with no passengers, 21 flyers boarded at the Gaya airport for the Gaya-Delhi section of the flight.”

Tourist footfall has nose dived at the Gaya airport due to Covid-19 outbreak. According to the airport director, as against an average of 400 tourists, the footfall was only 52 on Wednesday.

In another Covid-19 related development, Hla Tin, the 40-year-old Myanmar national kept in the isolation ward of the ANMMCH at Gaya, has tested negative. Subsequently, he has been discharged from the hospital. According to Gaya civil surgeon Dr BK Singh, the virological test report of the Myanmar national was received on Wednesday. Earlier, on Sunday, the Myanmar national during screening at the Gaya airport was found suffering from fever and other symptoms of Covid-19. He was immediately shifted to the isolation ward of the ANMMCH. A couple of days back, a Sherghati resident studying medicine in China was also discharged from the hospital as his virological test report was negative.

According to Gaya International airport director Dilip Kumar, altogether 18,986 passengers have so far been screened at the airport.

“Screening counters have been set up near the two aerobridges and screening was being done with the help of three infra-red thermometers. Two doctors and seven paramedical staff have been deputed at the airport,” he said.

Title: Kamal Nath government will survive, claim MP Cong MLAs in Jaipur
Content: JAIPUR: MLAs supporting the Congress government in Madhya Pradesh, including Independents, reached Jaipur on Wednesday afternoon amid a political crisis triggered by former Guna MP Jyotiraditya Scindia leaving the party and joining BJP.The Kamal Nath government in Madhya Pradesh is facing a severe crisis following the resignation of 21 MLAs said to be loyal to Scindia. Congress chief whip in the state assembly Mahesh Joshi, tasked with making arrangements for the MLAs’ stay, claimed 89 MLAs had arrived in Jaipur.But sources said that only 82 MLAs have come to Jaipur along with three Independents.“We had hosted Maharashtra MLAs in Jaipur in November last year, prior to government formation there, and the results have been good,” Joshi said, adding that the result of the current MP crisis will also end up “in favour of Congress”.The MLAs have been lodged at two resorts, Buena Vista and Tree House, on the Jaipur-Delhi highway on the city’s outskirts.The MLAs arrived at Jaipur airport around 2.15 pm on a special flight from Bhopal and were received by CM Ashok Gehlot and other party leaders, including state transport minister Pratap Singh Kachariyawas, party chief whip Mahesh Joshi, deputy chief whip Mahendra Chaudhary, and MLAs Rafeeq Khan and Amin Kagzi.Senior Congress memebrs, including AICC general secretaries Mukul Wasnik and Harish Rawat, also have reached Jaipur. CM Ashok Gehlot, too, went to Buena Vista resort to hold discussions with the MLAs and senior party members.At Jaipur airport, the MLAs looked in high spirits and claimed that some of them who had gone to Bengaluru were not Scindia loyalists but had been misguided and would soon return to Congress.Sajjan Verma, PWD minister in the Kamal Nath-led Congress government in MP, said he would go to Bengaluru and bring the MLAs back to Congress.The MLAs told reporters there was no threat to the Kamal Nath government and that it would survive. They lashed out at Jyotiraditya Scindia for betraying Congress and joining BJP for selfish ends.A Congress legislator, Sunil Saraf, said BJP was trying to end democracy by dismantling the party system but would not succeed. “The Kamal Nath government will complete its full term. There is no threat. We all are together,” Saraf said. He said the Congress MLAs who supported Scindia had been “misled and deceived” by BJP.MP Congress member Kantilal Bhuria, who also came to Jaipur with the MLAs, said, “There is no threat to the government. The state government has the majority.” He added that the MLAs would visit tourist sites in Jaipur.Congress MLA Harsh Yadav said those who had gone with Scindia would be rejected by the people.

Title: GHMC to spruce up 22 parks in Secunderabad with budget bounty
Content:
GHMC has built walls around the parks to protect them from land sharks

SECUNDERABAD: With the state government allocating Rs 10,000 crore to Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation ( GHMC ) in the budget, the civic body’s urban biodiversity wing plans to renovate 22 parks in Secunderabad . These parks are located in Seetaphalmandi , Tarnaka, Mettuguda, Addagutta and Boudha Nagar.

“Basic infrastructure such as walkways, cement or iron benches, playing area for children and washrooms will be provided in each park. We will also develop lush green lawns inside the park and place ornamental plants. The project aims to revive lung spaces in Secunderabad,” deputy director of GHMC’s urban biodiversity wing Syed Maqsood Mohiuddin told TOI.

Speaking about the expenditure , Mohiuddin said, “Renovation of each park will cost around Rs 3 lakh. Proposal are being prepared with details of expenditure. These will be sent to the GHMC commissioner in a couple of weeks for approval. Once the civic chief clears them, we will float tenders.”

The project is expected to bring relief for local residents who are often forced to go for their regular walks to parks in other localities. Renovating these spaces will also improve greenery and air quality.

Replying to concerns regarding encroachments, a GHMC official says the civic body has taken much care to build compound walls around the parks to protect them from land sharks.

“If all goes well, the works will be completed within three months,” Mohiuddin said.

Title: Kolkata cops clear first workday test, prepare for Tallah’s HS exam
Content:
Buses pass the Chitpore level crossing on Wednesday

KOLKATA: The cops have passed the first big test of the new traffic-flow plan between Chiria More and Shyambazar, but there are still some chinks in the armour that they hope to fix before Thursday, the first day of the higher secondary exams.

On Wednesday, goods vehicles were directed to Strand Bank Road. This proved advantageous for two reasons — the movement to Khagen Chatterjee Road became smoother with Cossipore Road offering more road space and RG Kar stretch remained snarl free. For now, this route will remain one-way to ensure hassle-free movement. “We will not allow any illegal loading and unloading on this stretch any more,” said an officer.

“The RG Kar stretch is slowly getting de-clogged. With Lock Gate now operating from north to south, the stretch has become even smoother compared to last week,” said Anindya Chakraborty, who travels to Shyambazar from Belgacchia every day.

The only bit of bad news from the RG Kar-Belgachhia sector was an accident reported around 9.40am, when 62-year-old Rabin Biswas was injured at Raja Manindra Road-Belgachhia Road crossing after being hit by a government bus plying on route D-23. Biswas was taken to RG Kar Hospital where his condition is stated to be stable.

The cops will continue to be deployed in huge numbers till the end of the HS exams. The only worry for vehicles taking the Lock Gate flyover concerns two crossings — PK Mukherjee and Galiff Street. With heavy crossover movement and motorists yet undecided on whether to take the PK Mukherjee Road towards Shyambazar or continue straight towards Central Avenue, the crossings witnessed some minor snarls in the morning office hours. TOI witnessed vehicles caught in the jam between 9.30am and 11am.

However, cops appeared confident that this was a minor irritant. “It happened on the first day when motorists are still trying to settle for the best possible route. Things will ease in the next 48 hours. Most are still unaware of the newer road options. Once they begin using them, things will look up,” said an officer.

Lalbazar officers indicated they would monitor the traffic flow for the next two weeks. The possibility of making the traffic flow tidal has not been ruled out yet. “We want to ensure that no student is inconvenienced during their board exams. With HS exams in progress, we will not go for too many experiments,” explained an officer.

“At present, for the northward journey, smaller vehicles should take Cossipore Road and buses should take Railway Service Road and the Chitpore level crossing for BT Road. For southward journey, buses and small vehicles should take Lock Gate Flyover for CR Avenue or Shyambazar. In this way, we have reduced the jams on RG Kar Bridge,” said an officer.

“As a precautionary measure, we are not allowing vehicles on Lock Gate flyover after midnight,” explained an officer.

Title: Patnaites celebrate festival of colours
Content:
PATNA: Folk songs, mostly in Bhojpuri, rent the air on Tuesday as revellers played Holi, smeared different-coloured ‘gulals’ on each other’s faces and sang ‘Bura na maano, Holi hai’. ‘Holika Dahan’ was performed on Monday evening.

Carrying balloons, water guns and buckets in hands, kids celebrated the festival of colours with enthusiasm. Adults and elderly people also had a great time greeting one another and meeting friends and relatives. They shared sweets and ate mouth-watering delicacies on the occasion. Many people also thronged shops selling mutton, chicken and fish.

Some youngsters celebrated ‘kurta-phaad’ Holi while gulping down numerous glasses of scented ‘thandai’. They also hurled water-filled balloons at passers-by from rooftops and balconies of their houses. However, a large number of police personnel were deployed at strategic locations across the city to avoid any untoward incident.

Budh Marg resident Mukund Anand (62) told this newspaper, “Holi is a time when we share happiness. My sons and daughters-in-law are here for the celebrations. We ate ‘gujiyas’, ‘malpuas’ and several other delicacies.”

Khajekalan resident Surbhi Lahiri said, “I had prepared ‘kathal ki sabzi’, ‘puri’, ‘pua’, ‘kheer’ and ‘dahi vada’ on Holi. I played with colours and ‘gulal’ with my family, relatives and friends. I also attended a family get-together.”

Cartoon masks and wigs were also in vogue among all age groups this Holi. Some youngsters spent time with friends at a water park in Sampatchak.

Saurabh Jaiswal, a resident of Patna City, said, “My friends and I played Holi with tomatoes at the water park. We also ate snacks and enjoyed some rides.”

Title: Heavy rush at airport, railway stations and bus depots
Content:
PATNA: Professionals and students who had come home for Holi celebrations with their family and friends in Patna are facing a tough time going back to cities where they work or study as there is no seat available in most of the trains and buses while the airfare has drastically shot up.

Flyers are facing tough time to get direct flight to Delhi, Mumbai, Hyderabad and Kolkata on an average fare. Reportedly, the heaviest rush can be seen on the Delhi-Patna route. The airlines executives say the increase in fares is due to demand and supply. “There is a huge rush, especially on Patna to Delhi and Mumbai routes. The airfare would remain high till March 16,” an executive said.

Travel portals showed on Wednesday that the one-way fare from Patna to Delhi is between Rs6,600 and Rs13,852 for the same day. Travel agents say the average airfare on the Mumbai-Patna route is usually Rs4,100, which now stands between Rs7,850 and Rs17,134. Airfare on the Kolkata-Patna route has soared from the average Rs5,400 to Rs12,177.

Kalpana Sinha, who studies in Delhi, said her train ticket could not be confirmed. “Today, I have booked a flight ticket at Rs7,280 for March 13,” she said.

Ranjit Kumar, a bank professional in Mumbai, said there is no direct flight available for Mumbai route. “I had to book a connecting flight via Delhi,” he said.

Railways has chalked out a contingency plan to cope with passenger rush after Holi. According to Danapur divisional railway manager Sunil Kumar, railways has opened additional ticket booking counters at Patna Junction.

According to East Central Railway (ECR) chief public relations officer Rajesh Kumar, railways has been running at least 17 pairs of weekly or biweekly special trains on the Barauni-New Delhi, Patna-Anand Vihar, Gaya-Anand Vihar, Patna-Lokmanya Tilak Mumbai, Patna-Pune, Gandhidham-Bhagalpur, Howrah-Gorakhpur, Patna-Ranchi, Patna-Indore, Patna-Secunderabad, Patna-Durg, Patna-Ahmedabad, Gaya-Bandra, Barauni-Bandra, Kolkata-Lucknow and Anand Vihar-Kamakhya routes to help passengers reach their respective places after festival.

There was a huge rush of passengers at Meethapur and Bankipore bus stands as well. A Bihar State Road Transport Corporation Limited official said the buses on Ranchi, Delhi and Tata routes are almost full for the next couple of days. “Many people booked tickets early this morning,” he claimed.

There are four buses on Ranchi route, two for Delhi and one for Tata. The fare for these routes is between Rs1,900 and Rs2,800 in sleeper and chair-car air-conditioned buses.

Sumit Agarwal, an IT engineer, said on web portal, it was showing there was no seat available in BSRTC’s Patna-Delhi buses via Ghaziabad. “So, I’m at the bus depot to inquire about the seats in other private buses. I have to return to Delhi by March 12 to join work from Friday,” he said.

Title: Man dies in Pandesara police lock-up
Content:
Surat: A 30-year-old man died in Pandesara police station lock-up on Wednesday after his health alleged deteriorated for unknown reasons.

Vimal Yadav, a resident of Balaji Nagar, was arrested for fighting with locals, was shifted to a private hospital on Wednesday morning where doctors declared him dead. Later the body was shifted to New Civil Hospital (NCH) for post mortem. While the family members refused to accept the body, they later agreed to take the body in the evening.

An employee of textile unit, Yadav was arrested along with his brother Vinay and father Tribhuvan, from near their home after they were found involved in a fight with some locals. After locals called up police control room, Balaji Nagar police reached the spot and arrested the trio under preventive actions and kept them in the lock-up.

Meanwhile, Yadav developed some breathing problems early on Wednesday and his family members also in the lock-up informed the police. Later in the day, the brother alleged that Yadav was not taken to the hospital immediately even after police was informed about his condition. He also alleged that police demanded Rs 2,000 to grant them bail.

"There were no allegations in the morning but later in the day the family members levelled allegations. Assistant commissioner of police of the area is inquiring into the matter to find out the truth," said Vidhi Chaudhary, deputy commissioner of police, zone III.

"We called an ambulance soon after the family members informed us. There was no delay and everything is recorded in the cameras at the police station," said D K Patel, police inspector, Pandesara police station.

"It is not clear how the deceased died. Family members informed police that he had respiratory problem. The post mortem report will tell us how the man died," said J K Panda, assistant commissioner of police, F division.

Title: Victoria Memorial assigns room for nursing mothers
Content:
Kolkata: For mothers with newborns, Victoria Memorial Hall will become a more inviting place from Friday with authorities recognizing their need for privacy to nurse babies. A room that is currently used by museum volunteers and guides to take breaks has been allocated as a mother-and-child room and refurbished with a table and couches.

“In the past, our staff and CISF personnel had brought up the need for a private room for mothers with newborns. However, we hadn’t been able to act on it till now as VMH was being renovated. Now that work is over, we are doing what is needed,” said VMH curator Jayanta Sengupta.

Sengupta had inaugurated such a room at the Indian Museum in May 2017 when he was functioning as the director in charge there.

The room at VMH, adjacent to the entrance hall, will allow nursing mothers the privacy needed to nurse their infants or even rest. Sengupta said the room was part of VMH’s ongoing efforts to make the facility more inclusive and friendlier towards visitors.

The issue was highlighted when a woman had trouble nursing her baby at a city mall a year-and-a-half ago. Thereafter, Kolkata Municipal Corporation had asked for child care rooms in all public facilities. All malls have since complied with the requirement.

On Friday, VMH will also inaugurate a Rajput miniature of Rani Padmini binding a turban on her head surrounded by companions as the ‘Object-of-the-Month’ exhibition. The painting will be on display in the Prince Hall on the southern side of the museum.

Title: 41% fall in diamond exports from India
Content:
Surat: The worst fears of diamond industry following novel coronavirus outbreak have come true with the polished diamond export from India witnessing its steepest monthly fall in February.

The export of gems has fallen by a whopping 41% in February, down to Rs 9,800 crore from Rs 16,679 crore during the same month last year. This has been revealed in the latest report of Gems and Jewellery Export Promotion Council (GJEPC).

Industry sources said that Hong Kong is the biggest export destination, consuming nearly 40% of the polished diamonds. Hong Kong is the gateway to China, where the polished diamonds are exported for studding in the diamond jewellery manufactured on a large scale.

GJEPC chairman Pramod Kumar Agarwal told TOI: “This is an alarming situation for the gems and jewellery sector. This is the biggest monthly fall in the month of February. Export to Hong Kong, China and Italy have been severely affected due to coronavirus outbreak.”

Agarwal said things are looking gloomy in the upcoming months too. We are anticipating a major decline in the export in March too as the situation has turned from bad to worse with the virus spreading in other diamond consuming countries.”

China and Italy are the largest manufacturers of diamond-studded jewellery with former alone exporting jewellery worth $4 billion to the US. Majority of the diamonds to both Italy and China are supplied from India.

The overall exports of gems and jewellery declined 6.38% to Rs 2.36 lakh crore between April-February 2020 compared to Rs 2.52 lakh crore during the same period previous year.

Managing director of Dharmanandan Diamonds, Hitesh Patel said, “Coronavirus outbreak dealt a huge blow to our industry. China, which is the major market is completely shut and export to Italy have been badly affected.”

Title: Three of family drown near Rameshwar temple in Mandvi
Content:
Surat: Three members of a family including a nine-year-old boy, drowned in the gushing waters of Tapi river at Varekhpetiya village in Surat district’s Mandvi taluka on Tuesday.

Seven family members from Surat’s Varachha and Kamrej taluka had gone to Mandvi taluka’s Varekhpetiya village to pray at Rameshwar temple on occasion of Dhuleti festival. Later they decided to take a dip in Tapi river on insistence of nine-year-old Rudraksh Kathrodia.

Sources said that Rudraksh, a resident of Shyamnagar society in Kamrej, went deep into the river and started drowning. In a bid to rescue him, his relatives Santi Jesalia (45), resident of Vajra village in Varachha and Atul Vashram Jesaliya, of Pasodara Patia, jumped into the water but they too drowned in the gushing waters.

A team of fire fighters and diver from Mandvi was called in which took up rescue operation. It took them about two hours to fish out the bodies of the deceased —Rudraksh, Santi and Atul.

Sub-inspector of Mandvi police station, J S Valavi told TOI, “The family was supposed to visit Dandi heritage site in Navsari, but they changed their plan and went to Rameshwar temple in Mandvi.”

Valavi added, “The river is dangerous for swimming as it has an underground cave where the current is very strong. We had to summon some local swimmers to fish out the body of the nine-year-old boy which was found deep inside the cave.”

Title: Man falls from terrace while playing Holi
Content:
Surat: A 30-year-old man died when he fell from the third floor of his house while playing Holi with friends on Tuesday.

Santosh Singh Rajput, a resident of Mahadev Nagar in Varachha, was shifted to SMIMER Hospital where doctors declared him dead on admission.

Meanwhile, 108 emergency service were flooded with calls for injuries. As many as 139 cases of injuries were reported on Tuesday.

Title: Climate concern: City youths gift vendors power-saving LED lights
Content:
Kolkata: A group of youths under the banner, Earth Day Network (EDN), embarked on a drive to replace incandescent bulbs with LED bulbs along the pavement of Asutosh Mukherjee Road on Wednesday. The act made a lot of difference — one LED bulb consumes less than 5% the energy consumed by incandescent bulbs and generates negligible heat.

“Our idea was to do something to fight the climate challenges in our small way,” said Ajay Mittal, director, EDN, India and South Asia. “We replaced 200W bulbs with 14W LED bulbs and made the hawkers pledge to switch to LED. We explained to them the benefits of using LED — both in terms of electricity cost and longevity. In run up to the 50th anniversary of Earth Day on April 22, we want everyone to take up a small action for change by challenging themselves to replace at least five filament bulbs with LED bulbs,” he added.

Raja Das, a textile hawker in Bhowanipore, said, “The EDN changed one of my five bulbs and told me how much I can save on my electricity bill by shifting to LED. The illumination of the LED lamp is quite good and I have promised to change all my filament bulbs into LED lamps.”

Earlier, Mittal and his friends, in their personal capacity, took upon the task of installing PVC ball valves on road-side taps to stop free-flow of potable water. That saved gallons from being wasted. “We pooled in money to replace filament bulbs and hope the corporate social responsibility fund will aid with the mass-scale replacement,” Mittal added.

Energy efficiency assumes significance in the current environment of shortages and concerns over climate change. The Indian government had launched a scheme to provide LED bulbs to domestic consumers while the KMC has started replacing incandescent street lamps with LED ones.

Title: Three held for trying to sell leopard skin in Mancherial district
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: The special team of Ramagundam police raided a house on Wednesday in Sirsa village near Kotapalli of Mancherial district in Telangana and arrested three poachers who were trying to sell leopard skin.

The accused were identified as K Tirupati, S Gangaram and V Tulsiram of Marupalli in Gadchiroli, Maharashtra , residents of Marupalli village abutting Pranahita river in Maharashtra. During interrogation, the accused confessed that they killed a leopard at Marupalli village in Aheri taluk of Gadchiroli district and brought the leopard’s skin to Telangana for sale.

According to police, the accused were agricultural labourers and have been poaching animals by laying electric wire traps. After coming to know from people about the movement of the leopard near Sironcha forest area abutting Pranahita river in Maharashtra, they planned to kill it and sell its skin for profit. “The accused identified the locations where the leopard was moving by tracking its pug marks. They connected the wires to the overhead electric line and laid traps. After killing the leopard, the accused removed its skin and nails,” Ramagundam commissioner V Satyanarayana said.

The commissioner said that they are using drone cameras to prevent poaching and timber smuggling. “We are binding over timber smugglers and poachers. So far, we have bound over 56 offenders in nine cases,” the commissioner said.

Previously, In March 2019, Ramagundam police arrested six poachers and seized leopard skin along with its nails from their possession. Ramagundam police had also arrested 20 persons in a tiger poaching case in 2019.

Title: At Rs 28.3 lakh crore, MFs’ assets set another record in February
Content:
(Representative image)

MUMBAI: Strong flows into equity and exchange-traded funds (ETFs) helped the mutual fund industry report its highest ever assets under management (AUM) at Rs 28.3 lakh crore in February. The growth came despite liquid funds witnessing outflows.

In the one year to February 29, while the benchmark indices like sensex and Nifty had grown by about 6%, the MF industry’s AUM surged by 15%, data showed. Steady flows through the systematic investment plan (SIP) route, which was above the Rs 8,000-crore mark for the 15th consecutive month, signalled investors’ tilt towards having a disciplined, long-term investment attitude, industry players said.

According to industry trade body Amfi’s chief executive N S Venkatesh, continued vibrancy in monthly SIP flows at Rs 8,513 crore, and net inflows into equity AUMs at a record high this fiscal at Rs 10,796 crore, helped the fund industry’s assets to set an all-time high figure.

“We expect continued buoyancy in SIP flows in March too, though a few institutional investors may reassess their investment strategy, given the deep correction in markets. Equity-linked savings schemes (ELSS) continue to find favour with individual investors, with positive net flows at Rs 871 crore during the month,” he said.

Amfi data showed that total equity AUM topped the Rs 8-lakh-crore mark for the first time in history. In February, as a category, liquid funds recorded the highest outflow at Rs 43,825 crore, while equity ETFs brought in over Rs 16,000 crore.

Title: Surat: 12-year-old brain-dead girl turns life saviour for five
Content:
Yesha Mangukia had slipped into coma after falling off the fourth floor

SURAT: While she barely lived her own life, this 12-year-old girl from Surat has become a life saviour to five others. Thanks to the supreme sacrifice by Yesha Mangukia ’s heartstricken kin, the girl will continue to live on through her valuable contribution of liver, two kidneys and two eyes.

Yesha, a Class 7 student, and daughter of a diamond polisher, had gone to play at a friends house on the fourth floor of a building in the same society in Varachha area on March 9. However, while playing she accidentally fell off from the gallery and hit the ground floor. She slipped into unconsciousness from severe head injuries.

She was rushed P P Savani Hospital in a serious condition which referred her to Venus hospital. However, the doctors there declared her brain-dead and informed Donate Life, an NGO working for organ donation. After counselling, Yesha’s family members decided to donate her vital organs.

Immediately, the police swung into action and a 260km green corridor was made which passed through six districts — Surat city, Surat Rural, Bharuch, Vadodara Rural, Anand, Ahmedabad Rural and Ahmedabad city. Police in all these districts were kept in attendance so that the distance of 260km could be covered in just 2.55 hours, which in normal time takes nearly 5 hours.

“We approached Yesha’s family members who understood the importance of organ donation and agreed to be part of the noble cause. With the consent of Yesha’s father Bharat Mangukia, we informed to State Organ and Tissue Transplant Organization (SOTTO) convener Dr Pranjal Modi and Transplant Coordinator Dr Priya Shah about the availability of two kidneys and one liver and Lokdrishti Bank about the two eyes,” said Nilesh Mandlewala, founder of Donate Life, while talking to TOI.

“One kidney was transplanted into a boy and another into a girl in Ahmedabad. The liver was transplanted into a 52-year-old man,” Mandlewala added.

Title: Bihar: Coronavirus outbreak ruins vacation plans
Content: PATNA: The coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak has ruined honeymoon plans and family or group outings to Thailand, Maldives and other affected countries owing to restriction on travel and other related advisories.Many airlines are cancelling the flights to other countries and holiday bookings have turned to temporary reservations.Saurav Kumar of S K Nagar had planned to visit Thailand with his newlywed wife, but the airlines sent the cancellation message of flight tickets to him about a week ago. Saurav rued that there would be no refund on cancellation of hotel bookings. “It would take around 10 days to get refund for flight tickets as it was refundable. I had booked the tickets for Thailand almost two months ago,” he said.Sandhya Prasad of Nala Road had also planned a trip to Thailand with her husband for anniversary celebration. “I have not cancelled the trip as it was non-refundable holiday package from Delhi to Thailand from March 22,” Sandhya said.Ritu Tiwari of Rajendra Nagar said she had to cancel the Europe trip for her honeymoon under parents’ pressure. “I’m getting married on March 26 and we were supposed to visit London, France and Switzerland under Euro trip package. But our parents are scared due to spread of coronavirus,” she told this newspaper.She added: “It is good that we had booked refundable tickets, but will not get back a penny for cancelling sightseeing and hotel bookings.”The travel agents are also facing tough time as many people are cancelling the holiday packages.Saurabh Khemkha, a travel agent, said five persons cancelled their bookings on Wednesday itself. They were to visit Maldives, Bhutan, Bangkok, Pattaya and Kerala. “Our business is going in loss as we have to refund the 25% commission that we make while booking the holiday packages,” he said.Anupam Singh, another travel agent, said not a single person is visiting our agency for the query of holiday packages even though it is one of the busiest times of the year.

Title: Coronavirus cases in Bihar: Surge in suspect cases for coronavirus test
Content: PATNA: A Samastipur native was kept in the isolation ward of Patna Medical College and Hospital (PMCH) on Wednesday after he developed symptoms of coronavirus . He had returned from Dubai recently.PMCH superintendent Dr Bimal Kumar Karak said the man was referred by Samastipur Sadar hospital and his blood samples will be sent for test. This is the second case of isolation in PMCH. Earlier, a Chhapra native was kept in the PMCH isolation ward. She had returned from China and was relieved after her sample tested negative.PMCH principal Dr VP Chaudhary said another Aurangabad native was advised home isolation.During Holi, the state has witnessed increased number of cases enrolled for observation as they had come from coronavirus-infected areas. Till March 9, total 128 people were put under observation, but the figures surged to 144 on March 10. Before March 8, either one or two new suspect cases were seen each day.State nodal officer for coronavirus Dr Ragini Mishra said, “This increase in number is because people are returning from countries infected by coronavirus to their native places. In coming days, we may expect more number of such cases.”Dr Mishra further said the health department has involved its 104 toll-free number from Wednesday to track people coming from outside Bihar. “With 20 lines, it was earlier being used to solve general queries. But now this will be actively involved to track passengers,” she said.The state government has called a coordination committee meeting on Thursday to monitor the situation and plan strategy for future action. As per the press release shared by state health society, total 52 samples have been collected for the test. So far, no positive case has been recorded in Bihar.

Title: Gautam Thapar can sell 25% of market assets: Sebi
Content: MUMBAI: Sebi has allowed ousted CG Power chairman Gautam Thapar and three former executives to liquidate up to 25% of the value of securities held by them. The regulator’s decision came even as it maintains the securities market ban on the erstwhile top honchos.The relaxation has been given following a plea by Thapar, V R Venkatesh (former CG Power CFO) and ex-board members Madhav Acharya & B Hariharan.The order pertains to a case of alleged fraud at the equipment manufacturer. Sebi has directed CG Power to take all necessary steps to recover amounts due to the company, which were extended to the four former executives and Thapar’s Avantha Group of companies along with interest.The markets watchdog noted that a “big corporate war” was going on between the present CG Power management and Thapar. “There has been a specific allegation against private equity firm KKR — which holds 8.1% in CG Power — with respect to market manipulation, insider trading and change in control of the company.”Sebi further noted that certain allegations were also made against Narayan Seshadri, an independent director on the board of CG Power, regarding his firm Tranzmute’s partnership with KKR.Moreover, Sebi has received complaints against Acharya concerning alleged siphoning of funds and a failure on the part of the CG Power board to adhere to corporate governance standards, including involvement of KKR in the company’s affairs. Though Sebi has not addressed these issues in Wednesday’s order, it said that it “may examine these complaints”.In a statement, KKR said, “We note that Sebi has not made any observation or findings in the order that is adverse to KKR, and we have not received any show-cause from Sebi. When and if we do, we would be fully willing to cooperate. We believe this is an attempt to malign the very lenders who have lost a lot of money due to value destruction that has taken place in CG Power.”

Title: Tamil Nadu: Hospital, patient’s kin trade charges on organ harvesting
Content:
Represenative Image

MADURAI: In a petition to the city police commissioner, a patient’s relative on Wednesday accused doctors of a private hospital in the city of threatening to harvest organs of the soon-to-be brain dead patient for payment of dues to the hospital. However, refuting the claim, the hospital authorities alleged that it was an elaborate attempt to extort money from the hospital and said that the patient himself is conscious and recovering well.

According to the petition, the patient’s wife, Nithya V, said her husband Veerapandian was admitted to the hospital in October last year for treating subdural haematoma. He underwent two surgeries during the hospitalisation. Nithya alleged that the hospital had taken lakhs of money from them over the months but her husband had not recovered. She further claimed that on March 7 doctors came to her saying that her husband would soon be brain dead. As Rs 3 lakh was pending in dues to the hospital, they threatened to harvest her husband’s organs once he was brain dead for payment.

Meanwhile, hospital authorities accused Nithya and her family of cooking up stories in an attempt to extort money from the hospital. “It is true that Rs 3 lakh was pending in payment but we never threatened anything. The expenses of the treatment availed as claimed by them is also incorrect and much less. The patient is conscious and recovering well. On March 7, he was briefly on ventilator support but now he is better,” a senior doctor told TOI. He also said that the patient was being treated for multiple ailments and was an alcoholic and drug abuser.

Title: RLSP backs Congress’s claim over one Rajya Sabha seat, RJD says no way
Content:
RLSP chief Upendra Kushwaha

PATNA: In a fresh turn of events in the Mahagathbandhan in Bihar over Rajya Sabha seats, Upendra Kushwaha-led RLSP has supported Congress’s demand of one seat from RJD. RLSP claimed RJD had committed one seat to Congress during the Lok Sabha elections last year.

“RJD’s Rajya Sabha member and national spokesperson Manoj Jha had said it in a joint press conference of Mahagathbandhan ahead of the previous Lok Sabha elections. RJD must fulfil its commitment to abide by the alliance dharma,” RLSP general secretary Madhav Anand said.

Given the strength of RJD, Congress and other allies in the state legislative assembly, the Mahagathbandhan can easily win two out of the 5 Rajya Sabha seats for which election is to be held on March 26.

Under the seat-sharing arrangement for the 40 Lok Sabha seats in 2019, RJD had contested 19 seats, Congress nine, RLSP five and Jitan Ram Manjhi-led HAM (S) and Mukesh Sahani-led VIP on three seats each. The Mahagathbandhan had left Ara Lok Sabha seat for CPI(ML), which also lost.

Incidentally, Congress’s Rajya Sabha member Akhilesh Prasad Singh’s son Aakash Kumar Singh had unsuccessfully contested on RLSP ticket from Purvi Champaran. Party insiders said now RLSP is supporting Congress in its demand for a Rajya Sabha seat from RJD in a show of solidarity.

Nevertheless, RJD functionaries are non-committal. “It is not our concern whether Congress wants to send its candidate to Rajya Sabha. We are thinking about whom from the party to send from our quota,” RJD state president Jagdanand Singh said.

RJD spokesperson Mrityunjay Tiwari claimed that Congress’s Akhilesh went to Rajya Sabha in 2018 from RJD quota only. “RJD has always respected its allies and shown generous attitude in all matters. However, we should not always be expected to make sacrifices. Hence, we are firm that people from RJD will only be sent to Rajya Sabha from our quota,” Tiwari said.

Though the last date of filing nomination papers is March 13, only JD(U) has announced its candidates so far and retained Harivansh and Ram Nath Thakur. The other retiring Rajya Sabha members are Kahkashan Perween of JD(U) and Dr C P Thakur and R K Sinha of BJP.

Title: Fallout of Yes Bank crisis: Fear factor hits private lenders
Content: MUMBAI: Smaller private banks were bearing the brunt of collateral damage triggered by the crisis in Yes Bank . Dogged by rumours and news of state authorities shifting business to public sector lenders dragged down the share prices of some private banks (see graphic). A few of them were forced to issue statements as rumours got out of hand.The Nifty private bank index closed higher by nearly half a percentage point, but some lenders closed lower. On the BSE, IndusInd Bank was down 5.8%, Federal Bank lost close to 1.9% and Axis Bank was down 0.8%. The Maharashtra government made matters worse for private banks by announcing that all state government accounts would be moved from private banks to those in the public sector.Despite the RBI issuing a statement earlier this week that it monitors all the banks and there is no such concern of safety of deposits in any bank, rumours continued to spread. The RBI had countered social media messages highlighting the fall in market capitalisation of banks, stating that there was no link between solvency of a bank and its market capitalising.Two old private banks — RBL Bank and Karur Vysya Bank — issued statements assuring depositors that the banks were sound and well capitalised. Shares of both banks closed in the green on Wednesday. Kotak Mahindra Bank also sent out a message to customers: “Baseless and factually incorrect messages are being circulated on WhatsApp about Kotak Mahindra Bank. We assure you that Kotak Mahindra Bank is a financially strong, well-capitalised bank with a strong risk and corporate governance framework. Your deposits with us are absolutely safe.”RBL Bank said in a statement, “RBL Bank is well capitalised with a capital adequacy ratio of 16.08%, higher than the prescribed regulatory requirement at 11.5%.” It added that there was no material adverse change in the asset quality since the bank announced its quarterly results and it had adequate liquidity cover. “Rumours around financial health and stability of the institution, especially in social media, seem to be misplaced, motivated and not based on facts,” the statement added.Karur Vysya Bank, meanwhile, said that the bank is highly capitalised, with a capital adequacy ratio of 15.87%. “KVB has the distinction of being consistently profitable throughout its 104-year history. KVB is a fundamentally strong institution across all relevant parameters,” the bank said.Banks unions called for Yes Bank to be brought directly under government control. “In order to protect the interest of the depositors and bank’s clients, Yes Bank should be immediately brought under the public sector. One by one private banks, which are being glorified by the government, are failing. It is high time that the government should take a call and repeat 1969 — all the private banks should be brought under public sector,” said C H Venkatachalam, general secretary of AIBEA.

Title: Gujarat: You’ll feel the heat from today, says IMD
Content:
File Photo

AHMEDABAD: If your summer wardrobe isn’t yet out, make sure you pull out your favourite pastels in cotton. After a pleasant few days till Wednesday due to the cloudy weather, brace for hot days ahead. According to India Meteorological Department (IMD) – Gujarat, the maximum temperatures will gradually begin to rise from Thursday onwards. The maximum temperature in Ahmedabad settled at 30.4°C on Wednesday, remaining 4.4 degrees below normal, while the minimum temperature stood at 19.4°C, remaining 1.4 degrees above normal.

While rainfall took place in isolated places of Saurashtra region, overall, Kutch and Gujarat regions reported dry weather.

“Cloudy weather prevailed in the state due to western disturbance . Very light rainfall also took place in Porbandar on Tuesday. However, the clouds will begin to recede from Thursday onwards and as a result, the maximum temperature will gradually begin to rise,” said Jayanta Sarkar, director, IMD – Gujarat.

“At the same time, the minimum temperature is also expected to fall over the next two to three days,” Sarkar further added.

On Thursday, the maximum temperature is expected to touch 30°C whereas the minimum temperature will settle at 18°C. According to IMD forecast, partly cloudy sky is expected.

Title: Tussle over CAA continues in Tamil Nadu assembly
Content:
After the AIADMK refused to pass a resolution against CAA, the opposition led by the DMK walked out of the hou... Read More

CHENNAI: The AIADMK government on Wednesday made it clear that the state legislature was bound by the Parliamentary law and adopting a resolution against CAA in the assembly would be unconstitutional. As revenue minister R B Udayakumar clarified the government’s standpoint in the assembly, the opposition DMK and its allies, the Congress and the IUML walked out of the House, charging that the Tamil Nadu government was not protecting the rights of minorities.

Udayakumar said as per the Centre’s instruction, house listing and housing census in Tamil Nadu would take place between June 16 and July 30, this year, ahead of the decennial census scheduled in February 2021.

Later, DMK chief M K Stalin told reporters outside the assembly that the AIADMK government feared that it would lose power if it passed a resolution against the Union government. “They will not only lose power, they (cabinet) will even go to prison as the Centre is vested with the powers to probe charges of corruption,” said Stalin. Earlier, he said in the assembly that people were in a state of fear over the impending NPR exercise and sought to know if the state government received any reply from the Centre on its request to avoid certain queries in NPR 2020. He said the DMK did not object to the NPR 2010 format as it was only a routine enumeration. But NPR 2020 is designed to pave way for NRC, said Stalin.

Udayakumar said the state was yet to receive a response from the Centre. “How will it be constitutionally binding if we pass a resolution against a law enacted by Parliament? Cases (relating to challenging the constitutional validity of CAA) are pending in the Supreme Court,” the minister said. The state had not issued any notification for the conduct of NPR. It would be done only after it receives “guidance” from the Centre as the state has requested the Centre to avoid three queries in NPR like place and date of birth of parents.

Pointing to the BJP allies YSR Congress and Telangana Rashtra Samithi changing their stance on NPR owing to local sentiments, Stalin said the Tamil Nadu government should also pass a resolution in the Cabinet and in the assembly.

Title: 7 of a family, including 4 kids, drown in Tapi boat capsize
Content:
Divers fished out body of a deceased on Wednesday

Surat: Seven people of a family , including four children , died after the boat in which they had gone for picnic capsized in the Tapi River on Dhuleti.

The tragic mishap took place in the upstream of Ukai reservoir at Bhitkhurd village, bordering Nandurbar district, in Tapi district’s Uchchhal taluka on Tuesday.

About 13 people, of whom 10 comprised youngsters and children from a family in Konkani Falia in Sundarpur village in Tapi district’s Uchhal taluka, had gone for picnic at Bhitkhurd village on Tuesday. Sometime in the afternoon, the picnickers decided to hire a boat to visit the small island located in the middle of the river.

Sources said that Bhitkhurd village, which borders the Tapi and Nandurbar district in Maharashtra, is a picnic hotspot for locals in Uchchhal taluka during weekends and festival holidays. A few locals from the village also provide visitors boat rides in Tapi River.

While returning from the island at about 2.30pm, sudden change in atmosphere coupled with strong winds toppled the boat which overturned and capsized in the deep waters. About six people managed to save themselves by swimming back to the island, while the others drowned in the gushing waters.

After the incident, scores of people from Bhitkhurd and adjoining villages gathered at the riverbed helping the fire brigade teams from Vyara, Surat and Songadh who sent their divers for search and rescue operation of the victims who had gone missing in the river.

Among the six people who swam to safety, three belong to Bhitkhurd village including the driver of the boat identified as Jignesh Valvi, 30, Amit Gamit, 28 and Vikas Gamit.

Sources said that two bodies — Angel Konkani, 5, and Sanjana Konkani, 14 — were recovered by the rescue teams the same night after search operations continued till late. The remaining five bodies could be recovered the next morning from the river. The other deceased have been identified as Abhishek Konanki, 11, Aradhya Konkani, 7, Urmila Konaki, 21, Vinod Konkani, 18, and Rajesh Konkani, 32 —all residents of Konkani Falia.

Superintendent of police, Tapi district, NN Chaudhary said, “All the deceased are relatives and had come to enjoy Dhuleti holiday at Bhitkhurd village. The boat got overturned due to bad weather and strong winds.”

Chaudhary added that all the seven bodies have been recovered by Wednesday morning and were handed over to the kin after post mortem at the Uchchhal community health centre (CHC).

Title: D-St on edge as Dow Jones crashes over 1,600 points
Content:
Mumbai: Crashing global markets are again pushing Dalal Street investors to the edge. On Wednesday evening, the American markets sank on fears about the spread of coronavirus, with the number of countries reporting cases of the deadly virus reaching 100. The crash in crude oil prices last week is also affecting global market sentiment, which could turn out to be a blessing for net oil importers like India.

The late evening sell-off in markets overseas more than nullified Wednesday’s slightly higher close in India after some initial volatility, market players said. In early trades, as there were reports that New York may consider a lockdown to contain the spread of the deadly virus, the Dow Jones Index crashed more than 1,600 points, or about 6.5%, while Brazil’s Ibovespa was down over 9,000 points or 10%. Across the Atlantic, in late trades, FTSE in the UK was down 1.4%, while Dax in Germany was barely changed from its previous close.

Latest data on the coronavirus spread showed that all schools in 16 countries have been closed even as the death toll crossed 4,000. In India, the financial capital reported its first two infections with the total in the whole country crossing 60.

For Thursday in India, a lower close for the US market will weigh on sentiment, but the cheaper crude oil will give some support to not only equities but also the economy. “Our markets will be affected by the global selling spree, but we may not mirror the Dow’s image,” said Arun Kejriwal, director of investment advisory firm KRIS . “Also, lower crude prices are a blessing in disguise for us.”

In Wednesday’s market, Reliance Industries, ICICI Bank and HDFC Bank contributed to the sensex’s gain, while Infosys, SBI and IndusInd Bank pulled it down. Outside of the index stocks, the Yes Bank stock jumped 36% to Rs 29 on the BSE after RBI and SBI worked overtime on a revival plan for the troubled lender.

Title: GJEPC pays Rs 17L school fees for 300 kids of diamond workers
Content:
The grant was the part of ‘Pratibha’ project launched by the GJEPC

Surat: The Gems and Jewellery Export Promotion Council (GJEPC) paid Rs 17 lakh school fees for 300 children of diamond artisans on Wednesday. The grant was the part of ‘Pratibha’ project launched by the GJEPC.

The event was organized at Ashadeep school in Varachha where the GJEPC distributed school fees cheques for 300 diamond artisans’ children to over 140 schools in the city.

The GJEPC office-bearers said that the aim of the project ‘Pratibha’ is to identify the talent of the diamond artisans’ children studying in schools and provide them with the opportunity to make their career in the gems and jewellery sector.

A survey was conducted by the Diamond Industry Career Foundation (DCIF) and Ratna Abhushan Welfare Trust, Surat, a few months back where the families of artisans needing support in terms of school fees were identified. The schools were invited to provide the details of outstanding fees for such students.

About 140 schools sent the details of about 300 students who were unable to pay the school fees due to the crisis in the diamond industry.

Regional chairman, GJEPC, Dinesh Navadia, said, “Many artisans lost their jobs due to the prevailing situation and many are getting partial salary from the units. It is difficult for the families of diamond artisans to survive in such situation. However, we conducted the survey and found 300 such children whose parents were unable to pay their school fees.”

Navadia added, “The GJEPC issued cheques worth Rs 17 lakh through the Gems and Jewellery National Relief Foundation (GJNRF).”

Title: Valsad municipality serves final notice to railways on Rs 44L tax due
Content:
Surat: The Valsad municipality has served final notice to the Western Railway (WR) on the pending amount of drainage tax to the tune of Rs 44 lakh on Wednesday and threatened to severe the connection in case of failure to pay the amount.

The WR authorities have been directed to deposit the pending tax with the municipality latest by March 17 under section 132 of the Gujarat Municipality Act, 1963, failing which the connections will be severed, the notice read.

Official sources said there are total of 402 residential and 19 non-residential drainage connection provided by the Valsad municipality to the Valsad railway station and its staff quarters. However, the railway has not paid the drainage tax to the municipality since 2004.

While talking with ToI, Jagatsinh Vasava, CEO of Valsad municipality, said, “Despite of several notices issued in the past, the WR has not paid the pending drainage tax of Rs 44 lakh. This time we have issued final notice to the railway and asked them to pay the dues latest by March 17. If dues are not paid within time, we may consider to severe the drainage connections.”

“The railway at Valsad has been using the drainage services provided by the Valsad municipality. There are residential as well as non-residential connections. The drainage dues are pending since 2004 till date,” Vasava added.

When contacted, area railway manager (ARM) of Valsad, Annu Tyagi, said, “I am not aware of such notice as I am on leave from last couple of days.”

Title: Man kills wife, self after brawl
Content:
Surat: A man stabbed his wife to death in Azad Nagar of Bhatar locality in the city on Tuesday afternoon. The man later ended his life at his home by hanging himself.

Police booked Ravi Khandare (35), a labourer, for allegedly killing his wife Mohini. The accused had stabbed Mohini multiple times. The woman was staying with her parents and the accused lived separately in a nearby home after the couple had a fallout. After killing his wife the accused went to his home and hanged himself.

Mohini’s family took her to a hospital where she was declared brought dead. The angry family members went to Khandere’s house and found him hanging from the ceiling. He had used a saree to hang himself.

According to the police, Khandere and his wife had separated from each other for the past few months after a dispute. Khandare had suspected Mohini of extra-marital affair, following which the couple used to fight frequently.

On Tuesday, Khandere came to the house of Mohini’s parents to seek the custody of his two daughters, as he was leaving for Maharashtra. When Mohini refused to hand over her daughters to him, Khandere got angry and attacked her with a knife.

Title: JD(U) retains Harivansh Narayan Singh, Ram Nath Thakur; BJP names Vivek Thakur for Rajya Sabha
Content:
Bihar CM and JD(U) national president Nitish Kumar. (PTI photo)

PATNA: JD(U) retained sitting members Harivansh Narayan Singh and Ram Nath Thakur while BJP named Vivek Thakur as its candidate from Bihar for the Rajya Sabha election to be held on March 26. Harivansh is Rajya Sabha deputy chairman while Vivek is the son of Dr C P Thakur, whose term in the Upper House is expiring in the first week of April. The last date for the filing of nomination papers for the five Rajya Sabha seats falling vacant from the state is March 13.

The five Rajya Sabha seats scheduled to fall vacant are of Harivansh, Ram Nath Thakur and Kehkeshan Parween from JD(U), as well as of Dr C P Thakur and R K Sinha from BJP.

Bihar CM and JD(U) national president Nitish Kumar on Wednesday cleared the names after the party’s core committee members “unanimously” zeroed in on Harivansh and Ram Nath, JD(U) state president Bashishtha Narayan Singh said.

Similarly, the BJP central election committee presided by party president J P Nadda cleared the name of former MLC Vivek on Tuesday itself. However, BJP announced the candidature of Vivek on Wednesday. RJD sources said it will announce its two candidates on Thursday.

Given the strength of the MLAs of the respective political parties in the state, JD(U) and RJD will be able to send two candidates each to the Rajya Sabha and the BJP one. In the NDA camp, JD(U) has 69 MLAs, followed by 54 of BJP and two of the Lok Janshakti Party (LJP). In the grand alliance, RJD has 81 MLAs, followed by 26 of the Congress, besides three from the CPI(ML).

Each candidate would require 42 MLA votes to get elected to the Rajya Sabha. If there is no sixth independent candidate in the fray by March 13, the five official nominees would be deemed elected to the Rajya Sabha.

From JD(U) side, Ram Nath is the son of former CM late Karpoori Thakur. He belongs to an extremely backward caste, a preponderant social group whose support to the NDA is considered crucial during the October-November assembly elections. Vivek from BJP belongs to Bhumihar caste, an equally critical segment from among the upper castes.

Also, there had been virtual revolt in the state BJP during March-April last year, because the party had fielded only one Bhumihar caste leader Giriraj Singh in the 2019 parliamentary elections. The revolt had forced the party to make open “promise” that Bhumihars would get representation in the Rajya Sabha election from the state.

By that token, the major NDA constituents have taken extra care not to ruffle the “political aspirations” of the powerful or predominant caste groups in view of the assembly elections, observers felt.

Title: Cops thrash BJP leader over comments, one sent to lines
Content:
Representative image

VARANASI: Bharatiya Janata Party’s OBC cell Sonbhadra district unit general secretary Sunil Giri was brutally thrashed by Renukoot police outpost in-charge and his colleagues after he allegedly passed obscene comments on police, on Tuesday.

Several BJP workers reached the outpost to save him. The police had to use force to disperse them after which they staged a sit-in. To pacify the situation, SP Sonbhadra Ashish Srivastava ordered to attach the outpost in-charge Anjani Kumar Rai to police lines and engaged a circle officer to probe into the matter. Srivastava said that future action will be decided on arrival of investigation report.

According to sources, Rai was standing outside his outpost on Tuesday morning when Giri reached there and started reciting Holi songs followed by obscene comments on Rai. The cop asked him to stop such recitals. When Giri did not stop, Rai allegedly slapped him.

As he continued to recite comments, Rai and his colleagues allegdely thrashed him inside the outpost. On hearing his cries, several BJP supporters reached there to save him.

In the meantime, inspector Pipari Abhay Narain Tiwari and other senior officers also reached there. They tried to pacify the situation but later had to use force to disperse the BJP supporters. Giri was admitted to Hindalco hospital.

The BJP supporters returned and staged a sit-in demanding suspension of Rai. BJP’s Duddhi assembly area in-charge Rakesh Pandey said that if Giri was involved in unlawful activity he should have been booked but police brutality was unacceptable. The stir was called-off after the SP announced to attach Rai to police lines.

Title: Met forecasts rain from Friday to Sunday
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: As predicted by weathermen, skies turned cloudy in Patna and many other places in Bihar from Tuesday, though no rainfall was reported from anywhere in the state.

India Meteorological Department (IMD) has, however, predicted showers on Friday and wet weather over the weekend as well.

The IMD has predicted fairly widespread rainfall in Bihar on Friday and scattered intensity of showers on Saturday and Sunday.

The Patna Meteorological Centre on Wednesday also stated that rainfall with thunderstorm is likely to occur at one or two places on March 12 and 15 and at a few places on March 13 and 14.

A yellow-coloured warning for thunderstorm with lightning and gusty wind (30-40) kmph at few places was also issued for south-west and south-east Bihar for Thursday. Similar warning has been issued for all 38 districts in the state on Friday and Saturday. A yellow-coloured warning alerts the authority to be watchful for extreme weather conditions.

Private weather agency Skymetweather also reported that east Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Jharkhand may see rain on March 15. There are chances of hailstorm activities and lightning strikes as well.

Meteorologists attributed the showers to an east-west trough running from induced cyclonic circulation to north Chhattisgarh across east Rajasthan and north Madhya Pradesh.

The prevailing weather is also expected to drop day temperature. Patna Meteorological Centre has predicted maximum temperature to come down from the prevailing 29-30 degrees C to 27-28 on Friday and Saturday. Minimum temperature is expected to be in the range of 17-18 degrees C till Sunday.

Title: RBI taps private investors to take stakes in Yes Bank
Content:
MUMBAI: The Reserve Bank of India has drawn up a revival plan for Yes Bank whereby not just capital but also funding lines will be finalised to ensure that there is no liquidity issue upon lifting the moratorium imposed on March 5. Meanwhile, investors in additional tier one (AT1) bonds have agreed to a plan where 80% of their investment will be written off and the remaining 20% will be converted into equity.

While the contours of the deal have been finalised, the plan to lift the moratorium by the weekend may not materialise as many investors in the consortium have to get internal approvals to invest. As per the plan, the RBI will soon announce commitments from the State Bank of India (SBI) and other banks. While SBI will provide the bulk of the funds, it is also leading a host of private investors. The plan is expected to be announced at any time after confirmation from the investment banks.

However, this is taking time because the banking groups are trying to figure which of their group companies are best placed to invest. Besides SBI, HDFC Group, Kotak Bank and ICICI Group have also been sounded out to invest in the equity of Yes Bank.

Private investors like Rakesh Jhunjhunwala and R K Damani, founder of DMart, are likely to join the consortium. RBI wants several investors to ensure that none of them (other than SBI) hold more than 5% stake. The government is keen on having private investors to ensure that the package is not seen as nationalisation. Also, most public sector banks are themselves in a capital conservation mode.

According to the plan, within 24 hours of the announcement (day two), the banks will infuse Rs 20,000 crore into the equity base. On the third day, public sector banks will invest around Rs 30,000 crore into certificates of deposits (CDs) of the bank; and the moratorium will be lifted on the fourth day. The reason why the fund infusion is being done through certificates of deposits is that it will give an assurance that the funding is there for some time and at the same time since CDs are tradeable the investing bank can sell them if required.

Yes Bank is also reaching out to large investors to reassure them that post-capital infusion, the bank will be in a sound position and is supported by the strongest institutions.

The capital infusion will improve the creditworthiness of the bank and make it easier for others to lend. By fixing an equity base of Rs 20,000 crore, the banks which will invest in the fresh equity will get a 75% stake in Yes Bank and the stake of existing shareholders will shrink to a fourth of the expanded equity base. Shares of Yes Bank were trading at Rs 28 in the BSE on Wednesday, 28% over its previous close. At current prices, the bank is valued at Rs 5,600 crore, which is twice the valuation announced by the RBI under its draft plan.

The AT1 bondholders have an investment of Rs 8,500 crore in Yes Bank. This will be converted into 170 crore equity at Rs 10 per share. As a result, the bondholders will account for Rs 1,700 crore investment in the consortium with a three-year lock-in. One tricky issue that could come up is that all the MFs are holding AT1 bonds in pure debt funds. While the lock-in norms require them to hold onto the bonds, Sebi guidelines have some restrictions about such funds investing in equities. One way out might be for the regulator to allow them to side-pocket those equities.

Title: Higher enrolment: Co-eds convert to women’s colleges
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Higher enrollment of female students has forced many co-ed degree colleges to convert into women’s colleges in the districts from the 2020-21 academic year.

In February, the Telangana State Council of Higher Education (TSCHE) had invited applications from college managements interested in applying for conversions from co-ed education to women’s college and vice-versa and received eight applications. Of them, seven colleges in the districts applied for conversion to women’s colleges. There is only one college, located in Hyderabad, that applied for conversion to co-ed education.

Sri Chaitanya Degree College in Warangal, Jagruthi Women’s Degree College in Rangareddy, and PHRM Degree and PG College in Mahbubnagar some of the colleges who applied for inter-conversion.

While the college located in Hyderabad has applied for conversion due to poor-enrolment of only female students, the trend is much the opposite in districts. Officials claim that only women colleges in districts have higher enrolment as against institution offering co-ed education.

“In the last four or five years, we observed that almost 90% of our seats were filled by female students. There were barely a handful of male students who sought admission in our college. So, we decided to convert the college from a co-ed to a women’s institution,” said Eshwar Siripuram , principal of Vikas Degree College in Karimnagar .

Meanwhile, experts say that colleges in the districts see less number of male students and most of them are sent to Hyderabad for their higher studies as opposed to female students. “In districts, enrolment for female students is much higher as parents prefer them to stay in their proximity due to security concerns. Whereas, for male students parents don’t hesitate to send them to Hyderabad,” said Ramana Reddy, president of Telangana Degree and Post-Graduate Colleges Association.

Title: Rajasthan Coronavirus: Rajasthan doctors cure coronavirus patient with HIV drugs
Content: JAIPUR: Sawai Man Singh (SMS) Hospital doctors here have successfully treated an Italian coronavirus (Covid-19) patient using a combination of HIV, swine flu and malaria drugs. The patient, who has now tested negative for Covid-19, had come to India along with her husband as part of a 23-member Italian group that had travelled major tourist destinations in Rajasthan.Her husband was the first in the group to be diagnosed with the disease. National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune, had confirmed him as a Covid-19 case on March 3. The next day, his wife also tested positive for Covid-19.SMS doctors first treated her with a combination of two drugs useful in HIV treatment. “We gave her a combination of Lopinavir 200mg/Ritonavir 50mg twice a day,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary (health department).Singh said ICMR was satisfied with the protocol of having a combination of two HIV drugs, which the SMS Hospital relied on. Besides, the doctors also gave her Oseltamivir, useful in swine flu treatment, and Chloroquine, useful in the treatment of malaria.SMS medical college principal and controller Dr Sudhir Bhandari said, “We provided her treatment following standard protocol and now she has tested negative for the disease, which is a major achievement for SMS Hospital doctors.”Her 69-year-old husband is still undergoing treatment for Covid-19 at the hospital. A day ago, his Covid-19 test was done, but he still tested positive. Doctors are providing him treatment on non-invasive ventilator support.“Since his wife has now tested negative for the disease, we offered to shift her from the isolation ward. She, however, has decided to stay with her husband in the same ward,” said Dr DS Meena, medical superintendent, SMS Hospital.Her husband is taking time in recovery as he is already having a lung disease, doctors said. However, his condition is stable, they added.

Title: Anna univ may not get IoE status, HRD says time’s up
Content:
Chennai: Anna University is set to lose its chance to become an institute of eminence (IoE). After clarifying doubts and waiting for eight months for a letter of commitment from the state government, the Union ministry of human resource development has informed Anna University that IoE status will be given to the next university on the list if it does not receive a letter of commitment immediately. Savitribai Phule Pune University is next on the list.

The MHRD had in August last year announced IoE status for seven public institutions, including Anna University and IIT Madras, and seven private institutions. While central institutions were granted the status instantly, the ministry a demanded letter of commitment for Anna University and Jadavpur University from the respective state governments promising their share of funds.

Anna University would receive Rs 1,000 crore from the Centre and more autonomy for the next five years if it gets the IoE status. The state government would have to spend Rs 1,570 crore.

"Although MHRD has agreed to all the conditions of the state government and university officials cleared the doubts of ministers, there has been no positive response from the state government for reasons unknown," officials from the university told TOI.

Earlier, the state government sought clarification on whether the Tamil Nadu Backward Classes, Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Reservation of Seats in Educational Institution and of Appointments or Posts in Services under the State) Act, 1993, which envisages 69% reservation would apply to Anna University after getting the IoE tag. The MHRD said the state government’s reservation policy would apply even after getting the IoE status.

Title: Cop fires at colleague who smeared him with colours
Content:
Chandigarh: A constable opened fire on his colleague when he smeared his face with colours on Holi in Sector 3.

The colleague escaped unhurt, but the constable was booked for attempt to murder and under the Arms Act at Sector 3 police station. He was later suspended and sent to Police Lines in Sector 26.

On Holi, accused Raj Karan, deputed at VIP security, was sitting with Naveen Kumar and Pardeep Kumar, also constables, at a roadside tea-stall near Sector 3 police station. Pardeep smeared Raj Karan’s face and uniform with colours. Raj Kanwar kept warning him not to do so as he was on duty, but Pardeep paid no heed. On this, both constables entered into a verbal spat, which escalated into a brawl. In a fit of anger, Raj Karan took out his service revolver and pointed at Pardeep. As he pressed the trigger, Naveen intervened and the bullet missed the target.

Pardeep escaped unhurt, but the matter reached police station. Later, both constables entered into a compromise. However, senior officers directed the Sector 3 police station to lodge an FIR.

Past incident

On August 12, 2016, under the influence of alcohol, a UT Police head constable had fired three shots in the air with his 9mm service pistol in Sector 46. On the complaint of an eatery owner, the Sector 34 police had registered a case under the Arms Act and the IPC against the head constable and arrested him.

Title: PG medical online process till March 16
Content:
Ahmedabad: The online registration process for candidates seeking admission in postgraduate (PG) courses in medical and dental colleges of Gujarat will be held from March 11 to March 16.

In a statement on Wednesday, the Admission Committee for Professional Post-Graduate Medical Courses (ACPPGMC) said that the online process for the PG medical and dental courses will be carried out for 1,700 seats.

The admissions are to be conducted based on scores obtained in National Eligibility cum Entrance Test (NEET) PG 2020. The examination, held in January this year, saw 4,800 candidates from Gujarat clearing the test. The entrance exam is for admission to various courses including Master of Surgery (MS) and Doctor of Medicine (DM) offered in government, private, deemed and central universities.

States can start admission process after the Medical Counselling Committee (MCC) conducts admission to 50% All India Quota seats.

For offline registration, students will be given PIN numbers by ACPPGMC for verification purpose. As many as 15 helpline centres have been set up in various colleges including B J Medical College. Students will have to reach out to the helpline centres for cross verification of their application and for documentary evidence. Candidates will be given a token in advance to avoid rush at the centres.

Title: Another KLIP trial run successful
Content:
Hyderabad: In another milestone in Kaleshwaram Lift Irrigation Project (KLIP), the trial run for lifting water from Mid Manair Dam (MMD) to Annapurna reservoir (Anantagiri) at Thippapur village in Rajanna-Sircilla district under package-10 was conducted on Wednesday.

Of the four pumps, trial run of one pump was conducted on Wednesday morning and the trial run of the rest of the pumps would be conducted on Thursday.

KLIP engineer-in-chief Hariram and irrigation advisor Penta Reddy said once all pumps become operational, water would be filled in Ranganayaka Sagar and Kondapochamma Sagar by end of the month. After completing the Link 1 and Link 2 of the KLIP, the state government has been focussing on Link 4, which has been taken up at a cost of Rs 2,700 crore. The package was executed by BHEL and Megha Engineering and Infrastructure Limited (MEIL) in record time. Officials said each pump with a capacity of 106 MW can lift one tmcft water a day with a height of 101 metres.

Title: Jaypee resists takeover, smells like court battle
Content:
Chandigarh: The city’s garbage-processing operator, Jaypee, has moved district court against last Thursday’s decision in the municipal corporation general house of taking over the plant in a week. The deadline expires on Thursday noon.

The court has issued notice to the MC for a 10am hearing before additional sessions judge Vijay Singla, where the civic body will get the case details. Sources in the MC said the decision about takeover and its cost could be the key points from the side of Jaypee, and the civic authority is ready with a reply based on National Green Tribunal’s orders for running the plant in a proper manner. “If required, we will keep those orders before the court,” an official said.

Sources said since the matter had financial jurisdiction of more than Rs 1 crore, it has been listed in the court of the additional sessions judge. The sources also said that after the decision in the general house to take over the plant, some of the senior representatives of the recycling company had met the senior MC officials but since the house had taken a call, the officials concerned were unable to help.

The garbage-processing plant at Dadumajra will go out of the hands of Jaypee Group after 12 long years. The memorandum signed with the company in 2005 was cancelled over improper processing, ending a feud that reached NGT. The house gave the company a month to dismantle its machinery. Else, the civic body will remove the equipment and recover the cost. The house decided to assess the value of the recently installed compost plant and pay its worth to the company.

The MC will call an expression of interest to hire a new company to run the plant. The councillors were unanimous in kicking out the company for relief to the villagers of Dadumajra and adjoining areas. A permanent solution to city’s solid waste management stayed in a mess for a long time, as Jaypee and the MC kept differing over the amount of trash being received at the unit.

Dadumajra villagers and the residents of Sector 38 West want the MC to shift the garbage-processing plant because of bad odour and improper operation, an issue they had raised even during the last Lok Sabha elections. A mountain of landfill building up outside Dadumajra village has worsened the situation.

Box:

Project’s 15-year lifecycle

2005 | MC, Jaypee sign MoU to run the plant

2008 | Plant comes into existence (MC gives away 10 acres for nominal fee of Rs 1)

2013 | Jaypee asks for tipping fee

2019 | Chandigarh Pollution Control Committee imposes penalty of Rs 1.46 on plant for violation of environment rules

Jan 2020 | MC meets Jaypee Group owner to discuss handover

Feb | NGT asks MC whether or not it wants to run the plant with Jaypee, house decides to cancel MoU

March | MC meets UT adviser on Jaypee row and how to run the plant, MoU terminated and company given a week to handover the plant, MC decides to bear any running cost till it finds a new company

Title: Schools told to follow safety guidelines
Content:
Madurai: Circulars were issues to all government and aided schools across the state to ensure prevention of spread of Covid-19 infection among teachers and students.

One of the circulars issued by the state school education department ordered to stop using biometric devices to record attendance from March 9 to March 31. The device is prone to causing spread of infections as many people touch the same surface multiple times every day. The attendance during the days would have to be marked manually in a register. However, the circular was initially ignored by some of the district educational officers (DEOs) in Madurai district and concerns were raised by teachers.

“Some of the DEOs didn’t follow the circular on March 9 and 10 as they said they had not got an official order from the district chief educational officer (CEO) in this regard. Later, the CEO intervened and immediately asked them to stop using the biometric device,” said the headmaster of a government school. By Wednesday, all schools had stopped the use of the device.

Apart from implementing proper hand hygiene and cough hygiene among students, one circular called for teachers to advise children with fever and cough to not to come to school, instead they should go to a hospital. All students were to be given proper awareness about the disease and preventive measures.

Title: Varanasi: US woman, four of 13 suspects test negative for coronavirus
Content: VARANASI: Five of the 13 persons, including an American woman, who were admitted to the isolation ward of the Banaras Hindu University hospital after showing flue-like symptoms, were discharged after their samples tested negative for coronavirus on March 7. The test reports of others are awaited.BHU spokesperson Rajesh Singh said, “A 48-year-old American lady was admitted to the isolation ward of the newly-built superspecialty block of the hospital on March 6. Her throat swab was collected for test. Before coming to Varanasi, she had visited China and Russia with a 35-member group. The samples of three other members of the same group and a local youth who visited Italy were collected on March 7 and sent for test.”The reports of the American woman and Italy-returned youth were found negative, after which they were discharged on March 7. The samples of three more persons, including a 12-year-old girl from Ahmedabad and two women from Mau district, also tested negative and they were also discharged on March 7, he said. The others in contact with the US woman were not admitted.Five more persons, including one each from Azamgarh and Rohtas, Bihar, were examined on March 9 and two locals and one from Ghazipur district were examined on Wednesday for showing symptoms and admitted to isolation wards, while their samples have been sent for testing.BHU hospital has made all arrangements to handle suspected coronavirus cases . A 10-bed special isolation ward has been set up and separate arrangements have been made in OPD. Nurses and paramedical staff have been trained to handle suspected cases.Chief medical officer Dr V B Singh said, “ There has been no confirmed case of coronavirus in the district so far.
