Five nodal officers have been appointed in urban areas and seven in rural areas in the district to keep a vigil on suspected infection cases. The nodal officers report to the CMO by 5pm every day. Apart from BHU hospital, isolation wards have also been created at Pt Deen Dayal Upadhyaya District Hospital, Pandeypur, and Divisional Railway Hospital, Lahartara.”An isolation room has also been created at Lal Bahadur Shastri International Airport.The CMO also appealed people to avoid crowded places and meeting tourists from affected countries for prevention of virus spread. He also asked private hospitals to report any suspect cases immediately to the district surveillance officer and additional chief medical officer Dr S S Kannaujiya on his number 9415830461. District magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma said the situation is being reviewed regularly and proper arrangements have been made for screening of visitors from WHO-identified countries.

Title: Pune Coronavirus: Coronavirus scare hits hotel, transport business in Pune
Content: PUNE: Cancellation of bookings because of the coronavirus scare has started affecting the hospitality and transport sectors.A top source from a city hotel said, “There has been huge cancellation in long-stay room bookings from guests from Korea, Japan and China. We cancelled almost 150-200 room bookings last month.”Some hotels have discontinued their contracts with cab companies, after a massive plunge in occupancy. Cab companies have also been hit hard after 60-70% cancellations of Pune-Mumbai airport transfers and on other routes.Ashwin Trivedi, the director of car rental agency Pluto Travels India Pvt Ltd, said, “We are associated with all five-star hotels in Pune. After room booking cancellations because of coronavirus, they have discontinued all our contracts. This has led to a loss of almost Rs75 lakh in a month. After the booking cancellations, the hotels do not have many customers to use our cab services for airport transfers and local pickup and drop.”Girish Makhijani, owner, Hare Krishna Comfort Tours, said, “Corporates have sent out communication to employees for meetings to be cancelled or have shifted to video conferences. So, cab bookings to Mumbai are getting cancelled. The cancellation rate so far has been 70%.”Transporters renting out luxury buses have been hit, too. Kiran Desai of Swamiraj Tourism said bookings worth anything between Rs10 lakh and Rs15 lakh had been cancelled. “Now that Pune has some positive cases, we don’t think the situation will improve immediately,” Desai, the secretary of the Pune Bus Owners’ Association, told TOI.Around 10,000 buses are given on rent in the city. “More than 90% of the operators are suffering losses between Rs20 lakh and Rs25 lakh. Close to 80% bookings have been cancelled for the whole month of March,” Desai added.Rajan Junavane, the president of the Pune Bus Owners’ Association, said, “A college had recently booked one of my buses for a tour to Goa, but the booking was cancelled because of the prevailing coronavirus situation. The fear factor is huge, and no one wants to take a risk.”Another transporter, requesting anonymity, said he had four cancellations in the past three days.“The recent decision of the state government to increase the VAT on fuel by Re1 is another jolt in these troubled times. The state government should take some steps to bail us out,” said Prakash Gavli of All India Motor Transport.An official of the Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML), which celebrated its “Bus Day” on Wednesday, said the passenger traffic was not as expected despite close to 1,700 buses being on roads. “Many are avoiding buses off late,” he said.

Title: Principal suspended for thrashing girls
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: A day after 120 students of Kasturba Gandhi Girls’ School at Khila Shapur in Jangaon were allegedly thrashed by the principal of the school for taking bath after playing Holi, after being told not to do so owing to water shortage, Jangaon collector K Nikhila suspended the school principal.

“Based on a preliminary enquiry, I have suspended the principal,” said Nikhila, adding that she will probe into the matter further.

She said that a complaint was filed against the principal, Sumalatha, stating that she had punished the students for washing their hair.

Balala Hakkula Sangham (BHS) president Achyutha Rao, who lodged a complaint with officials of Jangaon district , alleged that 120 students of Classes 6 to 9 of the said residential school were beaten up by principal Sumalatha for washing their hair after playing holi. “The students were asked not to wash their hair owing to shortage of water in the hostel,” Rao added, and said that the principal rapped the students over the knuckles with a cane.

The BHS demanded that a criminal case be registered against the principal under relevant sections of the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act and Section 325 of IPC. The sangham further demanded that the principal be permanently sacked.

The incident came to light after the students’ parents staged a dharna in front of the school on Tuesday.

Title: State has no clue about the fishermen stranded in Iran
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: Even as groups of fishermen from Kerala trapped in Iran , one of the worst Covid 19-affected countries, are sharing SOS videos on Facebook , the state government is clueless on their actual numbers or whether these men are legal immigrants.

“The Indian Embassy in Iran doesn’t have documents on their (fishermen’s) residence in that country, which suggests that these men are working there without a proper visa. The embassy informed that it has contacted this group of fishermen. We can only believe what they (Embassy officials) say,” said fisheries minister J Mercykutty Amma.

Government has collected some addresses based on a few complaints received from their families and has forwarded the details to Indian Embassy through Norka department, she said.

But, state government sent the details of only 18 fishermen from Kerala, while the SOS videos repeatedly talked about hundreds of them being stranded in various places in Iran. As per the information received from the embassy, there are 800 Indian fishermen in Iran and the numbers could be much higher if there are illegal migrants, the minister said.

Meanwhile, fishermen organizations back home pointed out that around 900 fishermen from Kerala and Tamil Nadu were working in places like Kish, Kangan, Lavan, Mogham, Zero, Chiruyeh, Bhushar, Sharak and Alshoor in Iran. These organizations have sent separate letters to the Centre and Indian Embassy informing that the fishermen have run out of supplies and hence they need to be rescued on a ‘war footing’.

“We sent a letter to the Prime Minister on Monday for an immediate intervention to bring them back safely to their respective states. The changing Covid-19 situations back home seem to be diverting the governments’ attention,” said general secretary of National Fishworkers’ Forum T Peter. The trapped fishermen have run out of supply of food and drinking water, and their sponsors are not at all helpful, he added.

“We were informed by our fishermen that no official from Indian Embassy met them and listened to their grievances... We are eagerly waiting to know the schedule of the medical test for the fishermen. Please provide them the medical test at the earliest. They are waiting for several days to finish formalities, so that they can return to India...” said a letter sent by Justin Antony, founder president of International Fishermen Development Trust to Indian Embassy in Iran0.

Meanwhile, the latest video from the fishermen has criticized the state government and political organizations back home ‘for sitting idle’ on their plea for an immediate rescue. “We have among us several people who risked their lives to save people during floods in Kerala. Nobody seems to care about us, while help is extended to students and pilgrims. Don’t our lives have any worth?” they asked in the video.

Title: Prospective kidney donors key to fight against chronic disease, say doctors
Content:
Madurai: Many prospective kidney donors, mostly relatives of patients suffering from chronic kidney disease (CKD), who are hesitant to come forward for live donations must change their perception to tackle the disease, urged doctors and experts on ‘World Kidney Day’, observed on March 11.

Two of the major causes of CKD include diabetes and hypertension, conditions which are in turn drastically on the rise due to lifestyle factors. “Transplantation is the only permanent solution for CKD as compared to a lifetime of undergoing temporary fixes like medicine and dialysis. So, we try to convince a patient’s kin to go for transplantation,” said Dr N Dhinakaran, director and chief nephrologist, Madurai Kidney Centre and Transplantation Research Institute.

According to Dr K Balakrishnan, head, Department of Immunology, Madurai Kamaraj University (MKU), the role of kidney donors is vital to prevent hospitals from being overburdened. “It has come to a situation where patients have to wait in a queue in hospitals for undergoing dialysis. Sadly, even the educated have an inherent fear of losing an organ, when it comes to donating. Donors need to manage their diet and lifestyle after transplantation for lifetime,” he said.

Dhinakaran said that one of the main concerns that prospective kidney donors need to watch out for is that though the human body can function normally with just one kidney, in case of an infection, it would be difficult to manage. However, the onus is on doctors and counsellors at hospitals to convince the prospective donor and ensure that the person is ready to face any difficulty.

Balakrishnan, who also runs the Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA) laboratory at MKU which does HLA tissue typing cross-match tests for around 30 hospitals across south Tamil Nadu, said that around 100 kidney transplants have been done per year in the region during the past 10 years.

He said there was a sharp rise in the number of cadaveric kidney transplants in recent times. The number of cadaveric kidney transplants is almost three times higher in 2018-2019 as compared to 2015-2016, jumping from around 40 per year to more than 130 per year.

“Since 2015-2016, a total of around 500 cadaveric kidney transplants have been done. More awareness about organ donation has helped in the rise of the number of cadaveric kidney transplants,” added Balakrishnan.

Title: Khosla joins as Imtech director
Content:
tnn

Chandigarh: Sanjeev Khosla has joined as the director of Institute of Microbial Technology (Imtech). He has more than two decades of research experience and succeeds Dr Anil Koul, who had resigned the previous year on personal grounds.

Khosla was working as a scientist at Centre for DNA Fingerprinting and Diagnostics, Hyderabad, which is an autonomous organization funded by the department of biotechnology under the ministry of science and technology. He had received his PhD from Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, in which he worked on the correlation of chromatin organization with genomic imprinting and sex determination in insects. After completion of his PhD, he joined as a research scientist at Babraham Institute, Cambridge, UK, where he was involved in analysing epigenetic differences between the genetic information inherited from mother and father in mammals.

Later, he moved to the Cancer Research Institute, Cambridge, UK, where he continued his work on the correlation of chromatin organization with genomic imprinting in mammals. He has more than 30 publications in reputed Science Citation Index journals like Nature Communications, Nucleic Acid Research and Journal of Biological Chemistry, among others.

He said, “It’s a great honour to lead a premier microbial research institution like Imtech, which will continue to strive in its mission to serve unmet societal and medical needs through cutting-edge science and innovation.”

Title: NGT orders check of civic incinerator on economic norms in Pune
Content:
PUNE: The National Green Tribunal (NGT) has directed a three-member expert panel to inspect the civic body’s incinerator plant at Keshavnagar, Mundhwa for disposal of animal carcass following a plea alleging that it was being operated without a valid environment clearance under the Environment Impact Assessment (EIA) notification of 2006.

Among other fears, Keshavnagar resident Mohan Nanasaheb Kudale raised in his plea concerns about the health hazards posed to the residents around the plant and the pollution and foul smell in the area caused by it.

The green tribunal’s bench of Justice S P Wangdi and expert member Satyawan Singh Garbyal on March 6 directed the Union environment ministry’s regional office in Nagpur, Maharashtra Pollution Control Board (MPCB) and the Pune district collector to jointly inspect the plant and file a report. The bench also asked the panel members to take action against the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) in case they came across any illegality and submit a compliance report before the next date hearing on April 23.

The civic body had taken up the incinerator plant project in 2012-13 and conducted trials on March 10, 2013. That is when a local resident had filed a writ petition in the Bombay high court, citing lack of apt consent and clearances to operate the plant. The high court on July 11, 2013, directed the PMC to not operate the plant unless it secured all the necessary permissions. This was after the PMC’s lawyer gave an assurance to that effect.

Kudale’s lawyer, Saurabh Kulkarni, told TOI, “The matter was since pending before the high court, which finally disposed of the petition on January 24, 2020 after the MPCB gave its consent to the PMC on January 20, 2020, to operate the plant.”

He said, “The PMC has since commenced its operation at the plant, but it is our case that the MPCB, while giving its consent, did not verify whether the civic body had an environment clearance for the project. In fact, it still does not have such clearance and that is the reason, the NGT has involved the Union environment ministry’s regional office at Nagpur for the joint inspection.”

Kulkarni said, “Entry number 7 in the EIA notification makes it mandatory for all hazardous waste and incinerator plants to obtain an environment clearance before they go fully functional. In the instant case, the incinerator plant falls within “A” category projects and an environment clearance for the same can be issued only by the central government. This not being the case, the PMC still went ahead with operationalising the plant.”

Applicant Kudale has said in his plea that the 2000kg capacity incinerator plant (500kg per hour burning rate) has been installed with an expenditure of Rs3 crore. As per the EIA notification, it is categorised as a Common Hazardous Waste Treatement, Storage and Disposal facility falling within red category of industries for which the consent ought to have come from the Central Pollution Control Board and not the MPCB.

Title: Women urged to make best use of their potential
Content:
Women shared their experiences in Ignou’s panel discussion on Monday

Nagpur: Women empowerment, discrimination and lack of opportunities at workplace, and challenges at personal and professional fronts were the focal points at a panel discussion on ‘Women in education administration – challenges, opportunities and solutions’ organized by Indira Gandhi National Open University (Ignou), Nagpur regional centre, to mark International Women’s Day, on Monday.

Regional director P Sivaswaroop, in his introductory address said that there is a difference between academic administration and office administration . “In the former, administration is done more in a consultative manner, however sometimes many administrations are apathetic to the problems faced by women,” he said.

The panellists included women who shared their experiences and challenges. Dr Shakti Sharma, Ignou coordinator, Raisoni Women’ College, said that by and large men don’t realize and acknowledge that women face discrimination. “In most organizations, there are few women at the top. Discrimination against women is not a problem of just women, but of men too.”

She stated that women have to work much harder and prove themselves again and again as compared to their male counterparts. “Fortunately, the world is changing. Today our voices are being heard and our potential is being recognized,” she said.

Dr Naqui Siddique, Ignou coordinator from Institute of Science, pointed out the difficulties in maintaining a work-life balance. “It is very hard to stay away from kids on holidays and festivals. It is inherently, but unjustly, expected from women to make sacrifices and compromises.”

Dr Sadhana Jain, from NSRC-ISRO, stated that if there is only one woman in a group of 10 while rest are men, chances of her getting an opportunity are significantly less. Jyotsna Meshram, head of the department of chemistry, Nagpur University, informed that there are less than 15% women working in science today. “This number needs to increase. It is unfortunate that society sometimes plays a negative role when it comes to women empowerment.”

According to Rajshree Yadav, dean, faculty of interdisciplinary studies, Nagpur University, it is very difficult to move forward without someone having faith in you. “We women are conscious beings with conscious minds. We are not mere showpieces. This needs to be taught to young girls and parents alike. Women have immense potential and ability. It all depends on the efforts one takes to harness it,” she said.

Title: Chandigarh: Pet dog bites 25-year-old woman, owner arrested
Content: CHANDIGARH: A 25-year-old woman was injured after a pit bull bit her in Sector 30 on Tuesday night. A few months ago, the same dog had bitten four others in the area and at the time the owner had promised he would send his pet away.Lovely, a resident of Kapurthala, along with her mother and sister had come to the city to meet her maternal aunt in Sector 30 on Holi evening. She said they asked dog owner Premchand, who lived next door, to keep the animal on a tight leash, but he refused, saying if they felt scared they should go inside their home.Lovely was taking out her stuff from her car outside the house around 8pm when the animal ran towards her and attacked her. She screamed and her family members came to her help. Premchand and his son also came out of their house and joined in rescuing the woman. Pit bull bit on her hand and she was rushed to GMH-16, where doctors vaccinated her.Her family members called up at 112 number and informed the police. Cops from Industrial Area Phase-I police station reached the spot and recorded the statements. On the statement of Lovely’s mother Renu, the police registered a case under Section 289 (negligent conduct with respect to animal) of the IPC against Premchand and arrested him. He was later released on bail.After the incident, angry residents and family members of the injured woman met SDM (east) and submitted a complaint against the dog owner, as this was the fifth such incident.The same dog had attacked Anureet Kaur, 12, when she was returning home from school on January 8. The entire incident was recorded on a CCTV camera. A video of the attack had gone viral on social media. Residents said Anureet’s family had given a complaint against Premchand to the police, but he promised to send the dog away and both the parties reached a compromise. However, he allegedly brought the dog back after three days.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Pune: Cops appeal against panic messages
Content: PUNE: The cybercrime branch of the city police on Wednesday appealed to residents not to forward or spread any rumours related to coronavirus on social media networking sites, considering the impact of such messages on society.Police have also appealed to residents not to disclose names and details of the patients on social networking sites.Deputy commissioner of police (cyber) Sambhaji Kadam said people should not spread rumours. “Fake messages are being spread on social media sites, especially on an internet-based phone messaging service. It has also been found that people are circulating names and addresses of patients. We appeal to people not to spread rumours and not to disclose names and details of the patients on social media sites.”Kadam warned that the police could file cases against people spreading rumours on social media sites. Such action will be under Section 505 (statements conducing to public mischief) of the Indian Penal Code. People prosecuted for such offence can face prison term up to three years on conviction.

Title: ‘DMK worried it can’t do politics over delta’
Content:
Chennai: Asserting that no new hydrocarbon scheme would be allowed in the state as the AIADMK government had enacted a law to protect the Cauvery delta, chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami said in the assembly on Wednesday that the opposition DMK was scared that it would not be able to do politics over the delta hereafter.

The Centre has clarified that the final decision on whether to allow any particular project in a particular region would continue to vest with the state government. “Our government brought the scheme for the welfare of farmers. It is now clear that the DMK dislikes it,” the CM said, pointing to a recent query raised by a DMK MP in the Parliament about the competence of the state government in enacting a law on a Central subject. Palaniswami said the DMK’s drama would not help hoodwink the people of delta region.

He was responding to former DMK minister T M Anbarasan’s observation that the Centre had given its nod to Vedanta Limited and ONGC to drill 341 wells to explore hydrocarbons in Tamil Nadu. The Centre has also amended the Environment Impact Assessment Notification, 2006, exempting hydrocarbon exploration projects from public hearing.

Later, intervening in the debate in the afternoon, the CM recalled a letter written by Union environment minister Prakash Javadekar, which he had read out in the previous assembly session just ahead of enacting the law. “You (the DMK) may not like it. But there is no confusion in our law. You are deliberately trying to confuse farmers in the delta,” the CM said.

While the law bans new industries, the CM said, banning existing units would not work as it would result in companies moving courts. The government would have to compensate their investment too, he said.

Title: Kin protest after suspended Aavin official ends life
Content:
Madurai: Following the suicide of a 35-year-old development officer at Aavin on Tuesday night, who had been suspended by the administration, his relatives protested on Wednesday outside Government Rajaji Hospital demanding for action to be taken against those responsible for his death.

Pugazhendhi, 35, from Othakadai, a development officer at Aavin, had been suspended more than a week ago due to some issues related to his work. Pugazhendhi is said to have been under immense stress during the past few days.

On Tuesday night, Pugazhendhi ended his life, said police. On Wednesday, after his body was recovered and brought to Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) for autopsy, the Pugazhendhi’s kin protested demanding for action to be taken against those responsible for his death.

The kin refused to accept his body and sat outside the hospital disrupting traffic. They demanded for a judicial inquiry and action against higher officials at Aavin for being responsible for Pugazhendhi’s taking the drastic step. After long talks with the police, the kin dispersed and received the body for burial at their native village. The Othakadai police have, meanwhile, registered a case and are investigating. During investigation, the police recovered a suicide note in Pugazhendhi’s handwriting from his room as well.

Title: Boy found hanging in school washroom
Content:
tnn

Mohali: A 17-year-old boy was found dead under mysterious circumstances at his school in Mataur on Monday evening.

Harmanjeet Singh, a resident of Morinda, was a Class XI (medical) student of Meritorious School in Sector 70.

Sources in the police department said, “Harmanjeet, a hosteller, was found hanging with a piece of cloth in the school washroom. Blood was spattered on the washroom floor and walls.”

Crying foul, Harmanjeet’s family accused the school authorities of negligence.

Tarsem Singh, his father, said “The school authorities called me up around 8pm Monday, saying my son had fallen unconscious. I immediately rushed to his school. My son cannot commit suicide. The school authorities should be probed.”

On March 8, Harmanjeet had told his father that he did not want to stay in the hostel as his friend was not talking to him. “But I told him to concentrate on his studies,” said Tarsem.

Mataur station house officer inspector Rajiv Kumar said, “A case has been registered against the school authorities under Section 304-A (causing death by negligence) of the Indian Penal Code. We are investigating the case.”

The post-mortem report stated that the boy died of asphyxia, said a cop.

Title: COVID-19 scare: Visitors banned at Amul Dairy and chocolate plants
Content: Anand/Vadodara: Amul nation’s largest food brand , will not allow visitors at its dairy and chocolate plant in Anand till further notice. The decision was taken on Wednesday in wake of COVID-19 cases being reported in the country.The dairy giant encourages people to visit its dairy and chocolate plants to bring awareness about the processing of milk and milk products. On an average 3,000 visitors come to the Amul Dairy and Amul Chocolate plant in Anand daily.A communique stated that the temporary closure is being taken as a preventive measure in accordance to an advisory released by the Government of India against public gatherings to arrest the spread of the novel coronavirus infection.Amul also assured that the outbreak will not affect quality and supply of milk and milk products which are prepared at Amul’s 80 state-of-the-art dairy plants located across India. The release added that all products undergo stringent quality checks at each stage — from procurement of raw milk to processing into various milk and milk products and distribution to the customer.

Title: SCR installs new passenger info system at Anakapalle stn
Content:
Hyderabad: South Central Railway (SCR) installed a new passenger information system at Anakapalle station in Vijayawada division that shows the estimated arrival time of the trains at the station based on real-time location of the trains.

Known as ‘At a Glance’ display boards, the system also provides a facility for the operator to modify the data instantly in case of emergencies, while providing information about all the trains expected at the station in the next two hours. “The real-time information will be provided by taking continuously updated data automatically from the Centralized Railway Information System server from time to time. The information is provided in Telugu, English and Hindi,” read an official release from SCR.

A passenger arriving at the station can identify all the trains coming to the station in the next two hours from the display along with their expected time of arrival and location of the coach from engine as the entire train composition is depicted in a graphical way. “This new system can also be used for displaying additional information about amenities available at the station and about their location on the platform," said the release.

Title: Coronavirus scare: 600 Indians returning from Iran to be quarantined in Jaisalmer
Content: PUNE: The Southern Command , headquartered in Pune, has set up a quarantine facility at Jaisalmer in Rajasthan and will have two more facilities at Secunderabad in Telangana and Chennai in Tamil Nadu for coronavirus “The first batch of 300 Indian nationals returning from Iran on March 14 will be quarantined at Jaisalmer. On March 16, the second batch of 300 travellers from the same country will be screened at the facility,” a senior army officer from Army HQ, who did not wish to be named, told TOI over the phone.The first facility was at Manesar in Haryana where people returning from China were tested. “Since our doctors have knowledge about the screening, similar modules will be followed at the new facilities. Community medicines experts in the Armed Forces Medical Services are sharing their experiences,” another army officer told TOI on condition of anonymity.The army has directed all its command and field hospitals to create isolation wards. “Our priority is to have measures at unit levels where troops are working and staying together. Awareness programmes are being run at peace and field posts in the southern sector,” the officer added.

Title: Govt suggests 500MW solar park in Kamuthi
Content:
Chennai: As the Centre recently cancelled the 500MW Kadaladi solar park project in Ramanthapuram district following the state’s failure to acquire land for the project, power minister P Thangamani on Wednesday said the state government has planned to set up the project in Kamuthi , 30km from Kadaladi, in the same district.

Solar Energy Corporation of India, functioning under the Union ministry of new and renewable energy, had originally made an offer for investment and development of the park on the land to be provided by Tangedco on build-own-operate basis. “There is an interim injunction from the court on the acquisition of land. We said the land could be given only after vacating the stay order but the Centre cancelled the project due to lapse of deadline. We have suggested an alternative site in Kamuthi in Mudukalathur,” the minister said in the assembly.

The Union government has assured inspection of the site, Thangamani said.TNN

Title: In spite of coronavirus scare, Barodians celebrate Holi with gusto
Content:
Vadodara: Barodians came out in thousands in different areas to play colours on Tuesday despite the coronavirus scare. The roads, especially in old city, were crowded with citizens who were seen playing in groups with their friends and relatives.

“We were bit sceptical in morning but later decided to visit our friends and family to play Dhuleti. There seemed to be no scare of Coronavirus as people gathered in big numbers and were playing with colours,” said Rashmin Jadhav, who works as financial advisor.

Students of M S University too came out on the road and enjoyed Dhuleti as the authorities had banned gathering campus due to coronavirus. When some students at Faculty of Family and Community Sciences tried to play with colours in the campus, the authorities confiscated the colour. While some Barodians preferred to play with organic colours, some even used rose petals to celebrate Dhuleti.

Police department hadn’t issued any guidelines for large gatherings during Dhuleti but the cops did organize awareness campaign on Tuesday asking people to avoid big groups or touching each other.

Title: Coronavirus scare: 600 Indians returning from Iran to be quarantined in Jaisalmer
Content: PUNE: The Southern Command , headquartered in Pune, has set up a quarantine facility at Jaisalmer in Rajasthan and will have two more facilities at Secunderabad in Telangana and Chennai in Tamil Nadu for coronavirus “The first batch of 300 Indian nationals returning from Iran on March 14 will be quarantined at Jaisalmer. On March 16, the second batch of 300 travellers from the same country will be screened at the facility,” a senior army officer from Army HQ, who did not wish to be named, told TOI over the phone.The first facility was at Manesar in Haryana where people returning from China were tested. “Since our doctors have knowledge about the screening, similar modules will be followed at the new facilities. Community medicines experts in the Armed Forces Medical Services are sharing their experiences,” another army officer told TOI on condition of anonymity.The army has directed all its command and field hospitals to create isolation wards. “Our priority is to have measures at unit levels where troops are working and staying together. Awareness programmes are being run at peace and field posts in the southern sector,” the officer added.

Title: Jaunpur clash over club membership, FIR lodged
Content:
Representative image

VARANASI: An excise inspector Prashant Singh was assaulted by an assistant professor and his companions in Line Bazar area of Jaunpur district in a dispute over membership of English Club, on Wednesday.

Inspector Line Bazar Dinesh Pandey said that on the complaint of the excise inspector a named FIR against assistant professor of TD College Jai Prakash Singh has been lodged under section 323, 504 and 506 of IPC and the matter is being investigated.

On Wednesday morning, the excise inspector and other members of English Club in Line Bazar area were busy playing badminton. In the meantime, Jai Prakash and his companion also reached there. The people present at the club started calling Jai Prakash and his companion as outsiders and demanded the club management to oust them.

This led to a heated argument between the two groups. After a few minutes Jai Prakash allegedly attacked the excise inspector with his badminton racket. Police said that appropriate action would be taken after investigating the matter.

Title: 8-year-old suffers burns in accidental acid splash by minor during Holi
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: An eight-year-old boy from Old Sangvi suffered burns after his 11-year-old friend accidentally threw floor cleaning acid on him while playing Holi at a construction site on Tuesday.

“The boy mistook the floor cleaning acid in a bucket for coloured water and splashed it on his friend’s back. The boy sustained 15% burns and is undergoing treatment at a hospital. He is out of danger,” senior inspector Dnyaneshwar Sable of the Sangvi police told TOI.

The injured boy’s father has lodged an FIR and the Sangvi police have registered an offence under sections 285 (negligent conduct with respect to fire or combustible matter) and 337 (causing hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others) of the Indian Penal Code.

Sable said the complainant and the boy’s (11) family were neighbours. On Tuesday morning, the boys were playing Holi in front their houses. “While playing, the boys went to the nearby construction building where they noticed a bucket filled with a yellow coloured liquid that they mistook for a coloured water,” he said.

“The 11-year-old boy picked up the bucket and threw the liquid on his friend. The boy started screaming as soon as the liquid was splashed on him. His shirt was burnt and he sustained burns on his back. His father immediately took him to a hospital,” the officer said.

Probe revealed that the bucket at the construction site was filled with floor cleaning acid, the police said.

Title: Lull in Kerala over corona hits banana farmers hard
Content:
Trichy: Traders from Kerala have asked banana growers in Trichy not to arrange consignments as a majority of hotels, shops and commercial establishments there are witnessing poor sales owing to the Covid-19 cases and subsequent restrictions imposed there. This has come as a double blow to farmers cultivating the Nendran variety who have been reeling under a drastic price fall.

Nendran cultivated in Trichy is predominantly sent to Kerala where it is consumed as a popular food item. However, the instances of Covid-19 cases in that state have now stalled the entire procurement of Nendran from Tamil Nadu, particularly Trichy. V Prabhu, a native of Pettaivaithalai, says he raised the variety on 13 acres. The harvest began two weeks ago, but he has so far sold the produce only from 3 acres. Meanwhile, traders who came from Ernakulam told him that they are going to suspend procurement for some time because of the Covid-19 impact.

“We don’t know how to sell and where to sell them now,” he lamented. Shino K Jose, a representative of a trader from Kerala who arrived at Pettaivaithalai told TOI that he was told to stop loading banana with Wednesday’s consignment. V Kalaichezhiyan from Uthamarseeli, who has cultivated Nendran on 5 acres, said his produce would usually be procured by traders from Thalassery, Edappal, Palakkad and Taliparamba in Kannur. “They have expressed their inability to procure banana from my field citing poor business in the state following the crash in overall sales in their state. We hope that the present condition will change soon”, he said.

When contacted A Akbar, 30, the proprietor of Akbar Food Exports in Ernakulam told TOI over phone that coronavirus instances have created panic among the public. “To avert any contact with others, people are avoiding hotels, shops and other commercial establishments. So we have curtailed banana procurement”, Akbar added. Deputy director of agriculture marketing, Trichy, Murugan confirmed that Covid-19 has brought down Nendran procurement considerably.

Title: Chennai: Police start fixing camera on MTC buses
Content:
A CCTV camera (in red) in a bus

CHENNAI: Police have started installing CCTV cameras on Metropolitan Transport Corporation (MTC) buses to ensure safety of passengers.

Three cameras were recently fitted, one externally and two internally, in a bus plying along route 54L (Poonamalle-Broadway). They were fitted in the front left corner (opposite to driver’s seat), rear end and above the left rear-view mirror.

While the first two are aimed at passenger safety, the third one is to ensure that no one travels on footboard and ascertain cause of accidents.

The initiative by Adyar deputy commissioner P Pakalavan and Saidapet inspector Pugazhendhi was primarily aimed at stopping Government Arts College, Nandanam students from travelling on footboard and creating nuisance but it has helped them in several other ways.

“For instance, we now have record of who all travelled on the bus. This will help in identifying bag lifting, pickpocket and eve-teasing suspects,” said Pugazhendhi.

The external camera will play a key role in solving other crimes too as it records all other vehicles, people on road during trip. Given that the bus is also moving at a decent speed, the external camera is able to record number plate details of vehicles with much better quality compared to static CCTV cameras,” he added.

Since the camera has a 15-day backup, footage can be easily retrieved soon after a crime is reported. Efforts are under way to install such cameras on buses on route 23C and 18K as well.

A senior MTC official said similar cameras will be fitted in all 3,300 buses soon at Rs 75 crore and tenders for the project were being prepared.

Title: Cops forcibly remove protesters from Parade Ground dharna sthal
Content:
Dehradun: With the ostensible objective of carrying out facelift of Parade Ground under Smart City scheme, protesters at the city’s lone ‘dharna sthal’ or protest site there were forcibly shifted by policemen on Wednesday evening.

The cops, accompanied by other local officials, asked the protesters to remove their tent, take their belongings, and move from the site. In the process, they faced resistance from the protesters there after which some protesters were held.

“We have arrested 10 protesters under Section 151 of the Indian Penal Code. They were causing disturbance and were not letting us do our job. A protester, who complained of health issues when we reached there, was admitted to Doon Hospital,” said Shweta Choubey, SP City. The protester, who was admitted to the hospital, had been agitating for a year with the demand to make Gairsain the state capital.

The action by police comes weeks after the administration had announced that the dharna sthal will be shifted from Parade Ground to Adhoiwala, Ekta Vihar. A notice (dated March 9) was put up by the administration which said that the designated site for protest is now shifted to Adhoiwala and all such protests shall take place in Adhoiwala from March 11 onwards.

However, the decision was vehemently opposed by protesters who claim that the administration only wants to weaken the impact of protests through the move.

“The current dharna sthal in the Parade Ground is situated right in the heart of the city. This is why protests get media coverage. The new location which is on the outskirts, won’t have that impact,” said Ramesh Singh, a protester.

“Adhoiwala protest ground is in a very bad shape. There is a bad stench there and the place has waterlogging issues as well. How can the administration expect us to protest there?” asked another protester.

Meanwhile, officials remained dogged in their pursuit of clearing the area and by late evening on Wednesday, JCB machines had already been deployed and the ground was being dug up for construction.

Title: Nalini plea on detention turned down
Content:
Chennai: The Madras high court on Wednesday dismissed a plea moved by Rajiv Gandhi assassination life convict Nalini Sriharan to declare her detention illegal. Nalini sought the relief on the ground that the governor has failed to act as per the recommendation of the state cabinet and release her.

Rejecting her plea, a division bench of Justices R Subbiah and R Pongiappan said the 2018 recommendation of the government will come into force only when the governor affixes his signature, which is mandatory.

Merely based on the advice of the council of ministers for premature release the detention cannot be declared by this court as illegal or unreasonable since it was not signed by the governor, the court added.

“The fundamental right or the personal liberty of the petitioner guaranteed under Article 14 or 21 of the Constitution has not been infringed and, therefore, we are of the view the petition itself is not maintainable," the court said.

Title: Inter exam: 90 students caught cheating on Wed
Content:
Hyderabad: In the intermediate public examinations (IPE) on Wednesday, 90 students are caught cheating. Most number of students (36) were caught in Adilabad, followed by 18 in Nalgonda. Apart from these, many students appearing for the exam from Nirmal, Karimnagar etc., too were booked in malpractice cases.

Board secretary Syed Omer Jaleel said that apart from these malpractice cases, no untoward incidents were reported. Till now, this is the highest number of students to be caught in a single day this year. On Saturday, during the English paper II examination, 57 students were booked for malpractice from across the state.

So far, 205 malpractices have been booked in the intermediate exams which began on March 4.

Title: 4-lane road over Ashok Rajpath in Patna approved
Content:
Bihar CM Nitish Kumar

PATNA: Works on construction of a four-lane elevated road between Kargil Chowk and NIT Mor is likely to commence by this year end. CM Nitish Kumar on Monday approved the project aimed at decongesting busy Ashok Rajpath.

While making a presentation on the elevated road, Road Construction Department (RCD) principal secretary Amrit Lal Meena said it will have four lanes. The road will also have connectivity with Patna Medical College and Hospital (PMCH) along with an approach, connecting Ganga Path at Krishna Ghat. It will have an estimated outlay of Rs315 crore.

CM Nitish said the elevated road will benefit people near PMCH, Patna University and many areas further east.

RCD minister Nand Kishore Yadav told TOI on Wednesday that detailed deliberation was held on the design and alignment of the project. “The DPR for the project is targeted to be made ready in three months, following which bidding process will commence for roping in construction agency,” he said.

Deliberations were also held on alignment of a new four-lane bridge parallel to JP Setu on river Ganga between Digha and Naya Gaon. Instructions were given to officials concerned to finalize the DPR for the bridge at the earliest. Yadav said the bridge will be constructed by the state government’s funds.

The chief minister also asked the officials to expedite works on Lohia Path Chakra on Bailey Road. Instructions were also issued for spot inspection of the project site by principal secretaries of the departments concerned, under the leadership of chief secretary to remove the bottlenecks in its speedy execution.

“The concept of Lohia Path Chakra is one-of-a-kind in the country. Officials should do regular spot inspections,” Nitish said.

The CM also said the proposed elevated road from Chiraiyatand railway overbridge (RoB) to Kankarbagh Colony will decongest vehicular movement in that part of the city.

Patna apart, approval was also given to the design of a Laxman Jhula (suspended cable bridge) on Falgu river between Vishnupad temple and Sita Kund. The DPR for the proposed bridge has been made by Bihar Rajya Pul Nirman Nigam Limited and it will be constructed at an estimated cost of Rs60 crore. “No vehicular movement will be allowed on that bridge. It will provide much ease to devotees and other people going to Vishnupad temple and adjoining areas,” the CM said.

Upcoming roads and bridges:

Ashok Rajpath elevated road

4 lanes from Kargil Chowk to NIT Mor

Project cost is Rs315 crore

DPR in 3 months

Bridge parallel to JP Setu

4 lanes from Digha to Naya Gaon

Status- DPR to be finalized soon

Laxman Jhula on Falgu river at Gaya

Vishnupad temple to Sita Kund

Project cost Rs60 crore

DPR made by Bihar Rajya Pul Nirman Nigam Limited.

Title: Coronavirus: No lockdown needed, says Gujarat Deputy chief minister
Content: GANDHINAGAR: The state government on Wednesday rejected the suggestion of the opposition Congress to place malls, cinema halls, and other places of public gatherings on lockdown to stop the spread of coronavirus The government said no positive case has been reported in the state so far. During the discussion on the measures taken by the state government, Congress MLA Naushad Solanki suggested that the government shut down public places for 25 days. Deputy chief minister and health minister Nitin Patel, said: “Even in China, only five to six worst affected cities have been sealed while life is going on normally in other parts.” He went on to say: “Thus, we don’t have to create panic here at this stage. We are taking all necessary steps to contain the spread of coronavirus.”Solanki also requested the government to start screening passengers at bus stations and railway stations. However, Patel said that at present screening of international passengers is being conducted at Ahmedabad and Surat airports in line with the Centre’s guidelines. “We are also screening foreigners staying at luxury hotels in the state,” he said.Patel said that all 56 samples tested so far have turned out negative. He said that as a precautionary measure, 576 isolation beds and 204 ventilators have been made available at government hospitals in the state. He also said that even those coming by boats are being scanned at ports. The government has scanned 2,300 people, mostly crew members, onboard 55 ships.Patel said that Gujaratis love to travel and are involved in businesses across the globe. “On any given day, if one travels to China one will find over 5,000 Gujarati travellers,” he said. The minister said that even if a person tests negative, his or her family is put under observation for 14 days.

Title: Varanasi: Six killed in accidents, one drowns in Ganga
Content:
Representative image

VARANASI: Six persons were killed in road accidents in Varanasi and adjoining districts while a 17-year-old boy was drowned in the Ganga in Varanasi during Holi celebrations on Tuesday and Wednesday.

On Wednesday, Sushila Devi (26) of Jathoda village was moweed down by a tanker near Bahera culvert under the limits of Lalganj police station. Police have seized the tanker and took the driver in custody before sending the body for postmortem. Sushila, along with two boys of her family, was going on a motorcycle to meet a relative when the incident occurred on Mirzapur-Halia road.

Earlier, on Tuesday night, a pickup van ran over six villagers, killing two of them when the villagers were celebrating Holi along the road in Chapail villager under the limits of Pannuganj police station in Sonbhadra district. The police rushed the injured to a local hospital where two of them, Govind (29) and Ramesh, were declared brought dead. The bodies were sent for postmortem on Wednesday.

Meanwhile in Jaunpur, Ramkumar (35) and his wife Manpati (32) of Majhgavakala village were run over by a bus near Nevada village on Jalalpur-Thanagaddi road while they were on way to Chanvari area from Jalalpur on Tuesday. Locals alerted the police who rushed the injured couple to the nearest hospital. They were referred to the district hopsital but succumbed on the way. The bodies were sent for postmortem.

In Varanasi, Rajnath Patel (70) of Bhattpurva village under Cholapur police station was hit by a motorcycle while crossing road. The motorcycle rider and his two companion fled the scene. Locals rushed Patel to a local hospital where doctors declared him brought dead.

Meanwhile, Aniket Rai (17), a student of class XI, was drowned in river Ganga while he was bathing with his friends near Tulsighat under the limits of Bhelupur police station in Varanasi on Tuesday afternoon.

As per the reports, after playing colours in morning, Aniket and his three friends had gone to Tulsighat for bathing. Aniket and his friend Shubham entered into deep water and started drowning. Their friends raised alarm following which the local divers rushed to save them. They managed to save Shubham but Aniket was drowned. Later, his body was fished out by the divers.

Aniket was only son of his parents, who dwell in Azamgarh. His father Sushil Rai, who is employed in some restaurant, had hired a room in Varanasi where Aniket used to stay for his studies.

Title: 3 tonne sea cucumbers seized in Nagapattinam
Content:
More than three tonne of semi-processed sea cucumbers, meant to be smuggled to South Asian countries, were seized by the Coastal Security Group (CSG) from a house at Keechankuppam in Nagapattinam on Tuesday evening. The seized sea cucumbers are worth more than Rs 1 crore, according to officials.

Acting on a tip off, a team from Coastal Security Group conducted a surprise check at the house of S Ramadoss, 37, of Keechankuppam. The team found 3,020kg of sea cucumbers in 56 boxes kept outside the house. The sea cucumbers were in a semi-processed stage. The seized sea cumbers have been handed over to the forest department.

Title: Social worker moves HC for sampling of road building material to test quality
Content:
Nagpur: A social worker has approached the Nagpur bench of Bombay high court with an intervention demanding sampling of road building material to test quality and removal of undulations and rough surfaces from the paver blocks laid adjacent to cement roads to make them less bumpy.

He also objected on position of the median on roads below Mankapur to Kasturchand Park flyover contending that those are very wide which is leading to severe congestion in traffic.

The application was filed in the suo Motu criminal PIL (No 838/2019) based on TOI report exposing dreadful conditions of city roads leading to several accidents and loss of lives till January 15. The HC had appointed Raheel Mirza as amicus curiae to plead the case.

After accepting intervener Mrunall Chakravorty’s prayers, the court had fixed the hearing on Wednesday, but it couldn’t reach till the judges were seated.

According to the intervener, potholes develop due to inappropriate quality and inadequate quality of bitumen in the bituminous mix. “I haven’t seen any road building agency sampling the bitumen mix and sending them for quality testing. Surprise sampling by reputed agencies would help.”

Pointing out towards apathy of Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC), Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT) and National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) officials while laying paver blocks adjacent to cement roads in the city, Chakravorty said undulations and rough surfaces makes riding on them bumpy and stressful. “The Central Road Research Institute (CRRI) in Delhi has facility for checking undulations and roughness of roads. Those can be removed by scraping the surface or laying a coat of bituminous mix,” he pointed out.

Expressing surprise over how only middle part of any road is concretized even as tar roads are excavated fully and then paver blocks are laid, he said when he approached the authorities for reason, he was told that utility lines like for power and telecommunications are laid latter. For maintenance of those lines and their repairs, it’s very easy to remove those blocks, he was told. “Instead of blocks, the entire portion should be re-laid with bitumen to prevent bumpy ride. At least the portion from where paver blocks are removed should be covered with the coat of bituminous mixture,” he said.

Quoting NHAI officials on median on roads below new flyovers at Sadar, Chakravorty said they gave a reason that a narrow single separator median would lead to damage to pillars by collision of vehicles.

“I told them about MahaMetro’s pillars, some of which are standing at the middle of roads, which are having a protective layer. Even metal guards surrounding those pillars would be enough for their protection. Simultaneously, it would provide more space for the traffic,” he said.

Title: Case against doctor over false info
Content:
Thrissur: Vadanappilli police have registered a case against Dr Shinu Shyamalan for allegedly spreading unsubstantiated Covid-19 alert about a patient who had returned from Qatar.

Dr Shyamalan had earlier complained that she was sacked from the private clinic at Thalikkulam for alerting the health officials about the patient who was having suspected symptoms of coronavirus alert. Thrissur district collector S Shanawaz and DMO Dr K J Reena had alleged that Dr Shyamalan had spread false information about the condition of the patient and had made defamatory statements against health officials. According to them, the patient, who had come to Kerala on January 31, had left country well after the quarantine period, and by spreading unsubstantiated information about him, Dr Shyamalan had created unnecessary panic among the public. Dr Shyamalan, who is also a human rights activist, had said the confusion could have been avoided if samples were collected from the patient and sent for Covid-19 tests.

1,040 under observation

The collector said in all, 1,040 people are under observation in Thrissur and out of them, 78 are under hospital surveillance while 962 are under home quarantine.

Cochin Devaswom Board (CDB) has decided to limit the festivities to rituals in the temples under the board.

Title: Youth held for raping, impregnating girl, 15
Content:
Trichy: The Trichy rural police on Tuesday arrested a 21-year-old man on charges of sexually assaulting a 15-year-old girl repeatedly and impregnating her.

The girl has been found to be three-and-a-half months pregnant.

The accused has been identified as A Bharathi from a village near Manapparai. Both of them were in a relationship. Bharathi promised the girl that he would marry her and used to have sex with her.

When her family members came to know about her pregnancy, she pointed fingers at Bharathi.

The all women police station, Manapparai booked the man under sections of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) Act.

He was arrested and produced in court, which remanded him in judicial custody on Wednesday.

The girl was admitted to the hospital for medical examination.

Police said that the medical termination of her pregnancy is yet to be decided.

Title: Custodial remand till Saturday for 3 held for murder
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A magisterial court in Pune cantonment has ordered the remand of three engineering students, arrested on charges of fatally pushing their 23-year-old roommate off the 11th floor of a Kondhwa building, in police custody till March 14.

Police told the court on Wednesday that they wanted to recover the motorcycle used by the arrested trio — Abhinav Jadhav (23), Akshay Gorde (22) and Tejas Gujar (19) — to bring the victim, Sagar Narsinh Chilevari, to the crime scene, and establish ownership of the bike apart from getting trio medically examined for their blood, nails and hair samples.

Sagar, who was living with the three suspects in an 11th floor flat at Kul Utsav society on Pisoli Road, near Khadi Machine chowk, had taken a Rs15,000 loan at 10% annual interest from Abhinav and was unable to repay him. Abhinav had been asking for his money back.

Late on Monday night, Abhinav, Akshay and Tejas drove triple-seat on a bike to Swargate, where they picked up Sagar. They brought him back to the society, where they assaulted him and eventually pushed him off the 11th floor, police said.

Seeking a five-day custodial remand for the three students, investigating officer Mahadeo Kumbhar told the court that the police wanted to establish the spot in Swargate where Sagar was picked up from, apart from establishing the source of money loaned to him. The police also want to investigate the possible involvement of any other person in the crime and secure details of cell numbers and call data records. The police were also probing if Abhinav had given money on interest to anyone else.

Title: COVID-19: China slowdown set to shake Indian market sectors
Content: AHMEDABAD: The ripples of the coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak across certain countries are likely to hurt various manufacturing and market sectors in India, where imports from China stand at US $70 billion.China and some countries in South-East Asia have been the worst affected by the disease accounting for approximately 90% of the cases reported so far.A March report by rating agency ICRA titled ‘Ripple effect of COVID outbreak to impact India Inc',’ says sectors like automotive, pharmaceuticals and others stand to lose, while those like steel and oil and gas stand to gain from the coronavirus outbreak fallout.Given that China’s share of global GDP standing at 17% is substantial, a cascading effect of China’s slowdown on the global economy is inevitable as China and South-East Asia are key suppliers and consumers of certain products, the report said.Supply disruptions of key raw materials in pharmaceuticals, electronics and renewable energy sectors will affect production in India if the situation persists, the ICRA report states. These sectors have a direct or indirect import dependence on affected markets for components or sub-components.COVID-19 could cause demand disruption and price corrections in sectors like cut and polished diamonds, cotton yarn (textiles) and seafoods where the affected markets are large importers from India. There will also be effects on commodities like oil and gas, metals, among others, according to ICRA.In the current scenario, where dropping and lengthening of payment cycles is expected, an entity’s liquidity position is of paramount importance to support its credit profile.“ICRA expects entities with weak liquidity buffer relative to its upcoming debt service obligations to report significant weakening of their credit profile over the next couple of quarters,” the report stated.AutomotiveChina supplies 27% of India’s auto components, valued at US$ 4.5 billion. Critical items like safety components, fuel injection pumps, EGR modules, electronic components, turbochargers etc, are sourced from countries currently affected by coronavirus. Currently, companies have overall inventory for a few weeks, but lack of a single critical component can affect productionPharmaceuticalsImport dependence is high at 60% for API requirement, of which China accounts for 65-70%. For some intermediates and key starting materials (KSMs), China is the sole supplier. Domestic API manufacturers have supplies till mid-March, beyond which production and prices including that of raw materials will be affected if the situation continues.Solar energyIndia imports approximately 70% of its requirement of photovoltaic (PV) modules from China, which controls about 80% of the global supply of solar panels. Shifting to other suppliers is currently next to impossible. Thus, execution timelines for ongoing solar projects are likely to be affected and costs of PV modules expected to go up.Gems & jewelleryWhile China buys around 14% of polished diamonds from India, a larger proportion of exports from India (35%) are routed via Hong Kong. The problem was compounded as the shutdown occurred during the peak sales period in China. Increased inventory levels and supply glut may lead to price corrections as well.TextilesOf the cotton yarn produced in India, 30% is exported, and one-third of that goes to China. With China locked down, yarn realizations have corrected 2-3% since beginning of February. Domestic spinners may lose their competitive edge in the global market if the situation persists. In the long term, sectors like apparels can benefit.SteelBenefiting from the situation, domestic steelmakers have effected two price hikes since February, given the likely decline in steel imports to India in Q1 FY2021. Indian mills have the opportunity to increase market share in exports to key markets as well, given the restrictions in trade flows from Korea, China and Japan.Oil & gasWith the demand for oil and petroleum products waning in the wake of the COVID outbreak in China, international crude oil prices have dropped. Distressed cargoes are being offered to large consumers such as India, with refining companies in China unable to deliver. Profitability of upstream companies is likely to be affected.

Title: Matrimony fraud: Four arrested
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: A four-member gang, which was duping people on matrimony portals, was busted on Wednesday. A Nigerian national and three nationals from Nepal formed part of the gang, police said.

The accused were identified as Giddy Isaac Olu (36) from Lagos, Nigeria, Sagar Sharma (24), Sudeep Giri (26) and Bikas Balmiki (25), all from Banke in Nepal. Another accused Eselu Udo of Nigeria is at large. Apart from recovering nine ID proofs, 25 SIM cards and 15 debit cards, cybercrime police also froze Rs 3 lakh in their bank accounts.

A doctor from Nallagandla created a profile on BharatMatrimony in search of an alliance. She was contacted by Vipul Prakash who claimed to be an UK-based orthopaedic surgeon. After a few days, he promised to visit India and marry her.

After a few days, he told her that he was sending gold jewellery, an iPhone, a wristwatch and some dollars through courier. The victim then received a call from a person claiming to be from the customs department who asked her to pay customs and GST for the gifts sent by ‘Dr Prakash’. The doctor deposited Rs 7,45,500 into the accounts provided by the fraudsters. Soon after, Giddy Olu went with a locker and convinced her that there was currency and gifts in the locker. She paid Rs 5 lakh to get the password.

She realised she was conned after losing Rs 12.45 lakh and approached cops in February.

Title: 57-year-old booked under Pocso Act for molesting minor
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Saidabad police arrested a 57-year-old man on Wednesday for molesting a seven-year-old girl. The accused is a resident of Singareni Colony in Saroornagar.

Police said that the victim lives with her grandmother in the same locality and the accused was known to the family.

The accused lured the victim to his house at around 7 am on Tuesday and molested her. “The accused tried to touch the victim inappropriately, but the girl panicked and managed to escape. She later disclosed the incident to her parents,” said Saidabad inspector K Srinivas .

The victim’s parents, who are daily wage labourers, approached the police on Wednesday and based on their complaint a case was registered. The accused has been booked Under Pocso Act for sexual harassment , kidnapping and other relevant sections.

Meanwhile, a court on Wednesday sentenced an offender to three years of imprisonment and a fine of Rs 1,000 in a Pocso case in Vikarabad district . The accused is a resident of Rompally village in Bantwaram. He was convicted under sexual harassment and other relevant section of the Pocso Act.

Title: PIL against ‘repulsive’ corona caller tune
Content: Chennai: Claiming that the pre-recorded coronavirus awareness audio message broadcast by phone operators during every call has become a ‘ nuisance and is creating mental agony ’ to callers, a lawyer has approached the Madras high court , seeking to restrain the Centre from playing the audio.Moving the plea as a PIL , advocate Siva Raajashekaran said such a voice message is repulsive and particularly the coughing sound makes a healthy person sick.The authorities can restrict it to some genuinely soothing words instead of coughing and they can also create awareness through other means such as text messages and social media posts and in cinema halls, the petitioner said.Though it is essential to create awareness on the spread of the virus, he said repeatedly listening to the pre-recorded message which starts with the cough is causing mental stress to mobile phone users. He added that such voice messages are in contrary to the principle of right to live peacefully as enshrined in the Constitution.As an interim relief, the petitioner wanted the court to pass an injunction against the Union health ministry from playing the audio pending disposal of the plea.The PIL, filed on Wednesday, is likely to be taken up for hearing on Thursday.

Title: Electronics trader dies after ‘drunk’ neighbour punches him
Content:
Adi Pathak

Vadodara: An electronic appliances trader from Jarod village in Waghodiya taluka was beaten to death by his allegedly drunk neighbour on Tuesday night over some unknown reasons.

Adi Pathak came in an inebriated state outside 47-year-old Vijay Rana’s house around 10 pm on Tuesday and started abusing him and his younger brother Rajesh. On hearing Pathak shout, the two brothers came out of their house. Seeing the duo, Pathak damaged the plants outside the house. Rajesh told police that when they asked Pathak to behave, he continued abusing them.

Police said that the two brothers had arguments with Pathak and they shoved him away. As Vijay held Pathak’s hand, he punched him several times on his chest due to which Vijay let him loose and complained of severe pain.

Rajesh took his brother to a doctor in their village. But even after taking medicine when his pain did not subside, Vijay was taken to a nursing home at Ajwa Road in Vadodara. The doctor told Rajesh, that his brother’s health was critical and suggested him to take him to a cardiac hospital. The family members rushed him to a private cardiac hospital in Warasia. The doctors there declared him dead on admission. Rajesh then informed Waghodiya police about the incident and a murder case was registered against Pathak in the wee hours of Wednesday.

Cops went to arrest Pathak at his home in the middle of the night, but he had fled by then. “We have lodged murder case based on the preliminary reports and are searching for the accused. The exact reason for his death will be known once the post-mortem report will arrive,” said a police official. He added that Pathak manages his father’s medical clinic at Jarod.

Title: Rly launches helpline, awareness campaign
Content:
Prayagraj: Indian Railways has geared up to take comprehensive measures to prevent coronavirus (Covid-19) infection.

Chief public relations officer (CPRO), North Central Railways (NCR), Ajeet Kumar Singh said minister of railways Piyush Goyal has directed the Railway Board to ensure adequate measures to spread awareness and inform people about preventive steps.

Railway Board chairman Vinod Kumar Yadav held a meeting with general managers last week to review preparedness and convey priorities and directions.

The CPRO said general manager Rajiv Chaudhry had asked heads of all the three divisions and units to make necessary arrangements to deal with the situation. “The situation is being constantly monitored and coordinated at all levels and control rooms have been set up all over the railway system. Staff members have been sensitized and coordination with health authorities is also being ensured,” Singh said. The official said people were being made aware through means of information, education, and communication (IEC) material (posters and pamphlets) regarding coronavirus and also being displayed for general public in local language at railway stations and in trains.

He said the material was also being distributed to patients visiting hospitals and in railway colonies. Control rooms and telephone helplines have also been set up at all railway hospitals, the CPRO added.

Title: NMC seizes properties over unpaid tax
Content:
Nagpur: Ashi Nagar zone of the cash-strapped NMC on Monday seized godowns of five domestic cylinder gas agencies in Sahare Layout for defaulting on property tax to the tune of Rs7,41,300 since last many years. Apart from this, the zone has also seized movable properties like television sets, sofa sets, two-wheelers, refrigerators, ceiling fans etc of five other property tax owners in default, who had together not paid tax to the tune of over Rs1.41 lakh.

All the five godowns were owned by one Sangita Gopichand Sahare, stated a press note issued by zone assistant municipal commissioner Ganesh Rathore.

“If these defaulters fail to clear their property tax dues within 15 days, NMC will auction the properties,” he warned.

Title: Centac: Last date for applications today
Content: Puducherry: The Centralized admission committee has extended the last date for online submission of applications for admission into postgraduate medical and dental courses under government, all India (management) quotas to March 12 . Candidates can visit the committee’s website www.centacpuducherry.in for more details. TNN

Title: From a humble beginning to hardcore Hindutva ride
Content:
Hyderabad: Fortyeight-year-old Bandi Sanjay Kumar was in-charge of vehicles during the rath yatra undertaken by veteran BJP leader LK Advani when it passed through the undivided Andhra Pradesh in 1990. Thirty years later, Lady Luck smiled on Sanjay who became the Telangana state party president.

Born in a humble agricultural family in Karimnagar, Sanjay was inspired by RSS leaders before he plunged into public service. A strong Hindutva votary, Sanjay nurtured himself from the grassroots before becoming an MP for the first time when he won the Karimnagar seat in 2019 general elections.

“Though Sanjay’s simplicity was much appreciated, his ability to strike a chord with lowest rung workers and build a rapport with seniors and new leaders has always come in handy,” a senior leader from Karimnagar said.

In 2014 assembly elections, he contested from Kariamnagar but lost to TRS candidate. He contested in December 2018 but lost again to TRS candiate. “Unfazed by the defeat, he entered the fray from the Lok Sabha in 2019 and defeated the sitting MP,” a party leader said.

Sanjay served as Karimnagar convenor of ABVP, town president and vice-president of ABVP state unit. He was elected as a corporator (for three times) in Karimnagar.

His growth in the saffron party was gradual. Before winning the Karimnagar Lok Sabha seat with a margin of 96,000 votes against TRS sitting MP B Vinod Kumar, Sanjay was drafted by the party leadership to look after the party affairs in Tamil Nadu and Kerala. In his election affidavit, Sanjay had declared Rs 22.7 lakh assets and Rs 13.41 lakh liabilities. He had six criminal cases filed against him but had not been convicted in any case.

Sanjay’s appointment looked inevitable with outgoing chief K Laxman sharing with party seniors that he would be happy to serve in any position. There is a strong speculation that Laxman could be offered a Rajay Sabha seat from Madhya Pradesh or Karnataka.

Sanjay also worked as director of Karimnagar Cooperative Urban Bank for two terms. His wife Bandi Aparna works in SBI and the couple has two sons.

Title: Another isolation ward gets ready at MGMGH
Content:
Trichy: An additional isolation ward is being set up at Mahatma Gandhi memorial government hospital (MGMGH) in Trichy to meet any Covid-19 exigency. “We have identified a ward near the existing isolation ward for this. As the funds have been sanctioned, the work is in progress. It will be ready in a few days,” said the dean, Dr K Vanitha on Wednesday.

The new isolation ward will have two floors and will be equipped with the necessary equipment besides a reception, an ante-room for the sterilisation of doctors and air-conditioned room for the patients. The ward can handle 12 patients like the existing ward, thus facilitating treatment of 24 patients at a time. “In case of necessity, one more ward also can be set up,” said the dean. As of Wednesday, the hospital has seen nine foreign returnees admitted with symptoms of the virus though none of them tested positive. A 35-year-old man now under treatment also is recovering from the fever, said the dean.

Stating that the test results of suspected patients can be obtained in 12 hours from Kings Institute in Chennai, the dean said that one more testing facility is coming up in the government medical college in Theni. “None of the private labs in the city is authorised to take up the test to confirm Covid-19,” she said. A public health department official said that about 35,000 passengers were screened in the Trichy airport till Monday. Of them, about 1,200 passengers had symptoms such as fever and cough. Since they were residents of other districts, the public health department of the respective districts were intimated about their arrival for the necessary follow-up for quarantining. In Trichy district, public health department officials have been monitoring 56 passengers as of Tuesday. Several passengers who were home-quarantined have recovered.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Man dies of poisonous herbs, one detained
Content:
Representative image

KANPUR: A 52-year-old man died while five others fell ill after consuming poisonous herbs purchased from a man in Saandh area of Ghatampur on Wednesday.

The police identified the deceased as Sharan Singh of Chirli village of Ghatampur. He became critically ill on Wednesday after consuming herbs purchased from a man identified as Baba Manoj Kumar. He died on way to hospital,” said SP West Anil Kumar. The SP said, “Five others who fell ill had also consumed herbs after purchasing from Manoj Kumar. They are undergoing treatment at separate hospitals. We have detained Manoj and his attendant Jai Prakash and are questioning them. Investigations are continuing.”

Title: Metro and rlys launch awareness campaigns
Content: Chennai: Metro rail and Southern Railway ’s Chennai division have kicked off awareness campaigns on precautions to be taken against novel coronavirus ( Covid-19 ) at its facilities.Metro rail authorities have begun sending text messages to people on the precautions. The messages dwell on the need to cover the face while sneezing, the need to frequently wash hands with soap and the need for people to maintain at least one metre distance from another person.A metro rail official said bulk text messages are being sent. “There is also a plan to undertake disinfection exercise at stations before train services start in the morning and after the services end on two days.”Notices have been put up near ticket counters of metro rail stations cautioning commuters about the virus. Staff at work have been advised to wear masks at the counters.“The Airport station receives people who arrive on flights from abroad, while Central metro receives people from across the country. So, the awareness programme and move to disinfect stations are crucial,” he added.Southern Railway also kicked off Covid-19 awareness campaigns at Central and Egmore railway stations on Wednesday. An exhibition has been organised at the concourse area of the stations explaining about coronavirus, precautions, tips for behaviour in public and others.P Mahesh, divisional railway manager, Chennai, distributed pamphlets to passengers and said, “We do not have instructions to begin screening passengers similar to the airport. St John Ambulance has set up a desk at Central so that people who have fever can get themselves checked. Help desks have been provided at major railway stations. Announcements will be made in the public address system.” He said all coaches and railway premises are being sanitised by housekeeping staff. Central railway station and the suburban station together handle around three lakh passengers a day.

Title: Officials to help Nendran farmers beat price fall
Content:
Trichy: Agriculture marketing officials have assured Nendran banana growers in the district that steps will be taken to create avenues to sell their produce at a reasonable price. This follows a report carried in TOI on Wednesday highlighting the farmers’ worries due to a sharp decline in price.

The report had also pointed out that facilities established by the government to help banana farmers by spending crores of rupees were idling for years. Following the report, the officials visited the primary processing centres established for the benefit of banana as well as onion farmers including in Mannachanallur on Wednesday. They elaborated the steps taken by the department to maximise the selling price of banana by linking them to proper channels.

Deputy director of agriculture marketing, Trichy, Murugan told reporters that two weeks ago Nendran was sold at Rs 33 a kg. However, the price had now slumped to a range of Rs 10 to Rs 13.

“To help farmers mitigate this situation, we have identified seven Uzhavar Santhai in the district and allotted separate shops for them to sell Nendran. Interested farmers can approach the concerned administrative officers in Uzhavar Santhai and enrol themselves”, he said.

Moreover, all efforts have been taken to operate all the primary processing centres at the earliest, he further said. “We have also planned to impart training to produce value-added products from their produce to maximise their profit”, Murugan added.

Title: Man arrested for his role in hostile takeover of city firm
Content:
Pavan Rathi

Vadodara: Five months after the chairman of Manpasand Beverages Ltd (MBL) Dhirendra Singh had alleged hostile takeover of his company by Bharat Patel of Mumbai-based Finquest Financial Solutions Pvt Ltd’s (FFSPL) and his associates, Vadodara rural police arrested the first accused on Tuesday.

Pavan Rathi, one of the associates of Patel as alleged by Singh, was nabbed by the local crime branch from his home in Gorwa. Rathi was absconding since Singh had lodged the complaint at Bhadarva police station on September 27 last year. LCB sleuths reached his home on Tuesday to arrest him on receiving information a few days back about his whereabouts.

Police said that Rathi and three other associates of Patel – Vishal Zariwala, Parashiva Murthy B S and Hardik Patel – arrived at MBL’s office in the first week of July last year to take possession of all its property and bank documents and papers of the company. They told the account executive that they have taken over the company and will be handling all operations.
