Rathi was made a signing authority along with Murthy and Zariwala of a new bank account of MBL. On July 23, the trio had transferred Rs 2.4 crore from MBL’s bank account to the new account. A day later Rs 2 crore from the new account was transferred to FFSPL’s account.

The trio has also been accused of transferring Rs 52.5 lakh from MBL’s bank account to the new account between July and August.

“The accused is being interrogated about more wrongdoings of his and others while they had taken over the control. Our teams are also trying to track down other accused,” said inspector D B Vala of LCB.

Last year, Singh was promised a loan of Rs 100 crore by FFSPL’s Patel and Ajay Agrawal as he had to pay Rs 17.77 crore to Central GST (CGST) department for bailing out his two sons and chief financial officer. Singh was asked to mortgage his personal holding of 44.32% in MBL and he was made to sign on a business agreement. Singh had claimed in his complaint that when he had signed the agreements, he was not mentally and physically fit, but as a former director of MBL Vishal Sood had assured him that he had seen all papers, he signed them, but later realized that he had been cheated.

Title: High on Holi, 1,026 motorists booked for drunk driving
Content:
Nagpur: Mixing celebrations with driving proved costly for 1,026 drivers in the state’s second capital, who were booked by traffic police on March 9 (Holi eve) and March 10 for driving under the influence of alcohol. City traffic police also booked 2,561 people for rash and negligent driving during the same period.

The number of cases was the highest in last three years. Police had caught 897 motorists in 2018 and 858 in 2019 for drunk driving, statistics revealed.

“For the last couple of years, our efforts have been concentrated on preventing accidents,” a senior official from the office of deputy commissioner of police (traffic) told TOI. The drive had a positive impact this year too, as the city did not report even a single fatal accident on Tuesday, said a cop from the police information centre. However, one Vikas Bagde, 47, died due to head injuries after his moped dashed against a road divider on Manewada Cement road on Monday night.

Armed with breathalysers, around 500 traffic police personnel from all 10 zones were out for crackdown on traffic offenders on both days for over five hours and stood at major intersections, taking motorists by surprise. The campaign reached its peak between 2pm and 4pm, and ended at around 9pm.

Along with booking the offenders, the police also detained their vehicles. A majority of those charged were in the age group of 20-50 and most were two-wheeler riders.

Among the 10 zones, the highest numbers of drivers were caught under the jurisdiction of Kamptee traffic zone with 150 cases, followed by Cotton Market with 144 cases, Sitabuldi with 116 and Lakadganj zone 111, respectively.

Besides this, the police also penalized 2,561 motorists — both two and four-wheeler riders/drivers for indulging in rash and negligent driving on both the days. 633 persons were booked for riding two-wheelers without helmets, while 555 motorists were caught after they were found riding their vehicles with two pillion riders.

Title: Job uncertainty looms for NRKs as Qatar and Kuwait ban entry
Content:
Kozhikode: Abdul Rahoof, who has been working as driver in Qatar for the past six years, was to fly back from Karipur airport to Doha on Wednesday morning, after his leave. But Rahoof is now stuck in his house at Vengara in Malappuram, following the sudden ban imposed by Qatar on March 8 on entry to all travellers from India and 13 other countries as part of Covid-19 precautions.

Worse still, Rahoof’s Qatar residency permit (work visa) is set to expire on March 14, making his return trip and even continuation of his job in the Gulf country all the more uncertain.

“I am now literally locked up here. I was planning to renew the residency permit soon after reaching Qatar and now there is no chance for me reaching Qatar before it expires on March 14. Some say that the expired visa can be renewed within a month of expiry if the sponsor approaches the passport office and submits an application. But with the indefinite travel ban in place, everything is uncertain,” he added.

Rahoof is not alone in facing such a predicament. The ban imposed by Qatar and Kuwait on entry of passengers from India has affected many expats who have come home on leave.

Also, non-resident Keralites (NRKs), who came home on long leaves, are concerned over the delay of their trip back to their place of work as Qatar visa rules say that foreigners holding Qatar residency permits are not permitted to be outside Qatar for a continuous period exceeding six months. “The travel restriction, which came all of a sudden, has left many stranded in Kerala. We now hope that the government authorities as well as employers would take a lenient view to enable the return of the people and safeguard their jobs,” said SAM Basheer, president of Qatar Kerala Muslim Cultural Centre.

Also, expats are worried if the travel disruptions to Gulf following Covid- 19 scare would affect their NRI status as the central government had, in this year’s budget, reduced the period of stay in India to 120 days from 182 days earlier to be categorized as non-resident Indians.

Title: Nine wanted criminals nabbed in 24 hours
Content:
Representative image

PRAYAGRAJ: Nine men wanted for crimes ranging from cheating and fraud to illegal possession of arms and rape were arrested in Georgtown, Kareli and Naini on Wednesday.

Inspector (Georgetown) Pradeep Kumar told reporters they nabbed five with three countrymade pistols and live cartridges. The quintet have been identified as Ashutosh Srivastava of Sohbatiyabagh, Kapil Dubey of Old Allahapur, Abhishek Yadav and Anishek Yadav of Tularambagh and Himanshu Sonkar of Georgetown. Kareli police, on the other hand, rounded up local resident Md Guas for cases registered against him under Sections 420 (cheating), 494 (fraud in marriage), 342 (wrongful confinement), and 376 (rape) of the IPC.

One Md Aman Khan, a resident of GTB Nagar , was also nabbed by Kareli police from Siddi trisection for rape, voluntarily causing hurt, poisoning, insult to provoke breach of peace, criminal intimidation and trespassing. Naini cops arrested two others — identified as Arvind Yadav and Amarnath Goswami, residents of Kaudhiyara and ADA Colony — who were wanted for causing hurt using weapons, breach of peace and criminal intimidation.

Title: Law varsity makes films on legal rights
Content:
TRICHY: The Legal Aid Committee (LAC) of Tamil Nadu National Law University launched legal awareness short films on Wednesday with a view to disseminating awareness and sensitizing citizens on basic legal rights and duties.

Five short films were made as a maiden project under Tamil Nadu Innovation Initiatives (TANII).

The TANII is a state government initiative to promote an innovative environment and a drive towards ‘Vision Tamil Nadu 2023’.

The vision of Tamil Nadu 2023 is to make Tamil Nadu an innovation hub in the country by encouraging a culture of innovation in government and government agencies by 2023. Short films directed by various private agencies with the title ‘Awareness against Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace’, ‘Cybercrimes’, ‘Maintenance and Welfare of Senior Citizens ’, ‘Right to Information Act’ and ‘Rights of Arrested Person’ were released by district revenue officer T Shanthi.

Vice-chancellor of Tamil Nadu National Law University V S Elizabeth spoke at the event held in this connection.

Title: Hindu Munnani leader, 2 aides torch own two-wheeler, file plaint, arrested
Content:
Trichy: A Hindu Munnani leader and two others were arrested as they tried to fool the police by torching a two-wheeler and then filing a complaint seeking a probe into the incident at Adhavathur here on Wednesday.

Police said the trio enacted the drama at the behest of the Hindu Munnani leader who had twin motives — avoid repaying his vehicle loan and also earn more prominence in the organization.

Somarasampettai police arrested M Sakthivel, 32, Manikandan union secretary of Hindu Munnani, his nephew Mukesh, 24, and their friend N Sakthivel. Sakthivel had lodged a complaint with the police in the morning that his moped parked in front of his house was set afire by unknown men around 2 am. He also alleged the involvement of other communities in the incident. Police said Sakthivel aimed at earning more prominence in his outfit by staging the drama. The arrest came after the police verified the CCTV footage that showed Mukesh and friend Sakthivel buying petrol in a bottle from a nearby bunk.

When the police grew suspicious and questioned them, it turned out that the two had themselves torched the two-wheeler. Sakthivel had stated in his complaint that the incident happened when he was sleeping inside his house. Police said that his wife and two children were at their relative’s house at the time of the incident. He had said that he found his moped burnt as he went to check after hearing the noise of window cracking from outside his house at Siva Nagar in Adhavathur.

Title: Ganga Mela to mark end of festivities
Content:
Kanpur: The Holi festivity of the city will conclude in 'Anuradha Nakshatra' with Ganga Mela to be held on March 15.

The function, to commence after paying floral tributes to the revolutionaries, will conclude on March 15 evening with Ganga Mela to be held on the bank of the river (Ganga) and a Bal Mela at Rajjan Babu Park. According to Kanpur Hatia Holi Mahotsava committee in between the two events, the unique 'Rangon ka Thela' will roam in the traditional routes of the city,

Patron of the committee, Moolchand Seth and conveners Gyanendra Bishnoi and Vijay Singh said that on March 15, DM Brahmadeo Ram Tiwari, SSP Anant Dev and other celebrities of the city would garland the stone on which are inscribed names of the freedom fighters, and then hoist the national flag at Rajjan Babu Park.

The 'Rango ka Thela' procession, after passing through Nayaganj, Kahu Kothi, Birhana Road and Hatia, would reach Rajjan Babu Park, they said.

Briefing about the history of the Ganga Mela in 'Anuradha Nakshatra', Bishnoi said that in 1942 the British collector of the city had imposed restrictions on palying Holi, but a group of youths, belonging to Hatia locality, decided to break the restriction and play Holi. They, under the leadership of Babu Gulab Chandra Seth, first hoisted the tricolour and then played Holi.

“The police arrested the youths. The action led to fury and the entire city, as a mark of protest, decided to play Holi daily until the arrested youths were set free. The British government ultimately bowed to their demand and released the youths. Since they were released in 'Anuradha Nakshtra', the youths again played Holi which later on became a tradition”, Bishnoi said.

The members of the committee complained that though Ganga Mela had a historical significance, but still there were some problems. Rajjan Babu Park has been encroached by the people and Kesco had installed its transformer inside the park. KMC authorities had neither repaired the routes of 'Rangon ka Thela nor done any fogging in the open drains.

Meanwhile, DM Brahmadeo Ram Tiwari on Wednesday inspected the lanes of Hatia, Generalganj area and Rajjan Babu Park. He directed the Kesco officials to tie the electric wires hanging on roads and remove transformer from the park. He also asked them to install swings in the park for children on the occasion of Bal Mela.

The DM also visited the inscription stone and asked about the history of the mela from Hatia Holi Mahotsava committee and the locals. He said Kanpur would continue live with its old and historical custom of Ganga Mela.

Title: Coronavirus in Kochi: Business at Broadway, Ernakulam Market affected
Content:
Many of the shops reported only 50% of usual sales on Wednesday

KOCHI: The Covid-19 fear among the public is taking its toll on the city’s commercial sector too, as Broadway and Ernakulam Market, which are the prime commercial hubs, are witnessing a huge drop in sales. Merchants and traders said that people are unwilling to come to public places and the sales of goods have dropped to nearly half of the usual sales. Many of the shops that sell stationery goods, grocery, vegetables, bakery items, fish and meat, spices, textiles, etc. reported only 50% of usual sales on Wednesday. Shopkeepers said that the situation was worse on Sunday which usually witnesses brisk sales.

“The sales are too dim and the vegetables are decaying due to low demand. We are now selling most items at half the price to clear the stock but still there are not enough customers. No new stocks are being taken as we will have shut down if the situation worsens,” said Ramesh Kumar, a veggie-seller.

As the businesses in restaurant and catering sector too are witnessing a dip due to cancellation of public functions, the number of bulk orders to purchase confectionaries, vegetables, fish and meat has reduced.

“Celebration at weddings, housewarmings and other functions are either scaled down or cancelled and these lead to decline in bulk orders. Usually, we have a sale up to four boxes of samosas in the morning itself but today not even one box was sold. The sale of chips too has declined and we have reduced the production,” said Pratheesh Vakayal, who works with a bake house.

“There were only two customers since morning and there was no wholesale purchase today. Broadway street and footpaths were less crowded even during peak hours,” said Zulfikar Ali, a wholesale textile dealer in Cloth Bazaar.

Title: Chennai Coronavirus: Tamil Nadu students take Italian university classes online
Content: CHENNAI: Last Saturday, before Italy’s government imposed a nationwide lockdown to control the spread of Covid-19, Tamiloli flew from Milan to Chennai. But that hasn’t prevented him from attending his classes.From 1pm to 9pm daily, the masters student of mechanical engineering at Politecnico di Milano, is glued to his computer at his Vepery home, attending online classes conducted by his professors in Milan.“Our classes were to begin on March 3 after the vacation, but due to the Covid-19 outbreak, particularly severe in the Lombardy region, the university decided to postpone the classes for a week as a precautionary measure,” says Tamiloli.“A few days later, we were informed online classes will be held in a bid to control the situation. So I decided to return to Chennai.”Many Indian engineering aspirants are drawn to universities in Italy where the courses are good, affordable and they can hope to find good jobs in Schengen countries.But, with 60 million people on lockdown in Italy, and a death toll of 168, many foreign students have returned home.And Italian universities are ensuring they do not miss out on academics.Tamiloli is one of many students from Tamil Nadu continuing their studies in virtual classrooms.R Aravindh, who is also pursuing his masters in management engineering at Politecnico di Milano, returned to Trichy on February 21 and attended his first online lecture on March 3. “It’s a live lecture and we can ask questions just as in a real classroom. It’s just that I am logging on from Trichy while my classmates are logging on from Iran, Spain, Germany, Poland and Pakistan,” says the 24-year-old.“The university has said it will offer online classes till April 8 and then make a decision based on how the situation is.”He chose an Italian university for his masters’ as it is affordable and English is the medium of instruction. “It is also close to Germany, which is the prime market for mechanical engineering and I did my UG in the same.”Arul Jebakumar, 24, also returned to Chennai on February 29. “I was in Puglia in the southern part of Italy, but I got to know that Covid-19 is spreading across the country so I decided to return. Yesterday, I was told that 30 people were infected in Lecce, the town I live in,” he says.On March 3, at 1:30pm, he began online classes from his home in Purusawalkam. “We use Microsoft Teams and our professor sends us notes as PDF files and also voice notes highlighting the important points ...”

Title: Nagpur’s RTE seats oversubscribed by 457%
Content:
Nagpur: Applications for RTE admission in Nagpur reached a record-breaking mark with available seats for 2020-21 academic session getting oversubscribed by 457%. The deadline ended for this session on ????. The education department’s online portal has received 31,043 applications for 6,785 seats.

The education department is expected to announce dates for the online lottery soon after which the admission process will start. The RTE admission process is completely online to ensure transparency in the process. The software is operated from Pune but the initial set-up is done locally.

The lottery software uses a unique algorithm logic which gets its initial starting grid by numbers randomly chosen by students at a public event organized by the Nagpur education department. The number grids are filled by students using chits put in four separate bowls.

Students are then called to pick up chits one at a time and the digit is entered into the grid. Before entering into the grid the number is verified by education officials and parents so that there is no dispute later. Once the grid is complete it is displayed on a large screen and parents were asked to click a picture, if they needed, of the screen.

These grid numbers will be then fed into the lottery software by officials at Pune and that will decide the fate of applicants.

RTE activist Shahid Sharif said once the results are announced, parents must approach authorities if they notice any irregularities. “I am part of the RTE verification committee and if at all any kind of fraud is noticed regarding admissions, parents much approach this forum. Sometimes admissions are taken using fake documents and such activities must be reported,” said Sharif.

The biggest challenge for RTE admissions will be the boycott by many private schools for non-payment of RTE dues. Independent English Schools Association (IESA) has declared that over 20,000 seats will remain out of RTE admission ambit this session.

Title: No plan to shut Yavatmal schools: Dist edu officer
Content:
Yavatmal: District Education Officer Vikas Chavne on Wednesday categorically denied rumours that school authorities are asking for parents’ consent to declare holidays in schools in view of the threat from coronavirus.

“I have not issued any circular to educational institutions under me so far to declare holidays in the district,” Chavne said, adding he has not received any such instructions from the state government.

However, he confirmed having postponed the training programme for 300 selected Teacher Brigade, set up by district collector M Devendra Singh to improve the standard of ZP run schools, scheduled on Thursday (March 12) in the local Bachat Bhavan. “Besides, the education department has cancelled its Shikshan Utsav and Skill Development programmes scheduled this month,” Chavne said.

No such notification has been received from the CBSE board too, said principal of Yavatmal Public School (YPS) Jacob Das, adding he hasn’t sent any SMS to parents in this connection.

Jawaharlal Darda English Medium High School and Junior College principal Mini Thomas John too said they haven’t issued any message to parents. Principals of School of Scholars (SoS) and St Aloysius English Medium Schools too refuted the rumours.

Meanwhile, medical student Snehal Chatki, who had returned from Wuhan in China, is also keeping fine in her village in Mategaon tehsil of Yavatmal district.

Yavatmal GMC dean Dr Milind Kamble has urged people not to panic as there is no case of coronavirus reported so far in the district.

Title: Mother and son killed, nine injured in clash in Unnao
Content:
Representative image

KANPUR: A woman and her son were killed while nine others injured in a clash during ‘Holika Dahan’ rituals between two families at Sukh Lal Kheda in Gangaghat police station area of Unnao district on Monday.

According to ASP Vinod Kumar Pandey, the incident took place on Monday night when the two families were performing the ‘Holika Dahan’, a ritual associated with the festival.

An argument broke out between the two families over some old issue, leading to the clash, he added.

“Both the groups attacked each other with sticks. Later, one group allegedly resorted to firing resulting in injuries to a woman identified as Gomti and her son Arvind”, he said.

The police official said both the injured died in the hospital.

“The deceased belonged to one of the two families. Six people from one side, and three from the other group sustained wounds. They are undergoing treatment at Lala Lajpat Rai hospital,” he said.

Both the sides have registered complaints against each other and the investigation is on, the police official said further and added, “Police and PAC personnel have been deployed in the area to ward of any kind of backlash.”

Title: Coronavirus scare: Medical tourist arrivals to Kochi drop by almost 75 %
Content: KOCHI: Coronavirus has hit medical tourism to the city, with most of the hospitals reporting 75-80% drop in arrival of foreign patients. Most of the hospitals said advance bookings have stopped as uncertainty looms over the spread of Covid-19 globally and even those who are in Kochi now for treatment are leaving mid-way. The patients made the decision after their embassies directed them to return home, said hospital managements.“We have not received any new patient in the past 15 days. Already, medical tourism to the city has dropped by 80%. Since Monday, after more Covid-19 cases were detected in Kerala, even those who are here are anxious,” said Dr Sunny Orathel, medical superintendent, Rajagiri Hospital.Most of the hospitals receive most of their foreign patients from Gulf countries, especially Dubai and Oman. They also have few patients from South East Asia, Africa and Europe. Also, persons of Indian origins (PIOs) plan treatment when they come for holidays during the months of July to September. But this season, even advance bookings from PIOs have dipped.“It seems everyone has adopted a wait and watch approach. Foreigners are reluctant to come to our hospitals in the prevailing situation,” said VPS Lakeshore CEO SK Abdulla.Since Monday, there has been a drop even in the number of patients who come for executive medical check-up offered by major hospitals. From an average 10 foreigners and 20-25 locals undergoing the medical check-up on a normal day, the numbers have dipped to 1-2 foreigners and 2- 3 locals this week.This is critical as medical tourism accounts for 25-30% of the earnings for most of the hospitals. “There is a significant fall in arrivals from foreign countries but the arrival of local patients has grown over the period. This is a trend across Kerala and is mainly due to the travel restrictions amidst corona scare. People now prefer to postpone elective procedures,” said Dr Harish Pillai, CEO, Aster Hospitals and Clinics, India.Though the first Covid-19 case was first detected in December 31, 2019, in Wuhan, its impact is being felt by the hospitals here only now. “Travel has been hit as flights have reduced operations. Now, the impact is being felt and it is very big,” said Dr Sanjeev Singh, medical superintendent, Amrita Institute of Medical Sciences.“People are not willing to travel unless it is a medical emergency. Most of these cases are elective procedures. Hence, many are postponing the procedure,” added Dr Singh.Incidentally, those who have made advance payments are not keen to postpone despite many hospitals making the offer. This is mainly because they fear that the wait will be too long. Most of the hospitals work through medical agents abroad and patients have to make full payments on booking. Those who approach the hospital directly, have to pay about 50% advance. Now, the hospitals will have to return the money of those who cancel bookings.Incidentally, even ayurveda hospitals are badly hit. “After floods and Nipah, medical tourism flourished here. But now, again, we are hit. Patients who have been seeking treatment have left midway and the few who are here are anxious. We have lost Rs 1 crore in cancellation in less than a week,” said Dr Anvar AM, chief physician, Raha Ayurveda Hospital.

Title: Citizen films gambling kingpins in Mankapur dens
Content:
A screen grab from the video

Nagpur: Some alert citizens have shot video clips of gambling dens at Mankapur, and they have gone viral on social media with the notorious names associated with the dens. After receiving the videos on Wednesday, senior police officers immediately sent a detection branch team from Mankapur police station to raid one of the dens, where four persons were arrested and some mobile phones were seized.

It’s learnt that residents of Mankapur are angry that their locality has become a haven for gamblers. There is also a threat of gangwar looming large as there is stiff rivalry between the gambling operators to outdo each other in attracting betters.

Shehzad and his brother Golu, both having faced police action in the past, are known to be the forerunners among the gambling den operators. Another gambling racketeer Bhurya, who managed to escape the raid on Wednesday, too is operating a den near Mankapur railway tracks. Golu’s rivals, Tassu, Baba and their gang too are operating gambling dens in the vicinity. It’s learnt that each group is eyeing an opportunity to attack the other.

The Mankapur-based gambling operators operate their dens along the railway tracks with the support of small-time goons and some hardened criminals who visit the places. PSI Kailash Magar of Mankapur police station, who led the raid on Wednesday after receiving a video of the gambler, said the operators use the railway tracks as a way to make for a fast getaway if cops arrive.

There had been a gangwar at Mankapur Chowk a couple of years ago between goons during the winter assembly session, leading to a riot-like situation.

A local resident, who shared the video of the gambling dens with TOI, said he found Feroze, Shehzad and Golu at the spot supervising gamblers playing with cash.

Feroze Goa, a former Maharashtra Control of Organized Crime Act (MCOCA) accused, and learnt to be operating a den at Goa Colony, near the railway tracks at Gaddigodam, also has interests in the popular dens of Shehzad and Golu at Mankapur.

It’s learnt Balya at Tandapeth, within the limits of Pachpaoli police station, despite a raid by crime branch, is still operating a major gambling den with one Mama from Ganga Jamuna. Pankaj and Shrawan also operate two major dens at Beda Hari and Toli in the outskirts of the city near Beltarodi.

City police chief BK Upadhyay said he would look into the issue of gambling operators thriving despite repeated action against them.

Title: Class X student falls into Narmada canal
Content:
Firemen searching for Pathan till late in the evening on Wednesday

Vadodara: While trying to make video , a 16-year-old boy fell into Narmada canal near Chhani on Tuesday and is still missing.

According to fire department sources, Arbaz Pathan, a student of Class X and resident of Navayard, had gone to the canal on Tuesday afternoon with his friends. He was recording a video standing on the canal’s bank and accidentally stepped over a slippery surface and lost his balance. He fell into the gushing waters of the canal.

On hearing the sound, Pathan’s friends who were sitting at a distance, rushed towards the bank, but could not see him and alerted the locals who informed the fire brigade.

A team of firemen from Chhani fire station searched for Pathan till late in the evening but could not find him. They had to stop the search due to darkness. On Wednesday morning, firemen from Vadiwadi fire station too joined in the search operation.

“Our teams searched a stretch of 5km from the location where he fell in, but were successful in locating him. We will continue our search on Thursday too,” said fire officer Om Jadeja. He added that the strong water currents in the canal is hampering the search operation.

Sources said that Pathan was appearing in Class X board exams and was to sit for Mathematics exam on Thursday. His father drives an autorickshaw while his mother is a homemaker.

This year, the district administration had banned tourists from venturing around Mahisagar river at Sindhrot and Lanchhanpura villages on Holi after several incidents of drowning have taken place there. However, there is no notification stopping people from going near the canal which passes through the city.

Title: Ahmedabad: Ex-EPFO officer duped of Rs 59 lakh
Content:
Representative Image

AHMEDABAD: A retired enforcement officer of EPFO (Employees Provident Fund Organisation) filed a complaint of cheating and forgery against three persons who introduced themselves as a UK national, a customs official and a bank employee, for duping him of Rs 59 lakh, states the FIR filed with cyber police on Monday.

Uday Bhatt, a resident of Satellite, in his FIR stated that he befriended a woman from England named Rosette Rosy Gaspard on Facebook in December 2019 and she began chatting with him on Messenger.

She told Bhatt her husband had died and she lived with her two-year-old daughter and would come to India on January 10, 2020 and wanted to meet Bhatt in Ahmedabad.

On January 10, at around 10.30am, a woman called Bhatt and introduced herself as a customs official and said that the English woman had been caught at Delhi airport with 50 Bitcoins worth Rs 50 lakh, for which she would have to pay a penalty of Rs 49,900.

Later, the woman also called Bhatt and asked him to pay the money and said she would return it when she met him. Bhatt went to a bank and paid the money for which the purported customs official sent a receipt to Bhatt’s WhatsApp number.

Later, the ‘customs official’ demanded Rs 85,000 for an ‘authorization certificate’ to convert the Bitcoins into Rs 50 lakh. Later, the purported customs official, a woman, told Bhatt to pay Rs 2.15 lakh for various other things. Bhatt followed the advice and paid money repeatedly. The purported customs officials sent him receipts for these payments, the FIR states.

On January 13, 2020, another person, who introduced himself as Khurana from Royal Bank of Scotland, called Bhatt and said that he would have to pay deposit money to get Bitcoins. He told Bhatt to make payments at regular intervals to get access to the Bitcoin money. Bhatt ended up paying Rs 55 lakh to various bank accounts in nearly 20 transactions.

After paying the money, Bhatt began asking the the England-based woman, purported customs official and alleged bank official about his money. They first gave him vague answers and later went incommunicado.

After waiting for two months to hear from the three, Bhatt approached cyber crime police and filed a complaint of cheating, breach of trust, forgery and use of forged documents along with charges under the IT Act.

Title: Kochi-Mumbai return fares dip to Rs 5k as virus spreads
Content:
Mumbai: With a rise in Covid-19 positive cases in India, domestic travel by air and rail is being hit.

Aircraft are flying with fewer passengers, train journeys are being cancelled. A sure indicator of low demand for air travel was low airfares, especially last-minute airfares or those on flights scheduled to depart in 24 hours.

A route that witnesses high demand throughout the year is Mumbai-Kochi. But this week, you could fly to Kochi and back for only Rs 5,000. “A last-minute flight to Kochi generally costs Rs 6,000-7,000 one-way,” said a travel agent. Return airfares on Delhi-Kochi route began at Rs 7,200. Flights to Trivandrum were comparatively higher in demand with return airfares from Mumbai beginning at Rs 9,000.

Airline companies have slashed the airfares in the Gulf-Karipur sector as Covid-19 fears have led to a significant drop in demand.

For instance, the one way direct trip from Karipur to Dubai on budget airline Flydubai for March 13 costs just Rs 5,859 while the flight from Dubai to Karipur on the same date is cheaper still at Rs 5,214.

Travel industry officials said that the prevailing fares are much lower than the normal rates at this time of the year.

“Normally, the fares in the sector hover around Rs 8000-Rs 10,000 for the same period. There is a severe slack in demand and people are putting off travel plans due to concerns over possible travel restrictions,” P V Vijesh, manager of Al Hind Tours and Travels, said.

Also, Saudi Arabia’s decision to temporarily ban flights from nine countries, including United Arab Emirates, Kuwait, Bahrain, has affected passenger traffic in the sector as many people depended on connection flights of Gulf based-carriers to travel to Saudi.

Added to that is the ban imposed by Qatar and Kuwait on passengers travelling from India.

Other domestic destinations like Bengaluru and Hyderabad were cheaper, with Rs 3,800 return airfares for travel from Mumbai. From Delhi, cheapest airfares began at Rs 5,800 for Hyderabad and Rs 6,700 for Bengaluru return.

On Tuesday, the cheapest Mumbai-Delhi return ticket for travel on Wednesday and return later in the week, started at Rs 5,000, that is, an average of Rs 2,500 one-way.

(Inputs from Kozhikode)

Title: HC stays arrest of Chiripals
Content:
Ahmedabad: The Gujarat high court on Wednesday granted interim protection to Deepak Chiripal and Jyotiprasad Chiripal, instructing police not to arrest them till the pendency of their quashing petition in connection with the fire at Nandan Denim Ltd in Narol, in which seven workers were killed last month.

The HC instructed the father-son duo to cooperate with the investigation. They have been arraigned in the FIR and are facing IPC charges along with four other employees.

The accused contended that an offence under the Factories Act has been registered and there was no need fpr IPC charges. Before the Chiripals, three employees approached the HC challenging the FIR, especially the police invoking atrocity charges.tnn

Title: Labourer beaten to death in Savli
Content:
Vadodara: A labourer in Savli was murdered by a man from his village on Tuesday over some past rift.

Accused Ganesh Rathodiya had heated arguments with the Sava Rathodiya (55) which escalated to a brawl. Police said that in the heat of the moment, Ganesh slapped him multiple times and kicked him after he fell on the ground after which Sava succumbed.

According to police, Ganesh’s mother lives with Sava’s brother Chandu as his wife after she separated from her husband. Police said that Ganesh often goes to meet his mother at Chandu’s house where Sava also lives. “The duo often used to argue over petty issues,” said a police official.

The duo walked out of the house while arguing and got into a brawl. Police said that neighbours did not see them fight as it was Holi. However, Sava’s niece Champa who lives in the same neighbourhood went to Sava’s rescue, but by then he was lying unconscious. When other members of the family arrived there, Sava had died due to severe head injuries.

The niece lodged a murder case at Savli police station following which Ganesh was arrested on Wednesday.

Title: Pune man dies of burns in fire at Bhandarkar Road house
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A 46-year-old social media content designer died of severe burns sustained in a fire that broke out around 3am on Wednesday at his residence off Bhandarkar road.

The Deccan Gymkhana police said Sandip Gokhale was asleep when the fire broke out. His relatives and friends told TOI that his wife, daughter and son had gone to a relative’s house at Karvenagar to celebrate Holi. They stayed back there and Gokhale was alone at home.

The cause of the blaze is being investigated. The police and fire brigade could not secure any immediate leads about what may have started the fire.

The Gokhale family lives on the ground floor of a two-storied building. The deceased’s relatives said he used to design logos and marquee for social media sites. “He would work for different companies and individuals. Everything was fine with him. His death has come as a shock to us,” a relative said.

Fire brigade officials told TOI that they received an emergency call at 2.53am. They rushed a fire tender to the house and brought the blaze under control within 20 minutes. “We found a man, who had sustained serious burn injuries, lying on the floor of the 200 sq.ft. house. We found two LPG cylinders in the house, both engulfed in flames, but managed to take them out safely,” an official said.

Around 3.30am, Deccan Gymkhana police and the fire brigade officials rushed Gokhale to Sassoon hospital where he succumbed to his burns around 4.45am.

The furniture, electronic goods and other articles in the house were damaged in the fire.

Local residents told TOI that the intensity of the fire was such that tall flames leaped out when the fire brigade officials broke open the doors of the house. The flames touched the roof of the building and neighbouring trees also caught fire. Deccan Gymkhana police have registered a case of accidental death.

Title: Three youths slip in Ganga, go missing
Content:
Kanpur: Three youths are feared to have drowned while bathing in the Ganga at Saraiya Ghat in Shivrajpur area of district on Tuesday.

Police identified the deceased as Divyamani Tiwari (27) and Sachin Verma (26), both residents of Keshavpuram and Rinku (26) of Panki.

Police said one youth, who didn’t know how to swim, slipped into deep water, started drowning and called for help. Two others rushed to rescue him and are also feared drowned. Some people standing on the banks raised alarm following which local divers rushed to rescue youths but they could not find them. Their bodies were untraceable till Wednesday.

SHO Shivrajpur Mahesh Yadav, said that the youths had entered the deep side of the river. “The bodies of the three are yet to be recovered,” SHO added.

Title: No law and order issue in TN: Govt to HC
Content:
Chennai: The Washermenpet anti-CAA sit-in entering 25th day on Wednesday notwithstanding, the Tamil Nadu government told the Madras high court that there is no law and order situation in the state as alleged by a batch of PILs which wanted authorities to stop such protests across the state. “Adequate protection has been provided to both protesters and public,” state public prosecutor A Natarajan said on Wednesday while making the submission before a division bench of Justices M M Sundresh and Krishnan Ramaswamy.

The issue pertains to a batch of six PILs moved by various people, including Gopinath, a lawyer from Tirupur, alleging that the anti-CAA protests are causing inconvenience to public. On March 5, the bench passed an interim order directing the state police to ensure that no protests both in support of and against CAA are permitted without prior permission.

However, based on the apprehension raised by a section of lawyers that the order might be used to take adverse action against peaceful protesters and that the petitioner who is a ‘history-sheeter’ has approached the court without clean hands, the bench on March 6 kept its interim order in abeyance.

When the pleas came up for hearing on Wednesday, court hall 6 where the case was heard was filled with a battery of advocates both in support of and against the petitions. Senior counsel S Prabakaran and others representing the petitioners argued that if the marathon protests are permitted to continue, it would set a bad precedent. “This would encourage anyone who can organise 1,000 people to sit on Anna Salai for his/her demands,” Prabakaran said, wondering whether the state police would follow the same approach in all such cases. “They claim that it is their fundamental right to protest or assemble in a place. But by exercising their right they are affecting the fundamental right of other people to move freely,” he said.

Senior advocate R Vaigai, N G R Prasad and others argued that Gopinath is a ‘history sheeter’ and that the PIL being a fraudulent petition is not maintainable.

Recording the submission, the bench posted the pleas to March 17 for further hearing.

Title: Dstrict collector invokes imposes crisis management act in Yavatmal
Content: Yavatmal: Yavatmal district collector MD Singh has imposed the Crisis Management Act in the district from Wednesday. He has designated the district civil surgeon Dr Tarangtushar Warey and district health officer Dr Balasaheb Chavan as the coordinators of the committee.A toll-free no. 104 has been set up to gather information and get the public updated on coronavirus . No. 91-11-23978046 is also operative from Wednesday in the collectorate.Singh has empowered the district coordinators to take instant action against chemists who sell masks at an inflated cost and indulge in black marketing of essential medicines. The officers are also empowered to take immediate action against those found guilty of spreading fake messages and creating panic among the people regarding the coronavirus.“We may use the services of private hospitals and doctors in case of any emergency,” Singh stated in a release.

Title: Showers affect revelry, but fail to dampen festive spirit
Content:
Prayagraj: As overcast conditions and sporadic showers partially affected Holi celebrations in Sangam city on Tuesday, city residents made up for the loss by coming out on the streets with great enthusiasm on Wednesday to enjoy the festival of colours.

The famous ‘kapda phad’ (tearing of outfits) Holi of Chowk area and floral Holi of Civil Lines was attended by a large number of locals on Wednesday.

Although the weather on Monday was fairly clear with bright sunshine and maximum and minimum temperatures at 29.2 degrees and 17.4 degree Celsius respectively, residents woke up on Tuesday to overcast sky.

As people started coming out to celebrate the festival, several localities witnessed drizzles.

The weather remained almost the same all day through as maximum temperature was recorded at 23.6 degrees (a drop of around 6 degrees) and minimum temperature stood at 12.7 degrees (around 5 degrees less than Monday).

Due to cold breeze and showers, many Holi revelers remained indoors or chose to play with dry colours like ‘gulal’ and ‘abeer’.

“We had called everyone to come in the apartment’s garden area. We had arranged for water, sweets and gulal to celebrate Holi like previous years but as cold winds returned, it was only sweets and ‘gulal’ which dominated Holi celebrations,” said Sukanya, a student of Allahabad University.

However, Holi celebrations remained unaffected in several localities of the city. Local residents, especially in Chowk, Khuldabad, Katra, and Sulem Sarai areas played Holi with traditional fervour.

People, however, celebrated the festival more on Wednesday as compared to the main day of the festival as weather became much more conducive for revellers. The famous ‘kapda phad’ (tearing of outfits) Holi of Chowk area was attended by a large number of locals.

Likewise, Holi milan events were organised by various private and government institutions, people greeted each other with ‘gulal’ and danced to the tunes of Holi songs. They embraced and greeted each other, offered sweets and wished prosperity to each other.

In various localities, men and women organised in-house parties. “We arranged DJ, Holi colours, eatables and sweets to celebrate the occasion with our near and dear ones,” said Meenu Khanna, a resident of Dariyabad.

Title: Pune: Poor census data limit Ayushman Bharat’s reach
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Poor quality of the census data has limited the reach of the Union government’s Ayushman Bharat Scheme, leaving out about 30% of the 50 crore intended beneficiaries.

The scheme, run under Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PMJAY), was announced in September 2018, aiming at providing free health coverage at the primary, secondary and tertiary level to bottom 40% poor and vulnerable population.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi had claimed that the scheme would benefit 50 crore economically disadvantaged people. However, till Feb 21, 2020, only around 12.20 crore e-cards under PMJAY were issued. Of these, 7.52 crore e-cards were issued by the Centre, while 4.68 crore by the states.

Indu Bhushan, chief executive officer of the Ayushman Bharat Scheme, said the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) 2011 database, which is used to identify the beneficiaries of the scheme, was “outdated” and left out around “30% of the intended beneficiaries” from its coverage.

On low penetration of the scheme, Bhushan said, “The programme is based on entitlement and not enrolment. Besides, e-cards are just one of the ways to avail of the treatment under the scheme,” he said.

He said there were some problems with the quality of the SECC data. “We are not able to trace about 30% of the intended beneficiaries. Since, some states joined late and a few are yet to join, the scheme has reached to about 30 crore people,” he said.

Bhushan said less than one-fourth of the 50 crore intended beneficiaries had been issued e-cards in the 17-month period since the launch of the Ayushman Bharat Scheme.

Experts said people can also check their names on the official website to see if they qualify for treatment under the scheme. “Another reason for the slow rollout of PMJAY is that four states are yet-to-join the scheme and two states only joined recently. That leaves out at least 2 crore potential beneficiaries,” Bhushan said.

According to the government, four states — West Bengal, Telangana, Odisha and Delhi — are yet to implement the scheme, while Punjab and Rajasthan joined only in late 2019.

Further, the data available on PMJAY website revealed on Wednesday that about 90 lakh people had availed of treatment under the scheme at about 20,000 empanelled hospitals across the country.

Budget allocation

The Union Budget for 2020-21, presented on February 1, kept unchanged the outlay for the scheme at Rs6,400 crore. The budget for the ongoing 2019-20 fiscal was, however, revised from Rs6,400 crore to Rs3,200 crore.

Bhushan said, this decision was partly because many states merged their existing health insurance schemes with Ayushman Bharat, thereby, making them liable to contribute in its spend. The insurers quoting a low premium also decreased the expenses.

“When we started, we had estimated a quote of Rs1,000 per family but in many states, the average premium has been pitched at Rs700-800 per family. Most of them are are insured by public sector general insurers,” he said.

To insure the 30 crore potential beneficiaries (or about 6 crore families), the government spent Rs3,200 crore in the current fiscal, translating to about Rs533 per family. However, the Centre’s move to revise the allocated funds downwards signals its under-utilisation, experts said.

Pune-based activist Anant Phadke said the Centre was not meeting its own projections. “NITI Aayog's projection was Rs12,000 crore, but the scheme will require about Rs 20,000 crore every year,” Phadke said.

Title: Kanpur: Timers to be fixed at 10 crossings for smooth traffic flow
Content:
Representative image

KANPUR: Kanpur Municipal Corporation (KMC) has decided to install timers at 10 crossings of the city to control traffic.

The timer besides displaying time will also indicate for how many seconds the traffic has to stop and move.

According to KMC sources, each channel of the crossing has one separate timer. "If a crossing has five side roads then five timers will be installed there. The timer will display the traffic stoppage time of each channel", the source said. KMC would install timers at other crossings of the city, the source added.

At present, the timer installed at the Taat mill crossing is very well controlling the traffic. The ten crossings in the city where timer would be installed are: Company Bagh crossing (5 timers), Colonelganj crossing (4 timers), Lal Imli crossing (4 timers), Naronha crossing (5 timers), Afeem Kothi crossing (4 timers), Jareeb Chowki crossing (5 timers), Fazalganj crossing (4 timers), Rawatpur Tiraha (3 timers), Gurudev Palace crossing (4 timers) and Yashoda Nagar crossing (4 timers).

Title: Sector V PO to get digital parcel locker
Content:
Kolkata: The department of posts, West Bengal circle, will unveil the country’s first digital parcel locker service at the Nabadiganta IT post office in CP Block, Sector V, on Thursday. The service will also be available at the post office in New Town’s Action Area I.

Digital parcel lockers allow customers to receive and collect parcels and letters addressed to them from the kiosks round the clock. It involves dropping parcels into digital lockers, followed by an SMS intimation with OTP to the customer. Customers can then use the OTP to open the locker and collect the shipment at their convenience. This facility is particularly helpful for those living alone or dual-income families where no one is at home during regular delivery hours.

“This facility is secure and free,” said postmaster general (Kolkata region) Amitabh Singh. The facility will be inaugurated by chief post master general (West Bengal circle) Gautam Bhattacharya in the presence of other senior officials. tnn

Title: Bhubaneswar: Ruckus in House over temple funds
Content:
Jaganath temple in Puri

BHUBANESWAR: The Congress MLAs on Wednesday created ruckus in the assembly, seeking fixing of responsibilities for deposit of Rs 545 crore funds of Jaganath temple in Puri in crisis-ridden Yes Bank . In Delhi, BJD MPs met Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman , seeking her intervention for withdrawal of the fixed deposits.

Moments after the assembly reconvened for the second phase of budget session, the Congress members stormed into the well of the House. Raising anti-government slogans, the MLAs demanded a probe to find out who “took the erroneous decision of depositing the money in the private bank.” Amid the din, Speaker S N Patro adjourned the House first till 12.30pm and again till 3pm. Speaking to reporters outside the assembly, Congress MLA Tara Prasad Bahinipati said, “We put pressure on the government to find out the person who decided to deposit the funds in a private bank, pushing its fate into uncertainty. The God’s money may be lost.”

The BJP had given notice for an adjournment motion discussion on the temple fund issue, but it could not be taken up because of the continued disruptions in the proceedings. “We had given a notice for discussion on the temple fund issue. The discussion could have brought out facts to the public domain. The Congress members stormed into the well and the speaker adjourned the House. It seems BJD and Congress have an understanding,” deputy leader of opposition Bisnhu Sethi said. Both BJD and Congress dismissed Sethi’s allegation. “It is unfortunate the Congress members stalled the proceedings though the government is ready for discussion on any issue,” government chief whip Pramila Mallik said. In the meantime, BJD parliamentary party leader in Rajya Sabha, Prasanna Acharya, led a delegation of party MPs and met Sitharaman in Delhi. “The finance minister assured us that the Lord’s money is safe,” Acharya said.

Jagannath Sena, a socio-political outfit, lodged a complaint with the CBI, seeking a probe into deposit of temple funds. One Pradipta Naik has lodged a complaint with the Odisha Human Rights Commission , seeking its intervention in the issue.

Title: 165 drunk driving cases during Holi in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The traffic police registered cases against 158 people for driving in an inebriated condition across the city on the occasion of Dhulivandan on Tuesday and nabbed seven persons on the similar charge on Holi the day before.

Additional commissioner of police Sanjay Shinde said, “Action against drunk driving was taken across the 24 traffic divisions in the city to avert any accident. Revellers often consume alcohol and drive during festivals such as Holi. Such a behaviour can lead to accidents. A special drive was conducted on Tuesday during which 158 persons were nabbed for drunk driving.”

He said cases have been filed against all the violators at the Motor Vehicles Court . “The police will continue to take action against people driving after drinking alcohol. We appeal to citizens to follow rules and refrain from drunk driving to ensure safe and comfortable travel in the city,” Shinde added.

The number of such cases during this year’s festival of colours was down from 214 in 2019 ad 424 in 2018, the police said.

Traffic expert and Save Pune Traffic Movement director Harshad Abhyankar said the reduction in the number was a positive sign, but statistics alone were inadequate to say if the situation has improved.

“We cannot compare the number of cases registered during Holi each year, as we do not know if the enforcement was identical over the years. One has to find if the number of police personnel on road was same during the festival over the years,” he said.

Civic activist Vivek Velankar said, “We did not see nakabandis to nab drunk drivers on Holi, as we see the arrangement on the New Year’s Eve. Also, many people from the city know where nakabandi is and take alternative routes to evade the police. It is good that the police have nabbed 158 people for drunk driving. But the enforcement needs to be more stringent.”

He added, “Rangpanchmi is coming up and the message should go out that people will be caught for drunk driving. Spreading such information will also lead to greater deterrence.”

Title: Coronavirus in Kochi: Demand for sanitizers, infrared thermometers up
Content:
Representative image

KOCHI: As Covid-19 fear grips the city, there is high demand for handheld infrared (IR) thermometers (non-contact thermometers).

Druggists said many companies, mostly those from the Infopark, are placing orders for infrared thermometers and there is not enough stock to meet the requirements. Even though new orders have been placed, the high demand across the world has affected the supply and production of these devices, said druggists.

Incidentally, till about Monday, there was a little demand for infrared-thermometers, with medical shops selling about one or two in a week. But suddenly that has changed and the demand for infrared-thermometers, masks, sanitizers and gloves has grown by almost 70% to 75%. Due to this, many medical shops at present don’t have these items in stock.

“Infrared thermometer permits temperature measurement from a distance without contact with the object to be measured using infrared rays. In the wake of Covid-19, people prefer these devices over conventional thermometers. We have received so many calls from IT companies to place orders for the devices but there in not enough stock, as these devices don’t have much demand normally,” said Aslam K A, a staff of a medical store.

With the state government having issued Covid-19 Standard Operational Procedure to IT parks that suggests health screening of visitors and suspected employees, many companies are using IR thermometers.

“In the past few days, nearly 10 to 20 lakh masks have been sold in the state. This is mainly because many Malayalis, who are travelling abroad, are carrying two to three boxes of masks as there is shortage abroad,” said P V Tomy, president, Chemist and Druggist Association, Ernakulam.

Title: Man held for drinking makes TikTok video inside lock-up in Ahmedabad
Content:
A screengrab of the video

AHMEDABAD: Meghaninagar police of city in dock with an accused in a prohibition case making a TikTok video inside the lock-up on Sunday, featuring a Bollywood song and his four friends who had come to meet him.

Police ended up registering a case under the Information Technology Act against accused, Karansingh Shekhawat, for making video from inside the lock-up and publishing it.

A Meghaninagar police official said Shekhawat had been caught drunk on Sunday and put in the lock-up. His four friends had come to meet him and Shekhawat suggested they make a TikTok video so it would go viral.

Shekhawat’s friends accepted his advice and shot a video on the title song of the Sanjay Dutt-starrer ‘Khalnayak’. The video went viral after which police swung into action and registered a complaint in a face-saving exercise.

Head constable Shankar Bhanudas of Meghaninagar police on Wednesday filed a complaint under the IT Act along with abetment charges under the IPC, against Shekhawat and his four friends.

According to the FIR, Shekhawat and the four others shot the video between 10.45am and 11.15pm on Sunday when they were allowed to meet him. Cops gathered CCTV footage of the incident.

The cops were clueless about the identities of the four persons who helped Shekhawat make the video.

The incident raised questions about the negligence of cops at police stations. On February 25, a youth committed suicide by hanging himself inside the lock-up at Kagdapith police station.



In Video: Ahmedabad man held for drinking, makes TikTok video from inside lock-up

Title: Odisha: Row over Swami Vivekanand National Institute of Rehabilitation Training and Research board
Content:
BHUBANESWAR: Authorities of the Swami Vivekanand National Institute of Rehabilitation Training and Research ( SVNIRTAR ), an autonomous institute run by the central government, at Olatpur in Cuttack district alleged that the Utkal University has selected ‘ineligible’ members to the board of studies (BoS) for physiotherapy and occupational therapy courses in the institute.

Courses of the SVNIRTAR are affiliated to Utkal University. Therefore, the university has reconstituted the BoS for the courses like bachelor and masters degree in physiotherapy, occupational therapy and prosthetics & orthotics. It has selected 11 members to the board on March 3. On March 6, Shakti Prasad Das, director of the SVNIRTAR, in a letter to Utkal University VC Soumendra Mohan Patnaik , informed him about the ‘irregularities’ in selecting members of BoS. Patnaik said he will personally look into the matter. “We had issued a notification regarding selection of members of BoS last month. When there were complaints, we changed the members. If the institute complains against the recent notification, we will discuss the issue and examine what can be done,” he added.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Don’t panic, but take precautions, says Chennai Corporation
Content: CHENNAI: Appealing to commercial establishments such as malls , multiplexes, wedding halls and hotels among others to not panic in the wake of fears over spread of Covid-19 (novel coronavirus), Greater Chennai Corporation has issued an advisory of precautionary measures that the establishment owners should follow.Deputy Commissioner (health) Dr V Alby John and city health officer Dr M Jagadeesan convened a meeting with representatives of commercial establishments where public gather in large numbers and issued an advisory. Explaining that the civic body’s zonal officials and public health department officials have been in touch with places of mass gathering for more than a month now, Alby John told the stakeholders, “There is absolutely no need to panic, but we have to be careful.”The business owners, perturbed over the onslaught of information on social media and messaging platforms, badgered the corporation officials with questions ranging from whether the virus is a cold country epidemic to diet restrictions to dealing with those showing symptoms and whether thermal screening devices have to be set up.The deputy commissioner and the health officer appealed to the establishment owners to not rely on sensational information on such online platforms and to seek clarity from the government and through reliable channels.“The reason for panic and uncertainty is because it’s a new virus. What is important to keep in mind is that the virus can attack anyone and hence it is imperative that all precautionary measures such as washing hands and disinfecting floors and surfaces are adhered to,” Jagadeesan said.He clarified that N-95 masks should be worn only by health workers and the civic body has not issued any advisory to the general public to wear masks. The civic body also appealed to hotels and lodges to notify it about any foreigner they allow to stay on their premises. Responding to queries on whether the virus spreads only in cold climate, Alby John said, “That is a popular opinion, but there are no concrete studies as yet backing up the theory.”Officials also clarified that the spread of the virus is not related to meat consumption.Jagadeesan took the opportunity to inform the hotel owners to treat those showing symptoms of Covid-19 in a humane manner as the civic body has received complaints about differential treatment by commercial establishments. The corporation said it has notified the drug control department on overpricing of hand sanitisers and masks by pharmacies.

Title: Twin baby boys die, parents blame polio vaccine
Content:
The babies were administered the vaccine earlier this month

Vadodara: The death of twin 40-day-old baby boys days after they were given the polio vaccine sparked a major row on Wednesday with the parents belonging to Katwara in Dahod district alleging that the boys died from the vaccine.

The babies were administered the vaccine earlier this month. They were brought to the SSG Hospital and admitted there on March 6 and they died within days of being admitted at the hospital making the parents express their suspicion over the vaccine.

Katwara police sub-inspector B A Baria said that the first baby boy died on Sunday while the second baby died on Monday. “They came with the baby to Katwara and informed us. When we asked the family to get an autopsy done, they did not agree and performed the last rites,” Baria said.

After the second baby died on Monday, the family agreed for a post-mortem and the father of the twins, Rakesh Katara approached the police. Baria said that a case of accidental death was registered regarding the incident. “We have sent viscera samples for forensic examination too. The parents have a doubt and we want that to be cleared,” he added.

Title: Poll for ‘Bird of Wardha’ in Limca Book of Records
Content:
Indian roller

Nagpur: The elections held on June 23, 2018 to decide ‘Bird of Wardha’ has made it to the Limca Book of Records .

A joint initiative by Wardha Municipal Council and NGO Bahar Nature Foundation, Wardha was the second city after Sawantwadi in Konkan to hold polls to choose ‘bird of city’. Sawantwadi held the polls in 2017.

Wardha’s honorary wildlife warden Sanjay Ingle Tigaonkar said, “In a certificate issued in December but received by the NGO on Wednesday, Vatsala Kaul Banerjee, editor of the Limca Book of Records, applauded the unique election.”

By garnering 58% votes, Indian Roller, popularly called as ‘Nilpankh’, had won the race for ‘Bird of Wardha’ by a thumping majority defeating its nearest rival White Breasted Kingfisher by a margin of over 21,400 votes.

In all, 51,267 people cast ballot in the polls that started on June 23 and closed on August 15. Of the total votes, 47,646 votes were polled through ballot while remaining 3,621 votes were cast online by Wardha residents staying abroad.

Of the five candidate-birds — Coppersmith Barbet, White Breasted Kingfisher, Spotted Owlet, Indian Roller, and Black Shoulder Kite — Nilpankh emerged winner. The 54-day election exercise had generated lot of interest not only among local residents but also nature lovers from entire Maharashtra.

Title: GU police file FIR for rioting
Content:
Ahmedabad: Gujarat University police registered an FIR against unknown persons for rioting, obstructing police action and hurting a constable during their celebrations on the university campus on the day of the results of the senate election.

The FIR was lodged by a constable accusing unnamed students of not obeying orders to reduce the volume of the DJ music, part of their victory celebrations. The students refused to remove the DJ from near the School of Languages and assaulted a cop when they were told to leave.

Police slapped Sections 186, 332, 353, 143, 147 and 149 of the IPC against the gathering, accusing them of obstructing cops, assaulting a government servant, unlawful assembly and rioting.

Title: Aurangabad: City police prepare for Shiv Jayanti
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: City police have made preparations like diverting traffic on certain routes ahead of the celebration of Shiv Jayanti as per the tithi on Thursday, amidst cases of coronavirus in the country. Aurangabad commissioner of police Chiranjeev Prasad said, “We have not denied permission for Shiv Jayanti celebrations.”

Despite the state issuing an advisory asking the authorities to abstain from granting permission for holding public events, the city police have granted permission for rallies.

As part of the preparations, police will close three key routes from 11am till midnight. The routes that would remain close for commuters include the one from Sansthan Ganpati temple to Kranti Chowk via Gandhi Putla , City Chowk, Gulmandi, Paithan Gate Sillekhana.

The second route to remain close will be the ones passing from N-12 nursery Cidco to Chishtiya Chowk via TV centre, M-2, N-2 Shivneri Colony, Parshavnath Chowk , Baliram Patil Chowk to Shivaji Maharaj statue. The third route to remain close will be from Jaibhavaninagar chowk to Jawaharnagar police station chowk. tnn

Title: Coronavirus scare: Kochi airport witnesses decline in passenger traffic
Content:
Ambulance sanitization works in progress in the Kochi on Wednesday

KOCHI: The Cochin International Airport Ltd (Cial) is witnessing a huge decline in the number of passengers in the wake of heightened Covid-19 alert. According to sources, the airport, that usually handles around 30,000 passengers daily, now witnesses only 50% passengers, both in international and domestic sectors. While the cancellation of several international flights and stringent visa curbs by India and other countries hit the passenger flow in international sector, domestic sector is affected by cancellation of tickets. The cancellation of tour packages is also a reason behind the reduced footfalls.

“Many flights in international sectors are operating without enough passengers. The situation is more or less same in both arrival and departure sector,” said Cial spokesperson.

“The frequent change in travel rules is confusing passengers and they just don’t want to travel. We have been receiving cancellation calls even though we have given offers like rescheduling trips without penalty,” said Air India Express spokesperson.

Title: Pandemic SOP issued for IT sector
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: The state government has issued standard operating procedure ( SOP ) for the IT industry to manage the spread of coronavirus, whose outbreak declared pandemic by WHO (A pandemic is declared when a new disease for which people do not have immunity spreads around the world beyond expectations). The decision came in the wake of reports that IT professionals, who frequently fly to international destinations as part of work, are vulnerable. On Wednesday, two IT professionals of Dell and Mindtree in Delhi were found to be Covid-19 positive. Another IT professional in Bangalore too was tested positive recently.

Though techies in IT parks in the state are not affected so far, an SOP was issued following a high-level meeting convened by IT secretary M Sivasankar at Technopark here on Wednesday.

The meeting, which was attended by IT parks CEO Sasi P M, Kerala Startup mission CEO Saji Gopinath, GTech chairman Alexander Varghese and GTech members, it was decided to identify IT employees who visited Ranni and Kottayam in the last two weeks. The companies were asked to conduct medical inspections and isolate them in case of any symptoms. The companies were asked to provide such employees the option to work from home for two weeks or 15-days leave.

Companies were asked to provide necessary preventive items such as hand sanitizers for employees.

The SOP stresses on the need for frequent cleaning of high touch surfaces.tnn

Title: Professors file FIR against Gohil
Content:
Ahmedabad: Two professors of Gujarat University on Wednesday filed a complaint for uttering abuses and criminal intimidation against Congress leader Indravijaysinh Gohil.

An official of Gujarat University police said that the complainants — Mukesh Khatik, 42, professor of political science and residents of Gujarat University quarters, and Ashok Unagar, 42, professor of Sanskrit — said Gohil had called them and abused over the senate elections.

Khatik said Gohil made a WhatsApp call whereas Unagar said Gohil and his aide, NSUI leader Aharnish Mishra, called him, abused him and threatened him.

The audio clip went viral in which Mishra and Gohil are heard using abusive language against the professors

The two approached Gujarat University police and filed a complaint against Gohil.

Title: Two men beaten to death by friend, accused on the run
Content:
Representative image

KANPUR: Two persons were allegedly beaten to death by one of their friends on late Monday night apparently after a brawl at Udetpur village under the limits of Chaubeypur police station in the district.

Police have been conducting several raids to nab the accused, identified as Bhagwati of Udeitpur and his accomplices, said Superintendent of Police (Rural) Pradyumna Singh.

The deceased have been identified as Manoj Chaurasia (36), a resident of Udeitpur and Ajit Yadav (38), a resident of neighbouring village Ghaghpur in the district. Singh said Manoj and Ajit were consuming liquor at a outlet in Kishunpur when Bhagwati, accompanied by his aides, reached there and had an altercation with them over some issue.

“They indulged in a fight following which Bhagwati and his men attacked Manoj and Ajit with stone. They both sustained serious head injuries in the brawl,” the SP said adding that both were admitted to Lala Lajpat Rai Hospital where they were declared dead.

The families of both Manoj and Ajit have accused Bhagwati and his men of murder, said DIG Anant Deo. “An FIR has been lodged and separate teams are conducting raids to make the arrest of the accused possible,” DIG added.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Passengers sent home for 28 days of seclusion from Kochi airport
Content:
Representative image

KOCHI: Medical teams have started segregating passengers who arrive at the international terminal of the Cochin International Airport from countries hit by coronavirus and are compulsorily sending them to 28 days of home quarantine, district administration officials said on Wednesday. The asymptomatic passengers were taken from the airport to their homes in an ambulance after they were asked to sign an affidavit stating that they will strictly follow the instructions of medical teams and will remain at home for the stipulated number of days.

Simultaneously, panchayat and police personnel in their respective areas have also been informed about the passengers sent for home quarantine.

“As many as 14 passengers came forward informing that they will go home only after they tested negative for coronavirus. Until then they will remain under observation in hospital,” said a health official.

“We can’t lodge all the passengers at a single location. It is best to send them home from airport by ambulance. It will help them avoid contact with others. It is safe to lodge asymptomatic people at home quarantine itself. Lodging them at a different location in quarantine will lead to more problems and they will get more tensed,” said a health official.

Of the 52-people who arrived from Rome on Wednesday, three passengers refused to cooperate with health officials. “They claimed they were not suffering from any illness and asked why there is so much mayhem here. But we convinced them about the need to take precautions,” said the official. As many as 35 passengers were sent to Aluva District Hospital for keeping them under observation. A majority of them were later sent to their homes.

Meanwhile, isolation wards were opened at more government hospitals on the district. As many as 10 rooms were opened at Aluva District Hospital and 40 at Muvattupuzha Taluk Hospital. Directions have been issued to government taluk hospitals in Perumbavoor and Fort Kochi to remove patients from pay wards so that passengers coming from Covid-hit countries, can be placed under observation.

Some of the private hospitals in the district have expressed willingness to accommodate the passengers.

Meantime, eight samples from private hospitals were sent to Alappuzha unit of the National Institute of Virology for test.

In total, 84 samples have been sent to the NIV unit. Six people were discharged from isolation ward on Wednesday.

Those who came from Rome on Tuesday were from Kottayam, Pathanamthitta, Thrissur, Kasaragod and Alappuzha districts.

Title: Many bigwigs now out of Jaipur mayors’ race
Content:
Jaipur: Many party bigwigs are now out of the Jaipur mayors’ race as both the top posts in the two proposed corporations got reserved for women (OBC) in a draw of lots after the delimitation.

Now, the parties are counting on fresh faces from among the OBC women candidates for the elections. Before the lottery was drawn, many candidates from the Brahmin community having a strong grip were asserting their right to the seat of the mayor , claimed that the community had the highest number of voters in the city. Similarly, Vaishya community was also vying for political mileage.

Sources said candidates who were proposing their names meekly for the posts have become the frontrunners as possibilities to become the mayor have improved.

From the existing lot of councillors, a Congress minister’s relative is among the frontrunners from Greater Jaipur, if she wins the election. Similarly, in BJP a former councillor’s wife in the Walled City is also eyeing for the post after situation swung in her favour.

Speculations are rife, a daughter-in-law of a senior Congress leader can contest from the Walled City area and later can pitch for mayor’s post.

Many still believe it would be a challenge for both the parties to zero in on strong OBC women candidates. A BJP legislator said, “There are a few strong candidates from the present councillors’ lot. As elections are vital, the party will decide on fielding a candidate from outside after elections or choose them from the councillors.”

In comparison with the Congress, the list of strong and winnable candidates for mayor’s post from general category was strong in BJP. However, all those prominent faces are out of the race.

Title: Jatayu Earth Centre, tourism spots under forest dept closed
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: As the state is put on high alert following the spread of novel coronavirus , various departments have issued restrictions on accessing tourist spots, where chances of public gatherings are high.Based on the government’s decision to avoid public gatherings, the forest department was the first to issue a directive to close all eco-tourism destinations. All major destinations under forest department were closed for public from Wednesday. This will be in effect till March 31.Popular hangouts such as Ponmudi, Brymore, Neyyar, Kottoor, Peppara, Vazhvanthol and Kallar are temporarily closed. Sources in the forest department said that in places like Neyyar, irrigation and other departments too have temporarily stopped their activities.“There is no tourist flow to these locations after the rise in Covid-19 cases in the state. Now, we have temporarily stopped all ecotourism activities, nature walks, etc,” said an official of the forest department.District tourism promotion council (DTPC) secretary Bindhu Moni S said that they have not introduced any such restrictions on public visits. “DTPC is not authorized to take such decisions. So far, we haven’t got any government direction on entry restrictions,” she said.Another popular tourism spot, the Jatayu Earth’s Centre at Chadayamangalam, too has stopped public entry in view of the state’s directive against public gatherings. Centre chairman and managing directed Rajeev Anchal said that the centre will be temporarily closed till March 31.Magician Gopinath Muthucaud said that Magic Planet and Different Arts Centre at Kinfra Film And Video Park will be closed from Wednesday.Kerala State Science and Technology Museum has stopped its activities, including regular shows in Priyadarshini Planetarium.A statement from Maheswaram Sri Siva Parvathy Temple, which is known for the world’s largest Shiva lingam, said that public visits will be restricted from Thursday due to the spread of coronavirus worldwide. “The daily rituals will be held as usual. In addition to this, a special pooja will be held from 4.30am to 7.30am for seven days,” said the statement issued by Swami Maheshwarananda Saraswathi.Sports minister E P Jayarajan said that mega marathon and beach games at Shanghumukham were postponed as part of avoiding public events due to Covid-19.All cinema theatres in the district are also closed as per the advisory issued by the state government. Hotel and resort employees, who interact with tourists, were advised to take necessary precautions such as maintaining social distance, frequent hand washing, using safety gear while cleaning, etc. Those who know about suspected cases are advised to contact Direct Intervention System For Health Awareness (Disha) at 1056.

Title: Coronavirus scare fails to dampen festivity, city drenched in Holi hue
Content: Kanpur: Holi festivities gripped the city on Tuesday as people smeared gulal on each other’s faces and danced on dhol beats.Several beautifully decorated Holikas were raised at various crossings. The festivities commemced after Holika dahan on Monday night. People greeted each other with ‘gulal’ tilak. On Tuesday, huge gatherings could be seen in various localities to celebrate the festival.The coronavirus scare seemed to have no effect on the city festivities as large groups of youths, women and men stepped out on roads to celebrate the festival. Holi songs could be heard playing in most of the localities as children played with their sprinklers and played colours with their friends.Water balloons and spray guns were the main weapons of the children who did not spare even passersby.Soaked in revelry of the festival of colours, people could be seen dancing on foot-tapping numbers. Later people visited their friends and relatives and enjoyed gujhiya and other delicacies prrepared on the festive occasion.On Wednesday people celebrated Bhai Dooj as sisters applied tilak on forehead of their brothers wishing for their well being.

Title: Cops suspect sex racket in Malappuram
Content:
Malappuram: After the report of sexual abuse of a minor Assamese girl at Kottakkal, similar cases of forceful prostitution of Assamese girls are being reported in Malappuram and Ponnani, and child welfare authorities and police suspect the role of coordinated rackets which are sexually misusing minor girls from other states for flesh trade in the state.

It was on Tuesday that Kottakkal police arrested three persons including a couple from Assam for forcing a 12-year-old Assamese girl for prostitution. It was the couple from Assam who brought the girl to Kottakkal.
