An Edarikode native Muhammed Ali who is owner of the rented quarters in which the girl was staying, was also arrested for supporting the abuse of girl.

On Wednesday, Malappuram police took three Assam natives , including the girl’s mother, into custody for forcing a 13-year-old Assamese girl for prostitution. The family was staying at a rented quarter in Melmuri. Police have collected statement of the girl and the arrest of the accused would be recorded later.

According to the statement given by the girl in Malappuram to ChildLine authorities, Muhammed Ali, who was arrested in connection with the Kottakkal incident coordinated the activities of the gang and she was presented to many people with the support of her mother.

Meanwhile Childline authorities in Ponnani have initiated probe into the complaint that an Assamese minor girl in Ponnani was sexually abused by several persons.

Child Welfare Committee (CWC) chairman Shajesh Bhasakar said that the similarity in the operation of gangs in Kottakkal and Malappuram is pointing to the possibility of involvement of sex rackets, which are sexually misusing the girls from other states such as Assam, Bengal and Orissa for monetary purposes and the details of fresh case reported in Ponnani would be available soon. “The victim girl in Kottakkal has already revealed to Childline volunteers that she was raped by several persons and the girl in Malappuram also revealed the same. Authorities have seized mobile phones with nude photographs of several minor girls and we have learnt that the gang was operating the racket using a WhatsApp group”, he said. CWC chairman said that only an investigation by a special team of police can conduct a detailed probe coordinating the investigation on cases registered at different police stations in the district.

Title: Coronavirus takes toll on festivals & fairs, Shri Nath Mahotsav cancelled in Aurangabad
Content: AURANGABAD: The Aurangabad district administration has called off the centuries-old tradition of celebrating the Shri Nath Shashthi Mahotsav — on the birth anniversary of Sant Eknath — at Paithan in Aurangabad in view of the Covid-19 scare.This is the first time in its history of about 425 years that the festival will not be held at the Shri Nath temple.The district administration cited statistics and guidelines issued by World Health Organisation (WHO) as well as that of ministry of health and family welfare, for calling off the festival. The administration stated the decision was taken to ensure that there is no coronavirus outbreak.Last week, state minister Sandipan Bhumre had announced that the Mahotsav would take place as per the schedule. The locals had then started preparing for the festival. They were taken aback when acting district magistrate Bhandudas Palve on Tuesday issued orders calling off the event.The Sansthan Shri Eknath Maharaj Vishvasth Mandal, a group of trustees, organise the Shri Nath Shashthi Mahotsav every year. Every year, at least a million people visit the temple situated on the banks of Godavari river. The place also has the Nath Samadhi.Mangir Baba fair andTableegh Ijtema uncertainWith the ministry of health and family welfare issuing an advisory asking the administration to abstain from granting permission for events where a large number of people may gather, there are doubts whether the Mangir Baba fair and the Tableegh Ijtema will be held this year. While Tableegh Ijtema is set to start on March 28, the annual Mangir Baba fair is scheduled to begin from April 10.

Title: Irumpanam: Fire breaks out at BPCL yard
Content:
Fire force officials said that more than 25 fire units worked for nearly two hours to bring the fire under con... Read More

KOCHI: A major fire was reported near the tank wagon gantry of the Bharat Petroleum Chemicals Pvt Ltd (BPCL) at Irumpanam on Wednesday afternoon, causing panic among Irumpanam residents for a few hours.

Source said the fire was reported at 2.30pm after leakage in one of the main fuel pipelines, linking the storage tank of naphtha and aviation oil, near the tank wagon gantry along Seaport-Airport Road. Official sources said the situation remained under control and no casualties were reported. The cause of the fire is yet to be ascertained.

Fire force officials said more than 25 fire units from fire force units in the district worked for nearly two hours to bring the fire under control. Fire tenders from Kottayam, Alappuzha, Thrissur, and Palakkad were also pressed into service, officials said. Fire units from BPCL, IOC and HPCL too joined the fire-fighting exercise.

Sources said the residents heard a sound of blast by 2.45pm and smoke billowed inside the plant sending around 32 families residing in the area into panic mode. “We panicked as we were not sure whether the wagons lined up in the Irumpanam yard were filled or empty,” said Pradeep Kumar C N, a resident.

“The fire spread to the nearby grass. Now it is extinguished and it is fully under control,” said a BPCL spokesperson.

The fire was brought under control by 5.45pm following efforts of nearly 100 firemen, officials said.

Title: In Kochi, CNG buses losing charm with private bus operators
Content: KOCHI: The private bus operators who were planning to convert their diesel buses to compressed natural gas (CNG) powered vehicles are now not keen to go ahead with their plans. The reason? Diesel price has decreased, making the option of converting to CNG less attractive, as price gap between the two fuels has come down below Rs 10.“CNG looks attractive when diesel prices are high. Bus operators will be willing to change to CNG only if there is a difference of at least Rs 15 as it will be profitable for them. Otherwise, they will not be keen to convert,” said TJ Raju, president of Kochi Metropolitan Transport Cooperative Society Ltd (KMTC), adding that the government should take efforts to combat falling CNG prices.While private bus operators are willing to convert BS2 buses to CNG, they are not interested in converting BS3 vehicles, Raju added. “That means, buses up to 2010 models can be converted,” he said. He expressed the opinion that CNG buses will begin services in the city by March 31.The first bus, which was converted to CNG in New Delhi and brought to Kochi, is currently being used as a demo bus. Though all relevant documents of the bus have been submitted for approval, Raju said that he is yet to receive it. The plan was to introduce at least 400 such buses in the city. It costs Rs 3-3.5 lakh for converting a bus running on diesel to a CNG-fuelled bus.A Delhi-based private company has also expressed interest in opening a unit in Kalamassery for converting diesel buses to CNG operated buses. The representative of the firm said that they have submitted applications before RTO for setting up the workshop.“Apart from the private buses, there are school buses and buses operated by various institutions. There will be a good clientele in Kochi,” said a representative of the firm.Meanwhile, transport secretary KR Jyothilal said that there are conversion kits approved by Automotive Research Association of India (ARAI). The International Centre for Automotive Technology (ICAT) also certifies CNG conversion. “There are approved kits and authorised workshops. After conversion, the vehicle owners will have to get the entry changed in RC book as CNG from diesel. There are no other hindrances,” he said.However, on a question whether the price benefits of CNG will be passed on to the commuters, the bus operators said that it would not be possible. The commuters will have to pay the same rates applicable to diesel buses.Meanwhile, the Ernakulam Auto Rickshaw Drivers Co-operative Society said that the main obstacle they face is the lack of charging facilities for e-autorickshaws. Around 200 e-autos are expected to arrive in the city during March-April. “The local body and other transport agencies should take the initiative to provide sufficient charging points,” said MB Syamanthabhadran, representative of the society.The auto drivers said that they have to pay a rent of Rs 350 for using these vehicles. They charge commuters a minimum fare of Rs 40 and if passengers are willing to share the fare, each one of them will have to shell out Rs 10 for travelling 2km distance.

Title: Tamil Nadu’s Winning Assist for ISL final
Content:
Chennai: It was 2012 when Edwin Sydney Vanspaul and M Soosairaj squared up against each other in the annual Reverend Father LD Murphy Memorial football tournament final, organised by Loyola College. It was Soosairaj, representing Madras Christian College, who triumphed on that occasion, as a penalty miss by Edwin proved costly for Loyola.

Eight years later, Edwin and Soosai will come up against each other once again. But this time, it will be on the biggest stage of Indian football — the Indian Super League (ISL) final between Chennaiyin FC and ATK . Till a few years ago young footballers from the state didn’t dare to dream big in football. Now, the journeys of Edwin and Soosai mirror the meteoric rise of Tamil Nadu football.

While Edwin from Neyveli played a major role in helping the Chennaiyin’s path to the final, Eraviputhenthurai’s Soosai did it for Kolkata’s ATK. Apart from them Chennai’s Dhanpal Ganesh (CFC) and Michael Regin (ATK), who is also Soosai’s elder brother, are expected to be on the team lists for Saturday’s summit clash.

The 27-year-old Edwin from Neyveli said it was beyond his expectations to see four Tamil Nadu footballers playing in the ISL final. "We have a common WhatsApp group and the other day we were discussing how life has changed for us. Till a few years ago, we never thought we would make the ISL, leave alone play in the final. Now, people recognise us. It’s a privilege and we are willing to work hard to prove that we belong here," Edwin told TOI.

Soosai, who has been engaging in social media banter with Edwin over the past few days, says their feat will open avenues for TN’s aspiring footballers. "It shows that if you have talent, skill and ambition, no one can stop you from realising your dream. It is about having the hunger and desire to use the platform and exposure ISL provides you. I hope this is only the beginning and we can inspire the next generation of footballers from the state," said Soosai.

Indeed, their achievements have gone beyond the field. Soosai, who comes from a fishing community, is proving to be a source of inspiration back from for the entire Kanyakumari district. "There was a time when people would leave fishing to play football. But with nothing much happening they lost interest. Now, that interest is back," Soosai said.

People from the 12 coastal villages near Soosai’s hometown now set up giant screens to watch ATK’s matches after their daily chores. Soosai said with football academies coming up young talent is being guided and things are getting more structured. "In Kanyakumari, we only play football. When I go home, many kids would ask me about my diet, routine, practice style … I would talk to them about off-season training and pre-match exercises. They are keen to follow it and make football a profession," Soosai said.

Behind these inspirational tales, there lies a story of anguish and frustration too. For the past two years, there has been no Chennai Football Association senior division league, a breeding ground for state footballers, due to differences between Tamil Nadu Football Association (TFA) and Chennai Football Association (CFA). Under the circumstances, whatever little opportunity the players have been getting is through the scouting process of Chennaiyin and former I-League champions Chennai City FC, based in Coimbatore.

Former India defender N Mohanraj, who has played in both ISL and I-League, said it is important that TFA and CFA cash in on the popularity of these footballers. "Last year, TN colts emerged runners-up in U-19 league. This means there is talent. But then there is a high chance that these talents might get lost as they don’t have a league to hone their skills," the Namakkal player said.

Edwin credits the grind of the CFA league for his progress. "Whatever might be our achievements, we can’t overlook that there is no proper football structure yet in our state. So the CFA league gives us game time and playing in the heat prepares us better. So it is my plea to the officials to sort out the differences and restart the league. Otherwise, our efforts will go waste and there might not be any more Soosais and Edwins," he said.

Title: Telcos to ensure high bandwidth
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: IT department , anticipating a hike in internet usage , met telecom providers on Wednesday to explore possibilities of ensuring uninterrupted internet as people are avoiding public contacts after new Covid-19 cases were reported recently in state. Telecom providers agreed to raise 30-40% efficiency of their services considering the emergency where more people are working from home or switching to digital options for various needs.

After a cabinet decision on Tuesday, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan, who is also the minister for IT, had assigned electronics and IT department to ensure that necessary steps are taken considering the rise in use of internet-based services.

Then, IT secretary T Sivasankar and department officials met representatives of Reliance Jio, BSNL, Vodafone, Airtel, Asianet, Tata Teleservice and central power grid corporation. tnn

Title: Rs 59 crore of government’s loan waiver money stuck in Yes Bank
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: About Rs 59 crores, one of the instalments that Aurangabad district central cooperative (ADCC) bank limited was supposed to get from the state under the farm loan waiver scheme, is stuck in the Yes Bank after the Reserve Bank of India imposed a withdrawal limit of Rs 50,000 a month on the customers.

The ADCC has shot a letter to the state government requesting them to help clear the situation.

ADCC director Abhijit Deshmukh told TOI, “We have written a letter to the government seeking their intervention in getting our Rs 59 crore of farm loan waiver stuck with Yes Bank. We are hopeful that the government will address the issue at the earliest.”

Only the major banking players such as Yes Bank are direct members of RBI, while the smaller as well as mid-rung ones including the cooperative banks are sub-members of RBI.

The money released from government is routed through its member banks, which further pass it to the sub-member banks.

ADCC has about eight lakh bank accounts, out of which, close to two lakh are loan accounts, with majority of them being crop loans. As on date, ADCC has total outstanding of Rs 900 crores in loans.

Sources in the bank said that they were to get about Rs 350 crores of the crop loan under the new Maharashtra government’s waiver scheme.

The state government announced farm loan waiver of up to Rs 2 lakh each last December. The first and second list of beneficiaries comprising about 21.82 lakh beneficiaries, who would be eligible for the waiver, has been released.

The money was to be disbursed from last week but the RBI restrictions on not allowing withdrawal of more than Rs 50,000 from Yes Bank hit transactions of at least 100 cooperative, mid and lower-rung banks in the state that routed transactions through the bank.

Title: Holi howler: 4 drown in separate incidents
Content:
Chandrapur: Four revellers, including an 11-year-old boy, drowned in separate incidents at different places during Holi celebrations on Tuesday. Sanskar Mogre (11) drowned in a deep ditch meant to excavate the red-soil (murum) for road construction near village Nandgaon Furdi in Gondpipri tehsil on Tuesday morning.

Sanksar and five other boys had gone to the ditch to bathe. The ditch was full of water due to the recent rains. After taking a dip in the 7.5 feet water, Sanskar did not come up. His body was recovered by Gondpipri police.

In another incident, Akhil Kamdiwar (27) from village Kavthi in Pombhurna teshil, died due to drowning in Andhari River at Bhivkund point. He entered the river to have a bath after playing Holi, but got drowned.

In third incident, Ankit Dave (26) from Warora town drowned in Wardha River. He had gone to have a bath with seven of his friends after celebrating Holi. Dave got stuck in the underwater shrubs. His body was fished out by expert divers on Wednesday.

An unidentified person, too, drowned. He was trying to cross the Vainganga River to go to Kharkada, his village in Bramhapuri tehsil on Tuesday.

Title: 3 corporators along with many out of voter list: Ex-corporator
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: Former corporator Sameer Rajurkar has claimed that at least one lakh voters’ names have either been reshuffled or have gone missing even as a claim has been made that the names of at least three sitting corporators are missing from the list.

“Althought the civic body on March 9 published a draft voters list, it is not available on its website. The administration has not yet made it available in the zone offices,” Rajurkar told reporters on Wednesday.

“It has now become difficult to ascertain and cross-check the voters’ names in the list,” he said.

Kaleem Qureshi, an activist whose family members were representing three wards, said the names of Shabnam Kaleem Qureshi, Malika Habib Qureshi and Khatija Qureshi were deliberately dropped from the list.

He said that even his name and that of his brother were missing from the draft list, though they were in the 2015 list.

Qureishi said he made a representation to the mayor in this regard. “I will pursue a legal course against those involved in such affairs as I suspect that it was done deliberately. Otherwise, there is no scope for my family members’ names along with about 500 others to go missing from the voters’ list.’’

Sources in the civic body pointed out that between 1,500 and 2,300 voters from Rozabagh (ward 13), Chetnanagar (ward 4) ward have been added to ward No 14 Wankhedenagar-Honajinagar.

“Voters too have been shifted from ward 53 (Samarthnagar) to the Kotla colony ward. Similarly, names of voters are missing from wards including Nageshwarwadi, Sillegkhan to elsewhere,” the sources said.

Rajurkar said that when according to the rules, the number of voters in a ward has to be between 7,000 and 9,000, several wards have the number between 3,500 and 4,800, while 28 to 30 wards have around 6,000. He said that 650 to 700 voters from Aurangpura have been added to the Gulandi ward.’’

Rajurkar demanded that the administration and election officials concerned institute an inquiry into the whole affair and urged them to add the voters of the Samarthnagar ward, which he represented earlier, to their original wards according to the 2015 voters’ list.

Rajurkar added that he has decided to challenge the voters’ list by filing his objections, but he wanted to alert people so that they check their names in the list to know whether they have been shifted to other wards or their names are missing.

Title: Courts, State Central Library introduce curbs
Content: T’puram: Concerns over Covid-19 has hit the judiciary too. The principal district and sessions judge here on Wednesday issued a directive to adjourn cases till Friday and consider only emergency cases in the bench to avoid crowding inside court rooms and on the premises of courts.District judge K Babu has directed all judicial officers in the district to adjourn all cases and always consider adjournments requested by lawyers or parties even in emergency matters.Only those cases that have to be considered in a time-bound manner, such as bail applications of under-trial prisoners and producing accused persons arrested by the police, will be considered without any change. Routine sittings of criminal cases and civil cases may be adjourned for a later date, the judge held.Jail authorities were informed that the under-trial prisoners need not be produced before the courts till Friday. However, there is no restriction in carrying out procedures with regard to remand extension of under-trial prisoners via video conferencing facility.The district judge also directed all court staff, especially those who directly deal with the public, to wear masks and use hand-sanitizer as instructed by the health department.The State Central Library authorities too have introduced some regulations in the functioning of the library in view of concerns over spread of Covid-19. The librarian on Wednesday issued a statement appealing the members to visit the library only if it is utmost necessary.The reference section and internet browsing section of the library will be closed from March 16 to 31. Reading rooms will function only from 8am to 11am on these days.Entry will be banned for foreigners. The touch screen information kiosk and children’s section and park will also be shut down. Children will not be allowed to sit together and study in the library.They have also cancelled a few programmes to be held in the library this summer. This include a discussion on the novel ‘Mamangam’ authored by Sajeev Pillai, which was scheduled for Friday, a poetry fest scheduled on April 4 and summer school that was scheduled to commence on April 14.

Title: Rs 903 crore for rail infra projects and safety works in Uttarakhand : Piyush Goyal
Content:
Piyush Goyal

DEHRADUN: Union railways minister Piyush Goel, on Wednesday, told the Lok Sabha that Rs 903 crore has been allotted to Uttarakhand in the Union Budget for infrastructure projects and safety works. The minister added that this amount is “383% more than the average of the Budget outlay in the state from 2009 to 2014.” He was responding to a question asked by Nainital BJP MP Ajay Bhatt about budgetary allocation to Uttarakhand. Bhatt had sought the details of the Budget allocation and also of the projects of new rail lines and their doubling/electrification works in Uttarakhand.

Goyal told the House that a new railway line is being laid between Rishikesh-Karnaprayag (125.09 km), Kichha-Khatima (57.70 km), and Deoband (Muzzafar Nagar)-Roorkee (27.45 km). Meanwhile, railway line doubling work is also being carried out between Haridwar-Laksar (27.03 km), added the minister.

Giving out the progress of the Rishikesh- Karnaprayag railway line, Goyal said that Rs 1,361 crore was spent on the project by March, 2020. The project is estimated at Rs 16,216 crore. The Union minister said that the works regarding final location survey, land acquisition, forest clearance, geo-technical investigation, and approach road for the entire project have been completed. He added that works in the first block section between Virbhadra and Yognagri, Rishikesh (5.7 km) has been taken up. This includes the completion of a Road Under Bridge and a Road Over Bridge in Rishikesh. “The construction of an important rail bridge over Chandrabhaga river near Rishikesh has been taken up. In remaining sections, construction of Rail Bridge Number 8 at Lachmoli and Bridge Number 9 at Srinagar over Alaknanda river has been taken up,” Goel told the House.

Title: Furore after rumour spread on meat burning in Holika
Content:
Rudrapur: Passions ran high after rumours spread that unsocial elements have thrown meat and bones in ‘Holika Dahan’ ceremony in Jaspur of US Nagar district on Monday night. Police reached the spot and pacified the mass gathering after showing them that the ashes did not have any bones.

Sources said that after setting fire to the Holika at the Holi Chowk near Mohalla Bhoop Singh, residents complained of a smell similar to the burning of meat and bones of animals. The police and the fire department were informed. The firemen extinguished the fire and police officials showed the locals that there were no bones or flesh burnt

Title: ‘Civic chiefs have to be fair and impartial’
Content:
Shyam Wardhane

Should the budget be head-wise or general?

Budget has to be head and even sub-head wise. They are important for prioritising work. Income received under a particular head and expenditure incurred on a particular work need to monitored for maintaining financial discipline in any organization and more so in public sector.

Do standing committee chairpersons present unrealistic budgets?

Yes. The standing committee chairman and members worry more about development works. They expect to meet aspirations of the people who they represent. In order to match the figures of expenditure, they increase the figures of income without considering the actual income received in the earlier three years.

Why does corporation fail to meet its revenue target year after year?

This happens due to lack of proper enforcement and monitoring system. There has to be checks and balances when it comes to valuation of property and it may happen that the property has more rateable value but assessed at a lower side causing loss to the corporation. When I was posted in the civic body, I exposed how shops near Law College Square were being taxed on the basis of residential properties though the civic body was supposed to levy commercial tax.

How should municipal commissioners deal with elected representatives?

Municipal commissioners have to be fair and impartial. He must respect every member because a corporator represents thousands of citizens. They are the elected representatives. We, as officers, have accepted the democratic principle. So, in my opinion democratically elected representatives need to be respected. Municipal commissioner has to adopt appropriate communication policy, plan and strategise for effective communication.

Have you ever faced political pressure during your tenure as municipal commissioner? How did you deal with it?

Yes. But I could convince the politicians through proper explanations. Sometimes, by refusing to do the things which rules and regulations do not allow. One can explain the difficulty in implementation. Maintaining transparency as regards to works done and works pending suggested by the elected representatives.

Should the municipal commissioner heed to advice from mayor and standing committee chairmen?

Yes, he should interact with all. He should take advice of various office bearers and senior officers of the local body but act only in accordance with law.

(Shyam Wardhane was commissioner of Nagpur Municipal Corporation from August 2012 to January 2015)

Title: Shiv Sena wants Aurangabad civic poll put off over Covid-19 concerns
Content: AURANGABAD: The Shiv Sena , which is in power in the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC), also wants the Election Commission of India to defer the election to the civic body, considering the concerns over coronavirus infections.The All India Majlis-e-Ittehad-ul-Muslimeen (MIM) had made a similar demand a few days ago. The term of existing civic body is scheduled to come to an end on April 27.Talking to the media on Wednesday, mayor Nandkumar Ghodele of the Shiv Sena said the poll panel must defer the election by at least six months.“The patients with coronavirus have been detected in Maharashtra. Although Aurangabad has not reported any case of the disease so far, it will be wise to put off the polls for the civic body by at least six month,” he said.Ghodele said the health authorities have issued an advisory asking citizens to avoid mass gatherings. “The election process involves holding rallies and public meetings, involving a large number of people. Therefore, we demand postponement of AMC election till the coronavirus is contained in the country,” the mayor said.The mayor said he would contact chief minister Udhhav Thackeray with their plea of deferring AMC polls.Earlier, MIM MP of Aurangabad Imtiyaz Jaleel had demanded that AMC polls be postponed. “Rallies of different political parties are inevitable during election and therefore it is desirable to put off election,” Jaleel had said on March 9.The Aurangabad municipal corporation came into existence on December 8,1982. Among its 115 members, 29 are from Shiv Sena, MIM (24), BJP (23), Congress (11), BSP (5), NCP (4) and RPI (2) along with 17 independents. The civic body has five co-opted members.

Title: Gujarat: Green Alang set to beckon more ships for recycling
Content: RAJKOT: Alang , the graveyard of ageing ships , is set to regain its glory that was dimmed by global downturn and unregulated markets of Bangladesh and Pakistan.After India ratified the Hong Kong international convention, which is aimed at environmentally safe ship recycling, Japan and Norway have committed to sending 40 ships each for breaking at Alang. This was disclosed by Union shipping minister Mansukh Mandaviya to TOI.Last December, the Union government had passed the landmark ‘The Recycling of Ships Bill 2019’ that not only provides for environmentally sound recycling of ships but safety of shipyard workers too.“Out of the 134 plots in Alang, 95 have been certified by international agency for adhering to the Hong Kong convention norms. Japan and Norway have committed to sending 40 ships each to Alang. We are optimistic that the European countries and the US too will prefer Alang now,” Mandaviya said.“The European countries and the US will now send ships to Alang for recycle process since we have adopted the international standard for the safety of the workers and maintenance of environment.”While Hong Kong convention was proposed in 2009, the Gujarat Maritime Board (GMB) had already started work on making Alang environmentally safer. “We have already got the first mover advantage by making several plots compliant with Hong Kong convention. This will help them attract more business and more ships will come for recycling in India,” said Mukesh Kumar, vice-chairman and CEO, GMB.According to an estimate, nearly 300 ships come to India for recycling and 90% of them prefer Alang.Vishnu Gupta, president of Ship Recycling Industries Association said, “We had started preparations to meet international environment standards since 2016 and the results are showing. In January and February, Alang got 30 and 25 ships for breaking respectively as against the average of 15-20 every month.”Atul Sharma, general manager (environment), GMB, said, “Over the years, we have done extensive work to make Alang safe for environment and humans too. Unlike earlier, the polluting waste like oil which was incinerated is now being reprocessed. Similarly metal cables and batteries of the ships which were also incinerated are now being purchased by empanelled vendors.”The shipping ministry is also considering to set up competent authority for issuing ‘ready for recycle’ certificate for ships coming to India at Alang.

Title: Coronavirus in Kerala: Strict vigil at sealed resort
Content:
Representative image

KOLLAM: Chirakkara grama panchayath authorities, revenue and police have made efforts to keep watch on the 42 foreign tourists who have been quarantined over Covid-19 fears at an Ayurvedic resort and homestay here.

Following reports that some foreign tourists who had travelled along with the Pathanamthitta natives from Italy on the same flight were staying at the Mythri Ayurvedic resort and homestay at Chirakkara, revenue authorities sealed the homestay on Tuesday night and ordered to quarantine 42 tourists and 30 employees working there for 28 days.

Deputy collector Sumeethan Pillai had inspected the homestay and sealed it. Further, police personnel have also been posted at the homestay to prevent any of the tourists or employees going out breaching the orders.

Health standing committee chairman of Chirakkara grama panchayath Ullas Krishnan said there were 39 people from France and three from Belgium staying there. He said only three French men had travelled with the Pathanamthitta natives on the same flight.

“The foreign tourists usually stay from January to June here at the homestay. All the 42 people staying here have come at different times. They are not part of a single group. They came separately,” he said.

According to reports, the resort had more bookings from foreigners and many of them were on their way to here. “However, we have given strict orders not to accommodate or let anyone go out till the situation is brought to normal and the threat of pandemic is over,” he said.

However, asked whether the resort was unauthorised as stated by the deputy collector who sealed it on Tuesday, Kirshnan admitted that panchayath had issued only a building licence to operate the business.

“What the panchayath issued was an initial licence to start business. The rest of the licences had to be obtained from the District tourism promotion council and other government authorities as relevant for running a resort,” he said.

Asked whether there was any other resorts functioning legally or illegally in the panchayath accommodating foreign tourists, he said they had conducted a thorough checking and no other foreign tourists could be found anywhere else in the panchayath.

Ullas Krishnan said they had ensured that all the natives coming from foreign countries including gulf countries were sent to the Public Health centre for the initial screening to ensure that they don’t have any symptoms of covid -19.

In view of the presence of foreign tourists who had travelled along with the Pathanamthitta natives staying in the nearby Chirakkara , an awarness campaign was held at Kottiaym and neighbouring places under the aegis of the SFI, Kottiyam area committee. SFI Kottiyam area secretary Sachindas told TOI that they had distributed pamphlets at major junctions besides launching a house to house campaign to sensitize people that instead of getting panic, people should take extra vigil against the virus spread. He said the campaign would be continued in the coming days.

Title: Nine-year-old raped near Modasa
Content:
Palanpur: A nine-year-old girl was allegedly raped by a 21-year-old man in a village of Aravalli district on Tuesday.

The crime was reported from Davli Van Dada village, some 20 km from Modasa.

Police said that the accused Kamlesh Rabari from Bhuval village in Meghraj taluka had come to his maternal uncle’s house to celebrate Holi. He picked up the girl who was playing dhuleti and took her to an empty trough and allegedly raped her.

After reaching home, she narrated the ordeal to her mother who lodged a complaint against Rabari. The girl has been hospitalized and police have arrested Rabari.

Title: Covid-19 hits agitations too
Content: T’puram: Concerns over increase in number of Covid-19 cases in the state has hit the protesters engaged in various agitations in the city, especially on the footpath in front of the secretariat.The agitators involved in the protest against CAA in front of the secretariat called off their agitation that was going on for more than a month in view of the unsafe conditions prevailing over the virus outbreak in the state. The agitators on Wednesday dismantled their makeshift tent under which they were staging the protest and cleared the place.Another major group that is staging an agitation nearby, Justice for Walayar Kids Forum, is also toying with the idea of calling off the agitation until favourable conditions return. They cancelled a collective hunger strike of 50 agitators to mark the 50th day of the agitation on Wednesday.“The members of our forum were staging relay hunger strike. We will hold discussions and will take a decision,” said forum convener Prasad Somarajan, adding that going on with the protest will only put the lives of their members as well as others at risk.The police said that they did not ask the agitators to clear the spot and it was the agitators’ own decision to do so. Anti-CAA protesters and Walayar Kids Forum were the only two major groups that were staging agitations in front of the secretariat at present. Barring them there are three protests by individuals going on at the spot. All three individuals are still continuing their agitation.

Title: Mayoral posts reserved for women in Jodhpur
Content:
Jodhpur: Lottery for the reserved wards of the municipal corporations of Jodhpur North and Jodhpur South was carried out at the Mini Auditorium here on Wednesday.

None of the parties expressed dismay, whatsoever, with the lottery, especially in the wake of both the posts of mayors having gone to female candidates.

“This lottery does not seem to affect the political prospects of any aspiring candidate from Congress and everything would be settled while fielding the candidates,” said Ajay Trivedi, spokesperson, Congress.

As per the lottery, 33 wards have gone to the general category in the municipal corporation (North), while 16 wards have been reserved for female candidates.

Ten wards have gone to OBC and seven to OBC (female) categories, while eight wards have gone to SC and four to SC (female). One each have gone to ST and ST (female) categories.

Similarly, 36 wards in municipal corporation (South) have gone to general category and 17 have gone to female candidates in general category.

OBC and OBC (female) categories have got 11 and six wards, respectively, while six wards have gone to SC category with three to SC (female). One ward has gone to ST category.

According to ADM Madan Lal Nehra, the printing of the electoral rolls will be undertaken on March 12 for the municipal election.

Title: Corona virus suspected in 26-yr-old man
Content: Rajkot: A 26-year-old man in Rajkot has been sent to the isolation ward of Rajkot civil hospital after he is suspected of having Covid-19 symptoms on Wednesday. The man, who had returned from France, has complained of fever, cold and throat pain and after he went for a check-up, the general physician suspected the symptoms to be similar to corona virus and informed the district health officers. A team of district health nodal officer verified the symptoms and shifted him to the isolation ward. His samples have been sent to G G hospital Jamnagar for test, the results of which are expected to come by Thursday. According to health officials, a 42-year-old woman from Paddadhri who was found H1N1 positive, has been shifted to a private hospital in Rajkot.

Title: 50 wards reserved for women in Jaipur Greater, 33 in Heritage
Content:
Jaipur: The lottery to reserve seats ahead of the municipal corporation elections, scheduled to be held in April, was conducted in Jaipur, Jodhpur and Kota on Wednesday.

In Jaipur district, 50 wards were reserved for women candidates in Jaipur Greater Nagar Nigam and 33 in Jaipur Heritage Nagar Nigam.

The six newly formed Nagar Nigams are Jaipur Heritage and Jaipur Greater (Jaipur), Jodhpur North and Jodhpur South (Jodhpur), Kota North and Kota South (Kota). While 150 wards were carved out in Jaipur Greater, 100 were created in Jaipur Heritage after delimitation. In Jaipur Greater, 32 wards were reserved for OBC, 22 for scheduled caste, 7 for scheduled tribe and 89 for the general category.

In Jaipur Heritage, 21 wards were reserved for OBC, 11 for scheduled caste, 3 for scheduled tribe and 65 for the general category.

Meanwhile, BJP MLA Kalicharan Saraf on Wednesday expressed dissatisfaction with the delimitation of wards, saying, “Bapu Nagar has been divided into two parts. But, the people’s represenatatives were not invited during the delimitation process of wards.”

Former mayor and MLA Ashok Lahoti alleged that there were many irregularities in the delimitation process. “The wards were not re-organised proportionally. More than 40 objections were raised in Sanganer during the delimitation process. Even the electoral roll was manipulated,” he alleged.

District collector Joga Ram said, “They (the BJP MLAs) had raised a few observations with regard to the delimitation process, which was conducted by the municipal corporation and not collectorate. They didn’t raise any objection with regard to the lottery process.”

In Kota, district collector Om Kasera conducted the lottery for Kota North and South municipal corporations. In Kota North, 11 wards have been reserved for general category and five wards for women and in Kota South, eight wards were reserved for general category and four for women.

Title: Grave History, Messy Geography, Rotten Civics
Content:
Standing from left: Anand Chandwani, Dinesh Naidu, Tejinder Singh Renu, Gopal Bhutada. Sitting from left: Mari... Read More

The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) is biting off more than it can chew. This is evident from the inflated budgets presented by successive NMC standing committee chairmen over the years, said chartered accountant Kailash Jogani. “Provision for expenditure is made accordingly. There is bound to be financial trouble when the receipts fall way short of the target and expenditures keep on increasing,” he said.

According to Gopal Bhutada, a homeopathy practitioner, the problem lies with the NMC administration and not with the people’s representatives.

Taking a tough stance over the financial mess in the NMC, the new municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe stopped all development works before the NMC house prevailed over his decision. Questioning the civic chief’s approach, Bhutada said why didn’t Mundhe take similar steps when he was the CEO of Nagpur Zilla Parishad to resolve financial issues there. “The commissioner should first set his house in order,” said Bhutada.

Presenting a counter view, Dinesh Naidu, secretary, Parivartan: The Citizens’ Forum, declared that the NMC is the most mismanaged civic body in the country. “The revenue is poor and the NMC is solely dependent on funds from the state government . This is mainly because the corporators are incapable,” he said.

Trying to explain the revenue deficit, Prashant Ugemuge, an entrepreneur , said that abolition of octroi was a major dent. “Octroi brought regular cash flow to NMC. Now, the property tax collection is low and the civic body can’t rely on GST compensation. Efforts are not being taken to resolve property tax disputes. Instead, suggestions like dissolving NMC are being made, which seems more like a political agenda,” he said.

The problem is an accumulation of inaction over the years, felt Piyali Kanabar, a schoolteacher. “There have always been discrepancies in NMC functioning. Despite complaints, those have been left unrectified,” she said.

Instead of getting the property assessment process done in the right manner, the civic body is trying to squeeze more out of the existing taxpayers, observed Tejinder Singh Renu, secretary of Vidarbha Taxpayers Association. According to him, many don’t even receive the property tax demand. “The NMC should target new properties,” he said and added that the state government should increase GST share to local bodies for their smooth functioning.

Businessman Anand Chandwani blamed inaction by the NMC administration against tax defaulters on political interference. “Lower rung officers don’t do what is necessary fearing backlash from the netas,” he said, and added that this attitude will ruin the civic body.

Chandwani also claimed that honest taxpayers are being exploited but denied even the basic facilities they deserve.

Taking the point forward, Jogani said the system in Nagpur is discriminatory. Demanding a scientific assessment, he said that owners of old properties are being made to pay higher taxes, while the newer ones are paying less.

For Maria Shakir, an entrepreneur, one of the major issues is the lack of communication and information. She also puts the onus on citizens to check whether the civic body is functioning properly. Kanabar sees mismanagement in many aspects of its functioning. Giving an example, she said that the civic body is not transferring the excess teachers in NMC schools and paying salaries for literally no work.

Given the mismanagement in civic services, can roping in private agencies to handle them improve things? Kanabar said there is a flip side to privatization. Bhutada too finds a problem. “The agencies are appointed through political patronage,” he said. Giving his take, Ugemuge said private agencies have no option but to establish political links to bag contracts.

Offering a solution to increase NMC income, Jogani said that every property in NMC limits must be assessed properly. He even suggested generating income from unutilized properties of the civic body. “Rents should be charged for hoardings scientifically,” he said.

“New properties needs to be brought under tax net. Lease ground rent of NMC properties should be increased gradually, taking into confidence the lessees thereon to avoid litigation,” said Renu.

On the calling attention motion by four Shiv Sena MLAS from Mumbai to dissolve the NMC citing that the civic body has collapsed financially, Renu felt that there has been no misuse of funds but over ambitious projects like London Street and malls should be put on hold. “All unproductive expenses like welcome gate, political statues and likewise need to be scrapped,” he said. Kanabar gave example of Futala Road work as one of the unwanted projects.

Jogani too said that funds were misused in gardens and constructing cement roads in every lane when it was not needed. Adding to this, Shakir said new roads are dug up in no time, and then again money is spent on its repairs. “This is due to lack of coordination between various department,” she said.

Questioning the need for cement roads, Naidu said that tar roads too can be good but there is lot of corruption in the work, leading to poor quality. Bhutada was of the opinion that cement roads are not needed in city because they are suited only to coastal areas.

Giving his views on Mundhe’s style of functioning, Renu said that as municipal commissioner, he needs to be strict and work as per the law. “At the same time, he needs to take everybody along,” said Renu. “Mundhe is making a difference. There are so many people who attend the darbar he holds daily. Even the officers are wary of his strict functioning style,” said Naidu.

Mundhe is an example of how every municipal commissioner should work, added Ugemuge. Chandwani felt that every corporator should be easily approachable for the citizens.

Bhutada said there should be no fight between the executive and the legislature, else the common man suffers. On this, Naidu said that a pressure group is needed to take issues of citizens with the NMC. “NGOs should be called for their suggestions before a project is planned,” he said. On this, Renu said since there is no legal provision for this, people should contact their corporators and give suggestions.

Panellists also felt that the ruling party is having it easy due to lack of a strong opposition. “Opposition is only for the namesake. Can’t expect much from them. In fact, opposition and ruling party are of the same species,” he said. Kanabar added that vested interest are killing our society.

Renu was of the opinion that the opposition members are less in numbers and also a divided lot. “Still, they have the option of approaching the court if they can prove any wrongdoings,” he said.

Title: 17 UP cops suspended for shirking work on Holi
Content:
Bijnor: Police in UP’s Bijnor have suspended its 17 personnel, including a sub-inspector (SI), who were found missing from the duty on Tuesday, the day when Holi was celebrated and leaves of all the policemen were cancelled to pre-empt any untoward incident in the communally-sensitive region.

Superintendent of police (SP) Sanjeev Tyagi had cancelled the leaves of all police personnel, and had also asked those who were on leave to join duty. Six towns and 46 villages of the district have been marked as “vulnerable” by police. And, as a precautionary measure, warning cards were issued to 3,650 people in the district who are considered “troublemakers’ by the department. The suspension of leaves was also a step in the direction to ensure safe celebrations, the SP said.

Those suspended included SI Neeraj Kumar, whose leave ended on March 7 but he did not join the duty. The others are Pintu Singh, Aanand, Satendra Kumar, Pramod Kumar, Dinesh Kumar, Anuj Rathi, Farhat Ali, Hardeep Singh, Manish Kumar, Riyajul Haq, Neerul Rathi, Sachin Tomar, Arun Kumar, Kuldeep Singh, Anuj Kumar and Mukesh Tyagi-- all constables.

All of them were suspended on the charges of “dereliction of duty and indiscipline.”

“17 police personnel have been suspended for dereliction in duty and indiscipline. Some of them went on leaves and their holidays had ended. They were asked to rejoin, but they did not comply with the instruction. Apart from that, some constables were absent without any pre-sanctioned leave.”

Title: Home quarantine for 34 Iythala families
Content:
Representative image

RANNI (PATHANAMTHITTA): Iythala, the epicentre of the Covid-19 in the state, is a small village in Pathanamthitta district. The three carriers of the novel coronavirus, who arrived from Italy, are natives of this village which come under Ranni’s Pazhavangady grama panchayat.

Currently, 34 families in Iythala are under home quarantine. These families live in the neighbourhood of the Covid-19-infected family. Already, four close relatives of the family in the village have been tested positive for Covid-19. The members of the 34 families have, in one way or the other, come into contact with the Italy-returned family.

The Iythala village is geographically divided into two parts. The Covid-19 affected area is called Meenmuttypaarra where there are 95 families residing. The other part Iythala is on the banks of Pampa River where there are more than 300 houses. This part was badly affected during the floods in 2018. In Meenmuttypaarra there is a small stream and a water fall. Though there are no schools in the ward there are two anganwadis.

Joseph Kuriakose, president of Pazhavangady grama panchayat, said the panchayat is taking care of the 34 families and is also monitoring to ensure that none of the members go out of their houses. “Most of these families are either relatives or friends of the infected family,” he said adding that the panchayat has started supplying food grains and grocery for free to the affected families. “Compared to other countries, India it is much better,” added Kuriakose whose daughter resides in California.

Bobby Abraham, a member of the Iythala ward expressed relief as the lab tests coming out are mostly negative. “We don’t fear about the spread of the disease. Only issue we are facing now is that the members of the 34 families are stuck inside their homes. Some have come for vacation. Students studying in other institutions are being asked to furnish medical certificates to re-join,” he said.

Ranni tehsildar Sajan V Kuriakose said situation is under control and normalcy will be restored soon. He also said the district administration is trying to make the shops reopen so that things will return to normalcy soon. He said he had received complaints from the public about the migrant workers chewing tobacco and pan and spitting on roads.

Title: Seven arrested for 3 murders in Kutch, Rajkot
Content:
Accused in police custody

Rajkot: Dhuleti , the festival of colours , turned gory with three murders being reported from Kutch and Rajkot on Tuesday. Seven persons were arrested for allegedly committing offences.

In Kutch, Gulam Jusab Shiru (55) was hacked to death by four assailants in Shirava village of Mandvi taluka. Police arrested Mamad Padhiyar, Abbas Shiru, Abdullah Padhiyar and Sultan Padhiyar for the crime.

According to the police, the accused had a long pending dispute with Gulam over the boundary of cattle sheds. On the fateful day, while Gulam and his son Rahim were herding out their cattle from the shed, Mamad entered into an altercation with them.

“As the altercation turned into a fight, the accused attacked Gulam and Rahim with axes and iron rods. While Gulam was killed on the spot, Rahim is battling for his life in Mandvi Civil Hospital,” said N M Chauhan, sub-inspector with Mandvi police station.

In Chobari village of Bhachau taluka in Kutch, Magha Meria (45) was rammed by a car by the accused, identified as Ramesh Varchand.

“Varchand purposefully rammed his car into Meria and killed him, as he was nursing a grudge against him after he ran into an altercation with him over an issue of driving,” said an official from Bhachau police station, adding that Varchand went absconding after the crime.

In Pad village on the outskirts of Rajkot, three persons were arrested for allegedly hacking to death Raju Ganava (24). “The accused, Shaitan Singal (32), Pappu Ajanar (50) and his son Mayalo Ajanar (21) had attacked Ganava over a financial dispute,” said an official from Lodhika police station.

Ganava’s younger brother Sanjay had eloped with Singal’s sister. As part of a compromise, Ganava had agreed to pay Rs 3.70 lakh to Singal, of which he had already paid Rs 2 lakh. Though Ganava had promised to pay the remaining amount later, Singal had started harassing him over the recovery of the amount. On the fateful day, when Singal came for the recovery, he entered into an altercation with Ganava, following which Singal and the co-accused attacked Ganava.

Title: Defying govt diktat, IIST holds classes
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: Despite the government direction to suspend regular classes in all but medical and allied educational institutions in the wake of rise in Covid-19 cases, the Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology ( IIST ) has decided to continue the academic activities without any interruption on its Valiyamala campus.A meeting held at the institute on Wednesday decided that academic activities need not to be put on hold. There was a suggestion to cancel undergraduate lab classes, for first year students only, for about two weeks. It was also decided to conduct meetings on a regular basis to assess measures against Covid-19. Five students on the campus have recently been diagnosed with H1N1.IIST director V K Dadwal said , “Since students were from all across the country, it would be impossible to send them back all at once”. However, he preferred not to respond to questions regarding how come the state government directive to close down educational institutions, except medical and nursing colleges, was not applicable to IIST.As per sources, the institute has decided to appeal all faculty members to put off official trips till March 31. It has also been decided to keep to minimum the number of faculties visiting the institute this month. Faculties who have travelled outside the city would be asked to share their travel details with the institute.

Title: 40-year-old farmer killed in road accident
Content:
Pilibhit: A 40-year-old farmer identified as Lalta Prasad of Khamaria Patti under Puranpur Kotwali police station was crushed by a speeding vehicle on Khamaria Patti-Puranpur road on Tuesday.

The farmer was returning home after exchanging Holi greetings with gram pradhan Ram Niwas. He was rushed to Puranpur community health centre by government ambulance where he was declared as “brought dead”. The police have sent the body for autopsy.

SHO Suresh Kumar Singh said the police had registered an FIR against the vehicle’s driver under sections 304 A (death caused by negligence), 279 (rash driving on public way) and 338 (causing grievous hurt) of IPC.

Title: UP: Man scolds drunk son, passer-by killed for stopping him in Moradabad
Content:
Representative image

BAREILLY: A 55-year-old man in Moradabad was battered to death, a day after Holi, on Wednesday. The man had asked his neighbour not to scold the latter’s inebriated son while celebrating the festival.

Upon interfering, the accused man had started abusing the 55-year-old. Other neighbours intervened and tried to calm them down.

On Wednesday, the accused man along with his brother and three accomplices attacked the victim again. They allegedly killed him. An FIR has been registered against five persons who are now on the run.

Police said that one Indra Singh was rebuking his son for consuming liquor on Holi when Rohtash, his neighbour, was passing by. Rohtash asked Singh not to scold his son publicly which made him angry and he started abusing him too. People gathered there intervened.

Station house officer (SHO) inspector Satyendra Panwar said that on Wednesday morning both the neighbours confronted each other again. “Indra Singh alias Joga Singh, his brother Bhoga Singh and three others reached Rohtash’s house and started thrashing him with wooden sticks. One such stick struck his head, he collapsed. The accused men then fled,” the SHO said.

Rohtash’s family took him to a hospital where doctors declared him as “brought dead”. “An FIR under section 302 (murder) has been registered against five persons and we are conducting raids to nab them. The body has been sent for postmortem,” the SHO added.

Title: Aurangabad: SPI alters pattern of entrance exam
Content:
Representative image

Aurangabad: The Services Preparatory Institute (SPI) here has introduced reforms in its entrance examination pattern, including clubbing two papers. Also, answer sheets will now have Optical Mark Recognition (OMR), which will ensure speedy and accurate assessment.

On Wednesday, SPI director Colonel Amit Dalvi said the reforms have been introduced in the entrance examination for the benefit of the students’ benefit and considering the logistics.

“Earlier, the SPI entrance had separate papers for General Ability Test (GAT) and mathematics, which used to take place on the same day with an interval between the papers. These two papers have now been clubbed,” he said.

Giving the reason behind clubbing two paper, Dalvi said students often solve GAT paper faster than the stipulated time. They can use the remaining time to solve the mathematics paper.

“Earlier, the GAT and mathematics papers were of one-and-half and two hours duration, respectively. After clubbing the two papers, the total time given for the single paper will be of three and a half-hour. It will help students in effective time management,” Dalvi said.

There is, however, no change in the marking system. GAT and mathematics will have 75 marks each. The SPI had introduced negative marking last year and it will continue. A wrong answer will result in deduction of 0.25 marks, Dalvi said.

SPI authorities also said that logistic convenience was one of the reasons behind having a single paper as the institution has limited manpower.

Five years ago, the SPI had decided to carry out two separate papers instead of one. The examination pattern, five years ago, was a single paper of 100 marks comprising questions on different subjects.

On OMR technology, Dalvi said it would help in a quick declaration of result. “We will ensure the assessment of answersheets with OMR takes place twice as per the standard procedure. It will ensure accurate and speedy results,” Dalvi said.

Title: Over 13,000 applicants in race for 60 seats at SPI in Aurangabad
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: The Services Preparatory Institute (SPI) has received 13,082 applications against the intake capacity of 60 seats for the entrance examination to secure admission to the academic year 2020-21.

The SPI, a one-of-its-kind state-run institution in Maharashtra, prepares students for admissions to defence courses. SPI director Colonel Amit Dalvi on Wednesday said almost 4,000 more (compared to last year) applications have been received this year.

“It is heartening to see the rising number of applications for SPI. This shows the ever-increasing popularity of our institution as well as ambition among students and their parents to join defence services,” he said.

Dalvi said the time-table of entrance examination for the academic year 2020-21 would be announced shortly. Followed by the entrance examination to be held in Aurangabad , Nagpur, Kolhapur and Pune, SPI authorities will conduct personal interviews of top candidates for its new batch.

Candidates studying English, Physics, Chemistry and Mathematics in Class X are eligible to appear for SPI entrance. Aspirants must have secured a minimum of 60% marks in Class VII, VIII, IX and X.

Dalvi said a set of constrains makes such proposals improbable. “The institution has limited infrastructure, physical facilities, and human resources owing to which we cannot admit more students despite our wish. Our hostels and campus can only accommodate 120 cadets (in two batches),” he said.

While in past, the government was mooting to open new institutions in other parts of Maharashtra on the line of SPI, Dalvi said a study group was formed to take a call on such decision.

“The study group was formed last year to decide on setting up new SPIs across the state. It will submit its report to the government after necessary study,” he said.

During the genesis of SPI, policy makers and authorities concerned from defence services had planned setting up of the SPI at four places in Maharashtra. While the establishment of SPI in Aurangabad could materialise in 1977, plans of remaining institutions at other places still remain at conceptual stage.

Title: BJP picks veteran leader Gehlot for RS elections
Content:
Jaipur: The BJP declared former minister and veteran leader Rajendra Gehlot (70) as its candidate for Rajya Sabha polls on Wednesday. His name came as a surprise for the party leaders who didn’t expect a veteran to be the party's candidate.

Sources said that his name was among the candidates forwarded by the RSS for the RS polls slated on March 26.

A two-term (1990-1993 and 1993-1999) from Sardarpura assembly seat in Jodhpur had lost the seat to the chief minister Ashok Gehlot in 1999 assembly polls.

His clout in the party has grown manifold during the government of Bhairon Singh Shekhawat (1993-1999) as he was elevated to the minister of prisons.

The defeat by Gehlot had stripped his political career and since then he was not given any major political role other than a post of UIT chairman of Jodhpur in 2006.

Once he was projected as a main political rival to CM Ashok Gehlot in the late eighties and in the nineties in Jodhpur.

At presently, he is holding a position of BJP vice-president but has maintained a distance from the limelight. He is keeping a low profile and believes in coming early and leaving quietly during the state-level organization meetings.

Elated over his name for the RS, Gehlot told TOI, “BJP is the only party which gives the opportunity to his grassroots workers. I now take this chance as a challenge to serve the state and western Rajasthan in a more effective manner,” said Gehlot, amid loud slogans from his supporters at his residence prior Jodhpur.

He was quick to chart out his priorities for the region, said, “Jal shakti minister Gajendra Singh Shekhawat is from Jodhpur and has taken several initiatives tackling the problem of water scarcity in the western districts. I will join hands with him in the cause and work towards providing an effective solution to the problem,” said Gehlot.

Even the BJP media cell is not prepared for the party's choice. The cell started collecting information on him after his name was announced by BJP high command.

Title: MNS plans grand Shiv Jayanti celebrations
Content:
File photo of Raj Thackerey

AURANGABAD: Maharashtra Navnirman Sena (MNS) chief Raj Thackeray arrived in the city on Wednesday, on the eve of Shiv Jayanti, to celebrate the birth anniversary of Maratha warrior king Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj as per Hindu calendar.

The first-of-its-kind appearance of MNS chief in Aurangabad on the occasion of Shiv Jayanti has come in wake of Shiv Sena breaking its tradition and celebrating the occasion on February 19 as per English calendar.

MNS Aurangabad district chief Suhas Dashrathe said his party will leave no stone unturned to ensure grand celebrations of Shiv Jayanti on Thursday.

“Our party chief, along with his son Amit, has arrived for the Shiv Jayanti celebrations. We are not among those who give up their religion and culture for the sake of some political gains and therefore will celebrate Shiv Jayanti as per Hindu calendar in a grand manner,” Dashrathe said.

Dashrathe, who quit recently Sena to join MNS, said every Hindu takes pride in celebrating his or her festivals and major occasions as per Hindu calendar only.

As per party release, MNS chief is scheduled to pay tribute to Shivaji Maharaj at a special event planned at Kranti chowk where special tableau and other decorative arrangements have been made.

Title: Without salary for 5 months, caretakers of UP govt ‘gaushala’ surviving on cow milk
Content:
Meerut: Everyday Surender Kumar, 35, and his wife -- parents to two school-going children-- work hard to maintain government-run Kanha Gaushala in Bulandshahr, which has 137 stray cattle. Surviving without a salary for the last five months, they sell three-litre of cow milk daily for a living, and get just Rs 100 for it.

Promised a salary, the couple has not been paid one ever since they were hired by civic body. Apart from the couple, a woman who removes cow dung, too, gets two-litre milk daily.

“Municipal board had appointed three of us here in October last year. We take care of 137 stray cattle, including cows. We clean the place and the cattle, feed them fodder provided by the board and ensure that none of the animals fall ill. But, despite our repeated requests, we have not been paid a single dime ever since we were appointed as contractual labourers. We have two children who go to a nearby government school. The cowshed is also incomplete. At least a small dwelling inside can help us live here with dignity,” says Kumar.

When contacted, UP Gau Seva Commission’s president Shyam Nandan Singh said, “This gaushala is under the municipal board’s management and we have little say in that. But I will look into the matter. If the caretakers are not paid, how will he take care of animals?”

Meanwhile, municipal board’s executive officer (EO) Nihal Chand tried to downplay the matter. “It is not entirely true. They were paid for two months. We are trying to regularize their payments.”

Title: After kids fall ill, CMO asks not to give ayurvedic medicine in health camp
Content:
Bareilly: After five children were taken ill reportedly due to “overdose of ayurvedic medicine for cough” in Kandharpur village of Bareilly district on Sunday, chief medical officer ( CMO ) on Wednesday said the ayurvedic medicine for cough will not be given to people here in Jan Arogya Swasth Mela, as a precautionary measure.

Officials said five children were taken ill on Sunday after they had consumed overdose of ayurvedic medicine which was distributed at a health camp on Sunday.

CMO Dr Vineet Shukla said, “After villagers complained of illness, we have decided that this particular ayurvedic medicine should not be given to patients in upcoming health camps as a precautionary measure.”

Nandram Lodhi, whose wife is village head of Kandharpur under Majhgavan block of Bareilly district, said, “Three children were taken ill on Sunday after they consumed ayurvedic medicine while two more fell ill on Monday. Their bodies had become stiff but the condition of these five children is currently stable following treatment. We believe that there was something wrong with the medicine.”

District Ayush officer Dr Suman Gehlot said, “Apart from these five children, the cough medicine was given to many other patients in camps across the district. These children consumed overdose of ayurvedic medicine and hence, they were taken ill.”

Title: Hoardings flaying cops put up in Gondal
Content:
One of the 40-odd hoardings

Rajkot: Around 40 hoardings have come up in several places of Gondal flaying the police for its inaction to curb illegal activities of bootlegging and gambling on Tuesday. The hoardings also contain names and addresses of those involved in the illegal activities. However, police conducted 19 raids at several of these places but could not find any evidence. Cops claim they will book anybody found guilty of defaming the police.

“We did not find anything illegal at the places mentioned in the hoardings. Clearly, these hoardings were meant to defame the police. Now, we will check CCTV recording of cameras installed near the hoardings. We will find them out and book them for the crime,” said Balram Meena, superintendent of police, Rajkot rural.

Title: Coronavirus in Kerala: Two years after deluge, Ranni faces another challenge
Content:
Ranni town, where five coronavirus cases have been reported, wears a deserted look on Wednesday

RANNI: Ranni town and Pazhavangadi market wore a deserted look on Wednesday afternoon after five Covid-19 cases were reported this week. Only two small shops were opened in the market- which sold vegetables and dried fish. A stationery store was also kept open on the main road. Among the 20 odd hotels in the town only three had opened, however, there were no customers.

It was only two years ago the town, which is situated on the banks of Pamba River, faced its biggest ever deluge. It took couple of weeks for the people here to bounce back to normalcy. Ranni market is considered as the biggest market in the district and people residing within a radius of 25km depend on this market.

NRI bank deposit and rubber have been the reasons behind the economic growth of Ranni, one of the largest taluks in Kerala owing to its vast forest land. According to a senior official of a leading bank in the region, NRI deposits in the taluk is around Rs 2,000 crore. The nearby Mallappally taluk is much more and is around Rs 6,000 crore.

“A majority of NRIs in Ranni are in the Middle East. Many from the Knanaya community in the region are also in the US and European countries,” said the official. He also said the total NRI deposit in Pathanamthitta district alone is around Rs 22,000 crore which is half of the total deposit in the district.

Mathew C V, president of the Ranni merchants association said though Ranni, which has around 850 merchants, had recovered quickly from the aftermath of the floods, this time it’s uncertain how fast normalcy would be restored. “Markets have been dull. People do not want to come out of their homes,” he said. “Awareness should be created amongst people regarding the spread of Covid-19 virus.”

Sony Zacharias, secretary of Ranni hotels association said the industry is in crisis. “After pressure from the merchants association I opened my hotel around 7am on Wednesday. The first customer walked in by 8.30am. Two more came in after an hour. I closed shop by 9.45am,” he said adding that he had to pay wages to his staff despite closing down the shop early. Hotels in the town have remained closed since Monday. Jose K Abraham, another merchant, said all the 230 shops on the premises of the Ranni bus stand remained closed. “It’s good that people are not coming out of their houses due to the situation. Most of them have stocked necessary products at home. However, they may not last for more than a week,” he said. After the floods, Corona scare has been a setback to the business sector, he added.

Title: UP: Youth killed while performing stunt on tractor for Tik Tok
Content:
Kapil was performing stunts and another man was shooting a video from the mobile phone. But he lost control ov... Read More

MUZAFFARNAGAR: A newly-married youth, 23, was crushed to death when a speeding tractor on which he was performing stunts for Tik Tok overturned on him, just 12 days after a youth drowned while shooting a video for the Chinese video-sharing app in the district.

Married just two months ago, Kapil was performing the stunts during the Holi revelry in Muzaffarnagar’s Khindidiya village on Tuesday.

“Kapil was performing stunts and another man was shooting a video from the mobile phone. But he lost control over steering and the tractor overturned on him,” said Ritiparn Singh, the village head of Khindidiya. According to villagers, Kapil was trying to lift the front wheels of the speeding tractor in air when it overturned, killing him on the spot.

Sources said that family members of Kapil cremated his body without informing the police. When contacted, station house officer (SHO) of Chapar police station said, “No complaint was given by the family members into the matter.”

This was second death in the last 15 days which could be attributed to the people’s craze to become famous on Tik Tok by performing dangerous stunts.

On February 28, Raj Qureshi (18) was killed while taking a plunge into a canal in Muzaffarnagar’s Meerapur area. Qureshi had decided to jump into the deep canal while his three friends were at the bank filming the stunt for Tik Tok. But, going by the video, it is evident that Qureshi hit a rock, got unconscious and drowned. The body was fished out two hours later.

Title: Med stores inflate N95 mask price amidst corona scare
Content: Visakhapatnam: Even as health experts raise alerts against the efficacy of N95 face masks to guard against coronavirus , a pharmacy store under a well-known chain with several outlets in the state was found selling N95 masks at Rs 150 per mask against its maximum retail price (MRP) of Rs 25 per piece. The MRP on a pack of 20 masks was marked at Rs 500.With the rise in demand, most pharmacies in the city have run out of stock of N95 and surgical masks.A private employee in the city, V Bhavani Shankar, purchased two N95 masks from the pharmacy outlet in MVP Colony on Tuesday. “I was shocked when they charged Rs 300 for two masks from a pack of 20 though it should be Rs 50 for two masks. The manufacturing date and MRP have been blacked out. I took an empty 20-pack box and removed the ink, which revealed the pack originally costs Rs 500. When I questioned the pharmacist for charging such a high price over MRP, he justified it by stating that local retailers and other stores are charging even higher.”When TOI inquired at the Siripuram outlet of the pharmacy chain, the pharmacist said, “After two days, stocks may arrive and each mask is priced at Rs 150 as they are of high quality.”Inquiries at another pharmacy chain revealed that though face masks were out of stock, N95 were being sold at Rs 25 per piece while surgical masks were even cheaper but a standalone medical store at Lawson’s Bay Colony said the masks would cost between Rs 200-Rs 250 but were currently out of stock.Speaking to TOI, medical superintendent of Government Hospital for Chest and Communicable Diseases (GHCCD), Dr KVV Vijaykumar said, “There is no high and low quality N95 mask even if packaging may differ. Escalating the price to this extent is unfair when there is not a single COVID-19 case in the city, nor any requirement for the public to wear it. A three-layer surgical mask is enough for those suffering from cough and cold.”Dr PV Sudhakar, principal of Andhra Medical College said, “N95, which should not be priced more than Rs 20-Rs 30, is recommended only for hospital staff and health workers. Those with asthma, pregnancy or cardiac problems should avoid wearing these masks unnecessarily. Drug inspectors should take action against pharmacies for over-charging.”

Title: Janasena-BJP to contest all 98 GVMC seats
Content:
Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: For the first time in the city following their alliance, BJP and Jana Sena addressed the media jointly on Tuesday. BJP MLC PVN Madhav said that BJP and Jana Sena are ready to contest the local body elections together. He informed that the BJP-Jana Sena alliance will contest all 98 wards of the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation (GVMC).

Jana Sena state secretary Siva Sankar said that the BJP-Jana Sena alliance is not an alliance for elections but for the welfare of people and society. He said that the alliance would display its strength in the local body polls. “The public should think twice before casting their vote. They have made a mistake by giving the mandate to the YSRC,” Sankar added.

Meanwhile, BJP’s PVN Madhav lashed out at the YSRC and alleged that the ruling party in the state is involved in land scams in Visakhapatnam just as the TDP was in Amaravati .

Title: On Holi, teenager falls off terrace, dies
Content:
Bareilly: A 16-year-old boy died after he fell off the terrace while feeding birds — a family custom during Holi — in Tumariya Khadar village under Rajpura police station limits in Sambhal district on Tuesday.

Upon getting information, police visited the spot, but the boy’s family refused to handover the body for postmortem.

Police said Om Prakash, alias, Fauji, participated in a post-Holi prayer observed by the family on Tuesday. “After the prayers,” said Prakash’s father Rajpal, “I asked my elder son to go upstairs and feed the birds as per our family custom.”

“My son was feeding birds, when he slipped off the terrace accidentally and fell down. We rushed him to a private hospital in Babrala, where doctors proclaimed him dead upon arrival,” said the aggrieved father.

Police said no case was registered as the family refused to lodge an FIR.

Title: Fencing mooted along rail tracks
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: Southern Railway, Thiruvananthapuram division, has proposed to construct fences to prevent dumping of garbage near railway tracks. Fencing is mooted along the tracks from Thiruvananthapuram Central to Pettah railway station. The aim is to keep the area garbage-free as part of the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan.

The Thampanoor–Pettah tracks run along the densely-populated areas of the city and dumping of waste is a common practice here, especially during the night hours.

According to a railway official, dumping of waste is a major issue for the railways and strict action is taken against people caught dumping waste in railway property. The Railway Protection Force (RPF), commercial staff and other railway staff had conducted a mapping of vulnerable areas between Thiruvananthapuram Central and Pettah, based on directives from division authority a few months ago. Regular inspections are conducted at these spots to check the issue.

The plan is to ensure fencing for around 3km railway tracks from Thiruvananthapuram Central to Pettah station.

As many as six CCTV cameras are installed in the stretch between Thiruvananthapuram Central and Pettah. Penalty is imposed on people caught dumping waste in the railway tracks.

“Strict checking on dumping of garbage on railway property was intensified after a team from National Green Tribunal (NGT) visited the station in August last year. The vulnerable spots are regularly monitored by RPF officers. Around Rs 2 lakh was collected as penalty for dumping waste in railway property including, railway tracks, open areas and station premises in 2019. Despite these measures, people continue to dump waste and fencing along the tracks was proposed as a solution. The fences will have a height of four to five feet,” said Ajay Kaushik, station director, Thiruvananthapuram Central railway station.

In a recent case in January, a team of RPF officers had caught a group of people who tried to dump waste on railway track in the city. Penalty was imposed on them and they were made to take back the garbage. tnn

Title: Covid-19 in Goa: Biometric attendance for govt staff on hold
Content: PANAJI: In a bid to contain any possible risk of spreading Covid-19, government departments on Wednesday decided to exempt employees from marking their attendance through Aadhaar-based biometric attendance systems till March 31.A communication to this effect was sent by the ministry of personnel, public grievances and pensions, and was then circulated to all state departments.Goa had no Covid-19 cases until Wednesday evening.
