Panaji: The Rural Development Agency (RDA) has picked four Goan villages where self-help groups (SHG) will be nurtured and later encouraged to shift towards a viable business model. Making the announcement, RDA project director Sanjit Rodrigues said that Gaondongrim, Barcem, Latambarcem, and Ozrim have been picked for the ambitious project, which is being undertaken through the National Rural Livelihoods Mission ( NRLM ).

The announcement was made at a function to mark the completion of an immersion study for block and community resource persons, where chief minister Pramod Sawant was also present.

“For long, development has been focused on the towns. Maximum focus has been on the urban areas and the villages have been left behind,” Sawant said.

SHGs have been urged to focus on agriculture, food processing, catering, bee-keeping, groundnut cultivation and other sources which can generate revenue for women.

RDA will fund the purchase of a small cargo vehicle for the Khola farmers’ association so the farmers can immediately transport khola chillies to the local market.

“Forming SHGs is not enough. We can’t stop there. In the second phase of the NRLM we have to convert these groups into business entities. We have picked four villages for this,” Rodrigues said.

Rodrigues also said that duplication of work by government departments should be avoided and instead departments need to collaborate and converge central and state government schemes.

The RDA will also fund the construction of a community kitchen and subsequently obtain Food Safety and Standards Authority of India certification for it. .

Title: Congress a sinking ship, Churchill warns Sardinha
Content:
Margao: NCP’s Benaulim MLA Churchill Alemao on Wednesday hit back at South Goa MP Francisco Sardinha reminding him that it was he who strengthened the BJP in Goa when he (Sardinha) defected to the saffron party along with several other Congresmen to form a coalition government with the BJP in 1999.

Sardinha, while addressing reporters last week, had said that while AAP was the ‘B’ team of the BJP, the NCP was in cahoots with the saffron party.

“I never joined the BJP despite having got many offers to do so. The BJP leaders are good people, but I don’t like the party’s roots,” Alemao said and recounted how his refusal to support the Atal Bihari Vajpayee government led to its collapse by one vote. He reiterated that the NCP’s support to the BJP-led government in Goa was issue-based and “because the chief minister hails from the weaker section.”

Referring to the latest crisis that has hit Congress in Madhya Pradesh, Alemao said that Congress was a ‘sinking ship’ and advised Sardinha to “put your house in order first.”

“The NCP saved Congress in Maharashtra, where they are zero,” he said.Alemao also accused Curtorim MLA Alexio Reginaldo Lourenco of trying to poach NCP supporters in Benaulim.

Title: Viveka murder: AP HC shifts case to CBI
Content:
Vivekananda

Vijayawada: The YS Vivekananda Reddy murder case was transferred to the CBI by AP high court on Wednesday.

Allowing the petitions of Viveka’s wife Sowbhagyamma and daughter Sunitha, Justice U Durga Prasada Rao said that time was essential in any investigation while pointing out that even after nearly one year of the murder, the Special Investigation Team (SIT) constituted by the state government had failed to make any progress in finding the killers.

While allowing chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy to withdraw his petition seeking CBI probe, the HC dismissed the petitions of TDP functionaries BTech Ravi and Adinarayana Reddy.

The high court further observed that apart from being a prominent politician, Vivekananda Reddy was into real estate and other businesses also. There could have been involvement of persons from other states and CBI was better equipped to investigate it, the HC said.

Vivekananda Reddy was found murdered at his residence on March 15, 2019. Though he was found in a pool of blood with severe injuries, initially it was reported that he had died of cardiac arrest. The incident kicked off a political storm as it had happened ahead of general elections. The YSRC and TDP traded barbs alleging each other responsible for murder.

The state government constituted an SIT to investigate the matter. However, the composition of the SIT was changed thrice, which was questioned by family members. The SIT has examined 1,300 persons, conducted Narco tests on three suspects and arrested three for sabotaging the crime scene by screening the evidence.

Sunitha, in her petition, raised many doubts over the role of 15 persons including some family members who were present at the time of screening of evidence. She also raised doubts on her cousin Jaganmohan Reddy, who had himself moved high court demanding CBI inquiry while in opposition and changed his stance after coming to power.

Title: Telangana: Unaware, panchayat officials employ grey langurs as guards
Content:
TimesView While the prompt action taken by the forest department is praiseworthy, strong action must be taken against the people involved behind the illegal trade of these protected species under Schedule-II of the Wildlife (Protection) Act. Wildlife authorities in coordination with activists and the police should immediately arrest people involved in capturing the animal from reserve forests.

KOTHAGUDEM: In an unlikely appointment, a gram panchayat office in Bhadrachalam has stationed three grey langurs to ward off other primates in the area. However, grey langurs are a protected species under Schedule-II of the Wildlife (Protection) Act and capturing them carries a penalty of either a three-year term or a fine of Rs 20,000 or both. After intervention from animal activists and forest department , the langurs were released back into the forest.Keeping in mind that other primates usually steer clear of langur-dominated areas given the latter is very territorial and more aggressive compared to other simian counterparts, the gram panchayat office had kept the langurs to guard the area. “Few people in our office said that they found these langurs somewhere and brought them to the office. They asked me if the langurs would be of any use to me. These langurs only listen to commands of these workers, as they used to train similar species earlier,” said Bhadhrachalam gram panchayat executive officer (EO), C Srinivasa Rao.When asked by TOI if the langurs had been chained to the office with his permission, Rao said: “The people who brought the langurs chained them. They might have brought them after villagers complained about monkey menace. We handed over the langurs to the forest department after I got a call from a woman who guided us and informed the forest officials.”Wildlife activists who raised an alarm about the chained langurs said that they went to rescue the primates after they received photos of a chained mother with her baby on the premises of the gram panchayat office. “A male langur was also seen nearby in a cage when we went to the spot. There were three langurs in captivity of the gram panchayat office,” said Uday Kumar, an animal activist.Members of Earth Quotient, an environmental organisation, have filed a complaint with police asking them to register an FIR. “Following complaints about monkey menace, gram panchayats and municipalities often appear to be buying langurs from illegal traders and poachers. We have both video and photo evidence of this,” said Dr K Shashikala, south India coordinator of Earth Quotient.“Rao spoke to me over the phone. He was trying to justify the incident unaware that this was a crime. WhatsApp evidence has been forwarded to him requesting immediate release of the langur back to its natural habitat. Rao stopped answering my calls since,” Shashikala’s complaint read. An FIR in this case was registered on Wednesday evening.

Title: Akbaruddin appears before spl court in hate speech case
Content:
Hyderabad: AIMIM floor leader in state assembly and Chandrayangutta MLA Akbaruddin Owaisi on Wednesday appeared before the special sessions court in connection with a hate speech case. Two witnesses in the case are said to have identified him. The II-Additional Metropolitan Sessions Judge cum Special Sessions Judge for the trial of cases against MPs and MLAs had earlier directed Akbaruddin Owaisi to appear before the court on March 11.

Two prosecution witnesses in the case identified him before the judge on Wednesday. Witnesses in their testimonies told that court that it was Akbaruddin who had delivered the alleged hate speech in Nizamabad in 2013. The case is presently under trial and the special court has already recorded the chief examination of the witnesses. For further proceedings in the case, the witnesses wanted to identify the legislator, who is an accused in the case before the judge. The court had asked Akbaruddin Owaisi to appear before the court for the identification purpose.

In 2013, Akbaruddin had allegedly delivered a hate speech in Nizamabad upon which a case was registered by Nizamabad-II Town police and on February 5, 2013, the II-Additional Judicial Magistrate in Nizamabad district granted conditional bail to the accused legislator.

Later, upon the Supreme Court’s direction asking all the state governments to set up special courts for conducting trials against legislators, the hate speech case of Akbar Owaisi was transferred to the special court in Hyderabad.

Title: Man arrested for murder of partner, confesses
Content:
Hyderabad: A man was arrested on Wednesday for the murder of a woman with whom he is said to have been in a relationship. According to Choutuppal police, it was on Monday when the man had allegedly killed the woman by banging her head on the floor. He later tried to portray the murder as a suicide by hanging her body using her saree. Suspecting foul play, the police questioned the man, who later confessed to killing her.

The couple is said to have been in a relationship for the last six years but were said to have been quarelling frequently in recent days. On Monday, the man is said to have gone to his partner’s residence where the duo is said to have gotten into a fight again. In a fit of rage, he pushed her against the floor when she hit her head and died as a result.

The man was arrested on Wednesday and produced before a local court.

Title: Police seize IEDs, kit bags left by Maoists
Content:
Hyderabad: Bhadradri-Kothagudem police on Wednesday seized IEDs, kit bags, pen drives, solar panels and revolutionary literature that were left behind by a few Maoists who fled after noticing the police personnel while they were conducting combing operations.

Cops took up combing operations on Tuesday after receiving information that four teams of Maoists have entered into the state from Chhattisgarh. They said that seven Maoists fled after noticing the cops. A case was registered and search efforts were intensified .

Title: No proposal on new airports from Telangana: Hardeep Puri
Content:
Hardeep Puri

HYDERABAD: The Airports Authority of India ( AAI ) has conducted a preliminary study at six sites for new airports identified by the Telangana government including Warangal , Adilabad, Peddapalli, Nizamabad, Kothagudem and Mahabubnagar. However, the Union ministry of civil aviation said that it had not received any proposal for development of new airports in Telangana.

The aerial distance between the Mamnoor site in Warangal, the second biggest city in Telangana, to the Rajiv Gandhi International Airport in Hyderabad is around 145 kilometres. As per the concession agreement of the latter, no new airport should come up in the range of 150 km for the next 60 years.

Replying to question raised by MP Komatireddy Venkat Reddy on the Warangal airport, minister of state for civil aviation, Hardeep Puri said: “Ministry has issued a Greenfield Airport Policy for development of greenfield airports across the country. The policy permits statement government or airport company or individual developers to establish a greenfield airport after obtaining site clearance and in-principle approval from Ministry of civil aviation.”

The developer shall make an application before a steering committee for the first stage clearance, known as a site clearance in the prescribed proforma. “We have not received any proposal from the state government or any other airport developer for construction of an airport in Warangal and Mamnoor in Telangana state as per Greenfield Airport Policy,” Hardeep Puri said.

“On request of the government of Telangana, AAI has undertaken preliminary study at the sites identified by the government of Telangana including Warangal,” the Union minister said. Basanthnagar in Peddapalli, Khanapur in Adilabad, Jakranpalli in Nizamabad, Gudibanda in Mahabubnagar and Kothagudem are the other sites identified.

The Mamnoor airport area is spread over 706 acres and has an airstrip from pre-independence era built by Nizam VII in 1930 and was operational till 1981. Khanapur in Adilabad, which was also inspected by the AAI team has already got 369 acres of the aerodrome that was operational during World War 2.

The Mamnoor airport served paper mills and also for the visits of VIPs. The Jakranpalli site, also inspected by AAI, is aimed at serving lakhs of ulf immigrants from Nizamabad region. The Kothagudem site falls under a reserve forest area.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Mumbai: Schools follow Unicef norms, cancel morning assembly, eye e-learning option
Content: MUMBAI: With year-end exams on or coming up soon, most city schools have already begun to follow the Unicef advisory on Covid-19 care in schools. The UN body recently issued an advisory to prevent and control the virus through instructions, including social distancing and exploring the use of online education in case of a shutdown.Listed as part of social distancing, the Unicef has recommended that schools cancel morning assemblies, sports events and any other activities involving mass gathering. The timing, though, has helped most city schools. “Internal exams are over and so are our classes. School will resume in April,” said Jose Kurien, principal, DAV Public School (Nerul). CBSE, ICSE and ISC board exams are underway. Most state board schools and junior colleges are centres for HSC and SSC board exams and are calling in younger students only for half a day. Annual exams for lower classes soon after will require them to come to school just for a few hours a day.In its guidelines for safe operations in schools, Unicef said, “Precautions are necessary to prevent the potential spread of Covid-19 in school settings; however, care must also be taken to avoid stigmatizing students and staff who may have been exposed to the virus. It is important to remember that Covid-19 does not differentiate between borders, ethnicities, disability status, age or gender. Education settings should continue to be welcoming, respectful, inclusive, and supportive environments to all.”The body has also discouraged perfect attendance awards and incentives.City schools have already begun taking steps. R N Podar School principal Avnita Bir recently participated in a webinar on online learning tips for school closures. “We are working on it. We will use Google Hangouts/Meets, pre-recorded content, Google Classroom, Zoom,” said Bir. HVB Global Academy, Marine Drive, which does not have a break coming up, is equipped to use a flipped classroom to teach students remotely.A teachers’ union has demanded the education department cancel the innovation exhibition on March 16 and 17. Another has sought cancellation of census duties.

Title: Maharashtra to shift cyclone relief account from Axis
Content:
All funds in Axis Bank, approximately Rs 2 crore, will be transferred to SBI

MUMBAI: The state government will close its National Cyclone Risk Mitigation Project account with Axis Bank at its Nariman Point branch with immediate effect and open one in State Bank of India ’s Churchgate branch. The move comes a week after the state cabinet decided to close accounts of all departments, state-run corporations and civic bodies in private banks.

“All funds in Axis Bank, approximately Rs 2 crore, will be transferred to SBI. The department of relief and rehabilitation has issued an official order for the purpose,” a senior bureaucrat told TOI on Wednesday.

A week ago, the cabinet took note of Yes Bank’s financial condition. Its founder Rana Kapoor was arrested under the Prevention of Money Laundering Act and the Reserve Bank of India appointed an administrator. The cabinet then took a decision to withdraw all its funds deposited in private banks and transfer them to nationalized banks. The relief and rehabilitation department is the first to transfer its funds from Axis Bank to SBI. “It was found that civic organizations had deposited huge amounts in Yes Bank ,” said the bureaucrat.

It remains to be seen if the home department, too, transfers its accounts to nationalized banks. “For a prolonged period, salary accounts of most police officials were with Axix Bank. We expect all these accounts to be transferred to nationalized banks in a time-bound manner,” he said.

Title: Telangana government readies Warangal master plan
Content:
HYDERABAD: In a boost to development of Greater Warangal , the Telangana government on Wednesday approved a master plan for the Kakatiya Urban Development Authority (KUDA). The plan has been readied for 2020-2041. Since the draft was prepared after consultations with stakeholders, municipal administration department has approved it.

Apart from this, 15-km mono rail connectivity will also be taken up, and works for 29 km of total 68km outer ring road (ORR) will be launched by June this year. The decisions were taken at a meeting headed by municipal administration minister, KT Rama Rao , along with ministers belonging to erstwhile Warangal district, Errabelli Dayakar Rao and Satyavathi Rathod, with officials on Wednesday.

KTR said the Centre has in-principle agreed to develop Warangal airport at Mamnoor, on the outskirts of the city. Since Warangal is the second-biggest city in Telangana, KTR said all developmental works taken up under Smart City and heritage conservation works should be completed at the earliest.

“All the promises made by chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao during his visit to Warangal a few years should be completed on war-footing basis, especially 2BHK houses,” he said. Officials informed that while the government had sanctioned 3,900 houses, 900 houses were completed and ready for inauguration, and 2,200 are under construction. Remaining 800 were not taken up due to local issues, officials informed the minister.

“To make the city clean and improve sanitation works, 1,000 public toilets will be constructed, and four dumping yards will be developed for disposal of waste. Currently there is only one dumping yard at Madikonda on the outskirts of the city,” KTR said.

He asked the officials to develop Kaloji Kala Kshetram, Eka Shila Park development, road widening, and junction improvement in the city. Another meeting on Warangal city development will be held on March 16, the minister said.

Title: Official, activist war over alleged encroachment
Content:
Hyderabad: In a letter to Chief Justice of Telangana High Court, former-convenor of Save Our Urban Lakes, Lubna Sarwath, has alleged encroachment of Malka Cheruvu in Raidurg village. She says that construction activities have affected more than four acres of the full tank Level (FTL). “For the demolition inside FTL boundary and restoration of Malka Cheruvu and its inflow channel for rain water inflows (sic),” she contended.

Accusing the GHMC and HMDA of encroachment, Sarwath said that satellite imagery overlayed with geo-coordinates of FTL as per official records show “gateway constructions, walkway, immersion pond, tar road and further stone constructions, all illegal inside the FTL boundary”.

Nagaraju, an assistant executive engineer of the irrigation department, said, “The court has been apprised of some beautification works taking place within the FTL. We are being transparent in our activities. Besides, fencing and bund work we have also completed lake desilting and water hyacinth removal.”

Title: Desi students put off foreign univ plans
Content: Mumbai: An admit from Stanford calls for celebration. A call from Cambridge is seen as a passport to success. But infected with fears over the Covid-19 spread, students are postponing confirmation of their admissions.India is the second largest sender of students to countries around the world. But admits for a blue-chip MBA or a cutting-edge programme on quantum computing mean nothing as candidates are unclear if campuses will open for the new academic year. Requests are going out from India seeking extension of fee payment deadlines.Meanwhile, USA has asked its schools to exercise flexibility with international students. The Student and Exchange Visitor Programme released an advisory on Tuesday for educational institutes seeking information on whether a campus is temporarily shut or instructions are being given at an alternative campus or have moved online.“There is tremendous uncertainty among students. Indian students have admits but they are not paying their enrolment deposits. In most cases, they are non-refundable and may be as high as US$5,000. Students are unsure about whether the city they are flying to will be safe or not. First it was Singapore, now Europe and the USA,” said Karan Gupta, a counsellor who works with students who wish to study abroad.In a new survey of 2,000-plus students from Africa, Asia, and Australasia by QS , nearly 3 in 10 (27%) said their plans had changed due to the virus while a much greater proportion (61%) said their plans were not affected as yet. As many as 37% said their plans had changed and the outbreaks have made them decide to defer their entry until next year while 33% said they will now choose an alternate destination. Just over 11% of those whose plans had changed said they no longer wished to study abroad.Param Jain, who passed out of Thadomal Shahani Engineering College, has multiple admits from campuses spanning three countries: Spain, USA and the UK. “I have asked the universities to extend the deadline for payment of enrolment fees. They have offered an extension till the end of March,” he said.Campuses are going quiet. Most have moved online. Travel advisories have been issued and conferences, athletic meets, immersion trips and industry experiences called off. Many Chinese students may be unable to apply as GMAT centres shut in China.“Students are mostly delaying taking visas till June,” said Pratibha Jain, another counsellor. Students said unofficial messages from universities state entry may be delayed by a month.Some schools have said if the enrolment deposit is paid, it would be refunded or admission could be deferred by a semester or a year.

Title: Women’s cricket dawns in land of the midnight sun
Content:
The tournaments has grown over the years and in its third edition, organisers expect a triangular or quadrangu... Read More

At a time when the Indian women’s cricket team was slogging away on the pitches Down Under, Telugus all the way in Norway had started preparations for a women’s cricket tournament of their own. “We have already organised two edtions of the Women’s Cricket League and this June, we will be organising the third edition,” said K Tharakesh of the Norway Telugu Association who had migrated from Visakhapatnam.

“There is increasing enthusiasm among women to participate in this tournament year after year. We have already begun preparations (for this year),” said Tharakesh. The toughest part, he says, is the organisation with cricket being a relatively unknown sport in Norway. The organisers have to book the field well in advance and prepare the pitch for cricket.

The organisers even have to arrange the equipment, bats, balls and even the trophies. “From the bat, balls, stumps to medals and trophies we bring everything from Hyderabad in phases. So it takes a lot time to organise the tournament,” says Tharakesh.

Those representing in this tournament are already excited about them. Though many among them have not played cricket before or are not regulars, they take up this tournament with utmost sincerity. “We do have a day or two for practice sessions before the match. The matches are real fun. It is good see that at least for a day we are playing and the men are cheering us on,” said Shalini Hema, one of the cricketers.

But how did the idea of the tournament come about? According to the organisers, while conducting the Telugu Men’s Cricket League, they wanted to involve the women of the community as well. At first, they wanted to organise matches with mixed teams, however, this could not materialise as many families felt that if both husband and wife were at the tournament, there would be no one to take care of the kids. It was then decided to hold a separate tournament for women only.

“In the first two editions, we managed to form only two teams. But the way the tournament is gaining popularity, this year it might even be a triangular or a quadrangular series. These 12-over matches are played with hard tennis ball in this tournament,” said Tharakesh.

Title: Demand for higher traffic fines grows
Content:
Margao: In view of the death of three minor boys in a car crash at Verna last week, Green Goa Foundation, a public trust, has demanded that the government implement the amended Motor Vehicles Act that provides for enhanced penalties for violators of traffic rules.

“While the punishments for traffic violation have been enhanced all over the country, we in Goa continue to follow the old regulations. The drivers will not learn to follow the rules unless they are heavily penalised ,” said chairman of the foundation, Raison Almeida.

The foundation has warned of moving the high court of Bombay at Goa if the state government fails to act.

Almeida said, “It is high time the government and NGOs hold driving classes for irresponsible parents who encourage driving by their minor children which is a hazard to the driver as well as others on the road.” He also pointed out that there has been a 25-fold increase in the number of vehicles in Goa over the past 50 years, without a corresponding improvement in the quality of roads, resulting in a large number of accidents

Title: ‘Stop tendering govt works till river sand is legally available’
Content:
Margao: Pointing out to unauthorised use of black metal dust in the place of river sand by government contractors in their construction projects, leading to allegedly substandard structures, the Shadow Council for Margao (SCM) has demanded that until river sand is made available in the state as per the Goa Schedule of Rates (GSR), government departments should stop tendering and execution of projects requiring cement and concrete.

Addressing mediapersons on Wednesday, Savio Coutinho of the SCM demanded that stringent action be taken against the contactor involved in the execution of “substandard work” for the construction of the nullah along the Eastern Bypass Road, near Gujarati Samaj School at Aquem.

The SCM had recently stopped the work forcibly after the proportion of the concrete mix was found to be substandard and cube samples taken for strength tests in the laboratory.

“On the completion of seven days, the cube samples were subjected to strength tests at the quality control laboratory of the water resources department at Gogol, Margao,” said Coutinho.

“The cube samples collected in our presence were found to have compression strength of 57.7kg/sqcm and 66.6kg/sqcm, which is far lower than the required strength of 140kg/sqcm for a concrete mix of 1:2:4 proportion. Even the third cube sample fell short of the required strength and achieved a reading of 124.4kg/sqcm,” he said, and demanded the PWD order a probe into all the work being undertaken and that stringent action be taken against the contractor.

Coutinho also urged contractors to refrain from adopting corrupt practices of giving kickbacks to politicians to bag contracts.

“The situation in Goa with respect to public works is going from bad to worse with the percentage cuts getting higher and higher. If this continues, we will soon achieve the distinction of having 100% bills paid for 0% work executed,” he said.

Title: Nashik Municipal Corporation snaps over 100 water connections of tax defaulters
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) has, over the past fortnight, snapped more than 100 water connections of citizens who had defaulted on water tax payments.

Municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game had instructed the officials to speed up the tax collection drive in the city given the approaching March-end. The NMC had set an annual tax collection target of Rs 133 crore — including the current demand of Rs 65 crore and the Rs 68-crore water tax dues of the last financial year. So far, the civic body has collected Rs 50 crore. It is yet to collect Rs 83 crore even though only 19 days are left in the current financial year (2019-20).

“We have intensified our tax collection drive. The municipal commissioner has already directed us to take action against the water tax defaulters ,” said the NMC officials. “We have snapped the connections of over 100 defaulters in the past fortnight. We will continue our drive until the defaulters clear their dues,” they added.

The civic body had collected Rs 40 crore as water tax in the last financial year (2018-19). It had collected Rs 29.50 water tax in 2017-18. So far this year, it has collected Rs 50 crore.

There are 1.96 lakh water connections across six divisions of the NMC, including 1.88 lakh residential, 4,000 commercial and the remaining 4,000 non-commercial water connections. Corporation officials said 27,000 high-value customers have dues collectively worth Rs 41 crore.

There are 15,168 tax defaulters who have tax dues in the range of Rs 5,000 and Rs 10,000. There are 8,530 defaulters who have dues above Rs 10,000 and up to Rs 15,000. There are 3,423 tax defaulters who have water tax dues above Rs 15,000 and up to Rs 25,000 and there are 666 tax defaulters who have dues over Rs 25,000.

“We are targeting these high-value customers and water connections of these defaulters are now being snapped,” said the officials.

There are six divisions of NMC — Nashik Road, Panchavati, Nashik East , Nashik West , Satpur and Cidco.

Title: RSS man Bandi Sanjay Kumar takes over as BJP chief in Telangana
Content:
BJP MP Bandi Sanjay Kumar

HYDERABAD: BJP’s Karimnagar MP Bandi Sanjay Kumar , known for his strong Hindutva stand, was appointed Telangana state party president on Wednesday. The appointment came four months shy of his 49th birthday. He succeeds K Laxman.

Sanjay belongs to Munnuru Kapu (Backward Class) community, which has a strong presence in north Telangana. Backward Classes constitute 52% of the population in the state, a factor that may have played an important role in his anointment.

Interestingly, in more than 20 years, the 48-year-old leader, a first-time MP, has become the first saffron representative elected outside Hyderabad to take over the mantle of the party in the state.

Though Sanjay is seen as a hardcore Hindutva face, his equations with his senior colleagues in the party and closeness with Union minister G Kishan Reddy worked in his favour, sources said. “RSS wants a strong face which can iron out the anti-CAA, NRC and NPR scenario in Telangana and Sanjay fits the bill,” a senior leader on condition of anonymity said. “We can expect fireworks from now on,” he said.

Sanjay, who has risen through the ranks, served in Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP), the student wing of the RSS, and was elected to the Lok Sabha in the 2019 general election from Karimnagar after defeating sitting TRS MP B Vinod Kumar.

Party insiders say Sanjay’s strong allegiance with RSS clinched the issue in his favour over strong contenders such as P Muralidhar Rao, DK Aruna, AP Jithender Reddy, Garikapati Mohan Rao and Laxman.

Veteran BJP leader Ch Vidyasagar Rao, a former Maharashtra governor, was the last BJP chief from outside Hyderabad (in undivided Andhra Pradesh) holding the party reins in 1999. He had also represented Karimnagar in Parliament. Laxman (Musheerabad assembly constituency), G Kishan Reddy (Secunderabad LS and Amberpet assembly seat) and Bandaru Dattareya (Secunderabad Lok Sabha MP) have served as the party chiefs. “The leaders who ran the party in Telangana between 2000 and 2020 were either from Hyderabad or united AP,” a party leader pointed out.

Sanjay’s name started doing the rounds only recently, while pollsters were betting big on Laxman getting a second term and Aruna to take on TRS and steer the saffron party to victory in 2023 assembly elections.

During civic polls in January 2019, Sanjay was embroiled in a controversy after he threatened to use bombs and knives on TRS and AIMIM activists if they target BJP workers. He even called TRS and AIMIM “anti-Hindu” for opposing CAA, NRC and NPR.

Meanwhile, party insiders say Sanjay’s appointment did not come as a surprise as his name was first considered for a Union MoS berth after his win in Karimnagar. With Kishan Reddy walking away with an MoS post, Sanjay had always stood an outside chance to get the party chief’s post, they said.

Sanjay will be heading the party for three years. A 20-member state committee of the party would be formed soon, party sources said.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Delhi: No link with chicken, but sales see massive dip
Content: NEW DELHI: While chicken has got nothing to do with the spread of the novel coronavirus , rumours and scaremongering on social media have impacted its sale drastically. Delhi meat merchants’ association has reported a dip of 70% in sale of chicken, while beef and mutton sale has seen a milder impact.Mohammad Arshad Qureshi, president, meat association, said the government’s animal husbandry department has clearly said that chicken consumption was safe. “There is no corelation between Covid-19 and the industry. It is just lack of awareness and basic knowledge about the disease that have caused the dip,” Qureshi said.The association estimated that overall poultry business was running at just 20-30% of what existed before January when information about this new disease started to pour in. “Mutton has seen a decline of just 20%, but it may be a seasonal downturn. Buffalo meat and fish sales have more or less remained the same,” Qureshi added.The impact of the downturn was visible from the wholesale market and the retail shops across the city. Manoj Rajora, who runs a Kacha Jhatka meat shop in southwest Delhi, said the region has seen 70% dip in meat sales. “People say they are taking precautions, but in reality both are not related. How many people can you convince,” he said.In central Delhi’s star chicken shop at Mirdard Colony, the sales reportedly dipped by 50%. Md. Salimuddin, the manager of the shop, said their customers were now reluctant to purchase meat despite it being part of their staple diet. “The rates have seen only a minor dip because we also have to pay the workers,” he argued. Chicken here was selling at Rs 140/kg. Rajora explained that since sales were down, people who reared chicken, also stopped bringing them to market. “The entire supply chain is impacted,” he added.Md Mushtaq, a meat seller in south Delhi’s Munirka, said the area has witnessed a drop in rates by Rs 60-70 in the past two months. “Demand usually goes up around Holi, but sales simply did not pick up this time,” he added. The rates in the high-end market of antibiotic-free meat, however, are still floating around Rs 145/ half kg from the past three months.Senior public health department official from South Delhi Municipal Corporation clarified that the meat consumption was safe and there has been no reported transmission of Covid-19 from chicken. “People seem to be confused between bird flu and the new virus. They should simply eat hygienically processed well-cooked meat,” he added. Meanwhile, DMMA members were busy forwarding the letter from the animal husbandry commissioner to poultry federation of India to counter the misinformation.

Title: Central govt staff demands CAT bench in city
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Employees of the central government in Andhra Pradesh gathered here to demand the establishment of a Central Administrative Tribunal ( CAT ) bench in AP, specifically in Visakhapatnam, on Wednesday.

Currently, the Hyderabad bench caters to central government employees of both Telugu states. Andhra Pradesh has over 50,000 central government employees (both retired and in service), with over 60 per cent residing in Visakhapatnam.

Y Bhaskar Rao, a member of All Central Government Pensioners’ Association, Visakhapatnam said, “Since maximum number of central government employees (both retired and in service) are based in Visakhapatnam, a CAT is much needed in our city. Else, employees and old or ailing retired personnel have to go all the way to Hyderabad, spend money in lodging and accommodation and it is quite inconvenient for them. Therefore, we have given a representation to the chief medical officer of Central Government Health Scheme to take up our issues with the central government authorities.”

Senior advocate Kuppili Muralidhar and president of Forum of Legal Professionals said, “The CAT bench at Hyderabad consists of a chairman and two members (including a judicial and another administrative member). One of the member’s post is vacant. The chairman is a retired judge of the high court who flies down from Delhi each time there is a hearing. Visakhapatnam is ideally suited to house the AP bench of CAT and can have a new appointed chairman, vice-chairman and members.”

Title: Delhi: Autos, buses from outside to be disinfected to prevent spread of coronavirus
Content: NEW DELHI: After ensuring that all Delhi Metro coaches and Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC) and cluster buses are thoroughly disinfected every day to prevent spread of coronavirus , Delhi government is now focusing on getting autorickshaws , e-rickshaws and the buses coming to the city from other states disinfected.“We are coming out with an advisory for drivers of autos, e-rickshaws, mini-buses, etc., to create awareness about the necessity to keep their vehicles disinfected. They will be advised to thoroughly clean the vehicles and follow general dos and don’ts,” a Delhi government official said.“This is not only important for the safety of their passengers, but also to protect themselves from any infection,” the official added.The official further said that drivers and owners of smaller vehicles, such as autorickshaws, Phat Phat sewa, eco sewa, maxi cabs and e-rickshaws, might not have the financial means to ensure thorough cleaning of vehicles by the prescribed disinfectants.“We are planning to disinfect these vehicles free of cost at DTC and Cluster depots. The owners will be able to visit the nearest bus depot and get their vehicles disinfected. This facility is expected to start within a couple of days,” he added.While all DTC and Cluster scheme buses are being disinfected daily, Delhi Metro Rail Corporation has also intensified the cleaning of its trains and common surfaces at stations. Inter-state buses coming from neighbouring states will be disinfected at the three inter-state bus terminals (ISBTs), starting Thursday.“All ISBTs, including the platforms and the common surfaces, are being disinfected. Starting Thursday, all buses arriving at Delhi’s ISBTs will be thoroughly disinfected,” said KK Dahiya, special commissioner (transport). He is also managing director of Delhi Transport Infrastructure Development Corporation, which manages Delhi’s ISBTs.“We are writing to the authorities concerned in the neighbouring states, urging them to ensure that all buses headed to Delhi are disinfected,” he added.As many as 3,467 buses from other states arrive in Delhi every day and most of these operate from Kashmere Gate ISBT (1,636), followed by Anand Vihar ISBT (1,210) and Sarai Kale Khan ISBT (621). Most of the inter-state buses arrive from Uttar Pradesh (1,519), followed by Haryana (757) and Uttarakhand (313). DTC doesn’t operate any inter-state buses as its entire fleet runs on CNG, which is not easily available in other states.

Title: Govt hand in glove with SEC: PCC prez
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Pradesh Congress Committee (PCC) president Sake Sailajanath on Wednesday said that the state government and the state election commission ( SEC ) were colluding in the conduct of elections to local bodies. Sailajanath said the government is holding the elections to get Rs 3,700 crore central government funds and questioned the government for not conducting polls three months before.

Speaking to media persons here on Wednesday, the PCC president alleged that there was no dividing line between the SEC, an autonomous body, and the ruling party adding that reservations were decided for the benefit of the ruling party. “It is not proper that reservations were announced only 24 hours before the nomination starting date. The ruling party is utilising the elections for its benefits. CM Jaganmohan Reddy has not only been threatening his own ministers and MLAs but also other parties’ leaders,” Sailajanath said.

Title: CTU to soon release admission notification
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The Central Tribal University (CTU) held its advisory committee meeting here at Andhra University (AU), the mentor institute of the CTU , on Wednesday. AU vice-chancellor Professor PVGD Prasad Reddy chaired the meeting.

The advisory committee discussed the courses, curriculum, admission process and other matters for the next academic year, 2020-21.

Prof Reddy said that they will take measures to increase the number of tribal students in the CTU. “The CTU will soon release an admission notification. We will increase the number of examination centres in the tribal pockets,” said Prof Reddy. The committee members, including AU registrar Prof V Krishna Mohan, former AU vice-chancellor Prof B Satyanarayana, IIPE director Prof VSRK Prasad and others were present.

Title: HC verdict: Bedi optimistic of collaboration with ministers
Content:
Puducherry: “The law has spoken ,” said lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi while responding to the order of the Madras high court bench that set aside a single judge order restraining her from interfering in the day-to-day affairs of the elected government and suggesting that the government and Raj Nivas work in unison for the welfare of people in the Union territory of Puducherry.

Bedi expressed optimism that the cabinet members will now accept her invitation for collaborative work in making Puducherry a clean, green, prosperous and water-rich Union territory. Excerpts from an interview with Bedi.

Now with the Madras HC bench setting aside a single judge order restraining you from interfering in day-to-day affairs of the elected government and suggesting Raj Nivas and the elected government work in unison, what are the efforts you have planned to undertake?

We hope that when we invite any of the honourable members of cabinet for discussions they shall accept the invite. (Earlier they were regretting by conveying both verbally as well in writing. Saying, ‘they do not need to meet’ or ‘at other places’ or ‘there is no need to meet”.) Also, when we were requesting them to join in on-site they either did not respond, or just excused themselves. We shall look forward to them now accepting the invites. I shall be grateful to them if they join in certain common programs like road safety, water rich Puducherry, green mission, allocation of unused built-up buildings like the World Bank-constructed fish market etc.

What sort of initiatives and efforts do you expect from the council of ministers and elected representatives to work in unison to ensure cordial relationship between Raj Nivas and the elected government?

That they will accept our invites which will help get their viewpoint. Also, the close work environment will speed up decisions on important public issues.

What are the main areas that remain stumbling blocks for cooperation between Raj Nivas and the elected government?

There are no stumbling blocks. The laws and rules are clear. We just have to abide by them. Be it service matters, financial approvals etc. Where consultation is required it is done as per law. The CS is ensuring this most adequately. This judgment will a great relief for bureaucrats.

Post the Madras HC order, do you plan to invite the council of ministers for a meeting to iron out differences once and for all?

I was inviting and I shall continue to invite. I do hope this time they turn up for the meetings... they accept the invite this time and turn up.

The council of ministers has been accusing you of adopting a confrontational approach towards the government. Are you willing to accept the HC suggestion and reach out to the CM to work together?

I have already said that the Raj Nivas was and remains open to HCM. He is always welcome to come and discuss any matter as he feels he needs to. And respect and communicate with a constitutional office as per the laid down protocol and decorum. I request all elected representatives to join me in field visits wherever they can, and let us know how we could be of help to them. As the goal is common ‘Water Rich Puducherry’, ‘Swachh Puducherry’, ‘Green Puducherry’, ‘Financially Prudent Puducherry’, ‘Law Abiding Puducherry’ and most of all a #ProsperousPuducherry.

Title: PM Modi to visit city on March 21
Content:
Vadodara: Prime Minister Narendra Modi will visit the city on March 21 to attend an event organized by the Gujarat Refinery.

Gujarat Refinery has set up facility to begin production of BS VI fuel that is energy efficient and environment friendly. HPCL too has planned to lay new pipelines for transporting the petroleum products. Modi will dedicate the projects to public at Navlakhi Ground.

Police department will soon install CCTVs at the venue that is now being prepared for the visit.

Modi is later expected to visit Kevadia in Narmada district to inaugurate the cruise facility that has been started near the Statue of Unity (SoU).

Title: Coronavirus scare in Nashik: Chinese importer cancels consignment due to outbreak
Content: NASHIK: A chemical container meant for export to China has returned back from Jawaharlal Nehru Port Trust (JNPT), Mumbai as the importer refused the consignment sighting coronavirus outbreak.Interestingly, this is the first export consignment from the district that has been affected due to virus.The container, which belonged to Halcon (a joint venture between HAL and Concor), was sent from Nashik to Mumbai but the consignment was cancelled by the Chinese importer on the grounds of the virus outbreak.According to Halcon sources, the export orders of grapes and fresh vegetables to China has been going on smoothly. So, the cancellation of the chemical consignment comes as a surprise to them. The total value of the consignment was worth Rs 45 lakh.Halcon has been providing custom clearance procedure for the fruits and vegetables at the facility. “Our objective is to increase the export of vegetables and fruits at large from here to benefit farmers,” said the Halcon official.The Inland Container Depot (ICD) and air complex at Ozar was inaugurated on March 15, 2008 adjacent to the airport. Halcon has invested nearly Rs.70 crores to upgrade the existing infrastructure.The facility at ICD and air cargo complex comprises warehousing, integrated packing center for perishables, cold storage, screening, comprehensive ground handling services for airlines, CCTV surveillance, bar-coding, labelling and customs clearance facilities.The facility has been set up to boost export of fruits and vegetables by sea and air. Most of the Nashik exporters are sending grapes, pomegranates and vegetables by sea cargoes to the ICD facility for clearance. The exporters don’t have to go to JNPT Mumbai for the same process.The containers are ferried by road to JNPT in Mumbai and then shipped further by sea cargo. Fresh vegetables are also exported by air to London, Dubai and other destinations via Mumbai airport.

Title: From well-paid HR to a sanitary worker, he takes pride in his job
Content:
Coimbatore: Along with a few sanitary workers, whose trust he had managed to win in a short span of time, 35-year-old Syed Mukthar Ahmed was seen cleaning roads at Town Hall on Wednesday. He isn’t ashamed to hold a broom in public nor to clean roads. A graduate, Syed says he takes only pride in doing his work. He is one of the graduates who was appointed a permanent sanitary worker by the city corporation recently.

“Is there a norm that a literate should not become a sanitary worker and clean the city?” asks Syed, who had completed MBA and worked as a human resource (HR) with a private concern for close to a decade. “In my previous job, I had to work up to 16 to 17 hours a day. I hardly had any time to spend with my family members. I was missing my family terribly and it was stressing me out.” He is a father of an eight-year-old boy.

Syed said the moment he decided to quit the private company, he was determined to settle for nothing less than a government job as he always dreamt of becoming a government servant. The first recruitment advertisement that he came across was that for sanitary workers and he grabbed the chance without any second thoughts. He is happy that he had managed to get the job.

“It is true that I will get much lesser pay than what I used to get with my previous company. But, after taking up this job, I am able to spend quality time with my family and that is what important to me, and not the money or prestige,” Syed said. The corporation has offered him about Rs 17,000 a month, whereas he was earning more than Rs 40,000 earlier.

Like him, 28-year-old Sathyaprabha, who had completed diploma in computer science, has also taken up the job. She has been sweeping the streets of Race Course for the past few days.

She was also determined to take up a government job and had been trying for the same over the past eight years. “After seeing the way the government servants are treated and the respect they earn from the public, I was determined to become a one since my childhood. I may not be perfect at what I am doing right now, but I will manage to shine brighter.” She said the job has also helped her become financially independent.

Title: UP man held guilty in 2017 attempt to murder case
Content:
Ponda: The additional district court on Wednesday held Akhilendra Kumar Singh, alias Anis, guilty of attempt to murder in a 2017 case. Arguments before deciding his sentence will be held on March 18. The prosecution examined 12 witnesses in the course of trial and the accused has been held guilty of the crime, public prosecutor Satyawan Raut Dessai said.

Singh, a native of Basuchak village of Ghazipur, Uttar Pradesh , is accused of attempting to kill his room mate on the intervening night of November 17 and 18, 2017.

Police records state that the victim, Lalbahadur Singh, then 35 years old, the accused who was 28 years old then and Chhoturam worked as casual labourers on construction sites and were staying in a rented room at Koparwada Curti together.

On the intervening night of November 17 and 18, 2017, Chhoturam went to a colleague’s room for dinner and did not return to his shared room. When he came back to his room, he found Lalbahadur lying unconscious and Anis was missing. He immediately rushed him to Ponda sub-district hospital and also informed his brother Monturam.

Following a complaint from Monturam, presently staying at Deepnagar-Curti, Ponda, police tracked the location of the accused. A team headed by then Ponda PSI Nitin Halarnkar apprehended the accused from Kenjar, a village on the Mangaluru airport road where he was on the look-out for a job, police said.

An offence under Section 307 of the Indian Penal Code had been registered against the accused and a chargesheet in this case was filed in 2018.

Title: Tug of war between Shivraj, Narottam for top post
Content:
Former CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan with former minister Yashodhara Raje Scindia addressing a press conference.

BHOPAL: With BJP feeling it has a real chance of returning to power after 15 months, the question now is who will be crowned chief minister. Party sources say it’s a tug of war between three-time CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan and chief whip in the assembly, Narottam Mishra.

A glimpse of this internal conflict was witnessed during the BJP legislative party meeting on Tuesday evening, when supporters of Chouhan and Mishra confronted each other and engaged in slogan shouting in a show of strength.

Supporters shouted slogans in favour of their respective leaders, and Mishra followers even raised questions on Chouhan’s role during the political crisis in Congress and the state, say sources.

Chouhan, with three terms as CM, is BJP’s most popular leader in MP and an obvious front-runner. Also in the running is Union minister Narendra Singh Tomar , who is close to PM Modi. And Mishra, the blue-eyed boy of Amit Shah, wields considerable clout in the party.

Sources said that Scindia will be offered a ministerial berth in the Modi government — perhaps a prize portfolio like commerce or heavy industries — so there is no chance of his coming to MP. BJP has offered an additional ministerial berth to a minister from among Scindia loyalists now in Bengaluru. And all the breakaway MLAs have been assured to be accommodated in boards, corporations and committees in Madhya Pradesh and the Centre, sources say.

Earlier, it was assumed that Chouhan would be made leader of opposition, replacing Gopal Bhargava. and move a no-confidence motion against the Nath government. But there was no talk on this at Tuesday’s meeting.

On previous occasions, Chouhan had opposed the name of Mishra for the post of LOP after which it went to Bhargava, say sources. Mishra’s name was also proposed for state party chief, but RSS backing propelled V D Sharma to the post. Now, a cold war has erupted between Chouhan and Mishra when they see the party inching towards formation of government. Sources in BJP feel the tussle could come to a nought as the leadership could well spring a surprise — just as it did with VD Sharma, and project a new face.

Title: Kolkata: Raid on mutton shops for using coronavirus scare to jack up prices
Content: KOLKATA: The Enforcement Branch on Wednesday carried out raids at New Market following the reports of certain traders jacking up mutton prices in the run-up to Holi.Cops said the action was taken in the wake of repeated complaints from people against certain mutton traders spreading wrong information about Covid-19 and using it to increase the prices to over Rs 700.Chief minister Mamata Banerjee on Wednesday reacted to the hike in mutton prices, stating that she would ask the enforcement branch to look into the issue.“We acted after receiving several complaints from across different sections of the society. We had been to New Market. We will continue the raids in other markets too,” said DC (EB) Biswajit Ghosh.The EB officers said they would also be visiting the bigger traders to ascertain if there is indeed any scarcity of mutton. “The jump has been phenomenal and coincides with the festive season. We will talk to chicken traders as well. All the factors — that have been cited for the price hike and most of which date back to November and December when severe winter in north India had led to a spurt in demand — will be verified,” said another officer.Most goats come to Bengal via Patna from Purnea, Champaran and Ara. For chicken, the city mainly depends on Andhra Pradesh.“We visited several shops in the city and found that while wholesale prices are between Rs 620 and Rs 640 per kg, the price hovers between Rs 660 and Rs 700 per kg in retail market. We found that the recent hike is a result of the combined factors of unusually high demand and short supply,” said Ghosh. The rumour that novel coronavirus is found in poultry refuses to die down, even though doctors have rubbished it.Heart Care Foundation president K K Aggarwal said: “It is simply a rumour without any scientific basis.”At most markets in the city, the price of mutton has gone up by Rs 50 to Rs 80 per kg in the last few days. Traders are unable to say when the prices will be normal, though most of them predicted that the same would continue even after Holi.“There are now WhatsApp rumours about mutton too just like chicken. Otherwise, the price has hardly seen a slide,” a trader told EB officers.

Title: Covid-19 scare: Hotel bookings at many hill stations cancelled
Content: NAINITAL/UTTARKASHI/HARIDWAR/MUSSOORIE/MUNSYARI: As the coronavirus scare grips the country, the tourism industry in Uttarakhand has started to suffer as well in terms of cancellations of bookings.Hoteliers in Nainital said that almost half of the advance bookings in the lake town’s hotels have been cancelled and the situation is expected to get worse if the fear of the virus is not contained now. “There are several hotels in the town that have said that almost half of their advance bookings have been cancelled. Almost all the big and small hotels have seen cancellation of bookings,” said Dinesh Sah, president of Nainital Hotels’ Association.Resort and hotel owners in and around Corbett Tiger Reserve (CTR) said that while hotels in their area were almost full till last weekend, there has been a sudden spike in cancellations. “Till last weekend, hotels were running at almost 100% occupancy. However, as the fear of coronavirus spread across the world, people have been calling to cancel their bookings. As a result, almost 30% of advance bookings have been cancelled so far,” said Hari Mann, president of Ramnagar Hotels’ Association.In a similar vein, Sanjay Aggarwal, secretary of Mussoorie Hotels’ Association, said that hotels in the Queen of Hills were fully booked for the Holi weekend but owing to the Covid -19 scare, over 30% bookings have been cancelled. He added that bookings for entire March have seen a sudden dip.Jayendra Rana, president of Himalayan Mountaineering and Trekking Association, Uttarkashi, said that trekking operators, too, were seeing bulk cancellation of bookings. “Nearly a dozen foreign tourists’ groups from America, Japan, Italy, Korea and France have already cancelled their bookings. Besides, tourists from Mumbai, Kolkata, Delhi, Pune and Bengaluru have also postponed their bookings to April-end,” he told TOI.Hoteliers in many other places in the state also reported similar situations. “Travel agents have been constantly calling us to inform that group bookings are cancelled as people are afraid to travel in groups. As a result, almost half of the bookings in hotels in Haridwar have been cancelled,” said Ashutosh Sharma, president of Haridwar Hotels’ Association.Puran Pandey of the hotel association in Munsyari said that the hill town has also witnessed a 30% dip in tourist footfall. “Over the past few days, the number of tourists visiting Munsyari has gone down by 30%. People are saying that they cannot take the risk of travelling, with the coronavirus threat looming large.”Meanwhile, Deepak Gupta, secretary of Hotel and Restaurant Association of Uttarakhand, said that if tourists keep on cancelling their bookings, then Uttarakhand as a state will suffer badly. “Most of the state’s revenue comes from tourism and if the sector suffers, effects will be felt across the entire economy.”— With inputs from Abhyudaya Kotnala in Uttarkashi and Anmol Jain in Mussoorie

Title: Demolish 195 polluting plastic units in Katedan: Telangana high court
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: While ordering immediate demolition of 195 polluting plastic units in Katedan area of Hyderabad, the Telangana high court on Wednesday also asked authorities to take action against officials who turned a blind eye all these years.

“With air and groundwater pollution reaching alarming proportions and the number of cancer and asthma patients on the rise, Hyderabad is all set to attain the dubious distinction of crossing Delhi,” said Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan while hearing a PIL against GHMC, pollution control board and power distribution companies for doing precious little to stop these illegal units from mushrooming.

The bench of Justice Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy said the sooner these units were closed, the better it would be for Hyderabad.

“The deputy commissioner himself filed a false affidavit before us saying that there were only three pollutant plastic industries in the area” said Dr Chauhan. “Later when the high court got the matter verified by member secretary G V Subramanyam of state legal services authority, he said that there were in fact a huge number of illegal plastic industries,” he said.

Later the deputy commissioner filed another affidavit admitting the presence of a huge number of polluting industries.

“Either the state or the polluting industries must pay compensation to the victims of pollution,” the CJ said.

GHMC commissioner Lokesh Kumar along with deputy commissioner D Pradip Kumar was present in the court under orders of court after the PIL filed by Vinay Palnitkar and MA Rasheed was admitted for hearing.

During the hearing, the commissioner made a candid admission that the GHMC did nothing in the last eight years to close these industries even though it concluded in 2012 itself that as many as 195 unauthorised plastic industries deserved to be closed.

“We issued closure notices to all of them and law mandates that they should be given a month’s time to get out of the area,” Lokesh Kumar said in court.

Appreciating the commissioner for admitting GHMC lapses honestly, the HC gave him the green signal to go-ahead with his job of closing down the pollutant industries.

The CJ criticised the PCB for sleeping over the issue for the last eight years.

The bench while posting the case to April 7 for further hearing, directed officials to file affidavits on what they have done in the last eight years in respect of these polluting industries and directed the PCB chairman and GHMC commissioner to be present in the court on that day.

Title: Video of ITBP personnel dressed up as bears to scare monkeys goes viral
Content:
Dehradun: A video of two Indo-Tibetan Border Police (ITBP) personnel dressed up as black bears and scaring a herd of monkeys in the ITBP camp at Mirthi in Pithoragarh district has been doing the rounds in social media for the past few days.

The video, apparently shot by ITBP personnel, captures two men wearing a bear’s costume and walking towards monkeys in the camp. Seeing the men dressed as bears approaching, the simians can be seen running away from the spot in the video.

ITBP sources told TOI that they devised the idea after the monkey menace in the area became “too much to bear.” A senior ITBP official said, “The monkeys have become a nuisance for all the people living in the area. Our camp has over 1,000 personnel who live with their families and many a times, they have been attacked. In the past, all efforts to scare away monkeys have gone in vain. But the black bear dress has worked wonders for us.”

Elaborating on how the ITBP stumbled on the bear costume idea, commandant of 7th Battalion of ITBP, Anupreet Borkar said they picked it up from social media. “One of our personnel got the idea from social media. The method is very effective and it does not involve animal cruelty.”

An ITBP personnel, who had worn the costume, told TOI that it is easy to make and wear. “We have designed it ourselves and it’s free-size, so anybody can wear it. It is not a real bear hide but is woven with fur.”

He added that the first time he wore it, the monkeys got so scared that they didn’t return the entire day. “So far, the bear costume strategy has worked well and now there is fixed duty of two personnel who take rounds of the campus in shifts wearing the costume.”

Title: Covid-19: Salem GH makes own hand sanitizer
Content:
Salem: In a first in western Tamil Nadu, the Salem Government Mohan Kumaramangalam Medical College and Hospital has come up with its own hand sanitizer to keep its staff safe from the Coronavirus (Covid-19) spread.

Talking to TOI, hospital dean Dr R Balajinathan said the prices of hand sanitizers have gone up in the market as there was a huge demand for the same today. “We can’t spend that much amount on sanitizers. So, I asked the head of pharmacology department to prepare vaporized sanitizer on their own.”

Subsequently, a 10-member pharmacology department team started preparing the sanitizer. “The team prepared the sanitizer in the second week of February and after getting suggestions and feedback from other doctors, the team refined the product, which is much better than the several existing ones in the market,” the dean said.

The key ingredients that the team used to prepare the sanitizer include isopropyl alcohol, glycerol and hydrogen peroxide. “This sanitizer will get vaporized within a few seconds of application as it contains 75 % alcohol,” said Balajinathan.

Pointing out that the hospital requires at least 25-litre sanitizer daily for its staff, he said, “We were spending nearly Rs 30,000 a week on sanitizer. Now, we are just spending Rs 12,000 to produce the quantity required for a week.” The dean said there wasn’t any plan to market the product.

Title: Government safe, say Congress MLAs in Jaipur
Content:
CM Kamal Nath speaks with media at his Bhopal residence.

JAIPUR: MLAs supporting the Congress government in Madhya Pradesh, including Independents, reached Jaipur on Wednesday afternoon amid a political crisis triggered by former Guna MP Jyotiraditya Scindia leaving the party and joining BJP. The Kamal Nath government in Madhya Pradesh is facing a severe crisis following the resignation of about 22 MLAs said to be loyal to Scindia.

Congress chief whip in Rajasthan, Mahesh Joshi, tasked with making arrangements for the legislators’ stay, claimed 89 MLAs had arrived in Jaipur. But sources said only 82 MLAs have come here.

“We had hosted Maharashtra MLAs in Jaipur in November last year, prior to government formation there, and the results have been good,” Joshi said, adding that the result of the current crisis in MP will also end up “in favour of Congress”.

The MLAs have been lodged at two resorts, Buena Vasta and Tree House, on the Jaipur-Delhi highway on Jaipur’s outskirts.

The MLAs arrived at Jaipur airport around 2.15 pm on a special flight from Bhopal and were received by CM Ashok Gehlot and other party leaders, including state transport minister Pratap Singh Kachariyawas , party chief whip Mahesh Joshi, deputy chief whip Mahendra Chaudhary, and MLAs Rafeeq Khan and Amin Kagzi.

Senior Congress memebrs, including AICC general secretaries Mukul Wasnik and Harish Rawat , also have reached Jaipur. CM Ashok Gehlot, too, went to Buena Vista resort to hold discussions with the MLAs and senior party members.

At Jaipur airport, the MLAs looked in high spirits and claimed that some of them who had gone to Bengaluru were not Scindia loyalists but had been misguided and would soon return to Congress.

Sajjan Verma, PWD minister in the Kamal Nath-led Congress government in MP, said he would go to Bengaluru and bring the MLAs back to Congress.

The MLAs told reporters there was no threat to the Kamal Nath government and that it would survive. They lashed out at Jyotiraditya Scindia for betraying Congress and joining BJP for selfish ends.

A Congress legislator, Sunil Saraf, said BJP was trying to end democracy by dismantling the party system but would not succeed. “The Kamal Nath government will complete its full term. There is no threat. We all are together,” Saraf said. He said the Congress MLAs who supported Scindia had been “misled and deceived” by BJP.

MP Congress member Kantilal Bhuria, who also came to Jaipur with the MLAs, said, “There is no threat to the government. The state government has the majority.” He added that the MLAs would visit tourist sites in Jaipur.

Congress MLA Harsh Yadav said those who had gone with Scindia would be rejected by the people.

Title: ‘Expand scope of screening for HIV patients’
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The District Aids Prevention and Control Unit has advocated enhanced screening of people to detect cases of HIV, even though the number of infected has been showing a steady decline.

The panel’s call went out during a meeting held at the district collectorate on Wednesday to review the treatment being provided to HIV positive patients.

Additional district collector Nilesh Sagar asked the units to expand the horizon of screening people to ensure that no one is left out.

“We are seeing a negative growth in the cases of HIV positive patients. We are happy because it is on the decline. We, however, want to further increase the scope of scanning so that more and more people are brought under the umbrella and nobody is left out,” said the additional collector.

Title: Thirumavalavan booked for hate speech, comments against national integration
Content:
Puducherry: The Odiansalai police on Tuesday booked Viduthalai Chiruthaigal Katchi (VCK) leader Thol Thirumavalavan on charges of hurting sentiments and beliefs of a religious community and passing comments and views that affect national integration during a VCK meeting in Puducherry last year. The police action came after the Perambalur police booked Thirumavalavan following a complaint against him by T N Kannan, Perambalur Hindu Munnani general secretary.

Kannan in his complaint accused the VCK leader of outraging the sentiments and feelings of the Hindus while addressing a party meeting on November 9 last year at Kamban Kalaiyarangam in Puducherry. The Tamil Nadu DGP had forwarded the case file and diary to the Puducherry police as the incident occurred in the Union territory. The case was transferred to the Odiansalai police station in Puducherry through proper channel. The Odiansalai police re-registered a case against Thirumavalavan under Sections 153-B (imputations, assertions prejudicial to national integration), 295-A (deliberate and malicious acts, intended to outrage religious feelings of any class by insulting its religion or religious beliefs), 298 (uttering words, etc. with deliberate intent to wound the religious feelings of any person) and 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace) of the IPC and began investigation.

Title: From waste to fuel: How Doon is leading the way in setting up plastic banks for sustainable management of trash
Content: Dehradun: At a time when depleting crude oil reserves have become a cause for concern, and pollution caused by plastic waste has shown alarming trends, an initiative to turn plastic waste into fuel has been going on for the past few months in the city. As part of this initiative, Doon-based organisation Social Development for Communities (SDC) Foundation is working in collaboration with the Indian Institute of Petroleum (IIP), which has developed a technology to convert plastic waste into diesel.Scientists at IIP have installed a plant with a capacity to produce 750 litres of diesel. The scientists said that the plant has a per day capacity of one tonne, and with setting up of around 10 plastic banks in the city from which they are getting plastic waste, and more in the pipeline, they are hopeful of producing more fuel from waste in the coming months. The plant had been inaugurated by Union minister of science and technology and earth sciences Harsh Vardhan in August, 2019.During the inauguration of the plant, the union minister had announced that for the purpose of collecting plastic, NGOs would be roped in.In Doon, the task of setting up plastic banks is being propelled by SDC Foundation. “The entire concept of a plastic bank is based on community participation. In this regard, we have met individuals, businessmen, RWA presidents as well as educational and government institutions. The idea has been well received by all, as a result of which, plastic banks have managed to become a reality,” said Anoop Nautiyal, founder, SDC Foundation.So far, SDC has set up 10 plastic banks in the city, from which more than 1200 kilos of plastic have been collected. The plastic collected is of two categories — polypropylene which is handed over to IIP for conversion to fuel, while the second category is called multi-layered plastic (MLP) which is recycled through local recycling channels.“When the concept of plastic bank was discussed with us, we knew at once that there could not be a better means of disposal of plastic generated at our showroom,” said Narendra Batra, director of a two- wheeler dealership in Dehradun.Once the collected plastic reaches IIP, it is kept at the plant for initial round of manual segregation. “Before putting the plastic inside any kind of machinery, it’s mandatory to ensure that there is nothing in the plastic which could possibly damage any equipment. This procedure is also important to segregate multi- layered plastic commonly generated from snacks wrappers etc. Once the process is completed, the plastic is prepared for the next treatment,” said Sanat Kumar, scientist leading the project at IIP.After performing the manual segregation, the plastic is shredded in small pieces which are then left for drying inside an enclosure. The dried plastic pieces are then sent to the main plant.The process of converting plastic into diesel lasts for over 36 hours. After the plastic is converted to diesel, the fuel is sent to the engine testing laboratory for checks.“Since the project is ongoing, we are studying every detail minutely for quality check and making the technology fool-proof. Over a span of one year, the quality of fuel produced at the plant has improved drastically. This can be ascertained from the fact that the diesel produced in the laboratory has emission of less than 10 ppm (parts per million) which is as per the standards of BS-6 fuel emissions. The plant is capable of producing 750 to 800 litres of fuel from 1000 kilograms of plastic, and we are working towards increasing it further,” added Kumar.

Title: ‘Cut dangerous trees along Karapur roads’
Content:
Bicholim: Villagers from Karapur, Bicholim, have demanded that dangerous trees along the highway from Bicholim to Karapur be cut . A complaint in this regard has been lodged with the deputy collector on February 13 by Santosh Chari, a social worker from the area.

A Maharashtra registered car was damaged and its occupants injured after branches crashed on the vehicle while travelling from Karapur to Sakhali on Monday evening.

In his complaint, Chari requested the deputy collector to cut trees that pose a threat to the public. A similar incident occurred on Monday wherein branches fell on a moving vehicle, damaging the car and causing its battery to catch fire. Power cables also came crashing down. The occupants were safe as they escaped from the car before any of them were injured.

Title: Police contain anti-CAA protest in Salem, detain 1,110 protesters
Content:
Salem: Tension gripped the city as several hundred Muslims belonging to various outfits and political parties attempted to lay siege to the district collectorate here on Wednesday in protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Register of Citizens (NRC) and the National Population Register (NPR). Police were left with no other option but to detain more than a thousand of them to restore normalcy in the city.

According to a police source, the protesters gathered at the Fort area in the city and started to march towards the collectorate. Police, however, rose to the occasion and managed to stop them before reaching the collectorate premises.

“More than 300 police personnel led by city police commissioner T Senthil Kumar stopped them about 100 metres away from the collectorate campus with the support of barricades,” the source said.

The protesters urged the central and state governments to go back on the CAA, NRC and NPR, which would affect the Muslims in the country. They also squatted on road, blocking the traffic, and raised slogans against both the governments. As the traffic on the stretch came to a standstill, police detained 1,110 of them, who were lodged in nearby marriage halls and let off in the evening.

Title: Scindia’s joining BJP upsets saffron leaders of Gwalior-Chambal region
Content:
File photo of Jyotiraditya Scindia

BHOPAL: For all the fanfare with which BJP welcomed Jyotiraditya Scindia into the saffron fold in Delhi on Wednesday, the Maharaj’s entry has ruffled the feathers of BJP leaders who have been fighting against ‘dynasty rule’ all this while.

Scindia, who was so long their prime target, is now in the same camp. Also, the power equation in the Gwalior-Chambal region will now get complicated as Scindia’s stronghold is also the turf of heavyweight BJP leaders Narottam Mishra and Narendra Singh Tomar — both CM hopefuls.

Scindia and tribal leader Harsh Chouhan have been named as BJP candidates for Rajya Sabha from Madhya Pradesh. There was intense lobbying within state BJP for these nominations for the past two months and many are feeling left out.

A little before 2pm, half an hour before Scindia was to join BJP, speculation erupted in political circles that BJP national vice-president and Rajya Sabha member Prabhat Jha has resigned from all posts, miffed by Scindia’s inclusion in the party. Around 4.15pm, Jha clarified through a tweet that no one should doubt his commitment to BJP. “I have nothing to do with these baseless reports. I condemn this mischief,” he tweeted.

“I was in Parliament. I didn’t know about these rumours till I came out of the proceedings. I have only one thing to say, nobody can challenge my morality, authenticity and loyalty to the party,” Jha told TOI over phone. BJP state media in-charge Lokendra Parashar said: “The reports of Prabhat Jha quitting party posts are false, baseless and mischievous.”

Sources said that former BJP minister Jaibhan Singh Pavaiya and some other leaders, who have been fighting to end ‘dynasty rule’, have not uttered the customary ‘welcome’ on Scindia’s joining BJP. Several leaders in Gwalior region are said to be upset over the decision to include Scindia but are keeping quiet, said sources.

Taking a dig at the situation, Congress state media coordinator Narendra Saluja said, “What will Scindia do? Shivraj will now be his leader. How will he manage with his opponents like Prabhat Jha, Jaibhan Singh Pavaiya and Kailash Vijayavargiya? Speculations of rebellion in BJP?”

Title: 1 held for assaulting MSEDCL staff in Nashik
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: An engineer working with the Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Limited’s ( MSEDCL ) Bhadrakali sub-division was allegedly assaulted by two people whose power supply was cut due to outstanding dues.

A case in this regard has been registered with the Bhadrakali police who have arrested one of the two people even as the prime suspect is missing.

According to complainant Shashank Pendharkar, the assistant engineer was in the office on Wednesday morning when two people approached him. One of them had outstanding dues of Rs 14,360. They created a ruckus in the MSEDCL office as their power connection was snapped.
