Pendharkar told police that MSEDCL had earlier sent notices to consumers seeking immediate clearing of dues; however, since it was not done, it was decided that the power supply of defaulters would be disconnected.

However, the duo engaged in a heated argument with the MSEDCL staff and assaulted an engineer, following which he approached the Bhadrakali police station.

The duo has been booked under various sections of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) including section 353 (Assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty), 323 (Punishment for voluntarily causing hurt).

Police said that a manhunt has been launched to nab the other suspect.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Divisional education officer suspended in Nashik
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The state government has suspended divisional education officer Nitin Bachchhav for creating fake identities of teachers for state government’s Shalarth programme.

Under the programme, teachers from government and government-aided schools get themselves registered for getting their salary directly into their bank accounts.

School education minister Varsha Gaikwad made this announcement in the state assembly while answering to a query raised by Pachora MLA Kishor Patil.

Patil, while asking about payment of teachers, said he had got number of complaints that teachers of various schools in Nashik division — Nashik, Ahmednagar, Dhule, Jalgaon and Nandurbar — had received fake ‘Shalarth IDs’ which enabled them to receive payment from the state government.

In reply, Gaikwad said she had received information from offices concerned and an FIR has been registered for further action against those on the wrong side of the law. “Acting divisional education officer has also been suspended,” she said.

Bachchhav said he would present his case in front of the enquiry officers. “I have nothing to say at this point of time,” he said.

Title: Kolkata Metro: Metro rake breaks down in tunnel
Content:
Shyambazar Metro station

KOLKATA: An old air-conditioned Metro rake faltered inside the tunnel soon after starting from Shyambazar on Wednesday afternoon. Metro services were disrupted for nearly 15 minutes due to the incident that spread panic among passengers. Officials finally reversed the rake and evacuated the panicked passengers at Shyambazar around 3.19pm. The empty rake started towards Kavi Subhash and also carried passengers from the Central station as no other defect was found.

“The incident occurred around 3.03pm soon after the Kavi Subhash-bound rake had left Shyambazar station. Initially, there was brake-binding and then it refused to withdraw power from the third rail. When the rake stopped, one-and-a-half coaches were still at the Shyambazar platform and the driving motorman immediately instructed the conducting motorman (the one at the rear of the train) to run it towards Shyambazar. Passengers were evacuated as soon as the rake reached Shyambazar,” said Metro Railway CPRO Indrani Banerjee.

While Metro Railway started operating the new AC rakes arriving from ICF, Chennai, it is still stuck with some older ones. Metro has now started running over 75% AC services and the older rakes are also being used. This has resulted in some technical glitches over the last few months.

Title: Bhopal: United colours of saffron in Scindia family
Content:
Former Rajasthan CM Vasundhara Raje welcomes Jyotiraditya Scindia after him joining BJP party.

NEW DELHI: At the oath-taking ceremony of Ashok Gehlot as Rajasthan chief minister in 2018, his predecessor Vasundhara Raje was clicked hugging her nephew and then Congress functionary Jyotiraditya Scindia . The picture had gone viral on social media platforms.

Raje shared the same picture on Twitter to welcome her nephew to BJP, the party which had her mother Vijaya Raje Scindia, the then head of the Scindia family, as one of the founding members. With Jyotiraditya Scindia joining BJP, this is first time since 1977 when the entire Scindia clan is together in one party. While daughters Vasundhara and Yashodhara Raje had followed in the footsteps of mother Vijaya Raje Scindia, son Madhavrao had joined Congress.

Although Madhavrao had first become Lok Sabha MP from Guna as a Jansangh candidate in 1971, he contested the 1977 elections as an independent and never returned to the saffron-fold, not even even when he rebelled against Congress in 1996 after being denied ticket in the wake of Jain Hawala case. Jubilation in the Scindia family was visible after Jyotiraditya’s entry into BJP.

“If Rajmata Sahab was here today, she would be elated to see you put the nation first. I admire your strength of character and courage. It’s good to be on the same team. Welcome to BJP,” said Vasundhara Raje.

Yashodhara, a BJP MLA in Madhya Pradesh, said differences within the family are over as she tweeted: “Descendant of Rajmata has taken a decision on the national interest. We shall work together for the nation-building ... all differences are over now. We welcome Jyotiraditya to the party (sic).”

Jyotiraditya joining also brought to fore contributions of Vijaya Raje Scindia, who played a pivotal role in the political journey of Jansangh and later BJP. BJP president JP Nadda recalled how she had contributed to the party since it’s “shaishav” (infancy) days. The Scindia matriarch had retained her faith in the saffron organisation even after pressure was on her to join Congress during the Emergency and preferred going to jail.

Former CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan, said, “It's a joyous day for BJP and me personally. Today, I remember Rajmata Scindia ji. Jyotiraditya Scindia has become a member of BJP family. Yashodhara ji is here with us. Entire family is with BJP. They have a tradition where politics is a medium to serve the people.”

Title: Dist sees increase in forest cover over past two years
Content:
Coimbatore: The forest cover in the district has increased by 9 sq km in a span of two years, said additional principal chief conservator of forests Debasish Jana.

He said compared to the forest survey of India’s report in 2017, the 2019 report showed that forest cover in Tamil Nadu has increased by 83sqkm. In Coimbatore, it has increased by 9s qkm.

He said, “If tree growers and farmers continued at the same rate, we could reach our national target of achieving 33.3% forest cover by 2030.”

Jana was speaking at the inauguration of day two of the tree growers mela organized by city-based Institute of Forest Genetics and Tree Breeding on Wednesday. Speaking about the country and state’s target of achieving 33.3% forest cover by 2030, he said the most recent forest survey report in Tamil Nadu showed a forest cover of 23.9%. “But we are seeing a definite increase if we compare the 2017 and 2019 reports. The credit for this goes to the tree growers and IFGTB which produces quality planting material for mass scale plantations,” Jana said.

Jana admitted that they were practical difficulties in mass scale plantation of trees, because agricultural land or fertile land can’t be used for this purpose as it would create food production issue.

He said multiple institutions including TNAU and IFGTB were working on creating WhatsApp groups for tree growers.

“They will upload videos on how to prune a teak tree, because if you prune it wrong, the tree gets injured, knots will form, and you won’t get good prices in the market. The group is also expected to update details like market price for the quarter, deweeding technologies, soil working ideas etc.,” he said.

He also advised farmers in the region who are eager to cultivate sandal, because of its high monetary value, to first check if they have resources to set up a security system for the trees to ensure it does not get smuggled off. “It is also important to check if they have the right condition to cultivate sandalwood, because the real value and money is in the tree’s heartwood. The outside sap is not that valuable,” he said.

Farmers were also encouraged to get into tree farming because it acts as an insurance against sudden crop price falls or even natural disasters. “These trees are like an insurance policy and can be used for your child’s education,” he said.

“We want farmers to give us feedback on our varieties or even varieties they are growing, to tell us the issues they face, so that we can research ways to solve it,” IFGTB director S Murugesan said.

Title: Restaurant up in flames
Content:
Saligao: Part of a restaurant in a shopping complex in Khorlim, Mapusa, was damaged in a fire on Wednesday. The blaze was triggered after a pan caught fire but intervention by the Mapusa fire service station stopped the flames from spreading to the rest of the high-rise building.

Mapusa fire service officials said that with dense smoke billowing from the kitchen, personnel had to use breathing apparatus to control the smoke. Two fire service tenders were pressed into service to douse the fire, said Mapusa fire service in-charge Bosco Ferrao.

Title: Sikkim accident victims reach home in coffins
Content:
Barasat: Relatives and neighbours mourned the death of Barasat resident Jharna Saha (56) who was killed after the SUV she was travelling in fell into a gorge at Keew Khola near Lingtam in east Sikkim on Tuesday afternoon.

The sound of wails and cries were heard on Wednesday as the coffin carrying her mortal remains reached her home on Taki Road at Barasat’s Kalikapur.

Her only son Raja, also seriously injured in the accident that was reportedly triggered by a landslide, accompanied his mother’s body. A pall of gloom descended on the neighbourhood since Tuesday evening after the news of Saha’s death was circulated in the neighbourhood.

The SUV involved with the accident was carrying 11 tourists, including Jharna, Raja (32) and their shop worker Subrata Das (28), who was also injured.

The Saha family owns a ready-made garment shop in Kalikapur. After Jharna’s husband Montu Saha died two years ago, she used to run the shop with her son. The three had set out for Sikkim with 16 others, including some kin, on March 5.

“We had hired two SUVs for a trip to Peling from Jhilok on Tuesday afternoon. While our SUV was passing by Lingtam Hill near Rongpo, the vehicle was caught in a landslide. Boulders crashing down the hill landed on our SUV, after which it fell into a nearly 100 feet gorge. We cried out in horror. Most of us almost fell unconscious. My mother was sitting in the middle row along with Rishipriya Ghosh (13), my relative who lived in Manicktala. Both my mother and Rishipriya died. When I regained consciousness, I found myself on a hospital bed near Rongpo,” said Raja as he broke down.

The body of Rishipriya arrived at her Maniktala residence. Her school friends and relatives bade a tearful adieu to her.

Title: Man held for spreading false message
Content:
Namakkal: The Namakkal town police on Tuesday evening arrested a 49-year-old man for spreading a false message that Covid-19 spreads through chicken and egg.

The accused has been identified as D Periyasamy, of Thennilai in Karur district. An employee with an edible oil manufacturing unit in Dharapuram in Tirupur district, Periyasamy uploaded the false message on his ‘Instagram’ page on February 10.

“Periyasamy had mentioned on his page that coronavirus spreads through chicken. He had even advised people not to eat chicken and eggs,” DSP Gandhi said.

During police inquiry, Periyasamy has confessed to his crime based on which he was arrested on Tuesday evening.

He was produced before the judicial magistrate of Namakkal district court and lodged in the Salem Central Prison on Wednesday morning under judicial custody.

Before making the arrest, police had made Periyasamy to leave a message on his ‘Instagram’ page that his earlier post on coronavirus was false. tnn

Title: We are with Shrimant, say breakaway MLAs
Content:
When Congress claimed that 13 of the 19 Scindia faction MLAs who are in Bengaluru ‘want to return to the party... Read More

BHOPAL: When Congress on Wednesday morning claimed that 13 of the 19 Scindia faction MLAs who are in Bengaluru ‘want to return to the party’, his supporters released a series of video statements to say they are loyal to ‘Maharaj’.

They also claimed that they are 22 in number and will “follow their leader wherever he goes”. Minister Imarti Devi, an ardent supporter of Scindia, said, “There are 22 of us in Bengaluru and all of us came here willingly and with the blessings of Jyotiraditya Scindia . Maharaj has taken the right decision to keep us here. If we need to jump into a well, we will. But will follow Scindia wherever he goes. Imarti will be there beside him.”

Another minister, Pradyumn Singh Tomar, said: “You know the present political situation. Why did we choose to go with Shrimant (a title to address members of the Gwalior royal family)?”

Tomar argued that Scindia wants development of Gwalior-Chambal region. “He stood with every poor person. Just think how many of us have been picked from the streets and brought to this position. It is our responsibility that development takes place. Since there has been no development, he took this step and we stand with him for the people,” Tomar said.

Imarti, a three-time MLA, claimed Scindia was sidelined “so much by Congress that it was worse than BJP rule”. “Kamal Nath did not listen to us,” she alleged.

In another video, Manoj Choudhary, Congress MLA from Haatpipaliya, asked: “Why did they behave this way with Maharaja? We remain with him and will continue to be so.”

Another minister, Mahendra Singh Sisodia, said: “Jyotiraditya Scindia has not betrayed Congress. He has been betrayed by Congress and Kamal Nath. Despite knowing that Scindia’s hard work brought Congress to power after 15 years, he has been ignored, along with his supporters. They keep saying there is no money and yet Rs 12,000 crore of development work get sanctioned for Chhindwara. Are other ministers and MLAs not to be considered for developmental work in their constituencies? What happened to the promise of farm loan waiver in 10 days? What happened to the promise of stopping corruption and exposing Vyapam scam?” tnn

Title: Bore tide damages Shibpur jetty
Content:
Howrah: The gangway leading to the Shibpur Launchghat jetty in Howrah collapsed as a tidal bore hit the banks of the river Hooghly around 11.30am on Wednesday.

Fortunately, there were no commuters at that time. Authorities of the Hooghly River Jalpath Paribohon Samabay Samity — that maintains the jetty and runs a launch service connecting different jetties on either banks of the river — had issued a warning about the impending high tide and ensured commuters remained off the gangway.

After the gangway collapsed, launch service between Babughat and Shibpur were suspended for the rest of the day. A samity spokesperson said: “Engineers examined the gangway. It will take three to four weeks to repair and restore the gangway”.

Title: Work on Zuari bridge at faster pace than Cortalim diversion
Content:
Panaji: For a year locals squabbled while state officials struggled to build consensus on the new 2.5km service road at Cortalim to facilitate work on the new eight-lane Zuari bridge. During this period, work on the bridge at the Cortalim stretch has already progressed and there may be no need for the road, work on which has commenced recently. Work on the service road was to begin in January 2019, but was delayed by a year due to a number of obstacles.

When the work was finally initiated, locals at Thane in Cortalim placed a condition on the construction work. They said they feared flooding during the monsoon and demanded that bridge contractor Dilip Buildcon construct minor culverts on the stretch, sources said. Company officials, however, told villagers that concrete pipes would be used instead to ensure that the natural flow of water in the area is not affected.

“The villagers were not in agreement. They said that the road would have to be removed and the land restored before the end of April, which was not possible, as it is too soon after the road is constructed,” sources said.

Meanwhile, Dilip Buildcon had already invested time and effort into levelling the ground in preparation for constructing the road.

“Only the preliminary work on the service road has begun and it would require at least another month to complete it. By the time the road is completed, the monsoon would be here already,” vice-president (constructions) Dilip Buildcon Atul Joshi said.

The service road was designed to lead from the Cortalim junction to RK Marbles in Thane. This diversion was a precondition Dilip Buildcon had set for the state to ensure safety of road users while the work on the new Zuari bridge progressed. However, with the service road delayed and the December 2021 deadline for the bridge looming, contractors have already started work on the superstructure.

This means that the service road, which is lying incomplete, and on which work can now be taken up only post monsoon, will be redundant.

The decision to create the service road was taken under former chief minister Manohar Parrikar’s tenure. After many disagreements among then ministers Ramkrishna Dhavalikar and Vijai Sardesai, and a series of inspections, it was agreed to construct the diversion parallel to the railway line, on land leased from Konkan Railway.

But work hit hurdle after hurdle, first because the land had to leased from the Konkan Railway, and then because some locals, who had encroached on the land, objected.

Title: Erode: IT officials raid three oil mills, owners’ houses
Content:
Representative Image

ERODE: Income Tax (I-T) department officials have conducted surprise raids at three oil mills and their owners’ properties in the district to check for any instance of tax evasion. The raid that commenced on Tuesday around 5.30pm lasted till 11am on Wednesday.

A 20-member team from the Erode and Coimbatore income tax offices was deployed to search the oils mills run jointly by S A Arumugam and N Shanmugam, of Erode city.

“They are operating three oil mills - King Refineries Pvt Ltd, Sri Venkateswara oil mills and Sri Padmavathi oil mills - at Kamaraj Nagar in Gobichettipalayam,” said a senior income tax department official, who was part of the raid team, seeking anonymity.

According to the official, Arumugam owns a hotel in Erode city, while Shanmugam runs a lodge.

The team entered the oil mills around 5.30pm on Tuesday and verified the documents. They also searched the houses of Arumugam and Shanmugam simultaneously.

Another source said the raids were conducted based on a tip that the mill owners weren’t showing proper accounts in the income tax statements. “We have collected a few documents and papers from the mills and their houses. We could ascertain any instance of income tax evasion only after verifying the accounts,” the source said.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Class I girl dies in school, parents allege she was beaten to death
Content:
Representative Image

VELLORE: A six-year-old girl student of a private school who reportedly fainted while playing in the school ground during her PET period at Kejalnayakkanpatti near Kandhili in Tirupattur district was declared brought dead at Tirupattur Government Hospital on Tuesday evening.

Charging that the girl was beaten to death by one of her teachers and demanding that the school administration take responsibility for her death, parents and relatives of the girl protested in front of the institution.

A senior police officer said Pachaiyappan, a native of Puliyampatti in Krishnagiri district, along with his wife runs a fast food outlet in Kumbakkonam. His daughter Devadarshini, 6, and son Darshan, 5, were raised by their paternal grandfather Govindhraj at Puliyampatti and studied in Class I and UKG at a private school at Kejalnayakkanpatti.

The school teachers in their statement to police said, “The siblings reached the school in the school van on Tuesday. Devadarshini was in the school playground along with other students for the PET period around 3pm when she fainted. She was immediately rushed to a primary health centre located close to the school and was immediately referred to Tirupattur Government Hospital as her pulse was not stable. At Tirupattur GH, doctors pronounced her dead and the body was shifted to the mortuary for autopsy.”

“In the wee hours of Wednesday, the girl’s parent reached the mortuary and found injury marks on her face. They suspected foul play by the teachers and protested along with their relatives,” the teachers told police.

Speaking to TOI, Ulaganathan, inspector of the Kandhili police station, said, “Demanding arrest of the school correspondent and to seal the school, more than 200 relatives of the girl led by Pachaiyappan picketed the institution and indulged in a road roko on Tirupattur-Krishnagiri road. After police detained school correspondent Nirmala, they withdraw the protest. However, Nirmala in her statement said the injury marks on the girl’s face were sustained when she hit the ground after losing consciousness. She claimed the girl was not manhandled by any of the teachers.” A case under Section 174 of CrPC has been registered and further investigation is on with Nirmala and other teachers of the school, he said.

Title: Elephants raid banana, tomato crops in Erode village
Content:
Representative Image

ERODE: A herd of five elephants raided a farmland in Pinapuram village in the early hours of Wednesday, damaging standing crops such as tomato and banana plants spread across two acres.

S Jayakumar, 48, the farmer whose farmland was raided, said, “This is the fourth such raid by elephants in the past 10 days.” According to him, nearly 300 banana plants and tomato crops spread across half an acre were destroyed in the elephant raid. He pegged the loss at Rs 2 lakh.

When alerted, forest officials assessed the damages that were caused by the elephant raid. Jayakumar said the government should compensate him for the loss. “I have incurred huge financial loss. Forest officials should take steps to properly compensate me for the crop damage.”

Pinapuram village falls in the Jeerahalli forest division near Sathyamangalam. The villagers said the frequency of elephant raid has increased in their area and appealed officials to do the needful to find a permanent solution to curb the same.

Title: Scindia arrives in Bhopal today, to hold roadshow
Content:
Jyotiraditya Scindia is flanked by BJP president JP Nadda and Madhya Pradesh BJP president V D Sharma, as he a... Read More

BHOPAL: After joining the BJP and jolting the Congress government in Madhya Pradesh, Jyotiraditya Scindia is all set to stage a show of strength in Madhya Pradesh, on Thursday. Scindia will begin his MP tour on March 12 from his native place in Gwalior and reach the state capital at 3 pm where he will hold a roadshow from the airport, before reaching the BJP state headquarters.

On March 13, he will file nomination for Rajya Sabha.

"Jyotiraditya Scindia will reach Bhopal airport at 3 pm. He will be taken to the party head office by BJP workers and his supporters in a rally from the airport. The party has organised a welcome programme to honour Scindia. After reaching the office, he will garland the pictures of saffron ideologues Pandit Deen Dayal Upadhyay, Kushabhau Thakre , his grandmother Rajmata Vijayaraje Scindia and his father late Madhavrao Scindia," stated an official release.

Interestingly, it will be first time that the BJP office will have picture of Madhavrao Scindia during an in-house ceremony. The BJP has also organised felicitation of Scindia, a rare event for the newcomers in BJP.

On March 13, Jyotiraditya Scindia will file nomination for Rajya Sabha election. He along with other BJP leaders, will gather at the party head office at around noon and reach the Vidhan Sabha premises to file nomination for the Rajya Sabha polls, said BJP state media in-charge Lokendra Parashar.

Meanwhile, former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan has welcomed Scindia in the BJP. Chouhan in tweet said, "Welcome Maharaj, from Shivraj." The BJP vice-president also supported Scindia in his allegations against the Congress-ruled Kamal Nath government.

“If there was anyone in Congress who was popular, it was Maharaj, so we used to say, `Maaf Karo Maharaj, Hamara Neta Shivraj'. But, it's a joyous day for BJP and me, personally. Today, I remember Rajmata Vijayaraje Scindia ji. Jyotiraditya has become a member. His aunt Yashodhara ji is here with us. The entire family is now with BJP. They have a tradition where politics is the medium to serve people. He also aptly mentioned the corruption and failures in the Congress-led state government," Chouhan told reporters at his official residence after Scindia joined BJP.

Jyotiraditya's aunt and BJP MLA, Yashodhara Raje said that the arrival of his nephew into the saffron fold will provide more strength to Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the party. "The arrival of my nephew (in BJP) will provide even more strength to Prime Minister Narendra Modi in politics at the centre. The heavyweight of Congress is in BJP, now. It will strengthen the party," she said.

Title: Bhopal: CM holds parleys with Digvjjaya Singh, confidante ministers
Content:
File photo of Kamal Nath

BHOPAL: Chief minister Kamal Nath on Wednesday remained busy holding parleys with senior party leader Digvjjaya Singh and a group of his cabinet colleagues.

Ministers Dr Govind Singh, Sajjan Singh Verma, Jaivardhan Singh , Priyvrat Singh, Tarun Bhanot , Lakhan Singh and Arif Aqueel were part of the deliberations. The meeting, which began in the morning after rest of the ministers and MLAs left for Jaipur continued till this report was filed.

“We have the numbers and we shall prove it on the floor of the House,” Nath told reporters.

The chief minister had sent Sajjan Singh Verma and Dr Govind Singh as his emissaries to Bengaluru in an attempt to woo back the rebel Scindia supporters. When they returned, they claimed that they had contacted the rebel MLAs and they would return to party fold.

Title: Students protest move to convert textile institute into research centre
Content:
Coimbatore: Students of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International School of Textiles and Management (SVPITM) in the city have been protesting for the past two days against the move to convert the institute into a research centre.

The director of the institute issued a notification on Monday stating that student intake would be stopped from the academic year 2020-2021. The students say this move would undermine the value of their degrees.

The notification said the ministry of textiles was now contemplating to set up a centre of advanced research on textiles at the institute. “The ministry has also communicated that the new admission 2020-2021 does not seem a viable option. However, the existing batches will continue till they complete their graduation,” it said.

Last month, the students staged a protest for around two weeks by boycotting classes seeking that the institute be affiliated to the Central University of Tamil Nadu (CUTN), so that it would get more funds for research and development. The students had said there was a decision to bring the university under the National Institute of Fashion Technology. They had also complained that the institute lacks laboratory facilities and qualified faculty members.

A protester said following their protest then, the institution’s administration had said they would not be able to get affiliated to CUTN but would function under the ministry of textiles. “We had withdrawn our protest as we thought half of our demands were met. But now they have said the institute would be closed and a research centre would be set up in its place. This would undermine the value of our degrees. We fear we also cannot aspire to get admitted in any other higher education institute of repute,” an undergraduate protester said.

Protesters also said they feared that if the admissions are stopped, the permanent faculty members would be sent away and in their place guest faulty members would be brought in their place, which would affect the quality of academics.

Around 150 students of the institute have been protesting at the campus.

Efforts to reach the institute’s director went in vain. When TOI contacted the institute, it was said the director was in Chennai. Other faculty members were in a meeting at the campus, it was said, but they couldn’t be reached for comment.

Title: Docs, nurses get latest updates on Covid-19
Content:
Coimbatore: An awareness session for healthcare professionals on the latest updates on Covid-19 was conducted by the Indian Medical Association’s Coimbatore chapter in the city on Wednesday.

More than 450 healthcare professionals, including doctors and nurses, from government medical colleges, the state health department and private hospitals attended the programme. They were taught the basics of the diagnosis of the disease and which patients they should refer for testing and treatment protocols in place.

The programme focused on self-prevention, checking the spread of the infection, diagnosis and treatment. “Since health professionals have to work close with patients, they were told the ways to protect themselves, including wearing masks and washing or sanitizing their hands before and after examining patients,” IMA state secretary Dr A K Ravikumar said. “Patients showing symptoms like fever, cold and cough with a recent travel history from abroad or fever with body pain is the main criteria for testing for the virus,” he added.

Reminding the professionals that anti-viral drugs for the virus are yet to be found, the programme pointed out that treatment is symptomatic for the disease. “If the patient is at the risk of developing pneumonia or some lung infections, we should treat them accordingly. They can be given oxygen support or ventilator if required,” said Ravikumar. Doctors have also decided to display the 104 helpline number prominently in all hospitals, for patients to contact if they suspect they were infected with the virus. tnn

Title: Ready to face scathing attack from DMK, says S P Velumani
Content:
Coimbatore: Claiming that the DMK has been spreading false information about him, local administration minister S P Velumani on Wednesday said he was prepared for the scandalous attack.

“I am the prime target for DMK president M K Stalin now. I am told that the DMK would start spreading more false information about me in the coming days,” the minister told reporters in the city. He said the DMK’s IT wing and certain leaders were behind the alleged misinformation campaign against him on social media.

“DMK leader R S Bharathi should stop his derogatory speeches,” he said pointing out that Stalin had not condemned the alleged unpleasant remarks made by the former against the media and the judiciary.

Velumani, however, said the AIADMK government would continue to do the good work. “We have spoken about expansion of VOC Park in the assembly during the demand for grants. Chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami as well as forest minister Dindigul C Srinivasan have assured support for the project. The government will bring in more welfare projects,” he said.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Nashik administration invokes DMA in district
Content: NASHIK: People who are directly or indirectly helping the spread of coronavirus or not co-operating with the government machinery in controlling the spread of the disease can be jailed for three months under the Disaster Management Act DMA ), which has been invoked in the district given the spread of coronavirus.District collector and chairman of the District Disaster Management Authority Suraj Mandhare has announced the implementation of the DMA in the district.The actual implementation of the Act will be done by civil surgeon Suresh Jagdale as the incident commander, while district health officer Dawal Salve has been appointed as the joint controller.Salve said, “The DMA implementation gains significance given the coronavirus scare. The district health machinery, under the instructions of the civil surgeon, can stop people from gathering at a certain place.”“If there is a need for a hospital to admit people suspected to have caught the virus or if the health department needs a few hospital beds, the civil surgeon can instruct the hospitals concerned. Services of private doctors can also be sought,” he added.Meanwhile, the civil surgeon would be preparing an independent medical squad to take preventive measures. Salve said they would also be spreading awareness about the virus. All primary health centres (PHC) have been instructed to put two banners on coronavirus — one at the PHC and the other at the ST bus stand.The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has been asked to take action against drug and medical store owners and operators if they are found selling medicines or masks at marked-up prices.

Title: Man accidentally shot dead on hunting expedition in Bicholim
Content:
Keri/Bicholim: A hunt for mouse deer in a forest at Sarvan, Bicholim , went horribly wrong when one man died after he was accidentally shot at by his hunting companion on Tuesday evening.

The incident has also highlighted that trophy hunting and poaching wild animals for their meat, skin, teeth, bones and blood is still rampant in the state.

Bicholim PI Sanjay Dalvi told reporters that when the accused, Anand Gawade, 39, fired at a mouse deer he had spotted in the forests of Vhavati on Tuesday, the shot mistakenly hit his companion, Santosh Govekar, severely injuring him.

Govekar, 55, was rushed to hospital by his relatives where the doctor on duty declared him ‘brought dead’. Gawade was consequently arrested under provisions of the IPC and the Arms Act. He also surrendered his rifle and two bullets to the police.

On Wednesday afternoon, North Goa SP Utkrisht Prasoon and a team of Bicholim police visited the area where Govekar was shot. They recovered his blood-stained shirt and found two bullets in its pocket. A blood sample of the deceased was also sent for testing.

This is not the first time someone has been accidentally killed while on a hunting expedition. Amrut Singh of the Bicholim animal rescue squad told TOI that one other hunting companion had mistakenly been killed under identical circumstances 8-10 years ago.

The forests of Vhavati in Sarvan’s Vathadev, which lie on the left bank of the Bicholim river, are foraging areas for several herbivores such as mouse deer, barking deer and wild boar. Incidence of animals being hunted in this area during the summer is generally high given the growing demand for their meat. Apart from rifles, snares, traps and explosives planted in potatoes are also used to hunt wild animals.

When contacted, North Goa deputy conservator of forests Kuldip Sharma said his staff was working hard to curb poaching. The Keri range forest officer also said forest guards have been patrolling the Sarvan-Karapur area and taking all the necessary steps to tackle poaching. However, despite having an anti-poaching squad in place, the forest department lacks vehicles and trained staff to contain the illegality.

Title: Nirbhaya case convict seeks FIR against Delhi cops
Content:
Pawan Gupta

NEW DELHI: One of the death row convicts in the 2012 Nirbhaya case has sought an FIR against two police constables for alleged physical assault inside Mandoli jail, where he is lodged. The incident, however, is stated to have taken place in July, last year.

Pawan Gupta’s counsel A P Singh filed an application and said the incident took place on July 26, 2019, when the convict was thrashed “very badly on the head and also his entire body with a stick” inside jail number 14 of Central Jail, Mandoli. Singh said that a court issued notice to the jail authorities concerned.

Gupta was beaten up again on July 28, 2019, when he once again received injuries all over his body besides being verbally abused, the application said. “Blood oozed from his head and only after repeated requests and a prolong delay he was sent to Guru Teg Bahadur Hospital,” the plea claimed.

It has been contended in the application that when Gupta’s father approached the local police station to lodge an FIR, he was harassed and threatened. And despite representations before various police authorities no action was taken, it added. “Please take legal action as soon as possible,” the application said.

On March 9, another convict, Vinay Sharma, approached the lieutenant governor’s office seeking commutation of his death sentence to life imprisonment.

Sharma, in his petition, described his life behind bars and what he faced during his confinement. The plea also urged the LG to allow Sharma’s lawyer to make oral submission before him.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Students protest move to convert textile institute into research centre
Content:
Representative Image

COIMBATORE: Students of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International School of Textiles and Management (SVPITM) in the city have been protesting for the past two days against the move to convert the institute into a research centre.

Protesters also said they feared that if the admissions are stopped, the permanent faculty members would be sent away and in their place guest faulty members would be brought in their place, which would affect the quality of academics.

Around 150 students of the institute have been protesting at the campus.

Efforts to reach the institute’s director went in vain. When TOI contacted the institute, it was said the director was in Chennai. Other faculty members were in a meeting at the campus, it was said, but they couldn’t be reached for comment.

Title: Bhopal: For supporters, loyalty to Scindia is above party
Content:
Congress MLAs show their resignation letters in Bengaluru on Tuesday

BHOPAL: Political observers believe that chief minister Kamal Nath and senior Congress leader Digvijaya Singh despite their sound political acumen failed to gauge the extent of influence Jyotiraditya Scindia exercised on his supporters, which may ultimately proved “fatal” for the incumbent Congress government in MP.

“Nobody, how-so-ever big leader can claim that all his supporters including the ministers and MLAs would quit the party on the issue of his neglect or disrespect. This is difficult more so, if the party is in power, but Scindia pulled it off. It’s here that the party leadership erred and were caught on the wrong foot in denying the “safe” Rajya Sabha seat to him,” said a senior PCC office-bearer on the condition of anonymity.

The question, obviously, is what is the source of Scindia’s enormous charisma among his supporters?

“It is unprecedented. Personal loyalty towards Scindia ahead of commitment to the party is obviously one of the reason, but there is another major factor what I could gather from Scindia supporters had been hinting at neglect by the party and the bureaucracy. In fact, they also had the same grouse as Scindia. They were also feeling marginalised as Scindia did. And, when Scindia decided to take the initiative, they followed suit, said political analyst, Girijashankar.

He recalled that none of the supporters of his father late Madhavrao Scindia except a few little-known names had left the Congress party when he floated his own party after being denied ticket by the Narsimharao’s Congress party in the aftermath of Hawala scandal nor anyone went with Arjun Singh when he launched Tiwari Congress with N D Tiwari about the same time.

Political observer, Jairam Shukla , said “It’s of course unprecedented in MP but I feel by the time budget session of state assembly begins on March 16, at least half of them would be won over by Kamal Nath. As the euphoria ebbs out, the rebel MLAs would also think about their own future.

Shukla also gave example of Gujarat BJP leader, Shankar Singh Vaghela , in this regard and said when he revolted against Keshubhai Patel in 1995, he had support of 105 out of 121 BJP MLAs, but when he decided to send his supporters to Khajuraho, the number reduced to 47 and ultimately a peace formula was brokered and Suresh Mehta was made the CM. “I am not contemplating a peace formula here but no. of Scindia supporters who revolted may come down by half”, he said.

A leader from Chambal region traced loyalty of Scindia supporter MLAs to feudal culture which still dominates Chambal and some other pockets of Madhya Pradesh “MLAs supporting Scindia went with him because they believe that the influence Scindias wield over electorate in Chambal region has a major role in ensuring their win.

Title: Bharne cracks the whip on officials to step up heat
Content:
Nagpur: Addl CP, crime, Nilesh Bharne has urged his collegaues to prepare records of goons and also undetected offences in the city to enhance the effectiveness of the police department in curbing and putting brakes on the criminal elements in the city.

During an internal meeting on Friday, Bharne is learnt to have asked the crime branch officials to ensure the crime data is updated on a regular basis and ensure they are available for the top brass to refer for analysis and supervision. He advised cops to prepare crime data and statistics zonewise and also at the police station level for micro-management and monitoring.

Apart from statistics on crime, Bharne has also stressed upon the existing data on the undetected crimes in the city, especially the ones like the firing on city mayor Sandip Joshi, which are of serious nature. He has also urged the cops to collect information on the goons released from jails, follow up actions on the hardened ones and update their modus operandi.

Bharne also made it a point to ensure that the information on the gangs involved in gang rivalry are also updated on a regular basis. He also instructed cops to keep a tab on the goons who are out on bail and their current whereabouts.

Title: Dining halls to be set up in schools
Content:
Coimbatore: The directorate of school education has sought details of government schools with unused classrooms to convert them into dining halls for the students who avail the midday meal scheme.

A recent communication from the directorate of school education to all chief education officers said it was decided at a meeting held by the commissioner of social welfare to identify an unused classroom at a government high school or higher secondary school per union to be converted into a dining hall for the students who avail the midday meal scheme. It has also sought details of such schools.

Midday meal scheme workers said at present only a very few government and aided schools were having dining halls for midday meal scheme. In most of the schools, students either sit under tree shades or on verandas to have food.

“There is no separate dining hall for the midday meal scheme in almost all the government and aided schools. Students find a space inside the school campus to sit and eat,” said a midday meal worker.

She welcomed the move, saying that would help the students have food in a hygienic atmosphere.

“If funds are earmarked for constructing dining halls and kitchens in government and aided schools, such facilities should be set up in all the schools in a few years,” the midday meal worker said.

Title: Suspected Maoist held in pre-dawn operation near Anaikatti by TN cops
Content:
Coimbatore: In a pre–dawn operation, the ‘Q’ branch sleuths of the state police nabbed a suspected woman Maoist near Anaikatti at the Tamil Nadu–Kerala border on Wednesday morning.

The suspected Maoist P Srimathi, 27, hailing from a village in Sringeri near Chikkamagalur in Karnataka, along with a woman was picked up by the sleuths from a TNSTC bus based on a tip. The police team rounded up Srimathi when the bus was nearing a check post at Anaikatti around 5.30am. Police sources said that the duo was traveling from Kerala to Karnataka via Coimbatore.

The source said that both Srimathi and the other woman were taken to an undisclosed location for interrogation and were likely to be produced before the court in Coimbatore on Thursday. Police were tightlipped about the identity of the other woman who was detained along with Srimathi.

Police said that Srimathi was a member of Kabani and Bhavani dalams of the Communist Party of India (Maoist). Though there were no cases registered against Srimathi in Tamil Nadu, over 20 cases were registered together in Kerala and Karnataka. She was on the watchlist of Karnataka and Kerala police.

When the Kerala’s anti–Naxal police force Thunderbolt carried out an encounter killing four suspected Maoists in Agali forests of Palakkad district in October last year, word spread that Srimathi was one among them. In fact, a team of Karnataka police even visited Kerala after the encounter, but it turned out that Srimathi was not among them. However, sources said that Srimathi was present along with other cadres when the Thunderbolt team swooped down on them killing four, but she managed to escape.

Since police believed that Srimathi might have sustained bullet injuries during the escape, vigil was mounted in hospitals along the TN–Kerala border on suspicion that she might get admitted for treatment. However, she managed to evade arrest till Wednesday. Soon after she was produced in the court and remanded, the Karnataka cops are expected to seek her custody in connection with the cases there.

This is the second arrest of a prime Maoist suspect in Coimbatore district after Deepak, another Maoist sympathizer who was arrested in November last.

Title: Excise raids across state to crack down on arrack sale
Content:
Vijayawada: In the largest-ever joint operation by police and excise officials aimed at curbing illegal liquor trade, raids were conducted across the state on Wednesday. The operation, code named Operation Sura, was led by excise and sand enforcement IG, Vineet Brijlal and was under the direct supervision of DGP D Gautam Sawang.

As many as 759 teams, each with 10 to 15 members from both police and excise departments, raided suspected places where arrack is brewed, belt shops and sale of non-duty paid liquor (NDPL).

The coordinated operation started as early as 5am with respective district in-charges supervising the teams. The enforcement teams seized 1,03,052 litres of jaggery wash, apart from 4,150 litres of illicitly distilled liquor. The raid was conducted in view of the local body elections to curb distribution of liquor to woo voters.

Speaking to TOI, Brijlal said Operation Sura was the largest coordinated operation conducted across the state. “Although the timing of raids is significant in view of local body elections, we would like to sustain the momentum with the synergy between police and excise enforcement wings to ensure that the state becomes arrack-free. The cooperation extended by the DGP, commissioners of police and district SPs was remarkable and we are looking forward to take the enforcement work to the next level,” he said.

While arrack was found in every district except Nellore, which stands out with no case of being booked with regard to it. Although the number of villages raided was second highest after Guntur, Nellore was found to be arrack-free. The district seems to be continuing its legacy where the Anti-Arrack movement took the combined Andhra Pradesh by storm in 90s.

But the raids revealed that Kurnool, East Godavari and Srikakulam accounted for more than 50% of the total jaggery wash destroyed across the state. The arrack menace seemed to dominate in districts with forest cover and borders with other states.

The enforcement officials also seized 1,575kg of dry ganja at Paderu in Visakhapatnam district apart from seizing illicit liquor. Five people were arrested and three vehicles have been impounded.

Title: 2011 Balli riots: Locals acquitted of all charges
Content:
Colva: Judicial Magistrate First Class Saee Prabhudessai on Wednesday acquitted all eight Balli locals persons charged with unlawful assembly, rioting and voluntarily causing hurt in 2011 .

The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) had charged Prashant Faldessai, Mohan Faldessai, Satyendra Faldessai, Arun Faldessai, Vinod Faldessai, Dayanand Kolkar, Bhupesh Naik Dessai and Surendra Fatorpekar under Sections 141, 143, 146, 147, 149 and 323 of the Indian Penal Code.

On May 25, 2011, United Tribal Associations Alliance (UTAA) had launched an agitation during which they blocked the highway and railway at Balli junction and also damaged police vehicles and assaulted government officials.

Balli villagers were shocked and frustrated at the alleged violence unleashed by UTAA members and, hence, gathered in large numbers and assaulted then Canacona MLA Ramesh Tawadkar using lathis.

In all, CBI lawyer A S Chand examined 55 witnesses in support of his case, while advocate Amey Prabhudessai represented the accused. The JMFC acquitted the accused of all the charges.

Title: Hyderabad Coronavirus: Three Italy returnees rushed to Gandhi hospital from airport
Content: HYDERABAD: Three passengers who had returned from Italy and had symptoms of Covid-19 were rushed to the Gandhi hospital from the Shamshabad airport on Wednesday morning. The three were among 25 new suspected cases reported on Wednesday.Meanwhile, the first and only positive Covid-19 patient in the state has now recovered completely. However, a suspected patient who had come from Kalburgi reportedly succumbed at a private hospital.“We do not have any information about the patient. We will try to find out the details and have already alerted the Karnataka government,” said a senior official from the state health department. Speaking about the control measures against the virus, Telangana health minister Eatala Rajender assured people that the state is free from the virus and all measures were in place.Sharing details, the minister said on Wednesday that three new testing centres — Institute of Preventive Medicine (IPM), Fever hospital and Kakatiya Medical College — have been approved. The three are in addition to the existing facility at the ICMR lab in Gandhi Medical College and the Osmania General Hospital. Trial testing at the OGH lab began on Wednesday . Testing in the rest is expected to begin in five days.The state government has released Rs 50 crores out of the Rs 100 crores promised for tackling Covid-19. After several rounds of meetings, state health authorities have decided to purchase air filters for the corona isolation wards at Gandhi hospital, Fever hospital, OGH and Chest hospital at the cost of Rs 1.5 crore each.

Title: I’m not for sale, says Congress MLA from Sheopur
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: Congress MLA Babulal Jhandel on Wednesday alleged that he was offered Rs 35 crore by BJP on Tuesday and asked to walk over to the saffron fold. “But, I refused, saying mein bikau nahi hun ( I’m not for sale ),” Jhandel said.

Jhandel, the Sheopur legislator, on Wednesday made the allegation when former PCC chief Arun Yadav met him at his ancestral village. Yadav, on a mission to mobilise Congress MLAs to be taken to Jaipur, went to Jhandel’s village in a chopper, accompanied by Baijnath Kushwah , Congress MLA from Sabalgarh.

Jhandel, who is mourning the death of his father on March 2, said he couldn’t accompany Yadav to Jaipur for the last rites. “Don’t worry, I am not on sale. No one can purchase me,” he told Yadav, and promised that after completing the rituals, he would be in Bhopal in time for the crucial assembly session.

“I am supporter of chief minister Kamal Nath ,” he said. He also spoke to Nath over phone and reiterated his support to Congress.

Sheopur is part of Chambal division , where Jyotiraditya Scindia wields considerable influence.

Yadav returned Bhopal in the evening. Talking to TOI, he sounded confident: “All is well. The government is safe.”

Title: 5 Covid-19 suspects admitted to Nashik civil hospital
Content: NASHIK: Five people, who returned to the city from the affected countries, have been kept under observation in the wake of coronavirus outbreak. While three people have been admitted to the isolation ward of the Nashik civil hospital, two people have been admitted to the Adgaon Medical College.Of the three admitted to the civil hospital, one is a 65-year-old woman while two others are husband and wife.The medical staff said that the woman, a resident of Nashik, had returned from Dubai on March 10. Soon after, she started suffering from cough and cold and was admitted to the hospital.Meanwhile, another city-based couple was admitted to the isolation ward on Wednesday. The couple returned from Dubai on March 7 and were suffering from health complication.Throat swabs of all the five people have been sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) Pune for examination.Civil surgeon Suresh Jagdale said that the 23-year-old woman from Nashik Road, who was admitted to the isolation ward of the hospital on Tuesday, tested negative for coronavirus. She has also been discharged.Health officials said that apart from the three people admitted to the isolation ward of the civil hospital, 22 others, who had returned from the affected countries, were under observation.Jagdale said that people should not panic due to the overall situation of coronavirus though everyone needs to take precautionary measures.District collector Suraj Mandhare has appealed to people to refrain from visiting crowded places and public gatherings as much as possible.

Title: 1 held in Nashik with cannabis worth Rs 6.10 lakh
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: City police have arrested a 54-year-old man with cannabis worth Rs 6.10 lakh from Nashik Road area of the city on Tuesday.

The suspect, Rajendra Baburao Pekhle, is a resident of Trikoni Galli in Sinnar.

During the patrolling, the central unit personnel came across a white car which was parked on the service road in the Palse area of Nashik Road.

The patrolling team grew suspicious when the car driver started his vehicle and began escaping the scene on seeing the police. However, the patrolling team was swift enough to intercept the car on time. Upon checking the car, police found 30 kg cannabis kept inside the vehicle.

Police inspector Seetaram Kolhe of the central unit of the crime branch said, “Officers and personnel of his team were patrolling the city area on Tuesday when they came across Pekhle.”

The suspect was presented before a local court that remanded him in four-day police custody.

Title: If we defeat its fear, cancer too can be defeated, says Sonali Bendre
Content:
Nagpur: Ace Bollywood actress Sonali Bendre who survived serious metastatic cancer last year said that getting over the fear and stigma of cancer is the first step towards defeating this deadly disease.

“For many of us, cancer means death. But, I’m a living example in front of you all. We can defeat cancer at any stage,” she said while sharing her experience of battling cancer.

The actor was diagnosed with high-grade cancer two years back, in 2018. Doctors had told her that she had 30% chances of survival. She decided to take the battle head-on and finally emerged victorious.

Sonali visited Nagpur’s National Cancer Institute (NCI) on March 5 to celebrate the first anniversary of ‘Ayushmati’, a unique initiative of NCI that supports free cancer screening for healthy women above 40 years of age.

In the last one year, 1398 women from Nagpur got themselves screened for three types of cancers in NCI for free.

“We all believe that cancer is not going happen to me. But we need to understand this can happen to anybody. Women feel shy or experience fear even from getting screened for cancer. If you don’t get screened, how will you detect it in the early stage?,” she asked while appreciating the Ayushmati project.

Sonali embraced and advocated the tagline of the National Cancer Institute which is “Freedom from Fear of Cancer”. “I think it is important to spread the message — Early Detection Saves Lives,” she said.

The programme began with the introduction to the National Cancer Institute and its initiatives, especially “Ayushmati”, by Shailesh Joglekar, General Secretary and CEO.

Dr Anand Pathak, medical director, gave an outline about the journey of ‘Ayushmati’ and the data trends observed. He impressed upon the need for cancer screening for women for early detection due to the growing prevalence of cancer among women in India.

Shital Teli-Ugale, Metropolitan Commissioner, NMRDA was the guest of honour.

“A complete household revolves around women and the well-being of women determines the well-being of the family. If we save lives of women through early detection, we are saving the complete household and all the members involved,” she said.

She encouraged women to come forward for early detection and appreciated the efforts taken by National Cancer Institute by conducting “Ayushmati”.

Sonali Bendre, chief guest of the function, expressed how fascinated and shell-shocked she was after visiting the National Cancer Institute as she compared it with other globally located cancer hospitals.

She shared her experience of battling cancer and her denial saying, “How can this happen to me? We all have the believe that this is not going happen to me. But we need to understand this can happen to anybody.”

“Ayushmati” will continue operating for the next year and would invite women who have visited through the past one year for cancer screenings and continue to encourage other women above the age of 40 to get themselves screened.

Title: Coimbatore: Hindu Munnani goes back on assurance
Content:
COIMBATORE: Hours after the religious outfits assured the district administration that they would drop all their protest plans for a week, Hindu outfits went back on their word and declared that they would hold a massive rally on Thursday in the wake of the attack on an RSS functionary on Wednesday evening.

“To condemn the Coimbatore police, which failed to control extremism, Hindu Munnani would take out a rally from Anna Statue on Avinashi Road to the district collectorate,’’ Hindu Munnani spokesperson C Dhanabal said. He alleged that the police had failed to prevent the attack on RSS functionary Suryaprakash at Sundarapuram as well as in controlling the anti–social elements.

Earlier in the day, Hindu outfit members who were summoned for a meeting by district collector K Rajamani assured him that they would not hold any protests for a week. They said the protest planned on Wednesday evening condemning the attack on one of their functionary was also being withdrawn.

State president of Hindu Munnani Kadeswara Subramaniam said that they took the decision in the afternoon to withdraw the protest heeding to the directions of the district collector. “But we would organize a massive protest in April if the police department fails to take action against those who had attacked the functionaries of Hindu organizations. The date would be finalized after discussion with party members,” he said.

However, the members held an emergency meeting and decided on the Thursday rally after the attack on Suryaprakash. In the wake of the Hindu Munnani rally, police have started beefing up security further in the city even as steps were on to get them drop the rally.

State president of SDPI Nellai Mubarak alleged that though seven incidents including attacks on party functionaries and stone pelting on vehicles took place, the accused have not been arrested.

Title: Italy-returned student tests ‘interim positive’ in Nellore
Content:
Vijayawada: An ‘interim positive ’ case of novel coronavirus was reported from Nellore city on Wednesday.

The swab samples of the suspected Covid-19 student, who landed from Italy via Chennai, were sent to Viral Research and Diagnostic Laboratory (VRDL) at SVIMS in Tirupati and NIV, Pune.

While the test in Tirupati showed positive, officials are waiting for confirmation from Pune as the latter is better equipped to diagnose viral infections.

During screening at the Chennai airport, the student tested negative for high temperature. He later developed symptoms of Covid-19 leading to his isolation at government general hospital in Nellore on Monday night. Earlier, he was in home isolation for three days but developed cold and fever.

With a suspected positive case, officials were alerted. Teams at the GGH were also alerted to take additional care in handling the suspected case. Sources said that on average three to five samples are sent to VRDL at SVIMS daily for past one week from various parts of AP.

Meanwhile, the state control room at the office of the director of health and family welfare, however, said so far no positive cases of Covid-19 has been reported in Andhra Pradesh. Of the 48 samples that were sent for examination, 44 tested negative while the results of the remaining four samples are awaited.

Title: RS nominees promise more central funds to state
Content:
Vijayawada: The four nominees of YSRC filed their nomination papers for the Rajya Sabha elections on Wednesday.

Ministers Pilli Subhash Chandra Bose, Mopidevi Venkata Ramana and industrialist Alla Ayodhya Rami Reddy filed one set of nominations while Parimal Nathwani filed two sets of papers.

All the four went to the assembly together and filed nomination papers with returning officer in the assembly premises in Velagapudi.

Earlier in the day, the four candidates met chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy at his Tadepalli residence and received the party B Forms from the party chief before filing the nominations.

After meeting the chief minister, the candidates thanked Jaganmohan Reddy for nominating them to the elders’ House. They said that they would work for the state and get funds from the Centre during their term. Nathwani, a close associate of Reliance Industries chairman Mukesh Ambani, said he would work for infrastructure development of AP.

Party senior leaders Sajjala Ramakrishna Reddy, minister Botcha Satyanarayana, former Union minister Ummareddy Venkateswarlu, MP Maragani Bharath and MLA Alla Ramakrishna Reddy were present when the candidates filed their nominations.

Rajya Sabha member V Vijayasai Reddy expressed confidence that the new MPs would strengthen the hands of the chief minister in developing the state. “The chief minister had maintained the social balance. Out of four seats, two seats were given to the BCs which indicates the YSRC party’s commitment to the uplift of the BCs and others,” Vijayasai Reddy said.

Title: Coimbatore: New sanitary workers while away time as expectations fall short
Content:
Representative Image

COIMBATORE: While a few women were busy sweeping a road near the city railway junction on Wednesday, a middle-aged woman with a broom in her hand was engrossed in a conversation on her phone. She was one of the candidates recruited as a sanitary worker by the city corporation a few days ago.

“It’s just the third day of her work but officials are really tired of dealing with her,” a corporation official said, when asked about the middle-aged woman. “Officials have been putting huge effort just to make her pick up the broom. Even after that, she neither does her job nor allows others to do their work peacefully.”

She is not the odd one. In the Town Hall area, four of the five workers, who were hired recently, did not turn up for the work after officials informed them on their first day of the work that they would have to sweep the roads, the official said.

“Of the four, only one managed to touch the broom on the first day and clean the roads for an hour. Even she left work crying. They thought that they would be given some office work. They were not ready to touch the brooms,” the official added.

Another official attached to the health wing of the corporation said similar reports were coming up from almost all the wards where new appointees were deployed. “Not all the new appointees are uninterested in work. Some of them are diligent and are already picking up the pace. But, some others are under the impression that they could get some office work by clearing the recruitment conducted for sanitary workers.”

At the time when the temporary sanitary workers are striking, lack of co-operation from some of the new appointees has put other permanent workers and officials under pressure.

A sanitary worker from the Vadavalli area said even before the strike, they were assigned multiple tasks due to less manpower.

“Now after half of the sanitary workers had gone on strike, our work has increased multiple times. Even before we could complete a task, another work is assigned to us and we are working overtime to complete it,” he said. However, we could not conduct door-to-door collection of garbage or clear bins in all the areas, he added.

Title: Shiv Sena moves Bombay HC for standing committee chairman repoll
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The city unit of the Shiv Sena filed a petition in the Bombay high court, drawing the latter’s attention to the civic administration’s observation that the strength of the party should increase in the standing committee of the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC).

The party has requested the court to order a fresh election for the post of the standing committee chairperson.

M L Patil, the civic body’s lawyer, said that he bench of Justice S J Kathawalla and Justice R I Chagla on Wednesday announced to hear the matter again on March 19.

After the mayor announced the appointments of eight new standing committee members on February 24, the state government had stayed the appointment after the Sena complained that BJP had more members in the panel than its strength in the civic body merited. Even the civic administration had stayed the polls, which was supposed to take place on March 3.

However, Jagdish Patil, the BJP group leader in the NMC, moved the high court challenging the state government’s stay order and the decision of the civic administration to stay the poll for the standing committee chairperson.

The state government had also asked civic chief Radhakrishna Game to file a status report about the appropriate representation of each party in the standing committee based on the party’s strength in the House.

In his report, Game had observed that the strength of BJP should be reduced from nine to eight and that of the Sena should increase from four to five. The strength of Congress, MNS and NCP should remain unchanged. These three parties have one member each in the panel.

“In our petition to the high court, we have submitted a copy of Game’s status report. We have requested the court to order the NMC to hold re-election for the post of the standing committee chairman . We are optimistic that the decision would be in our favour,” said senior Sena corporator Ajay Boraste.

Title: Coimbatore: Churches to get funds for repair, renovation
Content:
Representative Image

COIMBATORE: The state’s minority welfare department has been sanctioned Rs 5 crore to repair and renovate churches that function out of their own buildings. The district administration has called on the churches in its jurisdiction that are more than 10 years old to approach them for the financial assistance for repair and renovation .

A communication from the district administration said the churches have to be functioning from own buildings for more than 10 years to be eligible for the aid. The site on which the church stands should be registered and so should be the church. “It also should not have received any foreign funding for repair and renovation works earlier,” the communication said.

On applying for the assistance, a team that is constituted by the district collector would visit the church to study the building plan and project cost and based on merit recommend the same to the directorate of minority welfare. “The funds will be given in two instalments,” it said.

Those who wish to get the assistance should download the forms from http://www.bcmbcmw.tn.gov.in/ and submit the same at the backward classes and minority welfare department at the district collectorate, the communication said.

Title: Tamil Nadu government machinery plunges into action to bring normalcy
Content:
Tension gripped in the city after miscreants hurled a petrol bomb at Hindu

COIMBATORE: Even as the government machinery has plunged into action to contain tension sparked by communal elements in Coimbatore, a gang assaulted a member of a Hindu outfit on Wednesday evening.

Two men wearing helmets barged into the shop of Suryaprakash, 28, an RSS functionary, near Sundarapuram in the city outskirts around 6.30pm. The men assaulted Suryaprakash with rods and fled the place within moments in a motorbike. Soon after the attack, Suryaprakash, who sustained injuries on his head and in arms, went to a private hospital for treatment in his friend’s bike as a pillion rider. Police who rushed to the spot and conducted inquiries said they are yet to identify the assailants and the motive.

Incidentally, the attack took place when DGP J K Tripathy who flew down to Coimbatore in the afternoon, was holding a meeting with senior cops in the city on measures to be taken to contain the violent attacks.

On Tuesday night, unidentified men who were travelling on a two-wheeler had hurled stones at the auto of A Sheriff, 32, a resident of Kuniyamuthur, when he was traveling near Puttuvikki road in the city.

Tripathy has instructed the officials to step up vigil in the city and crack down on the anti–social elements sparking tension. He has also told the authorities here to expedite investigation into the assaults and petrol bomb attacks over the past few days and arrest all those behind the incidents.

Earlier in the day, ADGP (law and order) Jayanth Murali held a meeting with city commissioner Sumit Sharan where they discussed ways and means to diffuse the tension and reign on the outfits which are upping the ante every passing day.

District collector K Rajamani for his part held a meeting with Hindu outfit members and asked them to bring normalcy to the city. The collector told the functionaries that communal clash would pull down the growth of Coimbatore at a time when the city is bracing up for massive development.

Rajamani said both the district administration and police department was taking steps to ensure law and order in the city. “Following a few unpleasant incidents that took place in the city, meetings were conducted with outfits and they had assured to extend their full support to us. We have been taking serious steps to bring normalcy in the city,’’ he said.

He warned of stringent action against those who spread fake or hatred messages in social media.

Title: Canadian team meets Jagan
Content:
Vijayawada: A delegation led by Canada Council General Nicole Girard on Wednesday met chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy and showed interest in investing in Andhra Pradesh. The team admired the government welfare schemes in the fields of education, health and agriculture.

Speaking on the occasion, Girad consented to invest in various fields like pharma and smart city. “The relations between Canada and India are in good terms and both countries are working together on climatic changes. We are interested in improving relations with Andhra Pradesh and planning to invest in the state,” she said tnn

Title: Charges to be framed against two foreigners for possessing drugs
Content:
Panaji: The principal district sessions judge, North Goa, Irshad Agha has ordered that charges be framed against two foreigners Martin Akimov and Christopher Pattison, involved in separate cases for allegedly possessing drugs .

Akimov was found in possession of narcotics worth 4.90 lakh in January 2019 in Siolim . The court stated that the complaint in detail prima facie shows the involvement of the accused.

Police placed on record the seizure report, the house search panchnama, which shows that the raid was conducted in a flat and papers indicating that the investigating officer complied with procedure of sending the report to higher officers.

Akimov was allegedly caught with 30.8g of suspected MDMA, 7.6g of suspected 30 Ecstacy tablets, 0.3g of suspected 20 LSD Papers.

“The substance was sent for examination and was found to be tested positive for the above substances. Hence, charge has to be framed against the accused under Section 22(c) and 22(b) of Narcotics, Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (NDPS) Act, 1985,” the court stated.

In the second case, Pattison was allegedly found to have cultivated cannabis plant weighing 740g worth Rs 2.45 lakh in the international market, in the compound of his property in Porvorim .

After being sent for chemical examination to Central Forensic Science Laboratory, the report tested positive for Cannabis. The chargesheet papers show that information was received, and sent to higher officers and only thereafter, the police proceeded for the raid.

The court found the investigating officer followed procedure contemplated under Section 57 of the NDPS Act and stated that the material on record is sufficient to frame charge.

“Besides prima facie material, the police has taken photographs of the plant and property where the plant had been grown. All this shows that the accused has committed offence,” Agha stated.

Title: Coronavirus in Hyderabad: Round-the-clock doctor at Hitech city IT company
Content: HYDERABAD: An IT company from Hitech city has deputed a full-time medical centre to assure their employees that they will be protected from coronavirus . The employees have also been told that all medical expenses owing to the virus will be taken care by the company.“The medical centre is within the office premises, where employees can freely walk and get their questions and apprehensions answered, medically validated/checked and be suitably informed,” said Dr Megan Pinnamaneni, chief strategy officer of Tetrasoft.Meanwhile, in view of anxiousness in the IT corridor after the positive Covid-19 case in the city, the ‘nodal committee for Covid-19 Cyberabad’ has issued standard operation protocol.Screening of all visitors, barriers between employees and visitors, discouraging large gatherings which involve close proximity and encouraging use of technology for meetings was suggested. This is in addition to screening all employees having symptoms and recent travel history to affected countries, placing sanitizers and hand cleaning spaces.“Telangana government is actively engaging with industry bodies to review and monitor Covid-19. While Telangana had witnessed one positive case as on date, there has been panic in IT corridor due to one un-confirmed case reported on 4th March which was ultimately proved negative. The primary objective of releasing SOP is to equip all IT companies/IT Parks to deal with situation, should there be any Covid-19 suspected case reported,” read the document.

Title: Mantralaya deserted; uncertain times for chief-secretary-in-waiting
Content:
Offices at the Vallabh Bhavan were locked since morning

BHOPAL: Amid the political developments in the state, secretariat bore a deserted look on Wednesday. Most of the bureaucrats and staff were not seen at their workplace a day after Holi.

The chief minister’s office on the fifth floor of Vallabh Bhavan—which on weekdays is abuzz with ministers, MLAs and officers turning up—saw no such hustle bustle. Chief minister Kamal Nath ’s OSDs were not seen, except a couple of them. Political activities are being coordinated from CM House at Shyamla Hills in Bhopal, said sources.

A handful of ones who had turned up were seen discussing the fate of the state government. On March 5, the Nath government appointed additional chief secretary M Gopal Reddy as the OSD to the chief secretary’s office.

Offices of additional chief secretaries and principal secretaries were locked since morning. Officials, who are part of the crisis management team of the government, remained hopeful.

“It would not be that easy for BJP”, said an officer, who is part of the crisis management team. MP budget session is set to begin from March 16 and a floor test is expected anytime once thereafter. Kamal Nath took oath as chief minister on December 17, 2018. On December 31, Sudhi Ranjan Mohanty was appointed as chief secretary.

Mohanty is retiring on March 31 and Reddy was set to replace him. It’s normal practice to get the would-be chief secretary to the chief secretary office as OSD in advance so that he gets a hang of the job. If the ruling dispensation changes, it may impact Reddy’s prospects as chief secretary. It may also put on hold policies and schemes floated by Nath government.

Title: Red tape holds up proper salaries of Gaganauts
Content:
Isro chairman K Sivan

NEW DELHI/BENGALURU: India may be tom-tomming its maiden human spaceflight mission “Gaganyaan”, which is planned for 2022, but is yet to provide the four selected fighter pilots, currently undergoing training in Russia, with the requisite documentation and authorisation due to persisting bureaucratic bottlenecks.

The government sanction letter (GSL) for the four IAF pilots or “astronaut-elects”, who began their 12-month training programme in Russia from February 10, is yet to be signed and issued, said sources on Wednesday.

Incidentally, Isro has also been allocated only Rs 1,200 crore of the Rs 4,257 crore it wanted in the 2020-2021 budget for the Gaganyaan programme. As cleared by the Union cabinet in December 2018, the total cost of Gaganyaan — which envisages sending a crew of astronauts to space and bringing them back safely to earth before India’s 75th Independence Day in 2022 — is pegged at Rs 10,000 crore.

“Without the GSL, the pilots cannot get their proper salaries, allowances and furnished accommodation in Russia under the rules. Nor can their families join them in Russia. As of now, ISRO is making ad hoc payments to them for their sustenance. The bureaucratic lethargy even for a prestigious national mission like Gaganyaan is simply staggering,” said a source.

Sources say there is also some dispute between the finance and external affairs ministries over whether the four pilots should get “consular status” as has been proposed. Isro officials were unavailable for a response despite repeated attempts by TOI.

But a senior IAF officer in Bengaluru said: “Since Isro is the overall implementing agency of the Gaganyaan mission, the department of space had the responsibility of getting the test pilots the required documentation. They have not done it. We’ve been told there has been some issue with the finance department’s clearance, and that they are working on the matter.”

The four Group Captain-rank pilots, all with 20-24 years of service, were selected from an initial pool of about 60 after extensive screening and tests. They are undergoing the planned training programme at the Yuri Gagarin Research & Testing Cosmonaut Training Center (GCTC) at Oblast in Russia as part of the pact Isro signed with Glavkosmos, a subsidiary of Russian space agency Roscosmos, in June last year.

Glavkosmos director general Dmitry Loskutov had earlier told TOI that the training will include comprehensive medical and biological training, along with a strict physical regimen. They will also study in detail the systems of the Soyuz manned spaceship.
