“They’ll be trained for the eventuality of an abnormal landing of the descent module in various climatic and geographic zones. During the scheduled flights aboard the special Il-76MDK aircraft, they will also be trained to move and operate in weightlessness modes and environment,” he said.

At the end of their training in Russia and India, one or two of the four pilots will finally be selected to circle the earth in India’s first manned spaceflight mission after Isro undertakes two unmanned missions with humanoids. The country is keeping its fingers crossed.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Three Hyderabadis among 15 Indian students stuck at Milan airport
Content: HYDERABAD: As many as 15 Indian students, including three from Hyderabad, are stuck at Milan’s Malpensa airport as authorities have asked for medical certificates to prove that they are not afflicted by coronavirus As of Wednesday evening, the students had already spent 36 hours at the airport.Helpline numbers at the airport have been of no help as local doctors have asked them to contact the Indian embassy to get the test done.“We are unable to get the test done and are getting no help from anywhere,” said Donta Teja Sree, who had gone to Italy to pursue her masters in biotechnology. The Air India flight took off without them though they had been booked on it on Tuesday.Having nowhere to go, the students spent the night at the airport and are still there. “But airport authorities are asking us to leave saying that the flight we had been booked on has departed,” Dontha Teja Sree told TOI over the phone. Her parents live at Miyapur in Hyderabad. On Tuesday, there were as many as 50 Indian students at the airport. Some of them left to the houses of friends or relatives. The 15 who stayed back have nowhere to go. The students said they are hungry as there is no food available at the food courts.The Indian embassy in Italy initially told them that arrangements for accommodation will be made, but later asked them to organise it with an assurance that they will be reimbursed. The students, however, said that since the entire city was in lock down, like the rest of Italy, they could not venture out.

Title: MP health department’s response moves from containment to ‘mitigation’
Content: BHOPAL: For the first time, MP’s health department has used the term ‘mitigation’ instead of ‘containment’ in relation to measures being taken to slow down the spread of novel coronavirus (COVID-19).The state health department has sent three more samples of suspected COVID-19 cases for testing. So far, 27 people have been tested, out of which 19 samples are negative and eight reports are awaited, according to a press release. MP has not reported any positive COVID-19 case yet. ‘It is essential that steps are taken to mitigate the effects in Madhya Pradesh ,” said the directive issued by MP health department commissioner, Prateek Hajela . Dr Mohan Singh is in-charge of a COVID-19 team for detection, surveillance and control of the infection spread of the disease. The order was issued on Wednesday.Twenty-four more people with a travel history to COVID-19-affected countries have been added to the surveillance list in the last two days. Since January, in MP, 664 travellers from COVID-19-affected countries have been identified and 265 are under home isolation while 356 have completed their observation period. A total of 56 quarantine centres have been set up in the districts, with a total of 744 beds. The 104 call centre is activated to receive calls about information and guidance for COVID-19. Screenings of passengers coming from the affected countries are going on at Indore, Bhopal , Jabalpur and Gwalior airports.District chief medical and health officer and civil surgeons have now been vested with all authority to ensure control of the COVID-19 outbreak, under the Public Health ACT 1949 under Section 71 (2).

Title: Collectors in areas of Scindia sway transferred
Content:
File photo of Jyotiraditya Scindia

BHOPAL: With minutes of Jyotiraditya Scindia ’s joined BJP on Wednesday, the Kamal Nath government in Madhya Pradesh replaced collectors of five districts in areas of Scindia’s influence.

Ajay Singh Gangwar, collector of Neemuch, was transferred as commissioner of Sagar division and replaced by Jitendra Singh Raje. S Viswanathan will be the new collector of Guna district in place of Bhaskar Lakshakar , who was shifted as deputy secretary in state secretariat. Kaushlendra Vikram Singh is replacing Anurag Choudhary as Gwalior collector. Choudhary has been posted as deputy secretary in the state secretariat.

Pankaj Jain will be the new collector of Vidisha while Anurag Sharma has been appointed as collector of Harda.

Title: Telangana: Mahendra Hills safe, no coronavirus cases
Content: SECUNDERABAD: No person suffering from symptoms of coronavirus was detected in the one-day door-to-door survey conducted on Wednesday at Mahendra Hills in Secunderabad Cantonment.Mahendra Hills had garnered national headlines after a 24-year-old resident was tested positive for Covid-19, in Telangana’s first confirmed case.As the virus scare resulted into the area coming to a standstill, Secunderabad Cantonment Board (SCB) and health department swung into action for sanitation work. Efforts to identify persons affected by the virus are also being made.“Special teams from the state medical and health department and the Cantonment board on Wednesday deployed teams in Ravi Colony, Trimurthy Colony, Dhanalakshmi Colony, Vyjayanthi Colony, Balamari Society and Shantiniketan Colony to conduct a door-to-door survey. The teams visited nearly 2,000 houses and enquired about any person suffering from cough, cold or fever,” M Devender, senior superintendent of health and family wing, SCB, told TOI.No possible cases were detected, the official added. The teams advised the residents to follow protective measures and told them about the efforts taken by SCB.The survey report will be submitted to the state government (health department), said an official.Residents of Mahendra Hills and abutting areas have started attending their daily works as state health minister Etala Rajender has announced that the affected person is safe.

Title: Illegal mining: HC dismisses govt’s appeal
Content:
Panaji: The high court of Bombay at Goa on Wednesday dismissed the state government’s appeal against Sameer Salgaocar and Arjun Salgaocar in the illegal mining case. Justice Nutan Sardessai dismissed the state’s revision appealing against the sessions court verdict.

The sessions court last year had discharged the two, stating that it was beyond the limitation of 3 years as the complaint was filed by the mines department in 2014 while the offence was allegedly committed in 2009/2010.

Title: Coronavirus in Andhra Pradesh: Italy-returned student tests ‘interim positive’
Content: VIJAYAWADA: An ‘interim positive’ case of novel coronavirus was reported from Nellore in Andhra Pradesh on Wednesday.The swab samples of the suspected Covid-19 patient who landed from Italy via Chennai were sent to Viral Research and Diagnostic Laboratory (VRDL) at SVIMS in Tirupati and NIV Pune.While the test in Tirupati was positive, officials are waiting for confirmation from Pune as it is better equipped to diagnose viral infections.During screening at Chennai airport, the student tested negative for high temperature. He later developed symptoms leading to his isolation at government general hospital in Nellore on Monday night. He was earlier in home isolation for three days.Officials and the GGH have been alerted to take additional care. Sources said that on average, three to five samples are sent to VRDL at SVIMS daily for past one week.

Title: Harvard, Stanford, MIT go online
Content: Harvard University, Stanford , MIT and University of Washington have asked students to not return after the spring break. Campuses are moving to virtual instructions. Syracuse University and New York University have closed their Florence campuses. Stanford’s on-campus housing was vacated. University of Melbourne offered support of up to AUS$7,500 for students who incurred extra expenses due to travel curbs.

Title: Coimbatore Coronavirus News: Coimbatore-based man stranded in Rome, blames Indian government
Content: COIMBATORE: A city-based software developer is now stranded in Rome for the only reason that he does not have any symptom of Covid-19.Srinithin Jayabal, a resident of Peelamedu in the city, was stopped by airport authorities in Rome when he was about to board a flight after clearing the security check and immigration on March 10.Jayabal, who spoke to TOI over phone on Wednesday, said along with him around 15 Indian passengers had also cleared immigration and security check when a few Emirates staff panicked and asked us to step aside.“They told us that India had instructed all airlines not to board Indians on the flight unless we had a Covid-19 negative certificate,” he said.Srinithin Jayabal flew to Rome on February 26 for a two-week trip to meet his clients. At the time, Covid-19 had mainly affected only northern part of Italy and the Lombardy region. “I had planned to return on March 14, but since Italy went into a complete lockdown since yesterday, I rescheduled my tickets to return on March 10,” Jayabal said.Jayabal said he left the airport and approached multiple hospitals in Rome, both public and private. All the hospitals refused to give a certificate. “According to Italian law, only patients with Covid-19 symptoms can be tested for it. Doctors said they can’t simply test us just because we want to return to our country,” he said.Jayabal said the Indian embassy in Rome knows the Italian law and should inform the Indian government that getting Covid-19 negative certificates for people without symptoms is not possible. “The Indian embassy is impossible to reach, because the hotline does not work. When we went there physically, we were not even allowed inside and instead made to stand out in the 5 to 10 deg C. They told us that they have mailed the health ministry and only after they get a response, can figure out the next course of action,” he added.The 30-year-old businessman says he is yet to hear from the external affairs ministry or the Indian embassy even after his tweets to the external affairs minister C Jaishankar and a long email he wrote to all the three on Tuesday night. “Why are we not allowed to return to our own country? And how can an embassy not facilitate return of their citizens to their country? This is bizarre. Why do we pay taxes to facilitate such embassies then?” he asked.On Monday, all shops, restaurants, hotels and public transport in Rome went into a lockdown after Italy confirmed that they had more than 10,000 cases of the virus.

Title: Ahmed Khan issues a statement saying Kangana is a 'female Baaghi, the hero of Bollywood' and expressed his wish to collaborate with her!
Content:
Ha ha Arrey Khan Bhai saab, 155 crore ki film ko flop kehte ho, aapki film Baaghi3 ne 49 ka weekend kiya aur Manika… https://t.co/xSX6aMmDpl — Rangoli Chandel (@Rangoli_A) 1583916149000

'Baaghi 3' director Ahmed Khan recently stated that Kangana Ranaut tried to achieve success with 'Manikarnika: The Queen Of Jhansi'. He added that after making it on a large scale budget the but money was wasted and the makers faced a lot of losses.He went on to add the teaser of Kangana's upcoming action-adventure 'Dhaakad' was fabulous, however, after the fate of 'Manikarnika', the film has been shelved.Soon, Kangana's sister Rangoli Chandel took to her Twitter to react to Khan's comments. Referring to 'Baaghi 3' collections, she wrote, "Ha ha Arrey Khan Bhai saab, 155 crore ki film ko flop kehte ho, aapki film Baaghi3 ne 49 ka weekend kiya aur Manikarnika ne 45 ka, jayada peeche nahin hai aapse, Manikarnika ka 102 India karke dekhao phir baat karo, abhi toh aapke seetare gardish mein hain".The filmmaker received a lot of backlash for his comments on Kangana's projects. Now, according to the latest report, he has issued a statement where he praised Kangana by calling her female 'Baaghi' and 'hero of Bollywood'.Through the statement, he also expressed that Kangana is the only actress who can pull off an action flick. He further stated that he really liked the teaser of 'Dhaakad' and got 'gooseflesh' while he watched it. Showering love over the actress, he expressed that she is a brilliant and powerful performer. And also added that if the actress approves, he will definitely work with her.Meanwhile, Tiger Shroff and Shraddha Kapoor starrer 'Baaghi 3' has crossed Rs 80 crore mark at the box office on the sixth day.

Title: Crime branch set to bring court ‘Pairavis’ under its control
Content:
Nagpur: The court ‘Pairavis’ or constables entrusted with the responsibilities to co-ordinate with the police stations regarding the trial proceedings are shortly expected to be brought under one platform of the crime branch. As of now, every police station has its own ‘Pairavis’ who function separately.

The city police, faced with the uphill task of improving the conviction rate, has now been contemplating certain changes in its functioning. The latest modifications envisioned by the city police is to ensure that the ‘Pairavis’ or court constables are brought under the unified command of the crime branch.

In the statistics released by the state crime investigation department (CID), the conviction rate of city police in 2017 was as low as 8.5%. There had been some improvement in the next two years but the conviction rate remained a prime concern for the city police.

Sources in the police department said that the police station in-charges are waiting for a written order to release their pairavis.

Addl CP, crime, Nilesh Bharne is learnt to be keen to bring the pairavi constable under his command for better monitoring of the trial cases and proceedings. It’s learnt that Bharne has issued a fresh instruction to the police station in-charges for releasing the court constables at the earliest as per an earlier order from the top brass.

Title: Goa: Rs 1,400 crore Zuari bridge hit by coronavirus
Content: PANAJI: The eight-lane, over Rs 1,400 crore Zuari bridge project is set to become an unlikely victim of the novel coronavirus.As work of installing pipes for cabling in the superstructure of the bridge is to begin, suppliers of the cables from China and the design experts from Shanghai and Paris, who were to arrive in Goa soon have had to put off their travel plans after the central government suspended all visas and e-visas granted to nationals of France and China due to Covid-19.“The supplier of the cables has already written to us that they are unable to travel due to travel restrictions in place because of the coronavirus. There are no experts in the field in India,” the bridge contractor, Dilip Buildcon vice-president (constructions) Atul Joshi said.“We were to begin installing the pipes for cabling and then begin the cabling. The new bridge project has a complex design and before starting the work, we wanted the cable suppliers and the design experts to take a look at the calculations,” he said.The new bridge over Zuari has many unique features, which will be a first in India. It will be the widest cable-stayed bridge in the country at 54m.French bridge specialist Erwan Vicat of Paris-based Ingerop in association with Infinite Civil Solutions has done the technical design of the bridge. Similarly, Dewei Chan of Tongji University , Shanghai, who has checked the bridge design proof, was also scheduled to arrive in Goa along with an Ingerop expert.“We were to carry out the cabling in June-July after advice in the calculations from the design experts. We will begin the work at our end. But now it is difficult to say when the experts will be able to travel to Goa. If the situation does not ease, work will definitely be affected,” Joshi said.The bridge work has already been delayed and it is now scheduled to open for use in December 2021. One four-lane section was expected to open for use before this date.The bridge and the approach roads are being constructed by Bhopal-based Dilip Buildcon in a joint venture with Ukrainian company Mostobudivelnyi Zahin Ltd (MBZ).Once completed, it will be the second largest cable bridge lengthwise in the country after Vidyasagar Setu in Kolkata.The new eight-lane bridge will be an expressway of sorts connecting North and South Goa.

Title: TDP chief blames cops, SEC for attack
Content:
Amaravati: TDP president N Chandrababu Naidu on Wednesday alleged that YSRC has made mockery of elections to local bodies with tacit support from authorities. He said TDP leaders and activists were attacked and injured in several villages. He asked what purpose would serve if the State Election Commission failed to protect candidates from opposition parties.

Showing video-clips of the attack in Macherla, Naidu asked whether YSRC leaders wanted to kill TDP leaders. He said YSRC activists went on chasing TDP leaders Bonda and Budha Venkanna on 10 motorcycles and two cars. “They are using heavy logs and iron rods. When the DSP tried to rescue the TDP leaders, the YSRC activists damaged the DSP’s car,” alleged Naidu. He said DGP Gowtham Sawang should take responsibility for the police’s failure to prevent the attacks. He said they had informed Guntur rural SP Vijaya Rao about the visit to complain about tearing up of nomination papers of TDP candidate in Bodalaveedu.

“It is a total failure of the police and the SEC. They have not taken preventive steps,” Naidu charged.

Title: Bandhan Bank unveils 125 outlets in 15 states
Content:
Kolkata: Bandhan Bank has opened 125 banking outlets across 15 states. The opening of the new outlets comes days after the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) lifted its restriction on new branch opening for the bank. The apex bank had barred Bandhan from opening new branches in September 2018. The bank had a network of 1,010 bank branches, which now stands at 1,013.

With an infrastructure of 3,206 banking units and the 195 home loan service centres across the country, the total number of banking outlets now stands at 4,414. The bank has its presence across 34 of the 36 states and Union Territories (UT) in India.

Out of the 125 new banking outlets, 42 have been opened in Uttar Pradesh, 29 in Rajasthan, 12 in Madhya Pradesh, seven each in Andhra Pradesh and Telangana, six in Bihar, five in Chhattisgarh, four in Odisha, three in Tamil Nadu, two each in Uttarakhand, Karnataka, Maharashtra, and Assam, and 1 each in Delhi and West Bengal.

Chandra Shekhar Ghosh, MD & CEO, Bandhan Bank, said, “We are happy that with the withdrawal of restriction on opening new branches, we will be able to expand business growth rapidly. In our four-and-a-half-year existence as a universal bank, we have been quick to identify opportunities of expanding distribution and setting up our presence. The 125 new banking outlets will help further serve our customers who have shown faith in us. We are confident on continuing our growth trajectory driven by the trust that our customers and stakeholders shower on us.”

As on December 31, 2019, Bandhan Bank served 1.9 crore customers and, had deposits worth Rs 54,908 crore and advances worth Rs 65,456 crore. The total business of the bank stood at Rs 1,20,364 crore.

Box

Iskcon to write to PM on Yes Bank money

Religious organisation Iskcon will write to Prime Minister Narendra Modi and finance minister Nirmala Sitaram for a speedy resolution in case of Yes Bank. The organisaion whose finance is controlled from Kolkata has an exposure in the insolvent bank in the form of fixed deposit and savings account.

An official of Iskcon said that it has traced 42 accounts of the organisation all over India. In Kolkata, it has two-three accounts. The total amount in the city Yes Bank branches would be Rs 2.5-2.6 crore taken together its FD and savings accounts. “There is a separate account for mid-day meal also in Yes Bank but that amounts in small. This is a separate account from Iskcon,” added the official.

Title: Delhi University News: No salary in 12 Delhi University colleges for 2 months
Content:
Delhi University

NEW DELHI: In 12 Delhi University colleges, teachers and non-teaching staff haven’t been paid their salaries for two months now. The funds have apparently been withheld by Delhi government because the colleges haven’t notified their governing bodies , approval for which, they claim, is awaited from the university.

The 12 institutions, fully funded by Delhi government, are Indira Gandhi Institute of Physical Education & Sports Science, Shaheed Sukhdev College of Business Studies, Shaheed Raj Guru College, Deen Dayal Upadhyaya College, Dr Bhim Rao Ambedkar College, Acharya Narendra Dev College, Bhagini Nivedita College, Keshav Mahavidyalaya, Maharaja Agrasen College, Aditi Mahavidyalaya, Mahirishi Balmiki College of Education and Bhaskaracharya College of Applied Science.

Besides the faculty, salaries and payments to sanitation workers, contractual labourers and other non-teaching staff have also been held up. At DDU College, principal Hem Chand Jain claimed, “It seems we will not be able to pay salaries even from April 1.”

When asked for his response, deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia countered that the government-aided colleges had been doing a lot of “illegal work” because “without governing bodies in place the colleges can't function”.

The issue may take time to be thrashed out. Another principal pointed out, “We are yet to get a concrete response from Delhi government on when and how the issue will be resolved.” He, however, revealed they had information that government representatives would meet vice-chancellor Yogesh Tyagi on March 17 regarding the matter. A DU official confirmed the meeting.

The official also disclosed the possibility of the university’s Executive Council approving the names at its sitting on March 13. EC member Rajesh Jha had this to say: “The VC has not acted as per statuary laws on the governing bodies. Last year, the DU administration did not table the names for the EC’s approval.”

The DU official also accused the AAP government of “flouting norms in selecting some of governing board nominees” and argued that in the pattern of assistance, which is like an MoU between the government and the university, there was no clause saying that government funds wouldn’t be released to an institute that didn’t have a governing board.

Besides the state government, the university administration too is facing flak. Sujit Kumar, commerce teacher at Bhim Rao Ambedkar College, attributed the face-off to “a fight between two political parties”. He said that while Delhi government was wrong in withholding funds, “we believe the DU administration failed in its duties to resolve the problem due to political reasons”.

Kumar backed his view by noting, “If Delhi University had reservation about some of the government nominees, it could have asked for new names. But in some colleges, DU decided to go ahead with truncated governing boards. In some others, it could not even identify university or teacher representatives.”

Title: 20 beat up two athletes over wrong-side driving ruckus
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A mob of around 20 young men thrashed two athletes after they objected to wrong-side driving in Pashan.

The incident occurred in Sutarwadi on Monday night. The athletes, Adinath Naik and Jaygovind Yadav, have lodged an FIR with the Chatushrungi police, who registered a non-cognizable offence against the 20 men. The police also registered a non-cognizable offence against Naik and Yadav after one of the men lodged a cross complaint.

Naik told TOI that Yadav and he were riding a scooter towards Pashan from Sutarwadi around 8pm. “Near a school in Sutarwadi, two men on a motorcycle rode at us on the wrong side of the road and Yadav objected,” Naik said. He added the duo took a U-turn, intercepted and abused them.

Yadav tried placating them, Naik said. “One of them picked up a rock and hit me on the back and I picked up a bamboo stick to defend myself,” Naik said, adding, “His accomplice fled the spot and returned with 20 youths.”

The mob immediately set upon the duo. Naik’s left hand was fractured in the incident, while Yadav suffered bruises on his abdomen, hands and back. “Some local residents intervened and rescued us,” Yadav said.

But it didn’t stop there. “Sometime later, the mother of one of the youths came to my house and tried to slap my wife,” Naik said.

Yadav said that they have been staying in the area for a few years. “Naik is practising for a national athletics competition, while I am practising for ultra races. We had a narrow escape. Had anything happened to our ligaments, our careers would have ended,” he said.

“We have registered cross complaints. Our probe is on,” police said.

Title: Application money for retail liquor shops dips to Rs 860 crore
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: The application money for retail liquor shop licences came down to Rs 860 crore for the next financial year compared to the current year when the revenues were higher at Rs 1007 crore.

But a senior official in the excise department said that when the lottery system is conducted for the second consecutive year, the revenues generally go down. Secondly, the slowdown in economy is another reason behind lesser number of applications as it has affected the sentiment of businessmen.

“This year’s lottery revenue is Rs 860.24 crore. Second year lottery held in 2017-18 was Rs 834 crore. According to the trend, this is a better achievement. Also, we cannot ignore the fact that there is an economic slowdown in the country which has also affected the business sentiment,” said the official.

Rajesh Dukia, who puts in applications regularly, said that if the licence period is for two year, it makes a business case for the applicant.

“By the time one settles down to the business, it takes 3-4 months. So, a good part of the year is over. But if the licence is for two years, it provides more time to do business,” said Dukia.

But some in the industry pointed out that the margins are not there now and they are not getting the assured returns of about 20% which is putting off people.

“The new policy announced for 2020-21 is not very investor friendly. That’s why the response is not very encouraging this time,” said Naresh Pareek, treasurer of Raj Liquor Welfare Society.

He said the government should have withdrawn the mandatory increase in sales policy. Secondly, he said the prices have liquor have gone up significantly. “Such an adverse policy will only encourage bottle legging. In neighbouring states, the prices are very low and the government will lose revenues instead of increasing them by raising the rates,” added Pareek.

But the department sources said that they are hopeful of reaching closer to the revenue targets of Rs 12500 crore set internally for the next year. Others said the transparency measures announced in the policy like providing bills and getting details of the liquor through a smart chip could have been a dampener for retail shops who charge extra bucks over the printed rates.

“When they don’t get the mandated government return, they try to recover that from charging extra money over the printed rates. With new measures in place, that practice will have no scope,” said a retailer.

Title: Rajashthan: Minor girl’s body found in well in Tonk village
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: A 11-year-old girl’s body was found in a well in Tonk’s Nagar police station area on Wednesday afternoon. The girl had gone missing five days ago though the family did not register any missing person’s report.

The deceased was identified as Madhu Dhakad and the incident is of Raghurajpura village in Tonk district. Salim Khan, SHO, Nagar police station said, “According to the parents, the girl apparently left her house on February 6 evening without informing anyone. On the same day, they received a phone call that the child had fallen into a well but the unidentified caller did not specify the location.”

Police tried calling the number from which the family received the call but found that it did not exist. “We tried calling the number but found that it was not a valid one. There are few strange aspects in the matter. First being that the family did not register any complaint with us in the five days that the girl was missing. Secondly, they searched only one well though there are at least four in the area,” added the official.

According to the cops, the victim’s family claimed that Madhu did not have a mobile phone but police found that she did have one which was in her name as well. The girl’s body was found when a farmer was working in his field and when he went to fetch water from his well, he smelt a foul odour. On checking, he saw the body floating in the water and informed the girl’s parents following which they informed the police.

The postmortem was done and the body was then handed over to the family.

Title: Covid-19 victim was Iskcon devotee
Content: Kolkata: Monks and devotees of the International Society of Krishna Consciousness ( Iskcon ) remember him as the ever-smiling “young” man of 80, who would come visiting at least once every year.This was his pilgrimage. Manohar Krishna Prabhu was missed this year when he informed he would be away in the wake of the coronavirus scare. No one knew then that he would soon succumb to the virus.Prabhu, one of the senior most devotees of the Iskcon order, died in London, bringing a pall of gloom over the ongoing Gour Purnima festivities in both Mayapur and Kolkata. Krishna is the sixth UK national and the first one of Indian origin to have died of Covid-19.Krishna and his family moved to London from Gujarat many years ago and embraced Iskcon about 25 years back. The family was always present in every congregation that the London center organised since its initiation, devotees in city said.Krishna loved to spread the word of Geeta and read the Bhagvatam in every gathering and distributed copies of the Geeta among foreigners, trying his best to explain to them its universality.“He called his annual visits to India his pilgrimage because it gave him an opportunity to visit the Iskcon temples at Vridavan, Kolkata and Mayapur. We couldn’t believe our ears when we read that Prabhu is no more. He was a pillar of our London centre, better known as the Bhaktivedanta Centre at Watford, London,” said Radharaman Das, spokesperson of Iskcon, Kolkata.Interestingly, Bhaktivedanta Manor is an estate that belonged to George Harrison of the Beatles, who donated it to Iskcon after he got interested in Indian spirituality. His son is also in the ICU, and has been affected by the virus it was said. The two got infected by an Italian, who visited them over sales of some equipment.Prabhu was loved by all in both city and Mayapur, because of his affable nature. “He had retired from his business and devoted himself to the service of Iskcon,” Das said.

Title: Coronavirus in Goa: Cancel Ketevan festival on top priority, health minister tells Pramod Sawant
Content: PANAJI: Health minister Vishwajit Rane on Wednesday asked chief minister Pramod Sawant to cancel this weekend’s Ketevan sacred music festival “on top priority” in view of the exponential number of coronavirus cases worldwide. The festival, which boasts “70 artistes from 14 countries”, is set to become the state’s first Covid-19 casualty as Rane has asked the CM to act “in public interest and in the interest of the people of Goa”.In his letter, Rane mentioned a circular issued by the government of India on Wednesday which stated that persons coming from 14 identified countries must self-quarantine themselves for 14 days. Thus, he asked Sawant to direct the organisers to postpone the festival till further notice.The festival was to feature artistes from Argentina, Spain, Italy, Vietnam, France, Germany, UK, Spain, Portugal, Georgia, Switzerland, Russia and Japan. Many of these countries are in the throes of the global coronavirus scare Earlier in the day, art and culture minister Govind Gaude was keen that the festival carry on. “The show must go on,” he said.“This is a pre-planned programme so it should go on. Everyone knows about the virus and international airports are thoroughly conducting checks and only then are allowing people to go ahead. It is therefore the responsibility of the health department and the airports authority of India (AAI). Proper care must be taken by each and every one.”While many institutions worldwide cancelled their events in view of the coronavirus scare, the Ketevan organisers were keen to go ahead. Festival director Santiago Lusardi Girelli had said there would be no artists coming from “critical areas”. “We are following Indian government regulations,” he told TOI. “So no artistes from countries like Italy, Iran, China and South Korea will be hosted at the festival.” Girelli said that artistes representing Italy and Spain were “cancelled”. The move comes in the backdrop of the government of India suspending visas and e-visas granted to nationals of France, Germany and Spain.Meanwhile, the festival seemed to have taken some precautions in the wake of the virus. “Volunteers will wear gloves to hand out tickets and keep hand sanitisers at the festival venue for attendees,” the festival’s PR head told TOI earlier on Wednesday. Sources said that some of the artistes have already arrived in Goa, while others are scheduled to arrive. The festival team told TOI that many artistes already have their visas, and are expected to make it for the event.Though Goa has not yet seen a confirmed case of Covid-19, the the fear of the virus spreading at mass gatherings has led to the cancellation of major events across the globe, like Coachella. Even Holi celebrations in Panaji earlier this week received a lukewarm response owing to the fear of any breakout, while the event scheduled in Ponda was cancelled.Rane, meanwhile, said that the AAI is screening international fliers, and that there is no need to panic. However, he appealed to the people to avoid mass gatherings as a precaution.The Ketevan festival is held annually at various venues in Old Goa, including the ruins of St Augustine church, the church of Santa Monica, and St Antony’s Chapel. This year’s edition was scheduled to be held from March 13 to 15.

Title: Naidu stages dharna in front of DGP’s office, lodges plaint
Content:
Amaravati: Tension prevailed at the DGP’s office near Mangalagiri when TDP president N Chandrababu Naidu staged dharna on the national highway on Wednesday night.

Naidu squatted on the highway in protest against the police preventing him from entering the DGP’s office by locking the gates. TDP cadres and CPI state secretary K Ramakrishna joined Naidu’s protest resulting in tension in the area.

Naidu criticized the police for not allowing them to meet the DGP and lodge complaint about the failure of police administration during the run-up to the elections to local bodies.

With Naidu reaching the DGP’s office along with a number of party activists, the police refused entry citing security reasons. Naidu sat on dharna demanding that the DGP should come out and accept their complaint. The TDP activists shouted slogans against the government and chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy.

Naidu said it was unfortunate that the DGP was not willing to see Bonda Umamaheswara Rao and Budha Venkanna who escaped with minor injuries in Macherla. He said YSRC goons and leaders were resorting to violence across the state with the help of the police.

He said that State Election Commission (SEC) should look into the attacks and countermand the elections wherever there is violence. He said the elections to the local bodies were not being held in free and fair atmosphere due to pressure from the chief minister. Meanwhile, the police cordoned off the entire area. Later, additional DGP Ravi Shankar Ayyanar visited Naidu and held discussions with him. He requested Naidu to end the protest. Naidu ended his protest by handing over his complaint to Ayyanar.

Title: Three minors detained for burglaries
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The Kondhwa police have detained three minor boys and recovered loot worth Rs2.80 lakh they had stolen in four burglary cases.

The boys had committed the burglaries at Meethanagar, Bhagyodayanagar and Shivnerinagar in 2019-20. Technical investigations, launched to trace two smartphones stolen in one of the cases, helped the police zero in on the boys.

Ornaments, valuables and cash, worth around Rs4.5 lakh, were stolen. Later, a few more burglary cases were reported in Kondhwa.

Sub-inspector Santosh Shinde said, “The teenagers, all school dropouts, had spent money generated from the crimes. Chargesheets will be filed against them before the juvenile court.”

Title: 11-year-old drowns in Karauli dam
Content: A 11-year-old girl drowned in Panchana Dam in Karauli district after she slipped and fell down while she was standing on the edge of the water body on Wednesday morning. The child who was visiting the dam with her family from Karauli, drowned after the current carried her to the deep end of the water. The girl’s body was fished out by the divers and was handed over to the family. The deceased was identified as Rashi who had come to visit Keladevi Temple and the incident occurred around 6am on Wednesday.

Title: Locals attacked TDP men for injuring kid, not me: Pinnelli
Content:
Guntur: YSRC legislator Pinnelli Ramakrishna Reddy of Macherla has denied allegations of him having attacked TDP leaders Bonda Umamaheswara Rao and Budha Venkanna, claiming they were thrashed by locals for rash driving and injuring a child.

Pinnelli told mediapersons that TDP chief Chandrababu Naidu conspired to create law and order trouble in Palnadu region and deputed MLC Budha and former MLA Bonda to Macherla town especially for this. He said the election process was peaceful until Budha and Bonda arrived in town. He alleged that TDP leaders came to Macherla only to “create nuisance”. He said YSRC had not resorted to the attack on any leader.

He said the “frustrated” TDP supremo had unleashed false propaganda against the YSRC government. He said the TDP was worried of its imminent defeat in the elections to local bodies as the people would support Jagan because of his welfare programmes. TNN

Title: 2 detained in Bhubaneswar for assaulting woman in broad daylight
Content:
Representative Image

BHUBANESWAR: An purported video showing a group of men assaulting a woman in full public view in Old Town area here on Tuesday has gone viral, triggering backlash from citizens. As many targeted the police and state government over worsening law and order situation, Shree Lingaraj police said the motive behind the attack was land dispute and that they had detained two of the attackers, both residents of Old Town area.

In her complaint, the woman alleged that some members of a local community club has usurped a patch of her land near Bindu Sagar. “Their plan is to kill me so that they can take over our entire land. On Tuesday, the club’s members started pelting stones at my house. When I opposed, they assaulted me in public,” said 38-year-old Sabita Sethy.

She also complained that a number of people were seen filming the act on their smartphones, but none volunteered to stop the men from assaulting her.

As the video went viral on social media on Wednesday, people came down heavily on the police for the unsafe atmosphere in the city. “We do not see the fear of police in the eyes of anti-socials. Miscreants are striking at ease,” said Prabodh Mohanty, a social media user.

The alleged assault comes in the backdrop of the daylight attack on a Sikh businessman in Laxmisagar area of the city in January.

Opposition BJP and Congress reacted sharply on the issue. “It is disgraceful and shocking to see miscreants assaulting a woman in public. What could be worse than this? This has put a question mark on the law and order situation,” tweeted senior BJP leader Bhrugu Baxipatra.

State Congress president Niranjan Patnaik also took to twitter to target the police over the worsening law and order situation. “Govt has failed to protect its citizens, especially women & girls. Such violent acts have left people in a state of fear & panic,” Niranjan tweeted.

Police said all those involved in the attack on the woman would be arrested. “On coming to know about the attack on a lady last evening, police contacted the lady & on our initiative a case has been registered at Shree Lingaraj police station. The identity of the accused is known. The attack is over a land dispute. Action under law is being taken,” read a tweet from the DCP’s office.

Title: Rajasthan: Minor girl raped by two in Banswara
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: A minor girl was allegedly raped by two men in a village in Banswara district, police said.

The incident occurred around 2am on Tuesday in Lunawada village of the district where the accused took the girl from her house to a nearby farmland where the duo allegedly took turns to rape her, Kushalgarh deputy superintendent of police Sandeep Shaktawat said.

The 14-year-old survivor underwent medical examination and the accused are absconding with police looking out for them.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Worker held for murder of colleague in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The Sinhagad Road police arrested a 20-year-old casual worker on charges of murdering a 40-year-old man over the latter’s persistent demand for having unnatural sex with him.

The victim Bandu Ingle and the suspect Virendrakumar Singh were friends and worked with the same labour contractor, police said. Ingle hailed from Akola district while Singh hails from Uttar Pradesh .

Police probe revealed that around Tuesday midnight, Singh allegedly smashed Ingle’s head with a stone, stabbed the victim with an empty beer bottle and then set him on fire at an open plot near Sinhagad College at Vadgaon Budruk. The incident came to light on Wednesday morning when a local resident noticed the body at the plot and alerted the Sinhagad road police who rushed to the spot.

“On suspicion, we detained Singh and he admitted to killing Ingle over the latter’s demand for an unnatural sexual favour. Singh told the police that he was enraged by Ingle’s persistent demand and decided to kill him,” said senior police inspector Nandkishor Shelke.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Man, 63, sent to 6-yr RI for sexual assault of girl, 8
Content:
Cuddalore: A special court in Cuddalore on Tuesday convicted a 63-year-old man to six years ’ rigorous imprisonment for sexually assaulting a differently abled girl in the district.

District judge K Karunanithi handling cases booked under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences ( Pocso ) Act, 2012, slapped a penalty of Rs 2,000 on the convict .

Special public prosecutor (Pocso cases) K Selvapriya said the daily wage worker reached the house of the girl after her parents, also daily wage labourers, left for work on July 3, 2018. The girl, who’s physically challenged and mute , was aged eight then. He sent her two younger brothers out of the house claiming that he had come to give medical treatment to her and sexually assaulted her. The girl screamed for help and her two brothers who were playing outside entered the house and found the man assaulting her. They raised an alarm and their neighbours came to their rescue and caught the man and handed him over to police. Police booked him under Section 10 (punishment for aggravated sexual assault ) of the Pocso act and arrested him.

Title: YSRC, opposition clash in Rayalaseema
Content:
Tirupati: Clashes erupted between YSRC, TDP, BJP and Jana Sena cadre on the last day for filing nominations for local body polls in many parts of Chittoor district. In Tirupati rural mandal, nomination papers of TDP’s A Sasikala were torn allegedly by YSRC cadres. Former minister N Amarnath Reddy said TDP’s Karveti Nagaram was prevented from filing nomination by YSRC cadres.

In Punganur, Jana Sena’s Chinna Rayalu alleged that YSRC cadre tore his nomination. Similar clashes between YSRC and opposition were reported from Ramachandrapuram, Tirupati and Rampalli. Attacks on TDP nominees were reported from Kurnool, Anantapur and Kadapa districts. P Thikka Reddy, TDP constituency in-charge at Mantralayam, lodged a complaint that YSRC men kidnapped three TDP MPTC picks.

In Kadapa , YSRC activists allegedly tore nomination papers of TDP’s Chinnamandyam MPTC candidate.

Title: After common cold symptoms, Celine Dion tests negative for coronavirus
Content: Salman Khan, Disha Patani, Randeep Hooda and Jackie Shroff have returned to the sets of ‘Radhe: Your Most Wanted Bhai’ after almost 7 months. Today, the team of ‘Radhe’ has shared a BTS video and the experience of shooting amid the new normal with the necessary precautions.

Title: Road deaths decreased in 2019, new MV Act may have helped
Content: NEW DELHI: Around 1.49 lakh people died in road accidents across the country in 2019, a reduction of nearly 1,600 from 2018. Uttar Pradesh topped the list with 22,655 fatalities (15% of all road deaths) last year while Rajasthan, Odisha, Bihar, Chhattisgarh and Assam also reported a large number of deaths.All states and Union Territories barring Arunachal Pradesh, Sikkim and Manipur have submitted their provisional accidents, fatalities and injuries data of 2019 with the Supreme Court Committee on Road Safety. The panel has been compiling quarterly details to monitor the performance of states in curbing fatalities.According to the provisional data, Delhi, Gujarat, Maharashtra, Karnataka and Uttarakhand saw the decade’s highest year-on-year decline in fatalities in 2019. While Delhi reported 227 fewer deaths in 2019 as compared to 2018, Gujarat and Maharashtra registered 696 fewer fatalities. Karnataka reported 673 fewer road deaths followed by Uttarakhand (181).Delhi with 1,433 deaths and Tamil Nadu with 10,317 reported the lowest death tolls in the last decade, a comparative analysis of the details show.The data also indicates the impact of the amended Motor Vehicles Act , which came into force from September 1, on road deaths.The details shared by states and UTs show that between January and September last year, 300 more people had died as compared to the same period in 2018. However, during the last three months (October to December), there were nearly 1,900 fewer deaths and 5,000 fewer injuries in road accidents as compared to the corresponding period of the previous year, which reversed the trend of increase in fatalities.“If the earlier trend had continued after September, we might have ended up registering more fatalities than 2018. So, now with evidence that indicate positive impact of the MV Act, we expect all states to implement the law fully,” said an official who did not wish to be named.At the recently held global ministerial road safety meeting in Stockholm, UN-affiliated organisations, including World Health Organisation, had lauded changes in the MV Act as a right step to make Indian roads safer.Data showed that Tamil Nadu led the list of states showing decline in fatalities. The southern state has been reducing number of fatalities since 2016. In four years, it reported nearly 39% reduction in fatalities. “This shows how other states can do it by taking necessary measures,” road transport minister Nitin Gadkari told TOI. Tamil Nadu had reported 17,218 fatalities in 2015, which came down to 10,525 last year.UP, which has the largest share of fatalities, saw 399 more deaths in 2019, which was the slowest ever increase in the past decade.

Title: A day before special NMC meet, BJP cancels it
Content:
Nagpur: The ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) in Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has cancelled the special general body meeting convened on March 12 to discuss delay in presenting budget for 2020-21 by municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe. The civic chief will now present the budget to the standing committee on March 16.

NMC secretary and deputy municipal commissioner Rajesh Mohite issued a notification in this regard on Wednesday.

Now, the mayor has convened the general body meeting on March 20. Only one proposal of levying user charge for lifting door-to-door garbage, which was issued by the state government in July 2019, was tabled before the house for discussion.

As per Maharashtra Municipal Corporation Act, municipal commissioner is supposed to present civic body’s budget by February 15. Mundhe, who joined NMC on January 28, had put many restrictions on the ruling party and also asked officials to prepare his budget mentioning all works. All this delayed the civic chief’s budget.

Following a tussle between the ruling party and municipal commissioner, on March 5 mayor Sandip Joshi had announced special meeting over the issue.

Tension further fuelled in March first week after four Shiv Sena MLAs from Mumbai submitted calling attention motion in ongoing budget session of state legislature demanding dissolution of NMC. The mayor had alleged Mundhe conspired with Sena MLAs to tarnish the image of the city.

Ruling party leader Sandip Jadhav confirmed that the special meeting was cancelled following a requisition from the party. He further explained that the mayor has issued the notification on March 5 to convene the special meeting on March 12 while the municipal commissioner has submitted a letter to standing committee chairman to seek either March 11 or March 12 to present the civic body’s budget.

“The ruling party has decided to cancel the special general body meeting as the commissioner has already sought standing committee’s meeting date for presenting his budget,” said Jadhav. Senior official from the civic administration said that as mayor was out of town, deputy mayor Manish Kothe has sent a letter to NMC’s secretary informing about cancellation of the special meet.

Sources said the ruling party cancelled the special meeting for two reasons — the mayor is out of town and the second reason is suspecting humiliation by the civic chief in the special general body meeting for not responding to the former’s letter to present budget.

Meanwhile, the newly appointed standing committee chairman Vijay Zalke has convened a meeting on March 16 allowing municipal commissioner Mundhe to present his budget.

Title: Goons target TDP leaders on last day of nomination in Macherla
Content:
A screen grab of assailants smashing the vehicle of former MLA and TDP leader Bonda Umamaheshwar Rao at Macher... Read More

AMARAVATI: Incidents of widespread violence were reported from several villages in the state on the last day for filing of nominations to local bodies on Wednesday.

The attack on Vijayawada city TDP leaders Bonda Umamaheshwara Rao and Budha Venkanna in Macherla town of Guntur district has created ripples in political circles.

A high court advocate Para Kishore, who accompanied the TDP leaders’ to Macherla, sustained injuries in the incident. Armed with rods and logs, the assailants were seen smashing vehicle of TDP leaders in Macherla.

Shocked, the TDP leaders fled from the spot and proceeded in different routes. Kishore, who suffered head injury, went to Miryalaguda town in Telangana. He was taken to a private hospital for treatment. Following an SOS from Budha Venkanna and Bonda Umamaheshwara Rao, police escorted them to leave the town safely. Budha Venkanna alleged that YSRC activists chased them even after the police providing them escort. He said that YSRC activists tried to attack the CI’s vehicle. Bonda Umamaheswara Rao alleged YSRC cadres also attacked the DSP’s vehicle while the police officer was trying to rescue them. He said the situation in the entire Palnadu region was grim as YSRC cadres were not allowing local TDP activists to file nominations.

The TDP leaders said they arrived from Vijayawada to resolve the issue of a TDP activist’s nomination in Macherla constituency where all the officials were working under tremendous pressure and fear. He said that the gunman also fled the scene after the YSRC activists chased him.

Similar incidents were reported from Nellore, Chittoor and Kadapa districts during the filing of nominations. BJP candidate Manemma received serious injuries in Nidiguntapalem village of Venkatachalam mandal in Nellore district. Manemma’s son-in-law was also injured in the incident. They ran away from the village for the safety. The alleged YSRC activists attacked them for not listening to their advice and deciding to contest against their wishes. A TDP activist refused to file nomination after his son was arrested by the police in connection with gutka sale. He said his son was implicated in a false case only to prevent them from contesting the elections.

Source said that TDP’s Haripriya in Pudiputla village of Chittoor district failed to file her nomination after the rival group snatching away the papers. Similar incident was reported in Tirupati rural mandal where the TDP candidate’s nomination papers were torn into pieces by the rival group. In Jammalamadaka village of Macherla mandal , the TDP candidate said he was prevented from filing of papers. He said that the police have failed to provide him security despite repeated requests.

In Kadapa district, TDP leader B Chengalrayudu lodged a complaint with the police that their workers were prevented from filing of papers in many villages Rajampet constituency. Kadapa district TDP president Srinivasula Reddy alleged that YSRC activists attacked their leaders in Chinamandem village of Rayachoti constituency. He said that the police have turned mute spectators even as YSRC was resorting to violence.

Title: Bhubaneswar: Virus threat hits government school attendance
Content: BHUBANESWAR: The novel coronavirus (Covid-19) has not only spooked global markets but is also affecting parents, resulting in thin attendance in many government schools in the city. Unlike other states, the Odisha government is yet to announce closure of schools due to the possible spread of the virus and so many parents are reluctant to send their children to schools.“It is certainly a scary situation. Every day we are seeing reports of the disease spreading fast in India. Many states have announced early closure of schools. In schools, students are bound to come together. It is difficult to expect that they will follow the sanitation guidelines. So I feel it is better to keep my child at home,” said Namita Mandal, mother of two school-going children.While most of the private schools have suspended classes after the end of the final examination, in government schools, exams are scheduled start from this week for Class IX and next week for the rest.Of the total 85 students in a government-run primary school in Unit-4 area, only 37 were present on Wednesday after the school reopened after a break of three days. It was a similar situation in most of the government schools in the city.Parents said, it is high time the government suspends prayers, daily assemblies and group competitions to prevent a large gathering of students. “Though no positive case has been detected in Odisha yet, but as a precaution the government should suspend school prayers and other mass gatherings,” suggested Ramani Ranjan Sahu, a parent.“Officially the classes are not suspended but since students have had a long weekend owing to Holi, the attendance seemed to thin,” said Sonamika Ray, headmaster of Capital High School. “We are taking all measures advised by the government to create awareness among students regarding coronavirus,” she added.On Wednesday, the health and family welfare department has asked school authorities to identify students, teachers or any staff member suffering from cold or flu and showing symptoms of sneezing and coughing and advise them not to come to school.Besides, schools have been asked to keep furniture clean and sanitise items of mass use like doors, windows, computers, cupboards and so on. “All schools must use covered dustbins and make provision for water in toilets. The schools should also conduct regular health check-ups of students and staff in hostels,” health secretary Nikunja Bihari Dhal said here on Wednesday.

Title: ‘Hirkani Kaksha’ initiative of Pune Municipal Corporation runs out of steam
Content:
PUNE: The ‘Hirkani Kakshas’, started by the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) at various offices and establishments to enable mothers breastfeed babies in privacy, are either lying unused or are non-functional.

The facility is not even active in places like the Rajiv Gandhi Zoological Park or the Katraj zoo, which attracts a lot of visitors. A section of the water purification plant in the zoo has been converted into Hirkani cell. According to the civic staff working in the zoo, the centre is closed due to lack of maintenance.

The PMC officials said they have set up such cells at different places, including the PMC headquarters, in Shivajinagar .

Rajkumar Jadhav, the zoo director, admitted that the facility is closed. “We have plans to improve the facilities in the zoo and a plan has been approved. We will again set up a Hirkani cell,” he said.

Started in May 2011 by the Nashik district health office, Hirkani Kaksha is a special cell where lactating mothers are taught the importance of breast-feeding. The PMC head office started it in 2016.

According to civic sources, many of these facilities are either closed or lying unused. Sunil Indalkar, head of the PMC’s social welfare (urban community development) department, which looks after these facilities was not available for comment despite repeated attempts.

Title: Docs booked for spreading fake news on WhatsApp
Content:
AURANGABAD: Acting tough on those spreading rumours, the city police on Wednesday booked two doctors, both admins of a WhatsApp group, for promoting false message through their group named Arogyam Doctors Association .

This is the first offence in the state wherein doctors have been booked for spreading false Covid-19 information.

The duo falsely claimed on their group the Covid-19 positive patient, currently admitted in a private hospital, has passed away. The screenshot of the message sent by these doctors was received by the hospital administration where the patient is currently being treated.

Taking serious cognizance of the same, Himanshu Gupta , administrator of the city-based private hospital, lodged a complaint with MIDC Cidco police on Tuesday following which, an offence against the suspect duo was registered on Wednesday.

Inspector Vitthal Pote said the doctors have been booked under sections 188 and 505 (2) of the IPC.

Meanwhile, police said that it has been brought to their notice that some mischievous elements have obtained pictures of a woman patient from her social media account and made it viral along with unwanted claims and information.

“We are serious in tackling the misinformation menace. Also, we have a no nonsense policy when it comes to people compromising someone’s right to privacy,” Aurangabad commissioner of police Chiranjeev Prasad said. The officer also appealed to the citizens to abstain from falling prey to social media messages, and avoid forwarding and sharing of unverified, unwanted content on social media.

Title: Delhi: Taking IGI Metro? You may soon use bank card
Content:
The new system will be tried first on the Airport Express Line. (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Soon, your debit/credit card will double up as your Delhi Metro smart card . Delhi Metro Rail Corporation is planning to implement an open loop-based system by early next year that will allow credit or debit cards of any bank to function as a travel smart card.

“Currently, a few metros like Noida Metro Rail Corporation , Kochi Metro and Nagpur Metro have similar facility but they are applicable only for cards issued by a particular bank. DMRC’s system, however, will be able to accept transactions from all banks through the RuPay card issued by them,” a DMRC spokesperson said.

The rail company is planning to implement Open Loop National Common Mobility Card-based RuPay cards issued by all banks. The new system will be first implemented in the high-speed Airport Express Line, which currently operates between New Delhi and Dwarka Sector 21 and is going to be extended up to Dwarka Sector 25.

Currently, Delhi Metro uses ‘closed loop’ tokens and smart cards, while the Airport Express Line also has facility for QR-code based mobile tickets. DMRC plans to implement the new interface through a contractor, which will handle the open loop card and the existing DMRC smart card.

The process of changing from a closed loop system to an open loop will include retrofitting of the EMV reader on existing AFC gates. The next step will be the acceptance of open loop NCMC card-based RuPay card, having store value and trip pass, on the already installed gates having EMV readers, the spokesperson explained.

“The intention is to make the systems interoperable with other public transport fleet in the capital — DTC, DIMTS, Rapid Metro, etc,” he added. The work of implementing the new system on Airport Line is likely to be completed by December 2020.

Title: Blow for TDP as former min joins YSRC
Content:
Tirupati: In another setback for TDP ahead of the urban local bodies and Panchayat elections in chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy’s home district Kadapa, former TDP minister P Rama Subba Reddy resigned to join the ruling YSRC along with his followers in Jagan’s presence at Tadepalli in Vijayawada on Wednesday.

It was only 24 hours ago that former AP legislative council deputy chairman Satish Reddy resigned from the TDP and the second jolt came to the main opposition party with a senior party leader from Kadapa district switching sides and joining YSRC.

Speaking to reporters after joining YSRC, former minister Rama Subba Reddy hailed YS Jagan as a dynamic leader who had introduced several welfare schemes for the benefit of various sections of people.

He rubbished criticism that he had joined the YSRC out of fear of being targeted by the ruling party and said nobody threatened him and it was his own choice to join the YSRC which was providing good governance in the state.

Launching a counter attack on TDP, the former minister said the party leadership was insecure and had no chance of winning local body or municipal elections in the state, the opposition party is resorting to diversion tactics by accusing the ruling party of abusing power.

Title: New Barmer SP takes charge
Content:
Jaisalmer: The newly appointed Barmer SP Anand Sharma took charge and gave directions to stop the smuggling of intoxicants. The Kalyanpur police of Barmer district recovered 1,850 cartons of liquor being taken to Gujarat from Jodhpur in a container and arrested one person in the matter. The liquor was worth Rs 85 lakh. The SP, informing about the case, said that the police got information that illegal liquor was being transported in a container.

Blockading was done and the container MH04JK 9125 was stopped and 1,850 cartons were seized. Papparam (43) of Jodhpur district was arrested. The SP said blockading was done on NH-25 and the seized cartons included 990 cartons of nips and 860 cartons of quarts worth Rs 85 lakh. TNN

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: SPPU clarifies no shutdown after rumours about holiday
Content:
Exam cancelled

PUNE: The Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU) officials on Wednesday clarified that the varsity would function as usual and no holiday had been declared, scotching the rumours that it would remain closed for 10 days from March 20.A fake letter was circulated on social media using the SPPU’s letterhead regarding the “10-day shutdown” in wake of the coronavirus spread. The fake letter with the title “coronavirus information notice” had the logo of the SPPU and International Centre on top. It stated that after the Pune couple tested positive for coronavirus and with a total of five confirmed cases, the SPPU had declared holidays for colleges for 10 days.Registrar Prafulla Pawar said, “The letter circulating on social media about the university remaining closed for 10 days was not issued by the university. We shall take appropriate legal action against such false circulation of message.”Some members have sought postponement of the senate meeting, scheduled on March 14. Senate member Shamakant Deshmukh in a said, “The senate can be conducted once the effect of coronavirus dies down.”The Alliance Francaise issued a statement on Wednesday evening that the March 2020 Diplome D’etudes en Langue Francaise (DELF) exam, which measure students’ proficiency in the French language, has been cancelled on account of the prevailing COVID-19 situation.

Title: TDP chief blames cops, SEC for attack
Content:
Amaravati: TDP president N Chandrababu Naidu on Wednesday alleged that YSRC has made mockery of elections to local bodies with tacit support from authorities. He said TDP leaders and activists were attacked and injured in several villages. He asked what purpose would serve if the State Election Commission failed to protect candidates from opposition parties.

Showing video-clips of the attack in Macherla, Naidu asked whether YSRC leaders wanted to kill TDP leaders. He said YSRC activists went on chasing TDP leaders Bonda and Budha Venkanna on 10 motorcycles and two cars. “They are using heavy logs and iron rods. When the DSP tried to rescue the TDP leaders, the YSRC activists damaged the DSP’s car,” alleged Naidu. He said DGP Gowtham Sawang should take responsibility for the police’s failure to prevent the attacks. He said they had informed Guntur rural SP Vijaya Rao about the visit to complain about tearing up of nomination papers of TDP candidate in Bodalaveedu.

“It is a total failure of the police and the SEC. They have not taken preventive steps,” Naidu charged.

Title: Coronavirus in Bangalore: Schools mulling holidays, home exams for higher grades
Content:
Early holidays

‘Children safety paramount’

BENGALURU: With the department of public Instruction (DPI) declaring holidays for students up to grade 5 from Tuesday, some schools have decided to call off exams of higher classes and are also considering declaring holidays in a day or two.The DPI announced the holiday for students up to class 5 in all schools of Bengaluru North , South and Rural educational districts as a precautionary measure against Covid-19. Officials, however, said no decision has been taken on cancelling exams and added that an appropriate order will be issued in this regard once schools reopen.According to several school heads, given the government directive, the final examination scheduled from the second week of March had been cancelled. They have sent emails and SMSs to all parents about the same.Some like Delhi Public School (Bangalore East) and DPS (Bangalore South) announced that they’d be promoting students in classes 1 to 5 based on their performance through the year.Though the department had asked schools to wrap up exams for kids above class 5 by March 23, some institutions planned to declare early holidays for them too.As per circulars sent by some other schools to parents, the managements have taken a call to declare holidays for all classes, cancel examinations or use alternative methods to conduct tests and promote students based on their performance during the year.Susan Barrid, principal of National Centre for Excellence told TOI the institution decided to declare Wednesday as the last working day for all the classes as parents were getting anxious about their children’s safety. The school will put up worksheets for students below grade 6 and descriptive question papers for students in grade 6, 7 and 8 on the Edumerge application instead of the exams. “The answer key will be put up in the evenings (of the examination days) and parents are expected to monitor their kids. We will consider the cumulative of all exams as well to grade the students,” Barrid said.Anuradha Krishnan, principal of Primus Public School said plenty of worried parents are requesting postponement or cancellation of exams even for children in higher grades. “I will be taking a call on this by the end of the week. As the syllabus is complete, we might have to conduct online exams for children’s sense of closure,” she said.Sishu Griha said the annual exam marks for classes 6 and 7 would also be on the basis of the annual average of all tests conducted through the academic year. “We will be sending the annual exam question paper to your registered email address as per the scheduled exam timetable. This is for academic purpose only. However, your child must write it under exam conditions,” the school informed parents. New Horizon Public School announced that the annual exams for grades 6 to 8 scheduled to start on March 12 stand cancelled and students will be promoted on the basis of their year-round performance.The school said they may reopen for the next academic session earlier than the scheduled date.D Shashikumar, general secretary, associated managements of primary and secondary schools (KAMS) said: “As per the Right to Education Act (RTE), there is no provision to fail any student at the primary level. So, all students will be promoted to the next grade,” he said.S Rajendra, DDPI, Bengaluru (south) said as per the communication sent by the DPI director, a decision on conducting final examination for the classes one to five will be taken once schools reopen.* Declaring holidays for children below grade 5 and asking students in higher classes to attend exams and go out in crowded places deifies logic. We have been asking the school to declare holidays, but they keep saying they are waiting for the government’s directive. When there is continuous evaluation, why can’t it just be considered at such times?Shardha V | mother of class 7 seven* The government may have passed the order considering it is easier for older children to follow the precautionary measures. But my concern is how will kids write exams in this atmosphere. Whether the scare around the virus is valid or simply exaggerated is a matter of debate, but it can’t come in the way of children’s safety. It is always better to keep them safe than be sorry!Thejashree | mother of class 7 student

Title: Covid-19 scare in Pune: First contacts of infected couple under close watch
Content: PUNE: The district administration is keeping a close watch on nearly 43 “first contacts” of the Pune couple, who tested positive for Covid-19 on Monday.The reports of nearly 36 patients, who have been quarantined at Naidu hospital, are awaited. The five infected individuals, including the Pune couple, their daughter and co-traveller, are stable. The first contacts of the infected Pune couple are being monitored closely, Pune divisional commissioner Deepak Mhaisekar said on Wednesday.At a press meet attended by Mhaisekar, district collector Naval Kishore Ram, commissioner of police K Venkateshan and among others, the authorities urged citizens to stay calm and not fall for rumours.“There is no reason for alarm and efforts are being taken to prevent the spread of the infection,” Mhaisekar said. He has directed all the collectors in the division to spread awareness through various platforms against the disease.Chief minister Uddhav Thackeray, via video-conferencing on Wednesday, told the divisional commissioner to take action in coordination with the district magistrate and the health department among others. Deputy CM Ajit Pawar was also part of the interaction.

Title: Rajasthan: Camels dying of skin diseases, rearers blame govt apathy
Content:
Camps have been organised at Lathi, Sam, Barhat and Khana villages

JAISALMER: The number of camels in Jaisalmer and Barmer districts is declining of late, as many are dying due to skin-related diseases. Although the state government claims to have organised camps to treat the ailing camels and to vaccinate them, cattle rearers claim the measures are not enough to deal with the issue.

The state government has allegedly cut down funds for veterinary medicines and not enough funds have been given to organise camps to treat the camels, due to which the immunisation cannot be done, leading to the camel deaths.

Recently, a team from the Bikaner National Research Centre on Camel visited Jaisalmer and set up a camp for the purpose with a local NGO and vaccinated 555 camels in Lathi area. Cattle rearers are worried about the camel deaths. The animal husbandry department does not have sufficient medicines and funds to provide relief to the ailing camels.

According to the 2011 cattle census, in Jaisalmer, there were 50,000 camels and till now, camps have been organized at two places to treat the camels wherein the animal husbandry department is claiming to have vaccinated 500 camels in each camp. Confirming this, animal husbandry department Dy director Dr Subhash Jangid said that skin diseases among camels have spread in many parts of Jaisalmer and many have died while the department is making all efforts to control the diseases. Camps have been organized at Lathi, Sam, Barhat and Khana villages, where 500 camels have been vaccinated in each camp and the camels have been given medicines.

He accepted that this year, medicines worth Rs 15 lakh have been received for treating the cattle, which is very less and they have written to the government demanding more medicines and funds.

Generally, an additional budget of Rs 10,000 is given for organising camps and for medicines, but this time, the budget was not given. Sumer Singh Bhati, a leading cattle rearer from Jaisalmer, who has around 1,000 camels, is worried and said that this time, around 7% camels have died in Jaisalmer due to the skin ailments and it is very difficult to get the cattle vaccinated. The animal husbandry department is not paying any attention towards the issue and is not organizing any camps in his area, he claimed.

Title: Man, 45, who returned from US first from city to test positive for coronavirus
Content:
Nagpur: A man from Nagpur who returned from the United States recently has tested positive for Covid-19. The patient had got himself admitted to the Indira Gandhi Government Medical College Hospital (IGGMCH) on Wednesday morning and his swab samples were tested in a lab facility there.

“Reports came on Wednesday evening and they were positive. This is the first confirmed case of Covid-19 in Nagpur and there is no need to panic,” said district civil surgeon Dr Devendra Paturkar. The man is believed to be around 45 years old.

District collector Ravindra Thakare is expected to issue precautionary guidelines on Thursday.

Hospital sources told TOI that the patient had come back from USA via Mumbai on March 6. “He developed symptoms three days ago and reported to the hospital. After testing positive, he is now kept in the isolation ward (No. 24) of IGGMCH and being treated symptomatically. He has fever (99 degrees) but is showing no other symptoms,” they said.

Though it is not known from which city he boarded a flight to Mumbai, it is learnt that the man was not screened in Mumbai as travellers from US were not under scrutiny.

Meanwhile, three of the 40-member tourist team that travelled to Dubai with a Pune couple, which has tested Covid-19 positive, are from Nagpur. They were together in Dubai between February 24 and March 1. The Pune couple, their daughter, and their cab driver have tested Covid-19 positive. All these three patients are under home isolation.

On Wednesday, four other persons reported to the GMCH. One of them was a German woman who came to India as a tourist. She travelled to Delhi, Agra, Rajasthan and was in Tadoba on a jungle safari when she developed coronavirus symptoms. She reported to the GMCH and was admitted to the isolation ward. Her reports are expected to come on Thursday.

GMCH also admitted three Nagpurians having recent travel history to Dubai, Saudi Arabia and Italy in the isolation ward on Wednesday. Two of them, who travelled to Dubai and Saudi Arabia, came early in the morning. Their samples were collected and tested by evening. Both have tested negative. Reports of the person who travelled to Italy are still awaited.

Ten patients in Yavatmal

Ten of the 40 passengers suspected to have Covid-19 are from Yavatmal. They accompanied the Pune couple who has tested Covid-19 positive on the Dubai trip. Owners of different agriculture stores in Kelapur, Ghatanji and Yavatmal, all these residents had gone to Dubai on a paid pleasure trip by a leading agriculture company.

As the Pune couple, their daughter and cab driver have tested positive, all have been asked to stay indoors for the next 14 days. Nine of the ten are presently inside their houses.

One of them, a young boy who studies in Pune went directly there and developed symptoms like cough, cold and fever. He also tested positive. Government authorities in Yavatmal are now keeping a tab on the other nine patients.

“Nine members from the group have been kept under home observation at their respective places of residences and the civil surgeon of Yavatmal is regularly monitoring them. None of them have any symptoms of coronavirus,” said Dr Milind Kamble, dean of Vasantrao Naik Government Medical college and hospital in Yavatmal. Three of the nine suspects said on phone that they will strictly maintain home isolation.

“We are not going out for any reason. We skipped Holi celebrations too. Earlier, the administration team was to collect our samples from homes. But, later, they asked us to wait as none of us developed any symptoms,” said one of them.

Yavatmal GMCH has an isolation ward of 10 beds, but these suspects were not admitted there. Authorities said that the isolation facility is to meet emergencies only.

Title: BSF jawan falls from tower, dies
Content: A BSF jawan died after falling from the top of a tower at the Chitrakut border outpost on Indo-Pak border adjoining Sriganganagar on Tuesday evening. The jawan was taken to a nearby health centre where the doctors declared him dead.

Title: Secunderabad: Schoolmates attack teen with blade
Content:
Representative image

SECUNDERABAD: A class 10 student was allegedly attacked with a blade by two of his schoolmates at Kanojiguda in Secunderabad on Tuesday night. The two accused who are both minors were booked for attempt to murder, Alwal police said.

The 16-year-old victim is a student of a government school and a resident of Subhash Nagar. According to cops, the victim was on his way home after special classes when the two boys attacked him.

“The victim was involved in a petty quarrel with the accused persons a month ago. They study in the same school. The two 17-year-old boys beat the victim up and then attacked him with a blade on his throat,” inspector P Yadagiri said. The victim is out of danger.

Title: PMC garden shut to curb coronavirus spread
Content: PUNE: The civic body has decided to shut down the Krantijyoti Savitribai Phule garden in the vicinity of the housing society where three residents tested positive for coronavirus The decision was taken as a preventive measure following instructions from the health department to prevent the spread of the virus.
