The staffers said the garden was very popular among residents of nearby areas and people of different ages visited it on a daily basis.“Many people came to the garden on Wednesday morning but we did not allow them to enter the premises. Entry will be barred for the next few days. The gardener and other staff members have been instructed suitably. We have put a board on the entry gate,” said a staff member.

Title: Bangalore Coronavirus News: Without testing negative, students can’t leave Italy
Content:
Indian authorities unhelpful

BENGALURU: Unable to procure Covid-19 (negative) certificate mandated by the Indian government to enter the country, several students from Karnataka are stranded in airports of Rome and Milan in Italy, which is under lockdown in the wake of the viral epidemic.TOI spoke to the stranded youths, mostly students in Italian universities, who said getting a clean chit from the stretched Italian healthcare establishment is impossible and they can’t even venture out from wherever they are holed up due to fear of fine and imprisonment.According to the students, there are at least 20 of them from Karnataka stranded in Rome, Milan and Genoa airports. An estimated 200 Indians are stranded in airports in Italy, they said.On Tuesday, the Indian government ordered that whoever wants to board flights to India from Covid-19-hit countries like Italy and South Korea must get a medical certificate confirming they have tested negative for the virus.Speaking to the TOI from Malpensa Airport in Milan, S Karthik of Tumakuru said he had purchased a ticket to fly home on an Air India flight on Tuesday evening but was prevented from boarding the aircraft. “I was asked to produce the Covid-19 (negative) certificate in order to fly out. The authorities don’t realise it is impossible to find clinics or doctors as Italy has sounded a red alert for the virus and the entire country is under lockdown. Hospitals are overcrowded and have strictly told us that people without symptoms can’t be tested. We are caught between the devil and deep sea,” the IT student said.According to Karthik, over 50 people are stranded at the Milan airport alone and they can’t even venture out as there is a standing order since Tuesday against people leaving the premises without valid reasons. Violators can be arrested and fined 200 euros, he said.The hunt for the certificate and visit to medical facilities in Italy only render individuals more vulnerable to the virus, he added.The students also claimed that they were advised to call the helpline of the Indian ministry of external affairs, which in turn directed them to contact the Indian embassy or the consulate in Italy. “But when we contacted the embassy, we were told that the new rule (demanding Covid-19 [negative] certificate) is being strictly followed as per government instructions,” said Ashish, who is from Shivamogga and stranded at the Milan airport.Over 75 Indians are stranded in Rome and they include many from Karnataka. “Local Indian authorities have not paid heed to our pleas. We are being turned away from hospitals here as we don’t have any symptoms. Most students have an Indian medical insurance which is not valid here. We want to come home and are ready to be quarantined in our country,” said Madan Gowda, a student stranded at the airport in Rome along with 61 other Indian students since Tuesday evening.In a similar case, many Indian students, including 10 from Karnataka, who boarded an Alitalia flight from Genoa airport in northwestern Italy on Wednesday were allegedly forced out following orders from Indian embassy officials as they lacked Covid-19-negative certificate, sources said. Indian mission authorities in Rome were not available for comment till Wednesday evening.

Title: Collector invokes disaster management act in district amid coronavirus outbreak
Content: PUNE: Collector Naval Kishore Ram has invoked the Disaster Management Act, 2005, in the district, under which 18 private hospitals have been roped in for any emergency amid Covid-19 scare.The move came in the wake of eight people testing positive for Covid-19 infection in Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad till Wednesday evening.“Under the act, we have directed 18 empanelled private hospitals, including eight in the Pimpri Chinchwad area and 10 in the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) area to keep rooms and bed ready for emergency. On an average, 200 beds are being kept ready for isolation of patients,’’ he told TOI.Besides, the district administration is also taking steps to check hoarding of medical equipment or articles. “We are checking medical shops regarding hand sanitisers and masks. All private practitioners have been told to keep the history of patients ready, including foreign travel, and report it to the health authorities,”he said.The collector confirmed that there were no directives for schools and colleges to stay shut for now. “Having said that, no mass gatherings will be allowed. Strict action would follow against those flouting the guidelines,” he addedUnder the Disaster Management Act, the collector, who is also the chairman of the district disaster management authority, appointing district civil surgeon Ashok Nandapurkar as the ‘incident commander’ and district health officer Bhagwan Pawar as the joint controller for better planning and execution of the rules and regulations.Nandapurkar and Pawar will be responsible for coordinating with various departments and implementing ‘104’ toll-free number (for information related to coronavirus ). They will also help in providing health services at airport and other crowded places, besides creating awareness among public through various means. They will also make sure that medical stores don’t overcharge people for masks and medicines.The act helps the administration in better utilisation of the available resources and manpower in the public as welll as the private sector.

Title: High court criticizes Kerala government for ‘unnecessary’ appeal
Content:
Representative image

KOCHI: The high court has criticized the state government for unnecessarily filing an appeal on a verdict to pay Rs 1.5 lakh as compensation after a woman died following a sterilization surgery, leaving the family chasing justice for 25 years.

Justice Devan Ramachandran criticized the government for filing an appeal (RFA No. 356/2003) in the case over death of Valli T on January 31, 1995 following a laparoscopic sterilization at a primary health centre (PHC) on January 26. Tirur sub court had ordered for paying Rs 1.5 lakh as compensation in June 2003 but the government had filed an appeal, resulting in delaying justice further by 17 years.

Valli’s husband had alleged before court that she died due to negligence and carelessness of the doctors and nurses who were in charge of the surgery and that she was not given adequate postoperative care. While the surgery was conducted by doctor Vasanth R Galgali, the team included doctor Vijaya Gopal, medical officer at PHC, Vettom; Sulochana of JPHN PHC, Pallar; and doctor Girija Bai TP, government hospital, Tirurangadi.

The trial court had found that there was no negligence during the surgery but that Valli was not properly advised about postoperative care by doctor Vijaya Gopal and Sulochana.

The high court said in the judgment that the appeal should have never been filed as the death of Valli is conceded. The fact that the family was made to wait endlessly for more than 25 years is shocking to the conscience of the court, the judgment said. The court pointed out that it is an admitted fact that she underwent the sterilization surgery and that she suffered acutely on account of pain and infection, leading to septicaemia. The compensation awarded by the trial court was justified, the court said while ordering the government to pay the compensation and interest within two months.

Title: Dehradun-Kolkata direct flight service to start from March 29
Content:
Vistara is also going to start its operations from Dehradun airport from March 29

DEHRADUN: The air connectivity between Dehradun and other parts of the country is going to get a major boost as airlines are going to start direct flight operations on new routes from Jolly Grant airport from March 29 onwards.

Indigo Airlines, which operates eight daily flights from Dehradun , is going to increase its daily flight frequency to 13, according to the new summer schedule released by airport officials on Wednesday.

Apart from the existing flights, Indigo is also going to start direct flights on Dehradun - Kolkata, Dehradun - Ahmedabad and Dehradun- Prayagraj routes. Besides, the airline is going to start additional flights on Dehradun - Mumbai and Dehradun - Lucknow routes.

Another airline, Vistara is also going to start its operations from Dehradun airport from March 29. The airline will run a daily flight on the Dehradun- Delhi sector.

Airport director DK Gautam told TOI, “The Dehradun airport is on an expansion mode and the number of flights is going to increase significantly from this month-end. On an average, the number of daily flights will rise from 22 to 28.”

He said that a 78-seater ATR category airplane will operate on Dehradun - Ahmedabad, Dehradun - Prayagraj and Dehradun-Lucknow routes, adding that the increased number of flights will provide a major boost to the tourism sector in Uttarakhand.

Under the central government’s ambitious Regional Connectivity Scheme (RCS), state-run Pawan Hans helicopter company is going to operate its helicopter service on Dehradun - New Tehri - Srinagar - Gauchar route. The proposed helicopter service is aimed at strengthening air connectivity on Char Dham route.

Title: Rare lizard dead, 5 found injured in Jaisalmer
Content:
Jaisalmer: A rare spiny-tailed lizard was found dead, while five of them were found injured near Pokhran field firing range of Jaisalmer district by the forest department. The skin of a Chinkara was also recovered from the spot.

The lizard comes in the list of schedule II. Wildlife department ACF Balram Sharma said that the lizard species is on the verge of extinction and that they received information of poaching of spiny-tailed lizards and that some big poaching gang is active in the area.

He said the forest department team immediately reached the spot, following which the poachers ran away. They recovered one dead & five severely injured lizards. The team also recovered a knife and a wooden stick from the spot.

Title: Odisha: BJD to walk away with 4 Rajya Sabha seats as BJP stays away
Content:
BJD Rajya Sabha nominees (from left) Subash Singh, Sujeet Kumar, Mamata Mahanta with chief minister and party ... Read More

BHUBANESWAR: The BJD is all set to get all four of its nominees in Rajya Sabha after the opposition BJP decided not to field its candidate for the election scheduled on March 26.

The four BJD candidates — Subash Singh, Munna Khan, Sujeet Kumar and Mamata Mahanta — filed nomination papers here on Wednesday in presence of party president and chief minister Naveen Patnaik.

Naveen signed as a proposer on the nomination paper of Singh, while several senior ministers and MLAs of the ruling BJD were present on the occasion.

While a candidate requires at least 30 first preference votes to be elected to the Upper House, the BJD has 113 MLAs while BJP has 23 MLAs. With only nine MLAs, the Congress is not in a position to field even a candidate. The lone independent MLA has announced to support BJD nominees in the Rajya Sabha race if there will be an election while another CPM MLA has decided to abstain.

Though BJD has numbers for three candidates, no other parties have absolute majority for the forth candidate.

“Since we don’t have adequate numbers to elect a member to the Rajya Sabha, our party’s state and central leadership decided not to field a candidate in the Rajya Sabha poll,” said leader of opposition Pradipta Kumar Naik.

Though March 13 is the last date for filing of nomination, names of the victorious candidates is likely to be announced after completion of the deadline for withdrawal of the nominations on March 18, said an official source.

The election was necessitated after Anubhav Mohanty, Narendra Swain, Sarojini Hembram of BJD and Ranjib Biswal of Congress vacated the seats. Though Mohanty’s seat fell vacant after he was elected to the Lok Sabha in 2019 elections, tenure of other three leaders will end on April 2.

Naveen recently announced names of BJD candidates for the Rajya Sabha polls, giving emphasis on all the four regions of the state. Singh, a popular trade union leader from the coastal area, had joined the BJD before the 2014 elections. He had recently resigned as the chairperson of the Odisha Building and Other Construction Workers’ Welfare Board.

With a total movable and immovable properties worth Rs 83.5 lakh, Singh said, he would continue to raise issues for welfare of the working class and labourers in the country. He has seven cases pending against him.

Khan, who is associated with the BJD since its inception, hails from the southern Odisha. In his affidavit, Khan has mentioned that the value of his movable and immovable properties is Rs 31 lakh and Rs 1.09 crore, respectively.

An alumnus of Oxford and Harvard Universities , Kumar from the western region has movable properties worth Rs 1.10 crore while value of his immovable properties is estimated at Rs 74 lakh. Kumar has also invested in five companies.

Belonging to the Kudumi community (a backward community) from Mayurbhan (north Odisha), Mahanta said she would continue to fight for the causes of rural women. Mahanta has properties worth Rs 8 lakh.

Title: HC asks Telangana government’s stand on school fee case
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: The high court on Wednesday directed the state to furnish its stand on the report submitted to the state by Professor Thirupathi Rao committee on the issue of controlling school fees in private schools, by April 8.

The bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy was hearing pleas filed by parents and activists challenging the exorbitant fee structures in private schools and the inaction of the state’s school education wing.

The bench turned down the state counsel’s request to grant them eight weeks time to decide whether to accept the recommendations of the committee or to reject them. “It has been two years since the committee submitted its report and the state has to take a decision,” the bench said, posting the case to April 9.

Title: Hyderabad: Picture of corporator’s husband holding AK-47 goes viral
Content:
Mahatma, husband of corporator K Srilatha, with the weapon

HYDERABAD: A photograph of Rajendra Nagar corporator K Srilatha’s husband holding an AK-47 assault rifle went viral on social media on Wednesday. Police said they are inquiring into the issue.

Rajendra Nagar police said Mahatma, husband of Korani Srilatha, had switched off his mobile phone and became incommunicado. No gunmen were allotted to either the corporator or Mahatma. Police suspect the weapon might belong to the gunman of either an MLA or an MP. “Once we contact him, we can know from where he got the weapon. Depending on the details of the inquiry, we will corroborate with the person to whom the weapon was assigned by the department,’’ Rajendra Nagar inspector G Suresh said.

Police sources said if the weapon was not misused, there might not be any case against Mahatma. In case, if the gunman had given the weapon to Mahatma for taking a photograph, departmental action might be initiated against him based on the instructions of senior officials.

Title: Jodhpur: Railway police bust E-ticketing racket, seven held
Content:
Representative image

JODHPUR: Busting an E-ticketing racket in Jodhpur Division, Railway Police Force (RPF) arrested 7 persons and seized tickets worth Rs 1.37 crore from them on Wednesday.

Kingpin of the racket, Dinesh Jangid, a software expert, had been using different softwares developed for the purpose, for making the E-tickets. “The names of these softwares are iCON, iBALL, ABS, SPARK and Redbull, which were being used to generate E-tickets,” said senior spokesperson (North Western Railways), Gopal Sharma. The investigation led to the name of 6 other persons acting as agents for selling tickets, who also have been arrested by the RPF.

Sharma said that 8,067 tickets worth Rs 1,37,13,256 have been seized from them, of which live tickets were worth Rs 7,62.716. “All the tickets have been seized and blocked and further investigation was under process,” said Sharma.

The raid was conducted jointly by the teams of RPF from headquarters at Jaipur and Jodhpur division.

Title: Two killed in separate accidents in Nainital
Content:
Representative image

NAINITAL: Two men got killed in separate accidents in Haldwani and Ramnagar towns of Nainital district on Holi. In the first accident in Ramnagar, a 24-year-old man was killed after a car hit the scooter he was riding on.

Soon after the accident, another car rammed into an electric pole and the woman driving it sustained injuries. Later, the woman was hospitalised. “The deceased has been identified as Santram. His family was informed of the accident and the body has been sent for postmortem. The body will be handed over to the family once the formalities are completed,” Ravi Saini, Ramnagar SHO. The official added that Santram was accompanied by a woman who also sustained injuries and is receiving treatment at a local hospital. In the second accident that took place in Haldwani, a 26-year-old man was killed after the bike he was riding on was hit by another bike. The victim fell on the road after the accident and sustained critical injuries. Later, he was rushed to the hospital where the doctors declared him dead.

"The deceased has been identified as Bhupinder Maurya. His bike was hit by another bike coming from the opposite direction. He was taken to Dr Susheela Tiwari Government Hospital but the doctors declared him dead. His family has been informed and the body has been sent for postmortem examination," said Sanjay Kumar, Haldwani SHO.

Title: Two Dehradun men killed in separate accidents, Tehri man drowns in river
Content:
Representative image

DEHRADUN: Three persons were killed in separate accidents in Dehradun and Tehri districts on the occasion of Holi on Tuesday. In the first accident that took place in Dehradun, a 25-year-old man was killed and his friend sustained critical injuries after the bike they were riding on crashed into a house wall in Premnagar area. The deceased has been identified as Rishabh Chetri, a student at Doon-based University of Petroleum Energy Studies (UPES). His friend Aakash Bisht is undergoing treatment at a private hospital, said police officials.

In another accident in the state capital on the festive day, a 27-year-old man lost his life after the bike he was riding pillion crashed into a road side grill as the his friend who was riding the bike lost control over it. The deceased was identified as Om Prakash, a resident of Mehuwala Khalsa in Vikasnagar police station area. According to police, Om’s friend Veer Singh, who sustained minor injuries, and the deceased were under the influence of alcohol. The post-mortem will be conducted on Thursday.

Meanwhile, a 34-year-old man drowned in a river in Jakhni area of Kirtinagar tehsil in Tehri district on Tuesday. The victim has been identified as Dalwant Singh, who worked with the animal husbandry department. Upon receiving information of the accident, a team of state disaster response force (SDRF) reached the spot and launched a search and rescue operation to trace the missing person.

“The victim had gone to the river with his friends to celebrate Holi. However, he ventured into deep waters and was swept away by strong currents. A SDRF team, equipped with raft and other equipment, has been pressed into service to trace the missing person,” said a SDRF official.

Title: NIM to host sports climbing training workshop from March 16
Content: Uttarkashi: To promote adventure sports and find hidden talents in the state, Adventure Sports Association of Uttarkashi is going to organize sports climbing training cum talent hunt workshop at the Nehru Institute of Mountaineering (NIM) on March 16 and 17. The association has welcomed youths from all over Uttarakhand to participate in the two-day event, which will be held with support of the Indian Mountaineering Foundation (IMF) and NIM .

Title: Significant drop in crime rate in 4 years, says Kerala chief minister
Content:
Pinarayi Vijayan

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan on Wednesday told the assembly that the number of criminal cases reported in the state has come down significantly during the LDF rule.

The number of cases registered in police stations across the state was 6.85 lakh in 2015. The same has come down to 5.57 lakh in 2018 and it further got reduced to 5.09 lakh in 2019. “There is a significant year-on-year fall in the number of cases. Compared to 2015, the number of cases registered in the state has come down by 1.76 lakh,” the chief minister said. He was replying to a discussion on demands for grants for police, jails, stationary and printing and other administrative services.

Number of serious offences has come down during the last four years. While 2.57 lakh grave offences were reported in 2015, it got reduced to 1.76 lakh in 2019. The conviction rate, as per the latest statistics, was 82.24 %, he said. The chief minister also said the government was committed to induct more women into police force.

At the outset, he declared his decision not to react to the discussions based on the CAG report that put the State Police chief in the dock. “The law would take its own course as far as the CAG report is concerned. I don’t wish to make comments upon something on which is awaiting the scrutiny of the forum competent to look into it,” he said.

In reply to questions raised by opposition members, CM said his government had ordered an inquiry based on the C&AG findings on Vizhinjam project as such allegations had been rife even before the C&AG came out with the report.

Pinarayi Vijayan said it was not the first time that police department has purchased high security vehicles through single tender process. Such purchase decisions were taken in 2003 and 2004, he said.

Title: 23-year-old hangs self in Dehradun
Content:
Representative image

DEHRADUN: A 23-year-old woman allegedly committed suicide by hanging from a ceiling fan inside her house in Dalanwala area of Dehradun in the intervening night of Tuesday and Wednesday.

No suicide note was recovered from the spot.

The deceased has been identified as Kajal Chandra, who got married two years ago but had moved out of her husband’s house immediately after their marriage, police said.

On Wednesday morning, after not getting any response from inside, the family entered the room to find Kajal hanging from the ceiling fan. Police reached the spot soon after.

Police said that Kajal was staying with her parents at her maternal house on DL Road. Police suspect that the victim was undergoing depression due to on-going marital discord with her husband.

Meanwhile, police have launched an investigation to ascertain the causes behind the alleged suicide.

Title: Egrets, crows found dead in city, samples sent for testing
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: Stray incidence of bird deaths in the district triggered bird-flu scare on Wednesday. Bird deaths were reported in the city at Azhoor and Karode panchayats. Three egrets were found dead on a tree on the premises of MLA hostel. The fire force retrieved the carcass and officials with animal husbandry department sent the samples to State Institute for Animal Diseases (SIAD) to identify the cause of death. More than 30 crows were also reported dead at Azhoor and Karode panchayats and samples from these places were also sent to SIAD, Palode.

Officials with animal husbandry department (AHD) said that samples were sent for detailed tests in the wake of bird flu outbreak in Kozhikode where avian influenza was confirmed in domestic poultry, forcing mass culling of birds. “We sent the samples to SIAD as a precautionary measure. The state already has a confirmed case of avian flu in Kozhikode and we have to take precautions,” said an AHD official.

The carcass received at SIAD was in a putrefied state. The district is not known to have reported avian flu in recent times and according to officials there was no need to panic. The SIAD team will do a preliminary investigation and even if avian flu is suspected, it has to be confirmed by the National Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (NIHSAD), Bhopal. The samples will be tested in Palode on Thursday and in case of suspicion, the samples will be sent to Bhopal for confirmation. As per protocol, NIHSAD will communicate the findings to the Government of India and then a communication will be sent to the chief secretary, following which an official notification will be issued.

AHD officials and veterinarians said that the deaths of egrets and crows during summer many not be a cause of panic and these could be isolated incidents. Extreme heat stress could be one reason for the death of egrets.

Sometimes deaths also happen due to poisoning or bacterial infection, animal disease specialists said. The nature of the influenza virus is such that it has high mutation rates and undergoes frequent genetic reassortment (combination and rearrangement of genetic material) rendering vaccinations ineffective.

The lone preventive mechanism is culling and containment which was what the officials did in Alappuzha in 2014.

The carcasses of egrets also became a topic of discussion in the assembly session, with MLA P C George demanding a probe into the death of egrets.

Title: Kolkata: Internet ban in pockets likely on HS exam days
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: Senior Kolkata Police officers on Wednesday said they were awaiting an official notification on a possible internet ban in a few pockets of Kolkata — in south-west, central and north — during Higher Secondary examinations that begins on Thursday. HS Council, however, said a formal decision has been taken on banning internet in five sensitive districts. Sources said West Midnapore, Malda and Murshidabad, along with some pockets in Kolkata, were among the ‘identified’ districts. The move is aimed at curbing papers leaks that had dogged the West Bengal Higher Secondary Council (WBHSC) during last year’s examinations.

WBHSC president Mohua Das on Wednesday said the council had identified and provided details of ‘sensitive’ examination centres to the home department. “Five districts have been identified. However, the number of blocks can’t be divulged since we do not want to alert cheats. Internet service at these places will be suspended during the examination,” she said.

Though she refused to name the places where internet services would be affected on exam days, a few pockets in south-west, central and north Kolkata may experience internet shutdown for a short duration if the home department issues the necessary notification.

The council also urged the West Burdwan DM to track down various WhatsApp groups that were indulging in malpractices with help from coaching centres before exams and called for greater survelliance at these sensitive venues.

Das, on Wednesday, announced severe measures including de-affiliation against schools that do not take adequate precautions against HS aspirants resorting to unfair means during the board exam. “If we identify teaching staff, faculty members or invigilators to have remained a mute spectator during cheating, we shall be forced to take extreme measures,” she said.

As many as 300 metal detectors are being installed at examination venues to have a blanket security cover. Any candidate who is caught with a mobile will be expelled from the examination for the day. “Anyone who is found to have taken pictures of question papers or is found to be a part of the cheating racket, their registration will be cancelled and they can no longer appear in the HS in the future,” said Das. The invigilators and venue supervisors have been instructed to initiate an RA against candidates if they are involved in assaulting invigilators, creating ruckus inside the examination centre or taking away part or full answer scripts without submission.

Title: Telangana high court fiat: Let errant builders hear sound of bulldozers
Content: HYDERABAD: The Telangana high court on Wednesday sent out a stern message that those who are hiding behind stay orders obtained from courts to protect their illegal structures are no longer safe.The high court also asked GHMC commissioner Lokesh Kumar to submit details of all cases on illegal structures that were pending with the high court as well as the civil courts. The court also directed its registrar general to keep all such courts informed of the fact that the CJ bench is seized of all such matters.“We will create a special category for all such cases and would resolve all of them on a priority basis,” said a bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy , while hearing a plea filed by C R Sudhinder Kumar of Kruparam Bagh near Sultan Bazar in Hyderabad. The plea questioned the construction of five storey illegal structure in the area.GHMC Commissioner Lokesh Kumar who was present in the court informed the bench that there are 10,600 complaints seeking demolition of illegal buildings in Greater Hyderabad . This is in addition to the 1.10 lakh illegal structures that are awaiting regularisation orders under building regularisation scheme.“Of the 10,000 buildings that were declared illegal, we could demolish 3,400 buildings. But we were rendered helpless with respect of 4,600 illegal buildings whose owners obtained stay orders from courts”, Lokesh said.The CJ assured the commissioner that they would be designated as special category cases and would be resolved on a priority basis.“We cannot allow people to raise illegal structures and they cannot be permitted to abuse court process later,” the bench said, adding “We will take up a special drive to clear the city of illegal structures”. “Law of the land has to prevail and errant builders should be made to hear the sounds of bulldozers”, the CJ added.The bench also told the GHMC chief to be cautious with his staff who were seemingly hand-in-glove with the illegal builders. “You have to take stringent action against them. Otherwise they will pull the wool over your eyes,” the bench said.

Title: Jaisalmer: Cops seize 9,000 plants of doda post, two arrested
Content:
Representative image

JAISALMER: Many drug dealers in the state have started growing doda post illegally in fields after the government banned the substance. Jaisalmer police in two different cases seized over 9,000 plants of doda-post being grown in fields and arrested two culprits.

SP Kiran Kung said they got a tip-off that demand for doda post has increased in the district in the wake of the panchayat elections. A special drive was launched against smuggling and sale of doda-post and arrests have been made. Nokh police station SHO, along with a team, arrested a culprit and recovered 8,730 plants of doda-post.

Title: Odisha: Funds crunch ends study dreams of child workers
Content:
The school were run with 100% grant from Union government

KORAPUT: At least 23 National Child Labour Project (NCLP) schools in Koraput district have closed down since April last year due to lack of funds.

An official said the schools were run with 100 per cent grant from the Union government and a bridge course of two years was provided to dropout students aged between 9-14, those who were engaged as child labourers in various hazardous and non-hazardous activities.

Each school had an enrolment capacity of 50 students and in 2019 as many as 790 students of the district were moved to the mainstream after clearing the bridge course.

An official source said the scheme was very helpful in getting child labourers of the district back into the mainstream and also arrest the practice of child labour.

“Owing to lack of proper communication between the Union labour ministry and the labour department of the state government, the schools have been closed,” alleged Jeypore MLA Tara Prasad Bahinipati.

The MLA claimed that while it is the duty of the state government to monitor and review the activities of the NCLP schools and subsequently to apprise the Centre, it has not been done at the state level for years.

Also, non-allocation of grants has hit the child labour survey works at panchayat level and as many as 70 staffers, including 30 teachers, working under the NCLP have been pushed to an uncertain future, he alleged.

“The NCLP staffers have not received their salary since October 2018 and are in dire straits. Sincere efforts should be done to ensure that the school are opened in the upcoming academic session,” Bahinipati said.

An official said all related up-to-date documents have been submitted to the NCLP wing of the ministry of labour. “We are in regular touch with the NCLP authorities for the funds. Already, we have lost one year and the survey work is yet to be done. Once, we receive the funds, then the pending dues of the staff will be paid and schools opened,” said Prasanna Kumar Panigrahi , district labour officer, Koraput. The project was launched in 1995.

Title: Coronavirus Pune Update: Doctor visited once, food is bad, but med is working, say coronavirus patients in Pune
Content:
Wednesday, 7.30AM

Waiting For Health News

Connected Via Calls

Co-Traveller Goes Online

Pune: When quarantined, it is normal to feel stressed, confused, scared or angry. The Sinhagad Road couple and their daughter who have been in the Naidu Hospital’s isolation ward after testing positive for coronavirus since Monday, spend their time chatting, taking naps inside the room and attend to calls from friends.There is no television and they have to depend on friends for food. But what they would like utmost is an update about their health from the doctors.The Sinhagad Road couple is up and take turns in using the wash room. They are in one room, while their daughter is in another. “We have to tell the staff to fetch some tea which they get with biscuits. The food arrangement at the hospital is pathetic. We ordered breakfast once, and it was of very poor quality. None of us could eat it," the 51-year-old man infected with Covid-19 said. They have requested their friends for food. “They drop a tiffin at the main desk of the hospital and it is brought to our room by a hospital staff member," the husband said, adding that they did not want to trouble their friends.After breakfast, the 51-year-old man said, they all wait for a doctor. "More than two days have passed since we were admitted here. The doctor on Tuesday morning checked our blood pressure. Since then, nobody has come, even for a routine check. All three of us are now irritated by the system here and are waiting to be discharged," one of them said. “We are given medicines and are better since our arrival and now feel fine,” he added. For any help or enquiries about the check-ups, the staff tells them that the doctor would decide. “The doctor has not visited as yet," they added.The patients said they did not have much to do the entire day as there was no source of entertainment. They receive calls from friends who check on their health. They call their son who is in another building of the same hospital. "The connectivity is poor here so talking on the cellphone is difficult," the husband said.The 27-year-old co-traveller is quarantined at Naidu Hospital since Tuesday. “No doctor has come to see me or check my health. I have been ordering from food delivery aggregators who deliver at the gate and a staff member sends the package to me. I am not being updated about my health,” he said.

Title: Rishikesh: J&K student, Nepalese drown in Ganga
Content:
Haridwar: Two students drowned in the Ganga in Rishikesh on Tuesday evening. Soon after the accident, police launched an operation to fish out their bodies but had failed to trace them till the time this report was filed late in the evening on Wednesday.

The two victims have been indentified as Tushar Kaushik and Milan Podal. While Tushar was a Jammu & Kashmir (J&K) resident, Milan was from Nepal. They had come to Rishikesh on Holi with their friends, two of whom were Delhi residents while one was from J&K.

Sanjeet Kumar, senior sub inspector of Muni-ki-Reti police station, told TOI, “The accident took place in Tapovan area. Reportedly, Milan slipped into the river and to save him, his other friends also jumped into the river but they all got trapped in the waves. On seeing this, a German tourist jumped into the river and saved two persons, Bhumika and Sahil but Tushar and Milan got drowned. Police divers and SDRF teams are trying to trace the bodies and their parents have been informed.”

According to police, Tushar was a student at an engineering college in J&K whereas Milan was a student of Jamia Millia Islamia (JMI) in New Delhi.

Title: Over 550 Holi revellers rush to city hospitals
Content:
Jaipur: Over 550 Holi revellers reached SMS Hospital and other private hospitals in the city in the past two days. Two persons died in a road accident, while 108 patients were admitted to SMS Hospital for driving under the influence of liquor and other intoxicating substances. Among them were also those who were brought to the hospital after their condition worsened due to excessive liquor consumption.

According to the SMS Hospital officials, the hospital has received 440 patients during the two days of Holi at emergency and trauma centre. “We had deployed extra team of doctors for Holi keeping in mind the increase in footfall at the hospital during Holi. There were 440 patients brought to the hospital and out of those, 108 have been admitted. Most of them had met with accidents or their condition worsened due to excessive consumption of intoxicating substances,” said an SMS Hospital official.

The doctors also claimed that patients were brought to the hospital due to skin allergies owing to the use of chemical colours. However, they claimed that this year, the cases of skin-related problems have dipped. Besides, the police were also alert as they were seen dealing with the revellers allegedly involved in disorderly conduct.

Title: UoH: Spotted deer dies in dog attack, deforestation to blame
Content:
Hyderabad: A male spotted deer died at the University of Hyderabad ( UoH ) on Wednesday. Officials and students suspect that the deer was attacked by feral dogs. The incident occured near Aparna Sarovar. The deer died while being shifted to hospital.

Students said that deforestation in the area has led to animals losing their natural habitat. “ The spotted deer and wild hares are being attacked and killed by feral dogs. The animals are unable to hide and save themselves during the attacks due to loss of natural habitat,” said Rohit Kumar Bondugula, a PhD scholar from the UoH. “Many wild animals also die in summer due to lack of waster sources and subsequent dehydration,” Rohit added. TNN

Title: JD(U) leader among 19 killed in Bihar on Holi
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: Altogether 19 people were killed, including three in the state capital, during Holi celebrations across Bihar on Tuesday. Among the three killed in Patna district was a JD(U) youth leader Kanhaiya Kaushik (30).

Kaushik, who was the state spokesperson for the youth wing of JD(U), was shot at by one of his friends, Kush Kumar Singh, for not including his photo in a poster extending Holi wishes. Another friend Chandan Kumar, who was accompanying Kaushik, also sustained bullet injuries.

The incident took place at Patel Nagar at 8.30pm on Tuesday. While Kaushik died during treatment at a private hospital on Bailey Road, Chandan is under treatment, police said, adding, two people were arrested on Wednesday while the prime accused Kush Kumar Singh is absconding.

In-charge City SP (central) D Amarkesh said, “Kaushik was at Shashtri Nagar police station half an hour before the incident to lodge a complaint against a few persons who had misbehaved with him on the issue of the Holi poster.”

In two other incidents in Patna, a property dealer Karu Rai (22) and a daily wager Haroo Yadav were also killed.

Altogether 16 murders during Holi were reported from eight districts across the state on Tuesday. Of these, four were lynched, two were stabbed to death and the rest were shot.

In Begusarai, a 40-year-old daily wager Rajesh Kumar was beaten to death by two bike-borne men at Lohiya Nagar in Bhagalpur town on Tuesday night after Kumar’s cycle collided with their bike, DSP (headquarters) Kundan Kumar Singh said. In another incident, one Pashupati Yadav was shot dead and his uncle and cousin were injured by a shopkeeper Pankaj Yadav over a petty dispute.

In Sitamarhi, villagers lynched two persons, Mohammad Shahrukh Khan (21) and Mohammad Kasim (27), while they were trying to flee after allegedly looting money from a stationery shop owner Rampravesh Mahto at Sonbarsa on Tuesday.

In Gaya, one person was shot dead and at least three policemen were injured after a group clash between residents of two villages under Mufassil police station on Tuesday. The deceased was identified as Bittu Sao (25).

Gaya SSP Rajeev Mishra said Buniyadganj police station SHO Shashi Kumar Rana received a deep cut on his face while Wazirganj sub-divisional officer’s bodyguard got his leg fractured during the heavy stone pelting.

In Siwan, a retired Army jawan Rajendra Prasad (58) died in stone pelting between two groups at a village under Mharajganj police station area around 2.30pm on Tuesday.

In Jamui, two persons were killed after they stabbed each other at a village under Jhajha police station area on Tuesday. SHO Sudeshwar Paswan said the deceased were identified as Mantu Manjhi and Jugeshgwar Paswan.

In Munger, an elderly man was lynched while a block-level JD(U) leader received gunshot injury after a caste-based clash broke out at a village under Mufassil police station on Tuesday. Munger SP Lipi Singh said, “The political leader Ravish Paswan (30) has been taken to a private hospital in Patna for treatment. Five persons have been arrested.”

In Bhagalpur, two persons Mohammad Jhakhas and Mohammad Putun were arrested after one Bishnu Mandal was shot at a village in Jagdishpur on Tuesday night over playing a song in Holi, SSP Ashish Bharti said. In another incident, police recovered the body of a 26-year-old youth Shubham Saket from Vikramshila colony in Bhagalpur.

In Nalanda, one Raja Ram was lynched for opposing an illicit relationship between a villager and a widow. In another incident, a 19-year-old youth Aman Kumar was shot dead after being thrashed by some people at a village at Bena police station area on Tuesday.

(With inputs from Farrukh Nadim in Biharsharif , Abdul Qadir in Gaya, Kumar Rajesh in Bhagalpur & Shyam Kishor Singh in Sitamarhi)

Title: Police inaction: SHRC asks TN to pay Rs 25,000
Content:
Chennai: The State Human Rights Commission ( SHRC ) has directed the Tamil Nadu government to pay Rs 25 ,000 as compensation to a woman who moved the commission seeking action against the Nagapattinam police for not acting on her complaint .

According to V Thilagavathy, her husband married again without legally breaking off the marriage with her. Angered over this, Thilagavathy lodged a complaint with the Thalainayar police, for which a community service register (CSR) number was issued by police as acknowledgment.

The woman stated that no action was taken on her complaint and subsequently, she faced death threats from her husband and his family. The sub-inspector who issued the CSR countered that the woman has preferred a false complaint and claimed that the parties did not appear for inquiry. After examining the submissions, the commission noted that if any complaint is treated as CSR, the same should be disposed of within seven days. But, the sub-inspector failed to do so and had failed to perform his duty in accordance with law. “Police had not sent any summons to those involved nor had they taken any steps to investigate the case. Police cannot say that the parties did not appear for enquiry,” the commission said and held that there was human rights violation. TNN

Title: Kin can represent voter for personal hearing: SEC
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: State election commission has decided to allow representatives of applicants for enrollment in voters’ list for personal hearing before the electoral registration officer, ahead of the 2020 local body polls. “Immediate relatives of voters can be authorized to represent them in the event of their inability to appear in person,” said an official release issued by state election commissioner V Bhaskaran on Wednesday.

The applicant should fill up a declaration, which can be downloaded from website www.lsgelection.kerala.gov.in, and the applicant’s representative should submit it before the officer during the hearing along with other documents. The electoral registration officers will be considering this declaration to enroll the applicant in the voters’ list, the release said.

The EC has also directed the electoral registration officers to consider favourably applications which have photos of the applicants uploaded on the website, without more inquiries, the release said.

Title: Hyderabad court rejects Revanth Reddy’s bail plea, MP to appeal
Content:
Revanth Reddy (File photo)

HYDERABAD: A local court dismissed the bail petition of Malkajgiri MP A Revanth Reddy in the drone camera case on Wednesday. The Congress MP’s advocate said that they would go for an appeal, soon.

Revanth Reddy was arrested on March 5 on charges of instructing his associates to use a drone camera to take an aerial view of a farmhouse in Janwada. He was sent to judicial remand till March 18.

Revanth is currently lodged in Cherlapally prison.

Apart from Revanth, Narsingi police had also arrested six of his associates — Praveen Paul Reddy, Vijay Simha Reddy, Jaipal Reddy, Rajesh, Shiva and Om Prakash Reddy — for using drones in violation of government orders to photograph private property.

Following the judicial remand, Revanth’s legal team moved a bail petition, and after the arguments, a court in Kukatpally dismissed the bail petition on Wednesday.

“The prosecution argued that the case is still under investigation and if the bail is granted there is a chance for intimidation of witnesses. The bail petition was dismissed by the court. We are planning to go for an appeal in the higher court,” defence counsel Panduranga Reddy said.

On Wednesday, the Hyderabad police made elaborate security arrangements near the house of the MP at Jubilee Hills, anticipating a huge turn out of supporters, in case he gets a bail.

The police bandobust is still continuing at the MP’s house to prevent any kind of untoward incidents.

Title: Hospitalised coronavirus-affected cabby visited Pune RTO on March 3
Content: PUNE: A woman employee of the Regional Transport Office (RTO) in the city was sent to Naidu Hospital for check-up because she helped the coronavirus-affected cab driver in signing some documents when he went to the facility on March 3, after driving the contagion-hit couple to the city from Mumbai.“The cab driver had signed some papers related to a bank loan termination and left the building. We came to know about it on Wednesday, after which the woman employee, who helped him, was identified and sent to Naidu Hospital. The doctors said she was fine but advised her 17-day rest at home,” Sanjeev Bhor, the deputy RTO, told TOI.A senior official said the RTOs were expected to suspend biometric attendance soon. Pune RTO Ajit Shinde said hand sanitizers had been kept in different places. “The employees have been told to apply them on their hands before going for the biometric attendance,” he said.More than 100 employees, including senior officials, are posted at the Pune RTO office near Sangam bridge.Special ward at rail hospitalA special ward consisting of 10 beds has been set up in the railway hospital in Pune.“An additional 152 beds across the rail hospitals in the Pune division have been readied for people who need to be quarantined,” a railway official said, adding that the biometric attendance system at the divisional railway manager (DRM)’s office in Pune had been suspended.

Title: Miley Cyrus withdraws from Australian bushfire concert amid coronavirus outbreak
Content: Pop-star Miley Cyrus recently announced that she has pulled out from the World Tour Bushfire Relief concert that was scheduled to be held in Australia 's Melbourne on Friday (local time).Cyrus's withdrawal comes as a result of the safety concerns emanating from the worldwide COVID-19 outbreak. The event has now been called off due to the singer's absence.However, Cyrus has pledged a donation in favour of the victims of the devastating Australian bushfires.The gig was also set to feature artists by the likes of Lil Nas X and DJ Seb Fontaine Another concert that would take place on Saturday (local time), with Robbie Williams as the highlight, remains unaffected from the last-minute setback.In a recent Tweet, the 'Wrecking Ball' singer said: "Due to the recommendations of local, state, federal and international government authorities, including the Center for Disease Control, to reduce potential health risks in response to the current global health crisis, we are no longer travelling to Aus for the show"."I am so disappointed to not be there, but I have to do what is right to protect the health and safety of my band and crew. I will still be making a donation to help the victims of the Australian bush fire. I'm sorry to miss everyone in Australia, but I will be back soon," she further wrote in the Tweet.According to a publication, TED Dainty, the event promoter stated in a release that the ticket fees would be refunded to all the spectators who signed up for Cyrus's performance."We are very sad that Miley Cyrus has announced that she will not be travelling to Melbourne and that as a result, the World Tour Bushfire Relief concert at Lakeside Stadium on Friday 13 March can no longer go ahead. All fans will receive a full refund and will be contacted by Ticketek shortly," the statement read.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Experts advise not to panic in case of flu-like symptoms
Content: PUNE: Health officials have urged citizens to not panic over flu-like symptoms, as the novel coronavirus infection has so far been detected only among travellers and those in immediate contact with them.People with a recent history of international travel, who have flu-like symptoms, are suspected to have contracted the novel coronavirus infection. The officials said such people should self-report to doctors at Naidu Hospital. Those who have flu-like symptoms, but don’t have a recent history of international travel, can seek treatment from a neighbourhood physician, the officials clarified.“District health officials have directed all private medical practitioners in Pune to refer patients with the history of international travel in the past 28 days and also have flu-like symptoms to Naidu Hospital,” said Sanjay Patil, president of the Indian Medical Association ’s (IMA) Pune branch.“We have been receiving a lot of queries from people from across the city and even those from outside about whether they need to be screened for novel coronavirus infection (Covid-19), as they have flu-like symptoms. People with no history of international travel should not panic. Only symptomatic people, who have recent history of international travel, should report to the hospital to rule out the possibility of contagion,” state surveillance officer Pradip Awate said.Covid-19 and the seasonal flu are similar in many ways. Both are respiratory diseases that spread through the droplets of fluid from the mouth and nose of someone who is infected. Both are contagious, produce similar symptoms and may cause severe symptoms in some.“There has been a sudden rise in cases of viral illnesses following the drop in temperature and also the wide fluctuation in the mercury levels. We have been seeing many patients complaining of cough, cold and fever. Many of them often ask whether it is the Covid-19 infection. We clear their misconceptions and treat people without any recent history of international travel,” senior family physician Prakash Mahajan said.The doctors stated that Covid-19 and seasonal influenza viruses “have a similar disease presentation”. Both viruses are transmitted by contact, droplets and fomites. As a result, the same public health measures, such as hand hygiene and good respiratory etiquette (coughing into your elbow or into a tissue and immediately disposing of the tissue) are important actions all can take to prevent infection.Senior physician K K Aggarwal, president of the Confederation of Medical Associations of Asia and Oceania, said, “To tackle any disease or infection, it is imperative to dispel myths associated with it. There are certain misconceptions surrounding the new coronavirus as well. I urge people to get information from reliable sources only and not rely on forwarded messages or remedies propagated via social media platforms. They must stay informed and undertake hygienic practices.”

Title: Songs saluting women’s life warm up the heart
Content:
Nagpur: The important stages of a woman’s life, right from the time she is born to when she grows up to become independent, were celebrated through 31 solo and duet songs, at a programme ‘Shakti Ka Naam Hi Naari Hai’ organized on the occasion of International Women’s Day on Sunday.

‘Mere ghar aayi ek nanhi pari’ presented by Priya Gupta, followed by ‘Choti si pyaari si aayi koi pari’ by Prasad Kulkarni and ‘Dil hai chotasa, chotisi asha’ by Kishori Ganvir wonderfully brought out emotions experienced by a family when a girl child is born.

‘Phulo ka taro ka’ presented by Sachin Patrange won hearts of the audience as it highlighted the love between a brother and sister.

‘Solah baras ki bali umar’, ‘O hansani’, and ‘Kya khoob lagti ho’ signalled the age when a girl grows up to become a beautiful teenage girl who experiences many emotions for the first time.

Feelings of love were best expressed through songs like ‘Kora kagaz tha yeh man’, ‘Hava ke saath saath’, ‘Lambi judaai’, ‘Aaj unse peheli mulakat’, ‘Phool tumhe bheja hai khat me’, and more.

Songs on marriage, the next important phase in a woman’s life, were well received by the audience. They included ‘Shayad meri shaadi ka khayal’, ‘Priye praneshvari’, ‘Yeh tera ghar yeh mera ghar’, ‘Itna na mujhse pyaar badha’, and a few others.

‘Ruk jaana nahi’ delivered a message that people should keep trying until they attain goals in life, regardless of the challenges that they might have to face.

Some of the other singers who regaled the audience included Seema Luha, Swati Sumesh, Girish Sharma, Ketaki Pethankar, Varun Tambaskar, LN Bodade, Manan Khandar, and others.

The show was presented by Anshul Singer’s Hunt at Scientific Society Hall. Anchor Namarata Agnihotri kept the audience entertained throughout the programme, which was conceptualized by Anant Pardhi under the guidance of Amit Harkare. Pavan Manvatkar and his team accompanied the singers on the stage.

(Reporting by Janhavi Dave)

Title: 108 ambulance service braces for any exigency
Content:
Madurai: As the preparedness by the government is being stepped up with a steady increase in the number of people testing positive for Covid-19 in the country with every passing day, the 108 ambulance service too is gearing up for the crisis by keeping their staff and vehicles ready to prevent possible infection from spreading.

A total of 31 ambulances in Madurai region have been identified to handle the crisis. Crew in these ambulances are equipped with personal protective equipment (PPE) and disinfection kits to handle suspected patients . Madurai regional manager of GVK EMRI R Prasath said that 31 ambulances have been identified from their 289-strong fleet in the 14 districts in Madurai region. The vehicle to handle Covid-19 suspects has been stationed at Madurai airport.

Over the last one week, the number has been increased in such a way that there is at least one in the district headquarters of every district. It is for easy transportation of suspects from the primary health centres and taluk government hospitals to tertiary care hospitals in the district headquarters or in nearby districts. The number of such ambulances has been increased to five in Madurai to make it easy for easy transportation from neighbouring districts to the Government Rajaji Hospital as it is the referral centre for this region. Six such ambulances have been kept ready in Kanyakumari as it shares the border with Kerala that has high incidence of virus infections. Staffs in these ambulances are provided with PPE kits that comprise a full gown with hood, face mask, pair of shoe covers and pair of gloves and disposable protective eye wear. “It is a disposable kit that an Emergency Medical Technician (EMT) wears before handling Covid-19 suspect,” Prasath said.

The EMT and the ambulance pilot should dispose the kit in a bio-disposable waste bag in the hospital on completion of the task of shifting the suspect to the tertiary care center. The 108 ambulance service sources said that each of these dedicated ambulances have been provided close to 10 sets of the disposable PPE kits and the number of ambulances could be increases if need arises.

Title: List action against 1,137 buildings in Besa-Beltarodi: HC
Content:
Nagpur: Expressing deep anguish over delay of over a decade in acting against 1 ,137 buildings flouting norms in Besa-Beltarodi area, despite its specific orders in 2010, the Nagpur bench of Bombay high court on Wednesday sternly directed the collector to submit a detailed action taken report.

A division bench comprising justices Sunil Shukre and Avinash Gharote told the collector to provide details of builders involved in the violations and also names of civic officials who failed to act against the illegal structures. While adjourning the hearing for four weeks, the collector was asked to complete formalities before next date.

The directives came while hearing a plea by social activist Anil Wadpalliwar through counsel Shreerang Bhandarkar alleging rampant violations of basic rules and regulations by hundreds of high-rise buildings and townships in Besa-Beltarodi. According to him, even Development Control Regulations (DCR) was not followed and there was massive violation of floor space Index (FSI) by greedy builders.

Earlier, Bhandarkar had filed a civil application citing HC order of January 27, 2010, where the collector was directed to start survey of all buildings and other constructions in Besa-Beltarodi and report on whether those are built as per the norms. He was also directed to examine whether those structures had permission from the competent authority and, if not, to stop their construction. He was further told to issue notices to all such buildings and conduct a thorough inspection, either himself or though an officer not below the rank of a deputy collector. All these directives were issued by then division bench comprising justices Sharad Bobde (now, Chief Justice of India) and Vasanti Naik.

At the same time, the petitioner was allowed to add other areas where the city is growing like Hudkeshwar and Wanadongri, along with Kamptee, Wardha, Koradi and Bhandara Road. Subsequently, the collector constituted a panel of senior officials from his office, who submitted a report to him after inspecting all buildings.

The collector in his affidavit of October 27, 2010, through then government pleader Nitin Sambre (now HC judge) came out with shocking revelation that as many as 1,460 constructions, including high-rise buildings and townships in Besa-Beltarodi, were in complete contravention of rules and regulations due to ignorance of concerned authorities.

In his latest application, Bhandarkar pointed out that no action has been taken till date by the respondents to remove or regulate illegal constructions, which has led to massive problems in the locality. The buildings also pose a big threat to life and security of the residents. While attaching several media report of blatant violations, he contended that none of the authorities had taken care to submit any report for over 10 years since 2010 in HC, and also failed to reply on similar structures in other fast growing areas on city’s outskirts.

Title: Corporation seeks people’s proposals for next budget
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: Carrying forward the participatory budgeting model, which was introduced by the city corporation in 2019, the civic body is collecting proposals from the public for the 2020-21 budget. Public can post their proposals on the official facebook page of mayor K Sreekumar . Proposals will also be received at the main office. The final date for receiving proposals is March 15.

The city corporation has been keen on ensuring public participation in key projects over the last three years starting with choosing wards for smart city project and in preparation of new master plan. Ward level meetings were also convened as part of Clean Killiyaar mission . Recently, the mayor has collected suggestions from city residents to finalize spots for day and night vending zones.

In 2006, Pune municipal corporation had allotted Rs 38 crores through participatory budgeting in wards under civic administration. The civic body had invited suggestions from citizens at ward offices and compiled suggestions on basic infrastructure like roads, electricity, slum development, water supply and drainage.

According to a World Bank report, participatory budgeting (PB) began in 1987 in Porto Alegre, one of the most populated cities in South Brazil. PB is a process through which citizens present their demands and priorities for civic improvement, and influence through discussions and negotiate the budget allocations made by their municipalities. Since 1989, budget allocations for public welfare works in Porto Alegre have been made only after the recommendations of public delegates and approval by the city council.

Public consultation will be a key factor in formulating proposals for the master plan preparation as well. The civic body tentatively scheduled development seminar ahead of the budget on March 14, however in the wake of regulations following Covid-19 outbreak, the seminar will be postponed.

Title: Pune: Oseltamivir, used to treat swine flu, is go-to drug
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The five patients undergoing treatment for the coronavirus infection (Covid-19) at Naidu Hospital in Pune are being treated with oseltamivir , a potent antiviral recommended for swine flu.

Oseltamivir is also popular as Tamiflu or Fluvir. At present, there is no targetted drug to treat patients with Covid-19 infection. Treatment is mainly supportive. Antivirals are being used to treat patients with Covid-19 infection across the world.

“We are treating the five Covid-19 infected patients with oseltamivir. They are responding and recovering. Other supportive drugs like crocin for fever and body ache are also being administered," a civic health official said.

The official added that all the patients have mild flu symptoms.

A health official said doctors in Jaipur were using anti-HIV drugs to treat coronavirus patients. “They are using a combination of two drugs, lopinavir and ritonavir which are second line drugs for controlling HIV infection. They decided to administer the combination after some patients developed severe respiratory problems," he added. China and Thailand use the same combination.

Title: Sparks fly in assembly over distribution of flood relief
Content:
THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The opposition, on Wednesday, locked horns with the government in the assembly over disbursement of financial aid for 2018 and 2019 floods victims.

Seeking leave for adjournment motion, the opposition alleged lapse on the part of the government in the suicide of a Meppadi-native Sunil Chandran, one of the flood-assistance beneficiaries, and also demanded a high-level probe into the involvement of CPM leaders in siphoning off funds meant for flood victims in Ernakulam.

Replying to opposition charges, revenue minister E Chandrasekharan said the government had categorized Sunil Chandran under those who were eligible for flood assistance for 75% to 100% damaged houses, and had disbursed Rs 1,01,900 as the first instalment. But since the account number he had provided was SBI Janapriya account in which only a maximum of Rs 50,000 can be credited at a time, it got rejected. The minister added that the government has taken steps to credit the fund by clearing the technicalities.

He said a probe is under way and a case has been registered against the culprits involved in siphoning off of funds from chief ministers’ distress relief fund (CMDRF). He said the first accused Vishnu Prasad, an official at Ernakulam collectorate, had illegally diverted Rs 10,54,000 to the account of another individual. An SIT has been constituted under assistant commissioner, Kochi, and the probe is under way, the minister said.

Meanwhile, the opposition said the funds were transferred to the account of M M Anwar, who is the husband of Kaulath, who is the director of CPM-controlled Ayyanad service cooperative bank at Thrikkakkara. Opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala alleged that the government was helping CPM leaders which is why it is not taking any action against the cooperative bank.

The opposition also alleged that siphoning of CMDRF and flood assistance is not just limited to Ernakulam, but there are many such instances across the state that needs to be comprehensively probed. The opposition MLAs later staged a walk-out after speaker P Sreeramakrishnan refused to admit adjournment motion on the basis of explanation from the revenue minister.

Title: Telangana spends Rs 50,000 per annum on each student in govt schools
Content: HYDERABAD: The state government spends, on an average, Rs 50,686 on each student per annum studying in 602 government residential schools across Telangana.During the question hour, SC welfare minister Koppula Eshwar said in the last five years, students of these residential schools have come up with extraordinary presentations. “Some of the students in minority residential schools participated in a NASA presentation and this speaks volumes about their skills,” he said.In all, 2,75,610 students are studying in these residential schools. The schools have 10,711 teaching and non-teaching staff. “The food and menu provided in these schools is on par with any private school,” the SC welfare minister said.The minister said though there was a lukewarm response for minority girls schools, the admission has improved to 40 per cent. The minister also said that states like West Bengal and Bihar were trying to adopt the residential school model of Telangana.TRS MLAs urged the government to localise purchases of ration and other material for these schools. “It is better that procurement happens at the local level and MLAs of the local area where the schools are located should be involved,” MLA Balka Suman said.

Title: Two booked for illegal water line in Hyderabad
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: The special task force team and vigilance wing of Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWS&SB) registered criminal cases against two property owners for illegal water connections in Jubilee Hills on Wednesday.

FIRs were filed against G Vara Prasad and Syed Taj at Jubilee Hills police station and Sanathnagar police station, respectively.

While Prasad had taken an illegal connection after the water board cancelled his previous line, Syed failed to produce relevant papers. The two were booked under Sections 269 and 430 of the IPC. The cases will be withdrawn if the accused regularise their water lines and pay the fine, a vigilance official said.

Title: Relatives of Tamil Nadu fishermen stranded in Iran hold fast
Content:
About 100 women, took part in a fast in front of the Nagercoil collectorate on Wednesday pleading for steps to... Read More

MADURAI: About 100 women from Kanyakumari, Arockiapuram, Kovalam, Colachel, Rajakkamangalamthurai and Thoothoor region, who are relatives of fishermen stranded in Iran due to the Covid-19 restrictions, took part in a fast in front of the Nagercoil collectorate on Wednesday pleading for steps to bring them back.

“I am suffering from tuberculosis, diabetes and have pressure but I am fasting here to get the government to repatriate my son from Iran,” said 60-year-old S Arulselvi of Manakudi. She told TOI that her son Saviour Daniston, 32, who has a five-year-old son and a six-week-old daughter who he has not seen so far. “He says they are all afraid. We petitioned the collector last Monday but my son and fellow fishermen are still awaiting help,” she lamented.

The women asked how the government can ignore the fishermen while 58 students and tourists from India have been repatriated. “The Arabian employers are telling our men that India will not come to their rescue and they will have to resume fishing,” says Mehala Reeda, 29, wife of Michael Rajan. “Let them send an aircraft or a ship to bring them all home,” she said.

G Abraham of Makkal Pathai which organised the fast said it has been 2 weeks since the nearly 800 Indian fishermen stranded in Iran raised the issue but the embassy officials have not visited them. “Luckily nobody has been infected so far but they are struggling without food and supplies,” he added. Fishermen Ascar and Robinson, who are among those stranded, said officials from embassy have not contacted them till date.

“We are managing with the available food by reducing our intake. We have asked our employers to provide food and expect it to reach us in a couple of days. We don’t know when swab samples will be collected from us for testing us for Covid-19 and repatriated,” Robinson said.

Title: Kerala: Government transfers VR Premkumar
Content:
VR Premkumar

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The government, which rebuffed the pressure exerted by IAS officers, on Wednesday, issued the order regarding the transfer of land records director V R Premkumar as the director of industries department. A decision on the transfer was taken by the cabinet on March 4. Sources said that principal secretary (revenue) V Venu, who had openly taken a stand against the transfer, has decided to go on leave for a month in protest.

Track the pollution level in your city

In a strongly-worded note to the chief secretary, a copy of which was also marked to the chief minister’s and revenue minister’s offices, he had asked the government to reconsider the decision. He had said that the abrupt transfer of a young IAS officer will not only demotivate him, but also send a negative signal to the IAS officers. He had further said that there are several decisions in the past prescribing the procedures before shifting an officer, such as convening a civil services board (CSB), to ensure stable tenure to officers, which have not been considered while transferring the officer.

Later, the IAS officers’ association also came up with a resolution stating that such frequent transfers are extremely demoralizing and would adversely affect governance. It had also demanded that cadre management of IAS should be streamlined, and due process of CSB should be followed (which will act against removing any officer who has not completed a minimum assured tenure of two years unless without specific reasons) in cases where the officers are transferred within a short period of their posting.

However, the government refused to change its decision and now issued the posting orders of the new survey director, R Girija. An officer from 2014 batch of the IAS, Premkumar was posted as the director of survey and land records few months ago.

Title: Firms empty out floors as staffers test positive, offer work from home option
Content: PUNE: Two IT companies in different parts of the city advised their employees to work from home after one staffer in each firm tested positive for Covid-19 recently, prompting the managements to sanitize the premises.“We have learned that one of our employees has been tested for coronavirus (Covid-19), for which the test result is awaited…The floor will be extensively cleaned and will reopen once the process is complete,” one of the companies stated in the email to the employees, adding that the staffers were advised to work from home.The email also stated, “We are also in discussions with our clients to determine the best approach to deliver our services, which will continue to include remote, virtual and other technologies, among other options.”The other company went a step further and closed down the entire office for deep cleaning. “We are telling those associates, who can work remotely, to do so,” the firm said.An estimated 4.5 lakh employees work directly or indirectly with the IT industry in the city. In the last fortnight, the business planning teams of different IT companies and captives in Pune have been bracing up for possible impact due to the Covid-19 scare and positive cases.Many companies have also advised caution, including placing restrictions on travel to the affected countries.The Pune president of the Forum of IT Employees, Pavanjit Mane, said these precautions were currently being taken only by large IT firms. “An advisory from the district administration will be of immense help. We have appealed to the collector to do the needful,” Mane said.Some companies have provided for 24x7 helplines, face masks and hand sanitizers to help their employees tide over the prevailing situation. “We have put in place several measures, including increased precautions at our facilities, travel advisories, remote working and a dedicated helpdesk, to ensure employee safety and business continuity,” an IT company, which employs a few thousand employees in Pune alone, said.When the issue of IT firms was raised with district collector Naval Kishore Ram, he said the IT companies offering their employees work from home option can do so on their own as the administration has not issued any advisory in this regard.

Title: ABVP workers protest ‘nominal’ budget allocation for education sector
Content:
Protesters attempted to climb the assembly gates on Wednesday

HYDERABAD: Members of Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) led ‘Chalo Assembly’ protest on Wednesday demanding higher budget allocation for education sector. Dozens of students marched to the assembly around 11am as they tried to lay siege to the complex. Raising ‘we want justice’ slogan, some students attempted to climb the assembly gates, while others sat on the road to protest.

Agitated by reduction of budget allocation for education sector over the years, ABVP members blamed TRS government for neglecting public education.

Vacant vice-chancellor and teacher posts in universities, failure in releasing notification for government jobs, pending fee reimbursement dues and school fee regulation were some of the issues raised by the protesters. “We strongly condemn nominal funding for education in the state budget. The government should immediately establish a female university and resolve other issues,” said Matta Raghvender , a ABVP member.

The police used mild force to rein in the protesters who tried to breach the security. Total 25 protesters suffered injuries, of which five suffered grave injuries on their hands. The police took 140 protesters into preventive arrest and were later released. A criminal case was registered against 35 protesters on the charge of unlawful assembly, assaulting public servant, violence of prohibitory orders and obstruction to traffic.

Title: Over Rs 4,000 crore spent under Kalyana Lakshmi: Telangana minister
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: BC Welfare Minister Gangula Kamalakar on Wednesday told the state assembly that there is no proposal to provide the benefits of Kalyana Lakshmi - Shaadi Mubarak scheme on the day of the marriage.

Answering a question during the question hour, the minister said the scheme was launched only a few years ago and it is being streamlined.

He said that Rs 4,572 crore has been spent so far under this scheme since 2014-15.

“BC welfare department has been given Rs 1,900 crore, minorities welfare department Rs 1,021 crore, tribal welfare department Rs 1,036 crore and social welfare department has been allocated Rs 1,036 crore. A total of 6,15,573 families benefited out of this scheme and the maximum number of beneficiaries are from BC families (2,41,491),” said Kamalakar.

Title: Want to die before burying alive 9,000 birds: Poultry farmer
Content:
Akash Khurade (in yellow T-shirt) had started the poultry farm in his native village Lasnapur in Amravati dist... Read More

Nagpur: For 30-year-old Akash Khurade, it’s going to be a tough decision to bury alive more than 9,000 birds in his poultry farm.

“I don’t have any option but to bury them. I feel like committing suicide before doing that,” said Khurade, an MBA. He intends to seek permission from the state government to end his life in case he has to bury the birds.

Khurade started the poultry farm in his native village Lasnapur in Amravati district eight years ago with 1,000 birds. His management skills earned him an identity as one of the leading poultry farms in Vidarbha. But, due to rumours circulating after the coronavirus outbreak, chicken demand has gone down drastically and he is left with no option but to kill the birds.

“Not coronavirus, but rumours associated with it will claim more lives,” he said.

“Ahead of Holi, I had 13,000 birds ready for market. I was expecting at least Rs80 per kg rate as it takes more than Rs74 per kg to feed and vaccinate chickens and grow then to a 2kg bird. Due to low demand, I sold only some 4,000 birds at Rs13 to Rs14 per kg rate,” Khurade said. He is willing to sell off the remaining birds too, but merchants are not approaching him now. Those who approach are offering less than Rs7 per kg, which is less than even two-day feed cost of a bird.

This year, due to baseless rumours that coronavirus is spread through non-vegetarian food, people have stopped eating chicken. Khurade said he has very limited resources and cannot feed these birds for another 2-3 days. Depressed since past three-four days, he blamed news channels for fuelling the rumours.

“Every alternate day, most Marathi news channels run debates on chicken and coronavirus issue. Customers get influenced by these channels,” said Khurade, who runs a farm besides his poultry business. “I have been paying all loan instalments on time till date. Government should think of providing some relief to people like me,” he concluded.

Poultry birds are brought up in such a way that they don’t know how to search for food and will die of starvation if not fed artificially. They can’t live outside the poultry shade and there is also a risk of infection if not looked after properly. Hence, standard way of wiping out a poultry farm is to bury the birds in a pit alive. Many poultry farmers and hatcheries in India are doing this after low demand due to coronavirus rumours.
