However, this is devastating for many young and educated youths in Vidarbha who have taken poultry farming as an enterprise. Navneet Darokar has 5,000 birds in Amravati, Madhav Jadhav has 6,000 birds near Nanded, while Aniket Raut has more than 3,000 birds in Yavatmal. As per existing policies, they can take insurance cover for their shades and equipment but birds cannot be insured due to their short life. These are just a few names, said Dr Raja Dudhbale, president of Vidarbha Poultry Farmers’ Association.

“We are trying to create awareness through all possible platforms. But, it’s becoming difficult to convince people day by day. Small poultry farms in Vidarbha are getting buried alive with birds. State government should provide some relief or it will trigger suicide by poultry farmers,” he said.

Title: Mass screening to check spread of coronavirus starts from Sinhagad Road, Manjari Budruk
Content: PUNE: Health officials on Wednesday conducted mass screening of citizens living in and around a housing society on Sinhagad Road and in Manjari Budruk , where a couple, their daughter and a cab driver tested positive for the novel coronavirus live.At least 610 households in and around the housing society on Sinhagad Road were covered during the first day of the mass screening from 8am to 2pm. The screening is a part of the cluster containment strategy the health officials adopted to check the spread of novel coronavirus (Covid-19) in the community.The strategy entails screening of people living within a 3km radius of any housing society where an infected person lives.“The cluster containment strategy is being implemented on Sinhagad Road and also in Manjari Budruk near Hadapsar. The couple and their daughter, who tested positive for the Covid-19 infection, live in a housing society on Sinhagad Road,” a state health official said.“The private cab driver, who ferried the couple and their daughter from Mumbai to Pune, also tested positive for the contagion. He lives in a housing society in Manjari Budruk. We have also started screening people living in and around the society where the cab driver lives,” he said.Agra was the first city in India to implement the strategy after six residents contracted the infection from their relative who had returned from Italy. The five positive cases of Covid-19 in Pune — four travellers and a private cab driver — in two days underscored the need to curb the spread of the virus within the community as well.Union health minister Harsh Vardhan on Monday called upon states to adopt the cluster containment strategy, making district collectors more accountable, and laid emphasis on contact tracing and strengthening (district) surveillance teams to avoid widespread community transmission.“In the cluster containment approach, we immediately start checking and sensitising every household within the 3km radius of the house of an infected person and also those who have come in contact with the affected to prevent the community spread of the virus. We will implement the strategy in the city through the Pune Municipal Corporation ’s (PMC) health officials,” state surveillance officer Pradip Awate said.

Title: Pune: Naidu inmates to get food from private agency
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) has appointed a private agency to provide food to patients admitted at the Naidu Infectious Diseases Hospital here.

Civic health officials said that lunch and dinner would be provided to patients admitted at the facility. Besides, they also have the option of bringing food from home. However, entry to the relatives of patients or food providers would be allowed up to the entry gate.

Title: Trust violated lease conditions: Revenue min
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: The government has decided to resume the 65 cents of land known as Pathrakulam from Sri Vidhyadhiraja Trust , after it was found that the trust had violated several conditions including remitting the land value when it was assigned to it, revenue minister E Chandrasekharan said.

Replying to a submission in this regard by MLA O Rajagopal, the minister said that the revenue secretary had conducted hearing on January 9 and February 25 during which the trust members were heard on the basis of the court order. “The order to resume the land was taken after hearing the trust office bearers, examining all the relevant documents and the high court order in this regard and finding that the trust had violated conditions including the condition to remit the land value, while assigning the land to them,” the minister said.

The land which was assigned to the Vidhyadhiraja Trust in 1976, was resumed by the government in an order on February 29, in which it was said that the land will be protected as government land hereafter. The order had also said that it can be explored if this land can be utilized for mitigating floods in East Fort and Thampanoor areas in the capital, and the specific area within the land where Chattambi Swami temple is located, can be considered for handing over to the Vidhyadhiraja trust.

The trust had again filed a writ petition against the government order and the high court has asked the government to maintain status quo, last week. The minister said the government has followed only legal steps in this matter.

Title: All births, deaths not registered in Bihar: Study
Content:
Image used for representatioanl purpose only

PATNA: Even as the registration of birth is mandatory for the people aspiring to avail the benefits of almost all welfare schemes launched both by central and state governments, Bihar lags far behind in ensuring registration of vital elements under the civil registration system (CRS). Only 3/4th of the births and less than half of the deaths are being registered in the state, says a recent study made by Patna University’s Population Research Centre (PRC) in collaboration with UNICEF.

While the level of registration of births and deaths in the country stands at 84.9% and 79.6% respectively, it is only 73.7% and 37.1% respectively in Bihar, the study indicates.

The study made by Jayanta Kumar Basu of UNICEF and Dilip Kumar, B K Pandey and Ajit Kumar of PRC points out that the levels of registration vary substantially from district to district. For example, in 2018, the level of birth registration ranged from as high as 99.1% in Purnia to as low as 44.2% in East Champaran. Similarly, in case of death, the level of registration varies significantly from 51.8% in Munger to 5.5% in Banka.

According to the study, the need and importance of civil registration, particularly that of birth registration, is well perceived by the community. This is despite the fact that not much effort has been put forward by the district authorities in terms of information, education and communication (IEC) inputs. Hoardings on civil registration were once supplied by the Directorate of Economics and Statistics, but the same are not visible anywhere now. Interaction with various stakeholders as well as the community suggests that since birth registration is a requirement for school enrolment, Aadhaar registration, as well as for availing the benefits from schemes like Mukhyamantri Kanya Utthan Yojana, Janani Suraksha Yojana, Dhan Lakshmi Yojana and Pradhan Mantri Matri Vandana Yojana, the people have now become interested towards registering the birth of their children.

The awareness is, however, much lower in case of death registration. It transpired that only if the dependents of the deceased have some vested interests, they feel the need for death registration. This includes claim from life insurance, inheriting the title for land holding, etc.

Then, there are certain myths and misconceptions associated with birth registration as well. In some communities, there is a custom of not giving the name of the child just after birth. But, furnishing the name of the child is a necessary condition for birth certificate. This is a reason why they are not inclined to have the birth of the child registered within 21 days. This holds true also for home deliveries as well as institutional deliveries from private facilities.

The study suggests that for augmenting the process of registration, the monitoring role of the state, district and sub-district functionaries needs further strengthening with particular focus on quality of data collected and their use in decision making. Despite the fact that the state-wise targets for civil registration are set by the Registrar General of India, the targets set for the district and the sub-district level need to be worked out based on some scientific methodology. Aspects of migration, live births reported by the health management information system, etc may be taken into consideration, the study adds.

PRC joint director Dilip Kumar observes that registration of birth is a fundamental right of every child and is the first step towards establishing his or her legal identity. There is no denial of the fact that the information on vital events (birth and death) is not only essential for socioeconomic planning and development, but also for evaluation and effective implementation of various public schemes and programmes. It assumes more significance in the present context of preparing National Population Register (NPR) and National Register of Citizens (NRC), he adds.

Title: Big Temple, 3 ASI monuments to be shut
Content: Trichy: Four monuments in the central region of Tamil Nadu, which are managed by the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), will remain closed till March 31 to prevent the spread of Covid-19 ASI sources said it could not manage the footfall at Arulmigu Brihadeswara Temple (Big Temple) in Thanjavur, Arulmigu Airavateswara Temple in Dharasuram (Thanjavur), Arulmigu Brihadeswara Temple in Gaingaikondacholapuram (Ariyalur) and Arulmigu Valeeswarar Temple in Valikandapuram (Perambalur). “Ever since schools were ordered to be closed, there was a spike in the footfall of devotees coming in,” an ASI official said. Adhering to a directive of ASI New Delhi, all the four protected monuments in ASI Thanjavur sub-circle were closed around 10am on Wednesday. ASI sources said that devotees who were present in these temple complexes were asked to leave immediately. Notice boards prohibiting the entry of devotees were also placed. Though the temples will be closed for devotees, the rituals being conducted through the Hindu religious and charitable endowments (HR&CE) department will continue.“This is the first time that the great Chola temples managed by the ASI have prohibited entry of devotees,” the ASI official added.

Title: Railways sets up isolation wards, kickstarts disinfection campaign
Content:
Madurai: The Madurai railway division has established isolation wards and launched disinfection drives to prevent Covid-19 outbreak in the region. The preparatory measures were kick-started on a war-footing on directions from the general manager (GM) of Southern Railway to all divisional-level officials on Monday. The instructions were in detail and specific, a senior railway official said.

Isolation wards designed with 126 beds to accommodate suspected people have been set-up at the Railway Training Institute, Arasaradi (24), Railway Basic Training Centre, Thiruparankundram (13), RPF barracks, Dindigul (22), RPF barracks, Tirunelveli (26), Multi-disciplinary divisional training institute, Virudhunagar (25) and Madurai Divisional Health Unit (16).

The Madurai divisional health unit will have eight beds for men, five for women and three for children.

“The wards will be a first stop to quarantine suspected cases, from where they will be shifted to government designated hospitals. Machinery is in place to monitor suspected cases at different railway stations,” a senior railway official told TOI. Commuters need not panic as the wards are only a preventive mechanism.

The railways is also focusing on intensive disinfection. On directions of the divisional railway manager V R Lenin and chief medical superintendent, Baskar, staffs are engaged in disinfecting places such as the ticket counters, waiting halls, toilets, drinking water taps, pantry area, benches and handrails of stairs that are used or frequently touched by many.

“Disinfection drives are also carried out in rakes at the terminating stations like Madurai, Tirunelveli, Ramanathapuram and Tuticorin with focus on trains operated by the division. The rakes would be disinfected at least once a week,” the official said.

The schedule is planned to ensure that it does not affect the regular operating time. Officials said that efforts are under way to provide additional antibacterial products such as sanitizers and wipes at the stations, on the trains and in employee work areas.

Regular public announcements are also made at all important railway stations to create awareness among passengers and employees on the Covid-19 preventive measures. Education and communication material on coronavirus are also displayed at important locations.

Title: 10-year-old girl raped & killed in Mainpuri, accused arrested
Content:
Agra: A 10-year-old girl was allegedly abducted and sexually assaulted and then strangulated to death at a village in Mainpuri on Monday. The victim's body was found at a secluded place behind a primary school campus on Tuesday morning. Police have arrested the accused, identified as Manoj Kumar, 23. According to police, the accused lured the girl from outside her house in the afternoon. Since the accused was known to the girl, she accompanied him. The accused is a "mason" and was working at the school, police said.

When the girl’s parents did not find her for some time, they started looking for her in nearby areas but in vain. On Tuesday morning, the girl's body was spotted by a local who immediately informed the family.

A police complaint was subsequently lodged against the accused, who lives in a neighbouring village. Preliminary investigation revealed that the girl was strangulated to death after she was assaulted sexually. The body has been sent for postmortem, and we will be able to ascertain the actual cause of death once the report comes, police said.

Dannhar police station SHO Begram Singh said that an FIR was registered under sections 376 (rape), 302 (murder), 201 (causing disappearance of evidence of offence) of the IPC and Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act against the accused.

Title: Shah misleading Parliament, must resign: Congress
Content:
Congress leader in Lok Sabha, Adhir Ranjan Chaudhary speaks during the ongoing Budget Session inside Lok Sabha... Read More

Congress on Wednesday demanded home minister Amit Shah’s resignation for his “failure to contain the Delhi riots” even as most opposition parties demanded an independent judicial inquiry into the communal flare-up that claimed 53 lives and left over 500 injured.

Congress MPs staged a walkout during Shah’s response in Lok Sabha, claiming he was “misleading Parliament” instead of accepting his failure in containing the riots.

On Wednesday morning, Congress’s Adhir Ranjan Chowdhury gunned for Shah’s scalp as he referred to the violence as a “defeat of humanity”. Accusing PM Narendra Modi and Shah of being like Roman emperor Nero and “playing the fiddle in Ahmedabad to host President Trump” while Delhi burned, Chowdhury also referred to the midnight transfer of a Delhi High Court judge who pulled up the government and Delhi Police for “inaction” and called it a “midnight surgical strike on the judiciary”.

This saw heated exchanges between treasury and opposition benches. Even as BJP MPs asserted that the government had nothing to do with the judge’s transfer, BJD MP Pinaki Mishra clarified that the transfer was, indeed, cleared by the law ministry.

Questioning Shah on why he was “missing in action” from riot-hit areas when NSA Ajit Doval could visit to calm nerves, Chowdhury said, “Why did Ajit Doval have to step in? NSA does not step in to control law and order. He reports directly to the PM and his office. This means the PMO did not have the faith in the home minister’s office. It seems India now has two power centres, the PMO and the HMO.”

Several opposition parties echoed Congress’s charges. TMC’s Saugata Roy said BJP MP Meenakshi Lekhi's speech was “communal and polarising” and that she played the devil's advocate for “defending” BJP’s Kapil Mishra. He said the minority community suffered more in the riots and demanded Shah’s resignation.

AIMIM’s Asaduddin Owaisi said there was a “tsunami of Hindutva hate” and called for an impartial probe to find the perpetrators of the violence. BSP’s Danish Ali opposed Lekhi for “identifying” women of one community, a remark that led Speaker Om Birla to direct members not to take the names of any caste or religion. Birla also directed that some of Lekhi’s comments be expunged .

Referring to the riots as shameful because even the media and judiciary was not spared, DMK’s T R Baalu said, “Even mediapersons were not left alone. Those belonging to CNN, NDTV, Times of India, Reuters, India Today, and News18 were mercilessly attacked. Their equipment was seized and thrown into dustbins. All this happened during daylight on February 24, 25 and 26.”

BJD’s Pinaki Mishra said he was embarrassed and ashamed as an Indian by what happened. “I believe that there must be the most dispassionate, the most ruthless possible investigation into why these riots occurred, who the perpetrators were and they must be brought to book mercilessly. But this must be an independent inquiry and this must inspire confidence,” he said.

NCP’s Amol Kolhe said Indian was in the grips of “religious nationalism” and expressed concern over children being asking questions on religion. Samajwadi Party’s Shafiqur Rehman Barq demanded action against BJP’s Kapil Mishra, Anurag Thakur and Parvesh Verma. He also said Muslims were feeling insecure and demanded a judicial inquiry into the violence.

Title: Rain causes waterlogging on pothole-ridden roads
Content:
Agra: Rain on Wednesday morning caused waterlogging on the city roads. Majority of the roads have potholes on them. The hapless state of the roads caused much inconvenience to the commuters. Besides, sewer overflow in several wards added to the woes.

Even after extension of deadline several times, Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) has not been able to make the city roads pothole-free. Damaged roads in all the 100 wards of the city were targeted to be repaired by December last. However, many city roads remain untouched.

Senior municipal councilor Ravi Mathur said, “Quality of the repair work was very poor. In several wards, concrete of the roads repaired last year has started wearing out. Rainfall has caused waterlogging on the roads. The problem faced by people will be raised in the municipal board meeting.”

Wazirpura resident Vinod Kumar Singh said, “Even after the delay, the authorities have failed to repair the roads causing a lot of inconvenience to the commuters. Potholes are causing accidents on daily basis. We raised the issue several times but officials took no action.”

Half of the city roads maintained by AMC are not in a good condition. Roads at Madia Katra, Boghipura, Kailashpuri, Shahganj locality, Paschimpuri, Sikandra road, Maruti Estate, interior roads of Pratapura locality, Belanganj, Peepal Mandi, Langdey ki Chowki, Daresi, Heerabagh, Devri Road, Nunihai are among those in dire need of repair. Roads in Trans-Yamuna and Shahdara localities around Yamuna bridge and Guru-ka-Taal also require repair work.

The areas where sewer overflow took place on Wednesday include Awas Vikas, Paschimpuri, Sikandra, Kaushalpura, Freeganj, Lohamandi, Shahganj and Albatiya.

Municipal commissioner Arun Prakash said, “Complaints of water-logging on roads due to early morning rainfall have been received. Officials have been directed to identify all the roads that have potholes and start the repair work.”

According to the meteorological department, one or two spells of rain or thundershower can take place on Thursday.

Title: CRS inspects newly electrified double line
Content:
Madurai: Commissioner of Railway Safety (CRS) Southern Circle, Bengaluru, K A Manoharan carried out a three-day inspection from Monday to Wednesday on the newly electrified double line in and around Vanchi Maniyachchi in Tuticorin district. It included inspection of select portions on a motor trolley and speed trials as well.

The stretch is part of the doubling with electrification of the 160km Madurai – Vanchi Maniyachi – Tuticorin (160km) that is being executed at Rs 1,182.38 crore. The stretch that has been completed is for 45km from Kadambur – Tattaparai and Vanchi Maniyachchi – Tattaparai. The inspection was primarily covering the signalling and engineering works.

On Monday, the CRS inspected Gangaikondan – Vanchi Maniyachchi section, followed by the Kadambur – Vanchi Maniyachchi section on Tuesday. On Wednesday, he inspected the Tattaparai – Vanchi Maniyachchi section before conducting a speed trial between Tattaparai and Vanchi Maniyachchi.

The speed trial in a special train conducted at 120km an hour speed on the Tattaparai – Vanchi Maniyachchi section was completed in 12 minutes. Manoharan also conducted reviews of the completed work with officials from Rail Vikas Nigam Limited (RVNL) and Madurai railway division.tnn

Title: Coronavirus scare: 14 advised home quarantine by Vadodara Municipal Corporation
Content: VADODARA: As many as 14 persons remain quarantined at home in Vadodara city after return from countries affected by COVID-19 outbreak. The numbers went up since about a week as the number of countries where the outbreak was reported increased.On March 5, only five persons were advised to stay quarantined at home as they had returned from China and other affected countries. By Monday, the number increased to 18 including four Italian tourists who were staying at a hotel. Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) health department officials are keeping a close tab of persons who have travelled to the city from countries that are facing the viral outbreak. It came to light on Monday that a group of tourists from Italy had come to the city. They had travelled widely in the state making the officials wary. With Italy having a large number of COVID-19 cases, panic triggers were pressed.The tourists were asked to stay in isolation at the hotel and were examined by a team of doctors. Their samples were collected immediately and the samples were sent to Ahmedabad for analysis. It came to light that they were not suffering from COVID-19 and were allowed to go, said an official. He added that they had a flight to Italy from Delhi on Tuesday.With the four Italian tourists being allowed to go, the number of persons advised isolation stood at 14 on Wednesday. These 14 persons too have not shown any COVID-19 symptoms so far.VMC officials said that the number of persons being kept in home quarantine had increased because more and more countries are getting affected by the outbreak.

Title: Man shot dead after kids fight over water from public tap in Mathura
Content:
Agra: A 30-year-old man, Fateh Singh, was allegedly shot dead following a clash between two families after a fight among their children over drinking water from a public tap on the day of Holi in Mathura on Tuesday. An FIR has been registered against 10 persons but only four have been arrested so far.

According to police, an argument between the two families took place on Sunday too, but the matter was resolved after intervention of local residents. But on the day of Holi, the matter took an ugly turn when Ved Prakash and his family members attacked Fateh Singh and his mother, father and brother with sticks.

During the clash, someone from Ved’s family fired at Fateh Singh from a country-made pistol. The latter succumbed to bullet injuries. His mother, Atri Devi, father Durga Prasad and cousin brother Ashok Kumar were also injured in the clash. Though they are out of danger, doctors have kept them under observation.

Talking to TOI on Wednesday, station house officer (SHO) of Barsana, Subhash Chandra Pandey said that four persons - Prehlad, Maan Singh, Indra and Bhagwandei - have been arrested while others are absconding. He added that one country-made pistol along with a live cartridge has been recovered from their possession and they will be booked under the Arms Act.

The SHO said that Fateh Singh’s body has been sent for postmortem. An FIR has been registered under sections 302 (murder), 307 (attempt to murder), 452 (house trespass after making preparation for hurt, assault or wrongful restraint), 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace) of IPC at Barsana police station on the basis of a complaint filed by the deceased’s brother Komal.

After the incident, police force was deployed in the area to maintain law and order.

Title: CPM protests against corpn ‘bias’ in collecting tax dues
Content:
Madurai: Members of the CPM staged a protest by dumping garbage in front of the south zone office of Madurai Corporation, protesting against the bias shown by the civic authorities in favour of tax evaders who had crores worth of pending dues. The corporation is taking many steps to collect taxes from the residents and private organisations in the city. Tax evaders face various actions, including disruption of water supply and disconnection of UGD connections. Garbage bins of corporation are also placed in front of the premises of people whose dues exceed many thousands.

A few days ago, the authorities placed a dumper bin in front of a house in Hanumarkoil street in the 81st ward. Pleas by the woman resident to take it away were not heeded to. The CPM members, led by secretary of Madurai Central CPM, P Jeeva took it up with the corporation officials. “They told us that they needed money to pay salaries for their staff and had to collect the pending dues,” said Jeeva.

He said the corporation’s actions were not acceptable as the authorities harassed many residents in wards 81 and 82 with dire consequences if they did not pay their tax dues. “ They let off evaders who have crores worth of pending dues and harass ordinary people who have to pay only a few thousands of rupees,” he said. To protest this, the members of the CPM took bins of garbage and dumped them in front of the south zone office. The bin in front of the house was also removed in the evening.

Title: Unabated ‘illegal’ road cutting causes public inconvenience
Content:
Agra: The Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) administration has not been able to put a tab on unauthorized digging and road cutting for different works. The unplanned road digging by various government and private agencies for laying pipeline or wires are causing a lot of inconvenience to residents and commuters.

According to sources, in the city’s 100 wards, unauthorized digging and road cutting for different development projects were initiated in January. At several places where civic body had provided permission for digging, the spots were not properly covered after completion of work.

The area where the majority of the illegal digging and road cutting has taken place in past one month includes Fatehabad road, near Agra – Mathura highway, Sikandra, Bodla and Trans-Yamuna.

Awas Vikas colony resident Shyam Goyal said, “A mobile company had carried out road digging in January to lay underground cables. After completion of work, they didn’t conduct road repairing. Now, we are suffering due to damaged road. Civic body authorities have failed to take cognizance of the matter.”

Mayor Naveen Jain said, “Regular complaints are surfacing regarding illegal digging and road cutting. In this regard, officers have been asked to take all the complaints seriously and take suitable action in a time-bound manner. FIR will be registered against the officials of the agencies for repeatedly violating standard norms for digging and road cutting in the city.”

Title: Delhi Coronavirus News: 500 contacts of all five coronavirus patients under surveillance
Content: NEW DELHI: The number of Covid-19 cases in Delhi rose to five on Wednesday, with a 46-year-old man with a history of travel to Japan, Geneva and Italy being confirmed positive for the novel coronavirus infection The man, a resident of Janakpuri in west Delhi, has been admitted to Ram Manohar Lohia (RML) Hospital, officials said. “There are nine members in his family, all are asymptomatic except his mother,” said an official.He added that surveillance of nearby 50 houses has been done and authorities were keeping a close watch on anyone who may have come in contact with the patient.Of the five cases confirmed in Delhi, the first one was a resident of Mayur Vihar in east Delhi. The rest are from West Delhi, sources said.“Nearly 500 people who came in contact with the five persons found positive for Covid-19 are under surveillance. Some of them are from outside the state,” said a source. He added that 48 people suspected to be infected are admitted at Safdarjung and RML hospitals — the two nodal centers for treatment of Covid-19 cases in Delhi. “The state headquarters control room received 38 calls on Wednesday for Covid-19 related queries. More than 20 calls were made to CATS for ambulance services,” an official of the public health department said.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Kerala: For three days, they raced against time
Content:
Ambulance drivers at Pathanamthitta General Hospital get ready to take people to isolation ward on Wednesday

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM : Hours after five Covid-19 cases were confirmed in Pathanamthitta, district administration and health department knew that they were in for a massive tracing exercise because one-to-one interviews with the affected persons gave a picture of a large ring of contacts.

Tracing and establishing communication with primary and secondary contacts within the minimal possible time was the challenge. The flowchart depicting date, time and place of movement of affected persons within three clusters was the result of a midnight discussion attended by the state health secretary, NHM state mission director and Pathanamthitta collector PB Nooh.

Officials were looking for a solution for fast-tracking the isolation process and spatio-temporal mapping (STM), which employs data on time and space of movement from a single point to multiple destinations, emerged the best ploy.

“We had to beat the virus and manual surveillance was the first choice. Instead of going after primary and secondary contacts, we wanted info on them to reach us. We thought of STM since it enabled plotting on map and date, time, place stamping. It also ensured greater public participation. Soon after we released the flowchart, we started receiving calls from places we had denoted in the flowchart and each call gave us useful information,” said NHM state mission director Rathan Kelkar.

Over the past three days, 900 primary and secondary contacts were traced and put under isolation. For that to happen, storylines were made, route maps were drawn. Before the mapping process, the team from community medicine started with direct interviews that yielded incomplete data because the patients were not forthcoming. The team then collected call details of the patients between February 29 till their time of hospital admission. The search produced 250-300 numbers.

“We contacted each person on phone and traced how many of them were in personal contact with the patients and where. It also gave us information about 15 persons who were not actually on our list,” said Nooh. Seventeen field teams, each comprising six members, then collected CCTV footage and data from supermarkets, shops and post offices.

By evening, the team sat together with different set of data and missing links were marked for further verification. A storyline would be made for each cluster of patients and data, made available using STM, helped finetune the details. For instance, the preliminary information about the hotel, which was a point of contact, was that it was somewhere between two distant locations. The team did more digging to arrive at a time, exact name and location of the hotel. It was added as the last entry.

As a final verification process, tower location of affected persons between February 29 and March 9 were collected. There was a confusion over the hotel they had visited. While some people told the team where the persons were spotted, they couldn’t corroborate it since hotel records and CCTV footage did not yield anything. In that case, tower location was used to know whether the parties were anywhere near the location of hotel.

A three-member team led by district informatics officer Gigi George put together manually derived information, route maps and CCTV data to prepare STM. “We received over 100 calls and feedback from the public helped to ensure crucial corrections and updation on STM,” said NHM district programme manager Dr Abey Sushan. The name of a bus was corrected, timing of patient’s arrival in a place was made more accurate based on public response.

Title: Keeladi excavation: Work begins at Agaram village
Content:
Madurai: As part of sixth phase of Keeladi excavation, the bhoomi puja was performed at Agaram village near Keeladi in Sivaganga district on Tuesday, while the cleaning activities for the excavation began on Wednesday. Agaram is about six kilometres away from Keeladi.

Demands were made by many people, including Madurai MP Su Venkatesan, to take up excavation in the neighbouring villages of Agaram, Manalur and Konthagai as it could reveal more details of the ancient civilization.

The Tamil Nadu state archaeology department announced that the excavation in the sixth phase, which was started on February 19 this year, would be extended to the villages of Manalur, Konthagai and Agaram also.

Five phases of excavations have been completed in Keeladi in Thirupuvanam in Sivaganga district where an ancient river bed civilization was discovered nearly six years ago. While, the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) carried out the first three phases of excavation, the fourth, fifth and now the sixth phases are being undertaken by the state archaeology department.

Excavation in Agaram is being carried out in two acres of land belonging to the Tamil Nadu government. This site falls within the Kalugerkadai panchayat and is opposite to the village tank. Panchayat president Kottaisamy and officials of the archaeology department participated in the bhoomi pooja and cleaning of the site began on Wednesday.

Meanwhile, a second burial urn was discovered in Konthagai, where the excavation was started along with Keeladi. Manalur is expected to be taken up soon, according to archaeological department sources.

Title: Ahmedabad Coronavirus News: Man hospitalized with high fever in Ahmedabad
Content: AHMEDABAD: A 44-year-old resident of Satellite area of Ahmedabad was admitted to Civil Hospital in Asarwa on Wednesday, over a complaint of fever. The patient, who is suspected to have COVID-19 infection, has been admitted at the isolation ward set up at the state-run hospital, under quarantine condition. This is the 15th suspected case of COVID-19 reported at the hospital so far.“The patient came with symptoms akin to viral infection with high-grade fever. Since he has recently travelled to Germany – one of the affected countries – we have kept him in the isolation ward. His blood sample has been sent for testing and the report should be available by Friday,” said Dr GH Rathod, medical superintendent, Civil Hospital Asarwa.Rathod confirmed that the man is in a stable condition. “So far, some 14 patients with suspected COVID-19 were admitted at the hospital. However, all of their reports are negative,” Rathod further added.State health authorities are aggressively conducting surveillance and monitoring, to prevent occurrence and spread of COVID-19 cases. While a team of medical practitioners has been deployed at Ahmedabad and Surat international airports, even hotels across the state have been asked to make mandatory arrangements for screening all travellers and staffers and keep the state health department informed if anyone is reported with body temperature of 99°F or above.

Title: Hotel occupancy in Ahmedabad drops to less than 50%
Content:
File photo of staff being checked for fever at a city hotel

AHMEDABAD: As a fallout of travel restrictions by companies across the globe due to COVID-19 outbreak in various parts of the world, the footfalls of international guests have dropped to the barest minimum across hotels in Ahmedabad, causing hotel occupancies to fall sharply. Estimates by hoteliers suggest that average hotel occupancy in Ahmedabad has dropped to 50% or in some cases even lower across leading hotels in the city.

“A number of business delegate groups have cancelled their booking at our hotel, as companies have imposed travel restrictions after COVID-19 outbreak in various countries. Most of these group bookings were from international guests. The average occupancy is around 70% at this time of the year, which has declined significantly,” said a city-based hotelier, on condition of anonymity.

Hotel business has also taken a hit because of cancellation or deferring of a slew of events and business conferences. “Two business conferences which were to be held at our hotel were cancelled due to travel restrictions imposed by companies. As a result, the bookings for guests were also cancelled affecting occupancies at our hotel. However, bookings from travellers in transit hasn’t been significantly affected yet,” said Subhrajit Bardhan, general manager, DoubleTree By Hilton, Ahmedabad.

As a consequence of falling occupancies, the average daily rates have also marginally declined at several hotels in the city.

To sustain revenues, hoteliers however are banking on vouchers and catering services. “Group movements have been restricted across companies. While some have deferred their trips, others have cancelled altogether. On an average, we saw a 15% decline. As a result, we are also focusing on alternate avenues to keep up with revenue growth targets, by offering vouchers and extending our catering services. At the same time, we are also trying to convince clients whose events in other cities got called off, to host them at our hotel,” said another hotelier, without willing to be named.

Title: Ahmedabad: Safeguard communal harmony, says riot survivor
Content:
Firozkhan Pathan

AHMEDABAD: Firozkhan Pathan , a survivor of the 2002 Gujarat communal riots, has written to the chief minister demanding stern action against ‘attempts to disrupt communal harmony .’

Lauding the state government for ensuring peace and harmony over the past 17 years, Pathan said in the letter that attempts are now being made by members of political parties to instigate communal hostility.

Referring to a recent input by the intelligence bureau that politicians, police officers and religious leaders were likely to be targeted, Pathan wrote in the letter that certain political leaders had spread messages on social media about the input. “Those political leaders who posted the IB input on social media platforms, must be identified and strict action should be taken against them. This is an attempt to disrupt communal harmony in the state,” Pathan said.

He said in the letter that the state government has ensured communal harmony and peace after the 2002 communal riots and this ought to be preserved. “I have asked the chief minister in the letter to initiate action against any political person who indulges in provocative speeches or spreads communal hatred, irrespective of which party the person belongs to,” Pathan said.

Pathan, 45, lost 10 members of his family in the Gulbarg Society killings on February 28, 2002. He contested the 2019 Lok Sabha poll from the Gandhinagar LS seat as an independent candidate. Union home minister Amit Shah won the seat with a record margin.

Title: Best-before date for mishti is absurd, say confectioners
Content:
Kolkata: It was not possible to show the manufacturing and best-before dates on sweets displayed on trays at shops, confectioners announced on Wednesday evening.

Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI), India’s food regulator, had directed that from May 1, not only packaged sweets but also those displayed on trays, to be picked and chosen by buyers, should bear manufacturing and best-before dates to ensure customers’ health was not compromised with. But sweet manufacturers in the city, who have united under the banner of Paschimbanga Mistanna Byabasayee Samity, called the new rule absurd and said they would probably not follow it.

“We don’t have the infrastructure to display manufacturing and best-before dates on sweets. In Bengal, most sweets are made of chhena or cottage cheese. They expire fast, the shelf life of some being is less than 24 hours. So the question of mentioning manufacturing and expiry dates doesn’t arise,” said Samity president Rabindra Pal. “The sweet industry in Bengal is a cottage industry that runs on tradition and trust. This kind of an imposition in the name of health is absurd... All you can ask is whether the sweet is fresh or stale.”

Even if the bigger brands could display the dates, smaller brands would not be able to do so, he asserted. “Instead, FSSAI should ensure we can procure healthy raw materials.” a Samily member said.

The Samity members complained FSSAI was seeking reports for the water being used to make sweets. Calling it ridiculous, another member said, “For years, we have been using water supplied by the corporation or municipality. FSSAI should question the supplying authority, not us.” They pointed out that sending such reports would mean additional expenses that sweet manufacturers would not be able to bear.

They also complained instead to waiting to see if the manufacturers renewed their food safety licences or not by April 1, FSSAI had started imposing a fine of Rs 100 a day on all confectioners since March 1. “This is coercive and we are not going to accept it,” one of them said.

Title: Man who came from Dubai isolated at MCH
Content: Madurai: A 27-year-old man who recently returned from Dubai has been admitted to the Covid-19 isolation ward at Tirunelveli Medical College Hospital as a precautionary measure. Samples have also been sent for testing and results are expected soon. The man is a native of Kadayanallur in Tenkasi district. “The patient’s fever has subsided. He is showing no symptoms of Covid-19. We are only keeping him in the ward as a precaution because of his travel history,” said Tirunelveli MCH dean Dr M Ravichandran. The blood and swab samples of the patient have been sent for testing. “If it tests positive, of course, we’ll provide due treatment. If it tests negative, we will keep him in isolation as long as necessary,” added Dr Ravichandran.TNN

Title: ‘Withdraw DGCA circular blocking affected to return’
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan urged the Centre to immediately withdraw its circular stating that only citizens of the country travelling from abroad and who are free from coranavirus will be allowed to disembark in the country.Replying to a calling attention in this regard by MLA K V Abdul Khader, the chief minister said that the circular issued by the directorate general of civil aviation (DGCA) not allowing its own citizens to return to their country if affected by Covid-19 is an “uncivilised” move. He said that he has written to Prime Minister Narendra Modi requesting him to withdraw the circular. He said that he has written to external affairs minister S Jaishankar and would also write to health minister Harsh Vardhan in this regard.The chief minister also said that the assembly will consider passing a resolution in this regard. It has been noticed that several citizens who are abroad and some within, preparing for foreign travel, are facing several difficulties due to the regulations, he said. Several countries including Kuwait have made it mandatory for people travelling from 10 countries, including India, to mandatorily possess polymerase chain reaction test (PCR-test) medical certificate.Difficulties the citizens are facing while travelling abroad have been brought to the notice of the external affairs minister, he added.The chief minister also said that the chief secretary has spoken to the cabinet secretary, and it has been informed that a high-level medical team will be flown to Italy, where the stranded Indians will me medically examined. Those who test negative for Covid-19 will be allowed to fly back to the country, and those who test positive will be quarantined there itself.Meanwhile, minister of state for external affairs V Muraleedharan alleged that the chief minister is trying to gain political mileage out of the situation. He said that the Centre has no such anti-people approach and is taking a very serious view of the issue. Upon the instructions of the Prime Minister, the government has formed a ministerial team headed by health minister. The government had decided to send a medical team to Italy when it came to the notice that the Italian medical team is refusing to screen our citizens and issue certificates, Muraleedharan said.

Title: 20-yr-old student dies after being hit by garbage truck
Content:
Madurai: A 20-year-old college student riding a bike died in Villupuram on Wednesday after his bike was hit by a garbage truck.

The victim, Karthikeyan P, a resident of Thallakulam, was a third-year student at an engineering college. He was on his way to Kariapatti. He had just gone past Meenakshi Nagar in Villupuram, when a garbage truck belonging to Madurai corporation ran over him. Karthikeyan died on the spot while driver fled the scene. Police have recovered Karthikeyan’s body and sent it for autopsy.TNN

Title: This screentime habit is equivalent to secondhand smoking for kids, say experts
Content: All parents are cautious about ensuring that their kids grow up in the best possible way. From ensuring they eat right, study well and making sure that their internet access is curtailed, there are a lot many things to take care of when you have kids growing up in the house.However, there is one dilemma which is on the mind of many parents and that circles around screentime. As much of a boon the internet is, sadly, the internet and screentime isn't the best thing for kids and adults. With babies getting addicted to screens as young as six months, experts are now warning about another potential risk factor for kids- secondhand screentime. In fact, it is believed that secondhand screentime is just as dangerous as passive or secondhand smoking.While parents and guardians have the provision of limiting the content kids have access too, what they do not have control over is secondhand screentime. Secondhand screentime is what your kid watches when someone in close contact with the kid (i.e., the parent) browses through it in the near vicinity. The problem also becomes concerning if children spend time around parents or guardians who are on their phones for a long time.If left unmonitored, this can have drastic consequences for the child's development graph.Guidelines suggest that kids between the age of 2-7 are exposed to no more than one hour of screentime of gadget usage per day, while screentime should altogether be "avoided" for kids less than 18 months of age.Kids, when in contact with the parent who spends considerable time on the phone or the screen are at a higher risk of getting addicted to the screens as well and hamper the usual parent-child relationship. With secondhand screentime, there is a high risk of kids getting exposed to unmonitored content without proper supervision with the people surrounding the kids. Be it at the daycare, school, mall or any place where children are cared for by adults, spending a concerning amount of time around gadgets without proper control can have impacting consequences.Research shows that children have a tendency to exhibit irrational behaviour pattern when parents spend excessive time on their devices. They are also more prone to exhibiting symptoms like irritability, mood swings, slow language development, hyperactivity and reduced cognitive functions. Be it something as little as applying the same example, or throwing hissy fits to demand the parent's attention, there is also a high risk of excessive screentime impacting their self-esteem and emotional framework.Anything that crosses the 1-1.5 hour timeline per day is deemed dangerous for a growing child. In fact, for children in their adolescent and pre-teen days, the focus should also be put on the content quality they have access to.Excess screen time is bad for your kid's brain and there is more than one reason for you to cut down on your screentime. It is important to remember that kids model your behaviour and learn from what you do. So it is most important that you set the right examples for your child. Before you go about telling your kids to stop consuming internet fodder, be watchful of what you do on the internet. More frequently you use your smartphones, more likely are your kids to follow that.Screening what your kids have access to and what content you see can be quite a task, but it is something that has to be set in stone. As a rule of thumb, make sure you try and adopt a digital detox once you are home or in a child-friendly environment. When you are home, you can start by setting time limits and establish rules as in where phone or screens cannot be used.You can also try avoiding phone and screen usage when you are having a conversation with someone and that is the lesson you should be telling your kids too. No phones at the dinner table, having quality conversation is key.Parents can also make use of the same phones and timeline to impose curbs. Phones come with new features which set off alarms if the screen time exceeds limits.

Title: Covid-19: Indian students put off foreign varsity plans
Content: MUMBAI: An admit from Stanford calls for celebration. A call from Cambridge is seen as the passport to success. But infected with fears over the Covid-19 spread, students are postponing confirmation of their admissions.India is the second largest sender of students to countries around the world. But admits for a blue-chip MBA or for a cutting-edge programme on quantum computing mean nothing as candidates are unclear if campuses will open in the new academic year. Requests are going out from India seeking extension of fee payment deadlines.Meanwhile, USA has asked its schools to exercise flexibility with international students. The Student and Exchange Visitor Programme released an advisory on Tuesday for educational institutes seeking information on whether a campus is temporarily shut or instructions are being given at an alternative campus or have moved online.“There is tremendous uncertainty among students. Indian students have admits but they are not paying their enrolment deposits. In most cases, they are non-refundable and may be as high as US$5,000. Students are unsure about whether the city they are flying to will be safe or not. First it was Singapore, now Europe and the USA,” said Karan Gupta, a counsellor who works with students who wish to study abroad.In a new survey of 2,000-plus students from Africa, Asia, and Australasia by QS, nearly 3 in 10 (27%) said their plans had changed due to the virus while a much greater proportion (61%) said their plans were not affected as yet. As many as 37% said their plans had changed and the outbreaks have made them decide to defer their entry until next year while 33% said they will now choose an alternate destination. Over 11% of those whose plans had changed said they no longer wished to study abroad.Param Jain, who passed out of Thadomal Shahani Engineering College, has multiple admits from campuses spanning three countries: Spain, USA and the UK. “I have asked the universities to extend the deadline for payment of enrolment fees. They have offered an extension till the end of March,” he said.Campuses are going quiet. Most have moved online. Travel advisories have been issued and conferences, athletic meets, immersion trips and industry experiences called off. Many Chinese students may be unable to apply as GMAT centres shut in China.“Students are mostly delaying taking visas till June,” said Pratibha Jain, another counsellor. Students said unofficial messages from universities state entry may be delayed by a month.Some have said if the enrolment deposit is paid, it would be refunded or admission could be deferred by a semester or a year.

Title: Why a dhaba figured in coronavirus war
Content: NEW DELHI: One of the key measures to limit the spread of Covid-19 has been tracing contacts of persons affected by it and the central and state governments have launched an intensive exercise, often tracking down seat numbers in buses and even dhabas to identify and observe those who came in contact with affected patients.TOI spoke to health ministry officials who have been tracking each and every case from a ‘war room’ where data of patients and the place he or she may have visited is minutely analysed for subsequent action by local health authorities.For example, on February 20, a data scientist in Bengaluru, a resident of Telangana, returned from Dubai. He became symptomatic for Covid-19 two days later and took self-medication for a couple of days before approaching a family physician and subsequently reached Apollo Hospital.The data scientist was referred to the Gandhi Hospital in Hyderabad where samples for Covid-19 were confirmed, leading to local authorities identifying 76 of his contacts in Telangana and 10 in Bengaluru within hours. All were put under surveillance for Covid-19 symptoms but tested negative.The contact tracing of 23 Italian tourists, of which 16 were found positive for Covid-19 and are admitted in different hospitals, was more challenging. The group arrived at IGI Airport in Delhi on February 21. The group, along with a driver, a helper and a guide, visited various cities in Rajasthan and also went to Agra.“We tracked down even the dhaba where the driver, travelling with the Italian group, got his dinner packed. They too have been put under surveillance,” a senior official in the Delhi public health division said.A group member was ill at the start of the tour but did not report this. He travelled with the group to multiple destinations in Rajasthan and reached Jaipur on February 29. After tests confirmed Covid-19, the Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP) of Rajasthan immediately started contact tracing. A total of 361 contacts from eight hotels and staff of hospitals were identified in the state and the hotels sanitised as per protocol and staff de-rostered.A total of 43 contacts were identified in Agra at the hotel where the group stayed. All are under surveillance and the hotel was sanitised. In Delhi, the two hotels where the group stayed were sanitised, the staff serving the group de-rostered and all contacts put under surveillance.The Covid-19 patient’s wife stayed back with him in Jaipur while rest of the group travelled to Agra and stayed in a hotel there for a night. The wife also became a positive case later on.The group was finally taken to the quarantine facility at ITBP Camp, Chhawla. There, 14 Italians and one Indian was found to be positive.

Title: DK Shivakumar: Troubleshooter DK Shivakumar will head Congress in Karnataka
Content:
A KPCC appointment after prolonged internal debate

BENGALURU: Congress troubleshooter DK Shivakumar , who was relegated to the sidelines of Karnataka politics after he spent 50 days in Tihar Jail last year in connection with a money-laundering case, returned to the political centrestage on Wednesday as he was named president of the state Congress unit.The appointment of the 57-year-old veteran was part of several key organisational changes announced by Congress a day after Jyotiraditya Scindia’s exit from the party with loyalist MLAs in tow. Observers said Shivakumar’s elevation, after months of dilly-dallying, was a bid to stem further exodus from the party.The Kanakapura MLA acknowledged the task before him, saying, “I will do my best to do justice to the faith bestowed on me by the party leadership and end faction feud in the party”.The Karnataka Pradesh Congress Committee (KPCC) president’s post has been vacant since Dinesh Gundu Rao quit, owing moral responsibility for the party’s debacle in the bypolls held in December last year. With declared assets of Rs 840 crore, Shivakumar is counted among the richest politicians of the country.Shivakumar, a seventerm MLA, has served as minister under three former Congress chief ministers — S Bangarappa, SM Krishna and Siddaramiah — and under the previous JDS-Congress coalition government led by HD Kumaraswamy. Alongside Shivakumar, the party named three working presidents of KPCC — Eshwar Khandre, Satish Jarkiholi and Saleem Ahmed. The choices, sources said, were meant to balance caste equations and keep the various factions happy: Khandre is a Lingayat, Jarkiholi belongs to a scheduled tribe while Ahmed ticks the minority box. Not surprisingly, former chief minister Siddaramaiah has been asked to continue as Congress Legislature Party and leader of opposition in the legislative assembly. Ajay Singh, son of late CM Dharam Singh, will be chief whip in the assembly while M Narayanaswamy will be the party's chief whip in the legislative council.The KPCC appointments come after prolonged deliberations on whether Shivakumar, a Vokkaliga, or MB Patil, a Lingayat, should succeed Gundu Rao. Patil was seen as a better bet to lead the party in the 2023 assembly polls since BJP’s Lingayat strongman and chief minister B S Yediyurappa is expected to hang up his boots.Sources in the party said Shivakumar had emerged as the frontrunner in the discussions and the leadership was willing to appoint him much earlier but a section argued that the party should wait until he got a clean chit in the money-laundering case.As KPCC chief, Shivakumar’s biggest challenge would be to end the faction feud in the party and his style of aggressive leadership is expected to come in handy. “He will have to not only appease the sulking Siddaramaiah group in the party but also revitalise the demoralised state unit by uniting all leaders,” said a senior party functionary. Alongside, he will have to deal with his legal troubles.

Title: Murugan, VC of national SC body, is chief of Tamil Nadu BJP unit
Content:
National Comission SC/ST - L Murugan

CHENNAI: L Murugan, vice-chairman of National Commission for Scheduled Castes, was appointed president of the Tamil Nadu BJP unit by the party's national chief J P Nadda on Wednesday. The post has been lying vacant since September 1, 2019, after then state president Tamilisai Soundararajan was appointed governor of Telangana.

BJP will have representation in the Tamil Nadu assembly after the 2021 assembly polls and I will work hard to achieve it, Murugan said. After his appointment, which came as a surprise to many in the party, Murugan told reporters that it once again proved that hard work of even an ordinary cadre would be duly "recognised" and "rewarded" in the party. After S P Kirubanidhi, Murugan is the second dalit to head the party's state unit.

"Our primary work is to accomplish the task given by the party leadership," he said.

Murugan took up Panchami land issue involving DMK’s Murasoli

Before being appointed as the VC of the NCSC, Murugan, 42, of Namakkal was state secretary and later president of the party’s SC wing. He was also the secretary of the wing at the national level. He was also practising as a lawyer in the Madras high court.

Since September 1, names of several state and national leaders of the party, including Nainar Nagendran, R Srinivasan, K S Narendran, Karuppu M Muruganandam, A P Muruganandam and D Kuppuram were doing the rounds.

Meanwhile, a two-member team, from the party’s national headquarters, held a meeting on January 5 at the party headquarters in Chennai with the core-committee members and state-level office bearers to get their views for appointing a person to achieve the aspirations of the party in the state.

A few months ago, after a petition from BJP functionary Prof R Srinivasan, Murugan took up the Panchami land issue involving DMK’s mouthpiece Murasoli. However, the Madras HC, while hearing Murasoli –Panchami land case, directed Murugan to step aside from the issue following allegations that he had participated in an event organised by BJP, despite occupying a constitutional post.

Title: Undeterred by personal loss, Yash turns messiah for hapless children
Content:
Yash Gourkhede, 24, had twice tried to end life under depression after his then teenaged friend Twinkle Surekha killed herself in 2016. The pain pricked college dropout Gourkhede so much that he started nurturing his personal wound by catering to the grief of others, especially helpless children.

Yash, a bank executive, has transformed into a messiah for children with lost childhood. His NGO ‘Twinkle Foundation’, founded in memory of his late friend in 2016, rescues children from trafficking rackets, forced labour, begging, prostitution and such dark alleys of life.

The youngster and his team have so far rescued around 950 children, including almost 300 from the city and outskirts. The actions were taken along with government agencies, police and some through personal initiatives.

“The biggest rescue was of 450 trafficked children following a tip-off from an NGO. These children were forced into begging near Tulja Bhavani Mandir at Surjapur in Osmanabad,” said Yash who carries out the work through his personal income and financial help from friends and well-wishers.

The first rescue act was done at Sitabuldi. They freed a small girl from the clutches of a begging syndicate. “The girl had cut off her hair and posed as a boy on the road just to avoid being raped repeatedly. She was into addiction and severely violated,” he said.

The rescued children are sent to government homes and shelters. Explaining the modus operandi of begging syndicates, he said. “They are well organized rackets who inflict injuries on bodies of children, severe their limbs and keep them unkempt. This way they attract sympathetic citizens who offer alms to child beggars,” said Yash.

Near Tajbagh, the team had also across racketeers who would rent out children with women to make them pose as needy mother and child. “Despite the high risk of being attacked, we never let anything come in the way of our work,” he said.

Yash, who has won several recognitions and awards along with his key support Barkha Patnaik, said his team also launched ‘Milan campaign’ to reunite lost children with their parents. “We are stretching our network globally by tying up with like-minded groups in Nepal, Pakistan, Russia and Australia,” he said.

“We have 15,000 children advocates who are basically volunteers having legal awareness. Another 1,700 volunteers are engaged in the field as investigation officers or rehabilitation coordinators,” said Yash and added that social media is the biggest platform for their work.

The team also creates mass awareness about ills and perils of child labour, begging syndicates and such issues. They are also reaching out to senior citizens who are being ill-treated by their families.

Yash believes in encouraging others, especially youngsters. “A one-day carnival is organized for the rescued children and the elderly citizens. This way they develop bonding like grandson and grandpa, even if it’s momentarily. Under a programme called ‘Pankh’, we also give award to youngsters for their achievements in different fields,” he said.

Title: Understanding of concepts key to answering well
Content:
From the session 2019-20, the CBSE board has introduced Indian Economic Development (IED) for Std XII, which will make it tough for students to score 100, but it’s not impossible.

As per the new pattern, economics paper will consist of total 34 questions, which will include 20 questions of 1 mark (including MCQs, fill in the blanks, true-false, match the right answer etc), 4 questions of 3 marks, 6 questions of 4 marks and 4 questions of 6 marks.

Students must practice solved sample papers by CBSE to develop a strong understanding of concepts which will help you answer in a better way. Focus on past examination questions for macroeconomics.

As this will be the first batch appearing in IED, you can’t evaluate previous years’ paper. So, you need to practice NCERT questions in writing. Practice numerical problems and diagrams with pen and paper.

Never mix between sections. If you start with macroeconomics, then you should first finish it and then start with IED. Write your answers in points. Answer should be precise, relevant and up to the question. Length of answers and diagrams should be according to the marks allocated to that particular question. Solve numerical questions step by step. Inbox your answer and highlight the main points in theory answers.

After completing all the questions, revise your answersheet to check whether you have attempted all the questions and all the diagrams are properly labelled.

Remaining calm and focused will also help you in attempting all the questions, as you would feel confident which can help in remembering.

(The writer is a teacher at Delhi Public School)

PAPER SNAPSHOT

Subject: Economics

Board: CBSE, Std XII

Date of exam: March 13

Total theory marks: 80

Duration: 3 hours

Last-minute revision tips

Prepare a timetable to revise, allocate the time available between all the chapters

Practice numerical questions and diagrams

Solve last year’s paper; set your clock for 3 hours to help you manage your time effectively

Keep a cool head, don’t be over confident or nervous

Title: Neatness and presentation important, check spellings too
Content:
For ICSE X physics exam, I would suggest students to utilize 15 minutes of reading time completely as they’ll get an idea about all the questions. Most of the times, hints for answers are given in the questions itself.

In section B of the paper, students should bifurcate which questions they are going to attempt.

Importantly, give preference to diagram-based questions, as these questions can fetch students full marks. Students must keep in mind to label all the diagrams correctly while solving questions based on them. Use pro-circle and roller scale to draw diagrams of pulley more easily, quickly and neatly.

Many students make simple mistakes in writing wrong units in numericals. So, avoid this and write correct units. In theory questions, students should not write very lengthy answers; these should be of appropriate length and the use of keywords will do. Paper checkers always look for correct words and exact content in answers.

For scoring good marks in physics, neatness in diagrams as well as presentation of answers are important. Students must check correct spellings of answers.

Try to attempt all the questions, do not leave blank spaces. Students should try to finish their paper 10 minutes early so that they can check answers and correct silly mistakes. Students are advised to use two hours of exam time properly, giving all the questions worthy time.

(The writer is a teacher at MSB School)

Paper snapshot

Subject: Physics

Date of Exam: March 13

Board: ICSE

Total theory marks: 80

Duration: 2 hours

Last-minute revision tips

Remember and practice all diagrams correctly with all labels and units

Read all the important keywords of all the questions, it will help you construct your answer

Utilize 15 minutes of reading time completely

Title: Coronavirus scare: 'They know it’s not safe, but staying off work is a luxury they can’t afford'
Content: NEW DELHI: Rajesh’s hands are smeared with cement as he balances on the ledge to lay out bricks while his help holds on to a rusted pole. Ask them about coronavirus and they nod in affirmation that they are aware of the dangers of the fast spreading disease.They also share how important it is to wash hands and may be wear masks. But the reality is different. While the contractor has provided soap, staying off dirty surfaces is not a choice for these poor labourers.“Khaana khaney sey pehley haat sabun sey dho letey hain. Ab sabun rakha hai cotnractor ney. (I wash my hands now with soap before eating my food. Now the contractor has kept soap for us,” said Rajesh who lives in Madanpur Khadar in South Delhi. His help was more candid. “Maam hum labour hain itna dhyaan kahan rakh saktey hain (We are labourers, we cannot take so much care of ourselves.)”Though aware of the messages on precautions against coronavirus, the poor have additional risks.Sunita, who works as a domestic help in Jasola Vihar, bought masks for her two sons. She said how her employers insist that she wash her hands with soap before starting work, since the coronavirus outbreak . Pista Devi (37) from Okhla has to go through similar drill at house where she works as a help.Lakshmi (24) is nine months pregnant and has been focussing on washing hands and ensuring that her 4-year-old her son too follows the precautions. Lakshmi admits her husband, a daily-wager, is more exposed to the dangers.Shashi Kaur of Centre for Advocacy and Research, who works in 20 slums in the Okhla area, said they find that information and awareness is spreading fast but in terms of precautions not everyone has access. “For instance in Okha area there are women who work on segregating waste leather to collect usable pieces. They literally sit amidst waste and say they cannot get up and keep cleaning their hands and face at regular intervals,” he said.Nitesh Kumar from Society for Promotion of Youth and Masses, an organisation that operates 75 night shelters for 3000 people, said awareness drive was on. Many daily wagers like rickshaw pullers do not have access to clean water, soap and masks, he said.

Title: Atrocity case against lawyer an act of vengeance, say enraged lawyers
Content:
Members of the Hubli Bar Association sought immediate action against cops accused of manhandling a public pros... Read More

DHARWAD: Members of the Dharwad Bar Association gathered in front of the Dharwad suburban police station on Wednesday to protest what they dubbed the ‘humiliating’ treatment of a public prosecutor by cops.

The protesting lawyers charged cops with acting on a belated complaint filed by a constable attached to the Dharwad rural police station. In pursuance of the complaint being filed, a case was booked under the provisions of the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (prevention of atrocities) Act, 1989 against government pleader Sunil Gudi.

Similar scenes were also witnessed in Hubballi, where lawyers protested demanding action against personnel of the Hubballi rural police station. President of the Hubli Bar Association Ashok Baligar alleged that Gudi had been assaulted by Ganesh Kambale and Devaraj, PSI and CPI respectively of the Dharwad rural police station. “When Gudi had gone to the station seeking details of the case, the cops assaulted him. We have filed a case against the duo at the Hubballi suburban police station. They must be arrested immediately,” said Baligar.

The protest by advocates of the twin cities follows a demonstration on Monday, when they had taken to the streets questioning the treatment meted out to a member of their fraternity by police.

Gudi had alleged that the constable Ganesh Kambale manhandled him when the former visited the station. After lawyers sought immediate action against Kambale, Dharwad superintendent of police Vartika Katiyar suspended Kambale pending an inquiry into the case.

However, Kambale filed a complaint against Gudi on Tuesday evening, accusing the latter of having made remarks pertaining to caste. A complaint was lodged under the SC/ST Act at the Dharwad suburban police station. Questioning the timing of Kambale’s complaint, the protesting lawyers on Wednesday alleged that this had been done in a bid to seek vengeance. They further alleged that Kambale had been prompted to file the complaint by his superiors.

The current face-off between the two arms of the legal system – cops and lawyers – comes close on the heels of police trying to prevent Bengaluru advocates from entering the premises of a court when they were en route the court to file a bail petition on behalf of three engineering students from Kashmir. The enraged lawyers had pointed out that, in barring their entry to court, cops had violated provisions of CrPC Section 327.

The protesting lawyers in Dharwad on Wednesday said that they would not yield to any form of pressure, and would not allow police to stifle their voice. “We will continue this protest for an indefinite period until our demands are met,” they said.

The threat of the protest intensifying was endorsed by secretary of the Hubli Bar Association Guru Hiremath, who said that the stir would continue unless the errant cops were brought to book.

The protesters sought the withdrawal of the atrocities case against Sunil Gudi.

Title: Gadag locals returning from Malaysia and Singapore trip tested for Covid-19 symptoms
Content: GADAG: Returning from a sojourn in Singapore and Malaysia , 16 Gadag residents were tested at a Community Health Centre (CHC) in Laxmeshwar on Wednesday. They were subjected to a medical examination, and will continue to be on the radar of the healthcare authorities. These measures have been taken among heightening fears over the novel coronavirus , of which four people have tested positive in Karnataka so far.Members of a local outfit in Laxmeshwar had left for Singapore and Malaysia on March 2, and returned to Bengaluru on Monday, where they underwent a test for the Covid-19 virus. They subsequently left Bengaluru by train that departed on Tuesday night, and chugged into Yalvigi station around 9.30am on Wednesday.Gadag district health officer Dr Satish Basarigidad confirmed to TOI that the 16 people had been subjected to a thorough examination in Bengaluru. “In accordance with the instructions issued by the Gadag deputy commissioner and Laxmeshwar tahsildar we created a separate cell at the CHC. The 16 people were received at the station, and taken to the centre by ambulance, where they were tested for symptoms of Covid-19 such as cough, fever, etc., and we found that they had none of these. They were sent home after the examination, but we will keep be observing them for the next 14 days,” said Dr Basarigidad.Medical officer at the CHC Dr Girish Maraddi said that all the medical tests, such as checking the blood pressure level, the pulse rate, et al of the 16 individuals were performed in an isolated cell at the centre. He confirmed Dr Basarigidad’s affirmation of keeping a close watch on them. “We will visit the homes of each of them every day for the next fortnight, and if we detect symptoms of the novel coronavirus , they will be referred to the district hospital,” he said.Subash Odunavar, one of the 16 travellers who were examined on Wednesday, said that all members of their entourage had been healthy throughout the duration of the tour. “We have been tested at all the airports, and nothing wrong has been found with us,” he said.Meanwhile, residents of Nagavi Lambani Tanda offered special pujas to their favoured deity Sri Sevalal maharaj, seeking a quick end to the novel coronavirus menace. “Many of our relatives are working as labourers in Goa and Kerala, and we are very worried about their wellbeing. It is mostly women and the elderly who live here. We sought Sri Sevalal Maharaj’s intervention to eradicate the novel coronavirus from the world,” said Sonubai and Narayan, residents of the Tanda.

Title: Mangaluru: 8 quarantine facilities set up in DK; 49 people in self-quarantine
Content: MANGALURU: With the test report on an international traveller who returned from Dubai with light fever on March 8 testing negative for Covid-19 , the district administration that received the report on Wednesday said the traveller will be in self-quarantine for the next 14 days. The administration had dispatched the traveller’s swabs to the testing centre in Bengaluru on Tuesday, and the report from the centre on Wednesday, cleared him of Covid-19.Confirming this, deputy commissioner Sindhu B Rupesh said 49 international passengers have been quarantined in Dakshina Kannada and five have completed the 28-day quarantine period, and none tested positive for Covid-19. Out of the 10 swabs sent to Bengaluru, including that of the above international traveller, the district administration has received seven reports, all of which are negative for Covid-19, and three other reports are awaited, she said.If international passengers have fever, cold and cough that are symptomatic of Covid-19, they will be kept under quarantine at their homes, and under medical watch for 28 days. Swab samples, where found necessary, will be sent for testing, and if someone tests positive for Covid-19 positive, they will be shifted to any of the eight isolation facilities, including seven opened in as many medical colleges. ESI hospital will be turned into an isolation facility if the need for it arises, the DC said.With Covid-19 positive cases reported from Bengaluru, Sindhu said the district administration through a task force under her stewardship has stepped up their vigil in the district. She said two meetings of this task force have been held, and she said that guidelines by WHO and the Union and state governments are being followed. In all, 100 people including medical officers, paramedical staff and lab technicians have been trained to deal with people symptomatic of Covid-9 and to collect swabs, she said.The screening mechanism at Mangaluru International Airport has been strengthened with the posting of physicians from medical colleges in the district on rotation, to help the physician and para-medical staff of the airport health office. A 108 ambulance with trained paramedical staff has been kept on standby at MIA to shift people with Covid-19 symptoms to Wenlock Hospital for testing. All those trained have been issued personal protection equipment kits.A control room has been set up at the DC’s office. People in need may call: 104/1077/0824-2442590. With cruise ships entry at New Mangalore Port Trust banned till the end of this month, Sindhu said the district administration will extend help, if sought, for crew of cargo vessels calling on the port with signs of Covid-19. They too will be subjected to the same quarantine protocols, the DC added.

Title: Mangaluru: NITK allows faculty startups after 24 years, two incubated
Content:
National Institute of Technology Surathkal

MANGALURU: The Science and Technology Entrepreneurs Park (NITK-STEP) Suratkhal, after 24 years since its inception, has incubated startups of its faculty . The NITK-STEP commenced in 1994, and was then known as KREC.

Thanks to a tweak in its norms in 2018, which earlier allowed everyone, except institution faculty members to incubate at the centre. Within two years of the change in the rule, two faculty members incubated two novel products.
